book.name: Psalms
book.info: David wrote seventy-three psalms ([link book="Psa."]3-9[/link]; [link book="Psa."]11-32[/link]; [link book="Psa."]34-41[/link]; [link book="Psa."]51-65[/link]; [link book="Psa."]68-70[/link]; [link book="Psa."]86[/link]; [link book="Psa."]101[/link]; [link book="Psa."]103[/link]; [link book="Psa."]108-110[/link]; [link book="Psa."]122[/link]; [link book="Psa."]124[/link]; [link book="Psa."]131[/link]; [link book="Psa."]133[/link]; [link book="Psa."]138-145[/link]); the sons of Korah, twelve ([link book="Psa."]42-49[/link]; [link book="Psa."]84-85[/link]; [link book="Psa."]87-88[/link]); Asaph, twelve ([link book="Psa."]50[/link]; [link book="Psa."]73-83[/link]); Solomon, two ([link book="Psa."]72[/link]; [link book="Psa."]127[/link]); Ethan, one ([link book="Psa."]89[/link]); and Moses, one ([link book="Psa."]90[/link]). The authors of the other forty-nine psalms are unknown.
Beginning in the eleventh century B.C. (except [link]Psalm 90[/link], written by Moses in the fifteenth century B.C.).
book.subject: The Expressions of the Sentiments, Feelings, Impressions, and Experiences of Godly Men Seeking and Contacting God through Their Praises, Prayers, and Singing with Exultation

outlines.outline: Book One — Indicating that God's intention is to turn the seeking saints from the law to Christ that they may enjoy the house of God — the church
Book Two — Indicating that the saints experience God and His house and city through the suffering, exalted, and reigning Christ

Book Three — Indicating that the saints, in their experiences, realize that the house and the city of God with all the enjoyments thereof can be preserved and maintained only with Christ properly appreciated and exalted by God's people
Book Four — Indicating that the saints, being joined to Christ, are one with God so that He can recover His title over the earth through Christ in His house and city

Book Five — Indicating that the house and the city of God become the praise, safety, and desire of the saints, and that Christ comes to reign over the whole earth through the house and the city of God — the church

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed is the man / Who does not walk / In the counsel of the wicked, / Nor stand on the path of sinners, / Nor [xref]b[/xref]sit in the seat of mockers;
verse.note: Or, Happy. Psalms is not a book of doctrines or of any kind of teaching. It is a book of divine revelation composed of the expressions, sentiments, feelings, impressions, and experiences of godly men concerning (1) God and the way He is in His dealing with them; (2) the law of God as the holy Word with the divine revelation; (3) the house of God, the temple, and Mount Zion, on which the temple was seated, as the center of God's dwelling place on earth; (4) the holy city of God, Jerusalem, as the encompassing protection of the house of God; (5) the holy people of God, Israel, as God's beloved elect among the nations; (6) Israel's love toward God, their fellowship with God, their blessings received of God, their sufferings under God's dealings, and their environment; (7) their captivity; and (8) their thanksgivings and praises to Jehovah their God, whom they tasted and enjoyed. Through the godly expressions of the psalmists Christ is revealed and the church as God's house and God's city is typified.[br][br]The Psalms were written according to two kinds of concepts: the human concept of the holy writers and the divine concept of God. The human concept of the holy writers was produced out of their good nature created by God, formed with the traditions of their holy race, constituted with the teachings of the Holy Scriptures, promoted by their practice of a holy life, and uttered out of their holy sentiments and impressions. The divine concept of God as the divine revelation in the Psalms concerns three major items: (1) God's eternal economy, of which Christ is the centrality and universality; (2) Christ in His divinity, humanity, human living, all-inclusive death, life-imparting and church-producing resurrection, glorification, ascension, appearing in glory, and reigning forever; and (3) God's heart's desire, His good pleasure, in Christ as His centrality and universality, in the church as His fullness for His expression, in the kingdom for His eternal administration, and in the recovery of the earth for His eternal kingdom in eternity. In the Psalms only what is written out of the divine concept of God, and not what is written out of the human concept of the psalmists, should be considered as part of the divine revelation from God concerning His divine economy.[br][br]According to the divine concept, the central thought of the book of Psalms is Christ, as revealed in plain words ([link]Luke 24:44[/link]), and the church as the house of God and the city of God for His kingdom, as typified by the temple and by the city of Jerusalem. The spirit, the reality, the characteristic, of the divine revelation in the book of Psalms is Christ as the centrality and universality of the eternal economy of God. For this, Christ is first the embodiment of the Triune God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), then the house, the habitation, of God (signified by the temple — [link]John 2:19-21[/link]), the kingdom of God (signified by the city of Jerusalem — [link]Luke 17:21[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:3b[/link]), and the Ruler of the entire earth from the house of God and in the kingdom of God ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]). Thus, He is all in all in the entire universe (cf. [link]Eph. 1:23[/link]; [link]Col. 3:11[/link]). Such a divine revelation is the same as what is revealed in the entire Holy Scriptures. The only particular point related to the divine revelation in the book of Psalms is that such a high revelation, even the highest peak of the divine revelation, is prophesied in the expressions of the sentiments of the ancient godly saints. Thus, it is mixed with their comfort in sufferings and with the cultivation of godliness. The consummation of this highest divine revelation is the city of New Jerusalem as a sign of the habitation, the tabernacle, of God ([link]Rev. 21:1-3[/link]), through which the processed and consummated Triune God will be manifested and expressed in the all-inclusive Christ and will reign on the new earth in the new universe for eternity.

verse.text: Rather his [xref]a[/xref]delight is in the [note]1[/note]law of Jehovah, / And in His law he [xref]b[/xref]meditates by day and by night.
verse.note: Psalms 1 and 2 portray a contrast between the human concept and the divine revelation. The human concept exalts the law and the law-keeper as one blessed by God, whereas the divine revelation proclaims Christ as the One anointed of God in God's economy. In Psa. 1 the psalmist, according to his human, ethical concept, appreciated and uplifted the law to the uttermost. This is contrary to the divine concept in God's New Testament economy. In its nature the law is holy, righteous, good, and spiritual ([link]Rom. 7:12[/link], [link]14a[/link]), but in its position, the law is not in the main line of God's economy; rather, it entered in alongside the main line of God's economy ([link]Rom. 5:20a[/link]). God created man in His image and according to His likeness ([link]Gen. 1:26[/link]) with the intention that man would receive God as life in the tree of life ([link]Gen. 2:8-9[/link], [link]16-17[/link]) so that man could live God and express God. This is the main line of God's economy. But while this main line was proceeding, Satan came in to deceive man and constitute man with sin ([link]Gen. 3:1-6[/link]; [link]Rom. 5:19[/link]). In order to continue His purpose with man after man's fall, God added the law to the main line of His economy ([link]Gal. 3:19[/link] and notes 1 and 2). According to [link]Gal. 4:24-25[/link] (see note [link book="Gal." chapter="4"]24[sup]5[/sup][/link] there), the position of the law is that of a concubine. A concubine does not have an orthodox position. Thus, to appreciate and uplift the law is to bring a "concubine" into God's economy. This is absolutely against God's ordination.[br][br]The entire book of Psalms presents a contrast between the law and Christ. Only Christ Himself, not the law, can make us members of Christ and conform us to Christ that we may be His complement ([link]Eph. 5:30-32[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). The spirit of the Scriptures does not exalt anything or anyone other than Christ ([link]Matt. 17:1-5[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:7-8[/link]; [link]Col. 1:15-19[/link]). Eventually, by the end of the Psalms the only thing that remains is Christ with His complement, which is His Body, His church, the house and kingdom of God in God's economy to fulfill God's eternal purpose.[br][br]In the book of Psalms, as in the entire Bible, there are two lines: the line of the tree of life, the line of life, and the line of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, the line of death ([link]Gen. 2:8-9[/link], [link]16-17[/link] and note [link chapter="2"]9[sup]3[/sup][/link], par. 2). In addition to these two lines, the line of the law runs alongside the line of life. God's purpose in giving the law was to lead His people to Christ ([link]Gal. 3:23-24[/link]), i.e., to the line of life (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link]). However, if the law as the side line is exalted improperly, it becomes part of the line of the tree of knowledge, the line of death ([link]Rom. 7:7-11[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:6b[/link]). God has ordained Christ to be the centrality and universality of His economy to fulfill His good pleasure ([link]Eph. 1:9-10[/link]; [link]3:8-11[/link]). The law has been ended by Christ ([link]Rom. 10:4a[/link]), and the believers are no longer under the law ([link]Rom. 6:14[/link]).

verse.text: And he will be like a [xref]a[/xref]tree / Transplanted beside streams of water, / Which yields its fruit in its season, / And whose foliage does not wither; / And everything he does [note]1[/note]prospers.
verse.note: The human concept here is that the man who delights in the law of God prospers in everything, whereas the wicked man suffers loss ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]). But the experience of the psalmist in [link]Psa. 73[/link] was the opposite ([link]73:1-7[/link], [link]12-14[/link]). This seeming contradiction troubled the psalmist until he was instructed, in the sanctuary of God, to take only God Himself as his portion, not anything other than God ([link]73:16-17[/link], [link]25-26[/link]). According to the Lord's teaching in the New Testament, those who are persecuted for the sake of righteousness (not those who are prosperous) are blessed ([link]Matt. 5:10[/link]). In his pursuing of Christ, the apostle Paul did not prosper outwardly but suffered the loss of all things and counted them as refuse that he might gain Christ ([link]Phil. 3:8[/link]).

verse.text: The wicked are not so, / But are like [xref]a[/xref]chaff, / Which the wind drives away.
Therefore the wicked will not [xref]a[/xref]stand in the judgment; / Nor the sinners, in the assembly of the righteous.
For Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]knows the way of the righteous, / But the way of the wicked will perish.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Why are the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]nations in an uproar, / And why do the [note]2[/note]peoples contemplate a vain thing?
verse.note: [link]Psalm 1[/link], concerning the law in man's appreciation, is for the personal benefit of the saints, such as their being blessed in prosperity ([link]1:1-3[/link]). Psalm 2, concerning Christ and His attainments, is for the accomplishing of God's economy. The human concept of the holy writers uplifts the law to the extent that they treasured the law and desired to remain in it for their whole life. The divine concept of the unveiling God exalts Christ in order to turn the holy writers' concept from the law to Christ in accordance with the divine concept of the divine revelation.

This is the opposition to Christ by the nations and the rulers of the world ([link]vv. 1-3[/link]). This opposition began with Herod and Pontius Pilate ([link]Acts 4:25-28[/link]) and will conclude with Antichrist ([link]Rev. 19:19[/link]).

verse.text: The kings of the earth take their stand, / And the rulers sit in [xref]a[/xref]counsel together, / Against Jehovah and against His [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Anointed:
verse.note: Both [i]Messiah[/i] (from Hebrew) and [i]Christ[/i] (from Greek) mean [i]the anointed one.[/i] In His divinity Christ was anointed by God in eternity to be the Messiah — Christ — the anointed One ([link]Dan. 9:26[/link]; [link]John 1:41[/link]). He came in His incarnation as the anointed One to accomplish God's eternal plan ([link]Luke 2:11[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:16[/link]; [link]16:16[/link]). In His humanity He was anointed again in time at His baptism for His ministry, mainly on the earth ([link]Matt. 3:16-17[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18-19[/link]; [link]Acts 10:38[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:9[/link]). In His resurrection Christ became the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]) for the purpose of being God's Anointed, and in His ascension He was made both Lord and Christ ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]), becoming God's Anointed in an official way to carry out God's commission, mainly in His heavenly ministry. See note [link]41[sup]1[/sup] in John 1[/link] and note [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 2[/link].

verse.text: Let us break apart their [xref]a[/xref]bonds / And cast their ropes away from us.
He who sits in the heavens [xref]a[/xref]laughs; / The [note]1[/note]Lord has them in derision.
verse.note: Some MSS read, Jehovah.

verse.text: Then He will speak to them in His anger, / And in His burning wrath He will terrify them:
But I have installed My [note]1[/note]King / Upon [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zion, My holy mountain.
verse.note: [link]Verses 4-6[/link] of this psalm are God's declaration concerning Christ. In His ascension Christ was installed, enthroned, as God's King in the heavens for God's kingdom to fulfill His economy ([link]Mark 16:19[/link]; [link]Acts 2:36[/link]; [link]5:31[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5a[/link]). This kingdom includes all the nations as Christ's inheritance and the limits of the earth as Christ's possession ([link]v. 8[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:18-20[/link]). Eventually, in His universal kingdom Christ will rule the nations with an iron rod ([link]v. 9[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:15[/link]).[br][br]This psalm reveals the steps of Christ in God's economy, beginning from His being anointed in eternity in His divinity ([link]v. 2[/link]) and continuing with His resurrection (implying His death also — [link]v. 7[/link]; cf. [link]Acts 13:33[/link]), His ascension ([link]v. 6[/link]), His setting up His universal kingdom ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]) with the nations as His inheritance and the ends of the earth as His possession ([link]v. 8[/link]), and His ruling the nations with an iron rod ([link]v. 9[/link]).

God proclaimed that He had installed His King on Mount Zion, not Mount Sinai. Mount Sinai was the place where the law was given, and Mount Zion in the heavens is the place where Christ is today in His ascension ([link]Rev. 14:1[/link]). The New Testament believers have come not to Mount Sinai but to Mount Zion ([link]Heb. 12:18-22[/link]). Mount Sinai produces children of slavery under the law, but our mother, the Jerusalem above, which is in the heavens at Mount Zion, produces children of promise who inherit the promised blessing — the all-inclusive Spirit ([link]Gal. 4:24-26[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]).

verse.text: I will recount the decree of Jehovah; / He said to Me: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]You are My Son; / [xref]b[/xref]Today I have begotten You.
verse.note: [link]Verses 7-9[/link] are the declaration of Christ. This word was quoted by the apostle Paul in [link]Acts 13:33[/link], indicating that [link]Psa. 2:7[/link] refers to Christ's resurrection. After being cut off, crucified ([link]Dan. 9:26[/link]), Christ, God's anointed One, was resurrected to be begotten in His humanity as the firstborn Son of God ([link]Rom. 1:3-4[/link]; [link]8:29[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:5-6[/link]). Through the same resurrection all His believers were born with Him to be His many brothers, the many sons of God ([link]John 20:17[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:10[/link]). See notes [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 13[/link], [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link], and [link book="John" chapter="20"]17[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]3[/sup] in John 20[/link].

verse.text: Ask of Me, / And I will give the nations as Your inheritance / And the [xref]a[/xref]limits of the earth as Your possession.
You will break them with an [xref]a[/xref]iron rod; / You will shatter them like a potter's [xref]b[/xref]vessel.
[note]1[/note]Now therefore, O kings, be prudent; / Take the admonition, O judges of the earth.
verse.note: [link]Verses 10-12[/link] are a warning concerning the coming wrath of God and Christ upon the world. In the New Testament the period in which Christ will come to execute His judgment in His wrath upon the world is called "the day of the Lord" ([link]Acts 2:20[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 5:5[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:2[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:2[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 3:10[/link]), which is also the day of God ([link]2 Pet. 3:12[/link]). See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 1[/link].

verse.text: Serve Jehovah with [xref]a[/xref]fear, / And rejoice with trembling.

[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Kiss the Son / Lest He be angry and you perish from the way; / For His anger may suddenly be kindled. / [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Blessed are all those who [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]take refuge in Him.
verse.note: To take refuge in the Son is to believe into the Son, Christ ([link]John 3:16[/link], [link]36[/link]), taking Him as our refuge, protection, and hiding place. To kiss the Son is to love the Son and thereby to enjoy Him ([link]John 14:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). To believe in the Lord is to receive Him ([link]John 1:12[/link]); to love the Lord is to enjoy the Lord whom we have received. These are the two requirements for us to participate in the Lord. See note [link]9[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Cor. 2[/link].
Or, Happy. The human concept that man is blessed by keeping the law of Jehovah ([link]1:1-2[/link]) is in contrast here to the divine concept that man is blessed by taking refuge in the Son.

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David, when he [xref]b[/xref]fled from Absalom his son
[note]1[/note]Jehovah, how many are my adversaries! / Many are those who rise up against me!
verse.note: Psalms 3-7 show David's concept concerning a godly life. Psalms 3 and 7, and probably 4-6, were written by David in his flight from his son Absalom's rebellion ([link]2 Sam. 15:1-19:8a[/link]), which was the outcome, under God's chastisement, of David's sin of murdering Uriah and robbing him of his wife ([link]2 Sam. 11[/link]). David's prayers in these psalms, concerning his sufferings, his desire to be avenged of his adversaries, his condemning of others, and his self-righteousness and integrity, are according to his human concept and for his personal interest. They cannot compare with the spiritual prayers of the apostle Paul in [link]Eph. 1:15-23[/link] and [link]3:14-21[/link], which are for the fulfillment of God's economy.

verse.text: Many are those who say of my soul, / There is no salvation for him in God! [note]1[/note]Selah
verse.note: Meaning [i]lift up![/i] and probably denoting a pause in the recitation to allow the accompanying music to swell.

verse.text: But You, O Jehovah, are a [xref]a[/xref]shield around me, / My [xref]b[/xref]glory and the One who lifts up my head.
With my voice I call out to Jehovah, / And He answers me from His [xref]a[/xref]holy mountain. Selah
I lay down and slept; / I awoke, for Jehovah sustains me.
I will not fear the myriads of the people / Who have set themselves against me all around.
Arise, O Jehovah; / Save me, O my God! / [i]Oh[/i] that you would [note]1[/note]strike all my enemies on the cheek; / [i]And[/i] break the teeth of the wicked.
verse.note: David's prayer for vengeance against his enemies is contrary to the New Testament, which teaches us to love our enemies and to bless those who persecute us and pray for them ([link]Matt. 5:44[/link]; [link]Luke 6:27[/link], [link]35[/link]; [link]Rom. 12:14[/link], [link]20[/link]). In the Psalms the words concerning the psalmists' hating their enemies, their asking God to avenge them, and their cursing others are not the words of God but are words that issued from the psalmists' natural sentiment while they were praising God. They are recorded by the Spirit of God in the Holy Scripture to serve God's purpose of exposing the psalmists' spiritual condition, i.e., that although the psalmists loved God and sought Him, they were natural, not spiritual, in their sentiment.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Salvation is of Jehovah: / Your blessing be upon Your people. Selah
To the choir director: on the stringed instruments. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
When I call out, answer me, / O God of my [note]1[/note]righteousness; / Make room for me [i]when I am[/i] in straits; / Be gracious to me and hear my prayer.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1-4[/link] David asked God to vindicate him of his righteousness, proclaimed that he was a godly man whom God set apart for Himself and who was heard by God when he called out to Him, and admonished others not to sin. In light of his great failure in murdering Uriah and robbing him of his wife ([link]2 Sam. 11[/link]), he should have asked God to enlighten him so that he could see how evil and sinful he was.

verse.text: O sons of men, how long will my glory [i]be made[/i] a reproach? / [i]How long[/i] will you love vanity, will you seek a lie? Selah
But know that Jehovah [note]1[/note]sets apart the faithful man for Himself. / Jehovah hears when I call out to Him.
verse.note: Some MSS read and the Septuagint translates, deals wonderfully with.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Be angry, yet do not sin; / Consider in your heart upon your bed, / And be silent. Selah
Offer sacrifices of righteousness, / And trust in Jehovah.
Many are those who say, Who will show us [i]any[/i] good? / Lift up upon us the [xref]a[/xref]light of Your countenance, O Jehovah.
You have put joy in my heart, / More than when the [note]1[/note]grain and new wine of others abound.
verse.note: Lit., their grain and their new wine.

verse.text: In peace I will both lie down and sleep, / For You alone, O Jehovah, cause me to dwell in safety.
To the choir director: for the wind instruments. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
To my words give ear, O Jehovah; / Consider my moaning.
Give heed to the sound of my cry, / My [xref]a[/xref]King and my God; / For to You do I pray.
O Jehovah, in the morning / You will hear my voice; / In the morning I will set forth [i]my words[/i] in order to You, / And I will watch.
[note]1[/note]For You are not a God who delights in wickedness; / Evil will not sojourn with You.
verse.note: David highly uplifted and exalted the law and knew that God does not delight in wickedness but hates iniquity. But he conspired against Uriah, murdered him, and stole his wife ([link]2 Sam. 11[/link]), thus breaking all the last five commandments in the law. This shows that the law and the knowledge of it avail nothing.

verse.text: Those who boast will not stand / Before Your eyes; / You hate all workers of iniquity.
You will destroy those who speak lies. / Jehovah abhors a man of bloodshed and deceit.
But as for me, in the abundance of Your lovingkindness / I will come into Your [xref]a[/xref]house; / I will bow down toward Your [xref]b[/xref]holy temple / In fear of You.
O Jehovah, lead me in Your righteousness / On account of those who lie in wait for me; / Make Your way straight before me.
For there is no truth in their mouth; / Their inward part is corruption itself; / [xref]a[/xref]Their throat is an open [xref]b[/xref]grave; / They [xref]c[/xref]flatter with their tongue.
[note]1[/note]Hold them guilty, O God; / Let them fall by their own counsels; / Because of the multitude of their transgressions thrust them out, / For they have rebelled against You.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: But let all who [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in You rejoice; / Let them shout for joy forever; / And may You spread a cover over them; / And those who love Your name / Will exult in You.
For You will bless the righteous man, O Jehovah; / You will surround him with favor as with a shield.
To the choir director: on the stringed instruments, on the octave. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[xref]a[/xref]O Jehovah, do not rebuke me in Your anger, / Nor [note]1[/note]chasten me in Your burning wrath.
verse.note: David realized that he was being chastened by God, but in his prayer here there was little repentance and confession of his failure (cf. [link]Psa. 51:1-17[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 4[/link].

verse.text: Be gracious to me, O Jehovah, for I am languishing; / Heal me, O Jehovah, for my bones are shaken,
And my soul is greatly shaken. / But as for You, O Jehovah, how long?
Return, O Jehovah; deliver my soul; / Save me for Your lovingkindness' sake.
For in [xref]a[/xref]death there is no remembrance of You; / In [note]1[/note]Sheol who can give thanks to You?
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

verse.text: I am weary with my groaning; / Every night I cause my bed to swim; / With my tears I dissolve my couch.
My eye is wasted because of grief; / It has aged because of all those who vex me.
Depart from me, all you workers of iniquity, / For Jehovah has heard the sound of my weeping.
Jehovah has heard my supplication; / Jehovah receives my prayer.
All my enemies will be ashamed and greatly dismayed; / They will turn back; they will be put to shame suddenly.
A [note]1[/note]Shiggaion [xref]a[/xref]of David, which he sang to Jehovah on account of Cush the [xref]b[/xref]Benjaminite
verse.note: The meaning of the term is obscure but apparently denotes a musical form or tempo (cf. [link]Hab. 3:1[/link]).

verse.text: O Jehovah my God, in You do I [xref]a[/xref]take refuge. / Save me from all who pursue me, and deliver me;
Lest he tear my soul like a lion, / Tearing [i]it[/i] apart without anyone to deliver [i]it.[/i]
O Jehovah my God, if I have done this, / If there is [note]1[/note]unrighteousness in my hands,
verse.note: In this psalm David felt that he had done no wrong, and he asked God to judge him according to his righteousness and his integrity ([link]v. 8[/link]). This shows that David had not been enlightened and convicted by God concerning his own sinfulness (cf. [link]Psa. 51[/link]; [link]Isa. 64:6[/link]; [link]Rom. 7:18[/link]; [link]Luke 18:9-14[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:15[/link]).[br][br]Like the book of Job, many of the psalms give us the impression that we need to be godly, to fear God and trust in Him, to keep the law, to maintain our integrity, and to be righteous, upright, just, and perfect (cf. note [link]1[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in Job 1[/link]). Such a concept, however, is not according to the divine revelation of the New Testament; it is altogether the concept of the Old Testament under the law according to the knowledge of good and evil. The New Testament reveals that we have been crucified with Christ ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]) and buried with Him ([link]Rom. 6:4[/link]). Death has liberated us from the law ([link]Rom. 7:1-6[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:19[/link]). Now we should simply receive Christ, the embodiment of the Triune God, and let Him live in us, no longer caring for our righteousness, justice, or integrity but caring only for Christ, the living One ([link]Phil. 3:6b-9[/link]).

verse.text: If I have recompensed with evil him who was at peace with me / [note]1[/note](Rather, I have delivered him who vexed me without cause);
verse.note: Or, And have plundered him who vexed me without cause.

verse.text: Let the enemy pursue my soul and overtake [i]me,[/i] / And let him trample my life to the ground / And lay my glory down in the dust. Selah
Arise, O Jehovah, in Your anger; / Lift Yourself up against the overflowing wrath of those who vex me, / And awake for me: You have commanded judgment.
And let the assembly of the peoples surround You, / And over it return on high.
Jehovah will execute [xref]a[/xref]judgment on the peoples; / Judge me, O Jehovah, according to my righteousness / And according to my integrity that is with me.
Oh, let the evil of the wicked come to an end, / But establish the righteous man. / For the righteous God / [xref]a[/xref]Tries the hearts and the inward parts.
My shield is with God, / Who saves the upright in heart.
God is a righteous [xref]a[/xref]Judge / And a God who has indignation every day.
If one does not turn, He will whet His sword. / He bends His bow and makes it ready.
And He prepares instruments of death against him; / He has made His arrows fiery [i]shafts.[/i]
Behold, [i]the evil man[/i] travails with iniquity; / He conceives mischief and brings forth falsehood.
He digs a pit and hollows it out, / Then he falls into the hole that he has made.
His mischief returns upon his own head, / And upon the crown of his own head his violence comes down.
I will give thanks to Jehovah according to His righteousness, / And I will sing psalms to the name of Jehovah the Most High.
To the choir director: on the [note]1[/note]gittith. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is obscure. Perhaps a stringed instrument is meant.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]O Jehovah our Lord, / How [note]2[/note]excellent is Your [xref]a[/xref]name / In all the earth, / You who have set Your glory over the heavens!
verse.note: [link]Psalms 3-7[/link] reveal David's concepts concerning a godly life, whereas Psa. 8 is his inspired praise of the excellency of Christ.

Or, majestic. So also in [link]v. 9[/link]. [link]Psalms 3-7[/link] portray the poor and troubled situation on the earth according to David's human concept. Here, in Psa. 8, the name of the incarnated, crucified, resurrected, ascended, and exalted Jesus ([link]Phil. 2:5-11[/link]) is excellent in the earth according to the divine revelation, and the Lord's glory is above the heavens in the sight of David. In this psalm the earth is linked to the heavens and the heavens are brought down to the earth, making the earth and the heavens one ([link]Gen. 28:12[/link] and note 2).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Out of the mouths of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]babes and [note]1[/note]sucklings / You have [note]2[/note]established strength / Because of Your [note]3[/note]adversaries, / To stop the [note]3[/note]enemy and the [note]3[/note]avenger.
verse.note: Signifying the people of the kingdom of the heavens, who are like little children ([link]Matt. 18:3[/link]; [link]19:14[/link]). The Lord's salvation, including His redemption, regeneration, sanctification, renewing, and transformation, stops all our natural, human activity and makes us babes and sucklings to praise Him.
The Septuagint translates, perfected praise (cf. [link]Matt. 21:16[/link]).

Signifying Satan, who is God's adversary within God's kingdom, God's enemy outside God's kingdom, and the avenger who roves to and fro over the earth (cf. [link]Job 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:8[/link]). Above the heavens is God's splendor, and on the earth is the excellent name of Jesus; but between the earth and heavens are the adversary, the enemy, and the avenger ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]). The Lord stops these three categories of negative ones by establishing strength and perfecting praise out of the mouths of babes and sucklings, the youngest, smallest, and weakest ones. In this psalm the perfected praise includes the praise for the Lord's glory above the heavens, His excellency on the earth ([link]v. 1[/link]), and His incarnation, human living, death, resurrection, ascension, and coming kingdom ([link]vv. 4-8[/link]). To praise the Lord in such a perfected way requires strength. The highest consummation of the Lord's work in His redemption is to strengthen the weakest and smallest ones and perfect the praise they offer to Him out of their mouths.

verse.text: When I see Your [note]1[/note]heavens, the works of Your fingers, / [xref]a[/xref]The moon and the stars, which You have ordained,
verse.note: Here David's view was turned in the night (indicated by the moon and the stars) from looking at the earth to contemplating the heavens. In looking away from the dark earth to the moon and the stars in the heavens, David saw God's creation and the divine order in the universe. The Lord's aim in His redemption is to turn our view from the dark and troubled earth to the bright and ordered heavens.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]What is [note]1[/note]mortal man, that You [note]2[/note]remember him, / And the son of man, that You [note]2[/note]visit him?
verse.note: Man is the central object of God in His creation for the accomplishing of His economy to fulfill His heart's desire. What is written in [link]vv. 4-6[/link] concerning man was first alluded to in [link]Gen. 1:26-28[/link] and then quoted in [link]Heb. 2:6-8[/link]. These three portions of the word reveal man in three stages: first, the God-created man in God's creation in [link]Gen. 1:26[/link]; second, the Satan-captured man in man's fall in [link]Psa. 8:4[/link]; and third, Christ as a man in His incarnation for the accomplishing of God's redemption in [link]Heb. 2:6[/link]. Such a man God remembers in His economy and visits in His incarnation.

God in the heavens first remembered man; then, He came to visit man by becoming a man through His incarnation ([link]v. 5a[/link]; [link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:7[/link]). In this way He brought the heavens down to the earth and joined the earth and the heavens, making these two one ([link]John 1:51[/link]).

verse.text: You have made [note]1[/note]Him a little lower than [note]2[/note]angels / And have [note]3[/note]crowned Him with glory and honor.
verse.note: Referring to the man Jesus in His incarnation with His human living for His all-inclusive death ([link]Heb. 2:7[/link], [link]9a[/link]). See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 2[/link].
Heb. [i]elohim,[/i] normally translated [i]God.[/i] The translation here follows the Septuagint (cf. [link]Heb. 2:7[/link]).

Referring to Christ's resurrection, in which He was glorified ([link]John 7:39b[/link]; [link]Luke 24:26[/link]), and His ascension, in which He was honored ([link]Acts 2:33-36[/link]; [link]5:31a[/link]). Christ's all-inclusive death ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]), which preceded His resurrection and ascension, is implied.[br][br]This verse portrays all the steps of the Triune God's process in Christ: incarnation, human living, death, resurrection, and ascension. At the end of this process He was consummated to be the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]) to be breathed into and poured out upon His believers ([link]John 20:22[/link]; [link]Acts 2:17[/link]). Thus, God visited man through the long journey of His process, through which He became the life-giving Spirit to reach man and enter into man to indwell man ([link]John 14:17[/link], [link]20[/link]).

verse.text: For You have caused Him to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rule over the works of Your hands; / You have put [xref]b[/xref]all things [xref]c[/xref]under His feet:
verse.note: [link]Verses 6-8[/link] specifically refer to the one-thousand-year kingdom, the millennium, in which the man Christ will rule over all the created things, and to the restoration in the kingdom. This word was fulfilled first in Adam ([link]Gen. 1:26-28[/link]), but it was broken by man's fall. It will be fulfilled in full in Christ with His Body, the overcomers, in the millennium, the age of restoration ([link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]; [link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Isa. 11:6-9[/link]; [link]65:25[/link]).

verse.text: All sheep and oxen, / As well as the beasts of the field,
The birds of heaven and the fish of the sea, / Whatever passes through the paths of the seas.
[note]1[/note]O Jehovah our Lord, / How excellent is Your name / In all the earth!
verse.note: In this verse the psalmist considers that the earth is as excellent as the heavens, as indicated in the first part of the Lord's prayer in [link]Matt. 6:9-10[/link]. In the millennium the earth will be excellent because the excellency of the name of Christ will fill the earth. At that time the earth and the heavens will be one in a complete way.

verse.text: To the choir director: [note]1[/note]according to muth-labben. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is obscure. It may refer to a kind of singing voice. Some versions translate, over the death of a son.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I will give thanks to [i]You,[/i] O Jehovah, with all my heart; / I will tell out all Your wonders.
verse.note: This psalm combined with [link]Psa. 10[/link] is one of the alphabetical, or acrostic, psalms. In the acrostic psalms the first letters of each verse, or sometimes of each line of poetry, follow the order of the Hebrew alphabet.

verse.text: I will rejoice and exult in You; / I will sing psalms to Your name, O Most High.
When my [note]1[/note]enemies turn back, / They stumble and perish at Your presence.
verse.note: This psalm expresses David's concept concerning God's judgment on his enemies among the nations, and in [link]Psa. 10-14[/link] David speaks of man's condition before God. David's concept in these six psalms is according to the law given by God (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 1[/link]) and is based on the principle of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]). Nothing in these psalms is related to God's economy, to God's interest, to God's kingdom, or to God's plan. Everything is concerning David's personal benefit, personal interest, personal safety, and personal peace. The New Testament believers, who live by Christ as the tree of life for the carrying out of God's economy, should not take David here as a model.

verse.text: For You have upheld my right and my cause; / You sit on the throne, [note]1[/note]judging righteously.
verse.note: David's thought here and in [link]vv. 7-8[/link] is that God sits as the King on the throne only to judge the world in righteousness and with equity, i.e., with justice. His concept is according to the law and according to the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. In contrast, the principal concept of the New Testament is that Christ rules the world to save the world in mercy and grace ([link]Acts 5:31[/link] and note 2). In the New Testament God's throne is mainly the throne of grace ([link]Heb. 4:16[/link]), the throne of a loving Savior, not the throne of judgment. From eternity to eternity God's intention is to love the world, which is composed of fallen men, and to favor man with His mercy and grace ([link]Hosea 6:6[/link], cf. [link]Matt. 9:13[/link]; [link]John 3:16[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:3-4[/link]; [link]Titus 3:4-7[/link]). Of course, the New Testament also reveals that God's throne is the throne of God's authority and that God will judge His own people and the world in His righteousness ([link]2 Tim. 4:8[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:19[/link]; [link]Rev. 4:2[/link]; [link]6:12-20:15[/link]).

verse.text: You have rebuked the nations; You have destroyed the wicked; / You have blotted out their name forever and ever.
The enemies are finished; [i]they are in[/i] perpetual ruins; / And You have uprooted [i]their[/i] cities; the very memory of them has perished.
But Jehovah sits [i]enthroned[/i] forever; / He has established His throne for judgment.
And it is He who [xref]a[/xref]judges the world with righteousness; / He executes judgment on the peoples with equity.
And Jehovah is a [xref]a[/xref]high retreat for the oppressed, / A high retreat in times of distress.
And those who know Your name put their trust in You, / For You have not forsaken those who seek You, O Jehovah.
Sing psalms to Jehovah, the [xref]a[/xref]Inhabitant of [xref]b[/xref]Zion; / Declare His deeds among the peoples,
For He who avenges bloodshed remembers those [i]who were slain;[/i] / He does not forget the cry of the afflicted.
Be gracious to me, O Jehovah; look on my affliction from those who hate me, / You who raise me from the gates of death,
That I may tell out all Your praises / [i]And,[/i] in the gates of the [xref]a[/xref]daughter of Zion, [xref]b[/xref]exult in Your [xref]c[/xref]salvation.
The nations have sunk in the pit that they have made; / In the net that they hid, their own foot is caught.
Jehovah has made Himself known; He has executed [note]1[/note]justice; / The wicked have been snared in the work of their hands. [note]2[/note]Higgaion. Selah
verse.note: Or, judgment.
Referring, perhaps, to a resounding musical swell or to a meditative choral pause.

verse.text: The wicked will be turned back to Sheol, / All the nations who forget God.
For not always will the needy be forgotten, / Nor will the hope of the afflicted perish forever.
Arise, O Jehovah! Let not mortal man prevail; / Let the nations be judged in Your sight.
Put them in fear, O Jehovah; / Let the nations know that they are mortal men. Selah
[note]1[/note]Why, O Jehovah, do You stand [xref]a[/xref]far off? / [i]Why[/i] do You hide Yourself in times of distress?
verse.note: In the Septuagint, [link]Psa. 9[/link] and [link book="Psa."]10[/link] are one psalm. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 9[/link].

verse.text: Arrogantly the wicked hotly pursue the poor — / May they be caught in the plots that they devise!
For the wicked man boasts of the desire of his soul, / And the rapacious man curses, [i]even[/i] despises, Jehovah.
The wicked man, according to the haughtiness of his countenance, / [i]Says,[/i] He will not require [i]it;[/i] / All his thoughts are [i]this:[/i] [xref]a[/xref]There is no God!
His ways succeed at all times; / Your judgments are on high, out of his sight; / As for all his adversaries, he snorts at them.
He has said in his heart, I will not be shaken; / I will be in no trouble [note]1[/note]forever.
verse.note: Lit., from generation to generation.

verse.text: His [xref]a[/xref]mouth is full of curses and of deceit and oppression; / Under his tongue are mischief and iniquity.
He sits in the ambushes of the open villages; / In hidden places he murders the innocent; / His eyes secretly watch for the unfortunate.
He lurks in secret like a lion in [i]its[/i] covert; / He lurks [i]ready[/i] to seize the poor; / He seizes the poor, drawing [i]them[/i] up in his net.
He stoops, he crouches, / And the unfortunate fall by his mighty [i]claws.[/i]
He has said in his heart, God has forgotten; / He has hidden His face; He will never [xref]a[/xref]see [i]this.[/i]
Arise, O Jehovah; O God, lift up Your hand. / Do not forget the poor.
Why does the wicked man despise God / [i]And[/i] say in his heart, You will not require [i]it?[/i]

You do see! For You observe mischief and vexation, / To requite [i]it[/i] with Your own hand. / To You the unfortunate one [xref]a[/xref]commits [i]his cause;[/i] / You have been the help of the orphan.
Break the arm of the wicked man and the evil doer; / Seek out his wickedness until You find no more.
Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]King forever and ever; / The nations have perished from His land.
You have heard the desire of the lowly, O Jehovah; / You will establish their heart; You will cause Your ears to listen,
In order to execute justice for the orphan and the oppressed one, / That the mortal man of the earth may terrorize no longer.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David
In Jehovah have I [xref]a[/xref]taken refuge. How can you say to my soul, / Flee to [note]1[/note]the mountains like a bird?
verse.note: Following the reading of the Septuagint and some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, your (plural) mountain.

verse.text: For behold, the wicked bend the bow; / They ready their arrow on the string / To shoot in the dark at the upright in heart.
When the foundations are destroyed, / What will the righteous man do?
Jehovah is in His holy [xref]a[/xref]temple; / Jehovah — His [xref]b[/xref]throne is in heaven. / His eyes behold; / His [note]1[/note]eyelids try the sons of men.
verse.note: Signifying gazing.

verse.text: Jehovah tries the righteous man; / But the wicked man and him who loves violence, His soul hates.
He will rain down snares upon the wicked; / [xref]a[/xref]Fire and brimstone and a scorching wind will be the portion of their cup.
For Jehovah is righteous; He loves righteous deeds. / The upright man will behold His face.
To the choir director: on the octave. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
Save, O Jehovah; for the faithful man is no more, / For the trustworthy have vanished from among the sons of men.
Each man speaks falsehood with his neighbor; / With flattering lips and a double heart they speak.
May Jehovah cut off all the flattering lips, / The [xref]a[/xref]tongue speaking great things,
Those who said, With our tongue we will prevail; / Our lips are our own: Who is our lord?
Because of the devastation of the poor, because of the sighing of the needy, / I will now arise, says Jehovah; / I will set him in the safety that he longs for.
The words of Jehovah are [xref]a[/xref]pure words, / Silver refined in a furnace on the earth, / Purified seven times.
You, O Jehovah, will keep them; / You will guard them from this generation forever.
The wicked go about all around, / While vileness is exalted among the sons of men.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
How long, O Jehovah? Will You forget me continually? / How long will You hide Your face from me?
How long will I bear concern in my soul / [i]And[/i] sorrow in my heart day after day? / How long will my enemy be exalted over me?
Consider [i]and[/i] answer me, O Jehovah my God; / Enlighten my eyes lest I [xref]a[/xref]sleep the [i]sleep of[/i] death,
Lest my enemy say, I have prevailed against him, / [i]And[/i] my adversaries exult when I am shaken.
But I trust in Your lovingkindness; / My heart will exult in Your [xref]a[/xref]salvation;
I will sing to Jehovah, / For He has dealt bountifully with me.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David
[xref]a[/xref]The fool has said in his heart, / [xref]b[/xref]There is no God. / They are corrupt; they commit abominable deeds; / [xref]c[/xref]There is none who does good.
[xref]a[/xref]Jehovah looked down from heaven / Upon the sons of men / [xref]b[/xref]To see if there was anyone who had insight, / Who seeks after God.
They have all turned aside; / They are together perverse. / There is none who does good; / There is not even one.
Have they no knowledge, all the workers of iniquity, / Who eat up my people as they would eat up bread / [i]And[/i] do not call upon Jehovah?
There they were in great fear, / For God is among the generation of the righteous.
You put the counsel of the afflicted to shame, / But Jehovah is their [xref]a[/xref]refuge.
Oh that the [xref]a[/xref]salvation of Israel might come forth from [xref]b[/xref]Zion! / When Jehovah [xref]c[/xref]turns the captivity of His people, / Jacob will exult, Israel will rejoice.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[note]1[/note]O Jehovah, who may sojourn in Your [note]2[/note]tent? / [xref]a[/xref]Who may dwell on Your [xref]b[/xref]holy mountain?
verse.note: Psalms 15 and 16 are a pair showing a comparison between the keeping of the law and the participation in Christ. Psalm 15 is full of the concept of good and evil, whereas in Psa. 16 Christ, the person, replaces good and evil.
Referring to God's house, the temple.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]He who walks in integrity / And does righteousness / And speaks truth from his heart.
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 2-5[/link], David's concept was that the man who is perfect according to the law may dwell with God for His heart's desire and good pleasure. Thus, [link]v. 5[/link] says that he who does the good things of the law will not be shaken forever (cf. [link]16:8[/link]). However, [link]Psa. 16[/link] reveals that only Christ, the God-man, can satisfy God's desire and fulfill His good pleasure ([link]Matt. 3:17[/link]; [link]17:5[/link]). Only He — the very God who became a man, lived a human life full of the divine attributes expressed in human virtues, died, resurrected, and ascended to the right hand of God — is perfect according to the law and can sojourn in God's tabernacle and dwell with God on His holy mountain. In God's economy only the God-man Christ as the firstborn Son of God with His many brothers as the many sons of God ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]) can satisfy God's desire and fulfill His good pleasure.

verse.text: He does not slander with his tongue; / He does not do evil to his friend, / Nor does he take up a reproach against his neighbor.
In his eyes a reprobate is despised, / But he honors those who fear Jehovah. / Should he swear to his harm, / He does not change.
He does not lend his money on interest, / Nor accept a bribe against the innocent. / He who does these things will not be shaken forever.
A [note]1[/note]Michtam [xref]a[/xref]of David
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain; some understand, a golden jewel (of a poem); others, an epigram.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Preserve me, O God, for I [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]take refuge in You.
verse.note: This short psalm refers to Christ ([link]vv. 8-11[/link]; cf. [link]Acts 2:25a[/link]), the wonderful God-man, in His four stages: His human living (implying also His incarnation — [link]vv. 1-8[/link]), His death ([link]vv. 9-10[/link]), His resurrection ([link]vv. 10-11a[/link]), and His ascension ([link]v. 11b[/link]). See [link]Acts 2:25-28[/link] and notes.
When Christ was a man on earth, He took refuge in God and trusted in God's preservation.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I say to Jehovah, [note]2[/note]You are my Lord; / [xref]a[/xref]No good have I beyond You;
verse.note: Some MSS read, You say (perhaps addressing the soul).
As a man, Christ took God as His Lord ([link]Matt. 4:7[/link], [link]10[/link]) and had no good (no blessing, no pleasure, and no enjoyment) beyond God as His portion (cf. [link]Luke 18:19[/link]).

verse.text: As for the [note]1[/note]saints who are on the earth, they are the excellent; / All my [xref]a[/xref]delight is in them.
verse.note: In His human living Christ loved God the Father ([link]John 14:31[/link]) and delighted not in the law but in the saints, the excellent people on the earth, because they are the members of His Body, the church ([link]Eph. 1:22b-23[/link]; [link]5:30[/link]).

verse.text: The sorrows of them who bartered for some other [note]1[/note]god will be multiplied; / Their drink offerings of blood I will not offer, / Nor will I take up their names upon my lips.
verse.note: Christ in His human living had nothing to do with other gods and their offerings, nor did He take up their names upon His lips ([link]Matt. 4:10[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]portion of my inheritance and of my [xref]b[/xref]cup; / You maintain my lot.
verse.note: As a man on earth Christ took God the Father as the portion of His inheritance (His possession) and of His cup (His enjoyment). Furthermore, Christ trusted in God to maintain His lot (the portion of His inheritance). God maintains the earth for Christ that He may inherit it as His possession ([link]2:8[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:2b[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]measuring lines have fallen on pleasant places for me; / Indeed the inheritance is beautiful to me.
verse.note: Christ appreciated the measured possession and the beautiful inheritance given to Him by God. All the nations with the earth ([link]2:8[/link]) will be not only pleasant but also beautiful to Christ as the man who inherited God's inheritance ([link]Heb. 1:2b[/link]).

verse.text: I will bless Jehovah, who [note]1[/note]counsels me; / Indeed in the nights my [xref]a[/xref]inward parts instruct me.
verse.note: Christ, the humble Servant of Jehovah, was counseled by God, and His inward parts instructed Him in the nights ([link]Isa. 50:4[/link]; [link]Luke 6:12[/link]). When God counseled Christ as a man, Christ's inward parts instructed Him through His contact with God. The inward parts of Christ were one with God. This is the proper experience of a God-man (cf. [link]Phil. 1:8[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I have [note]1[/note]set Jehovah before me continually; / Because He is at my right hand, I shall not be shaken.
verse.note: In His human living Christ set God (not the law) before Him continually to be His security. Jesus was never alone, for God the Father was always with Him ([link]John 8:29[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore my heart rejoices and my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory exults; / Even my flesh [note]2[/note]dwells securely.
verse.note: The Septuagint translates, tongue. See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 2[/link].
In His death, while Christ was in Hades, His flesh (His physical body) dwelt securely, being buried in a secured tomb ([link]Matt. 27:59-60[/link]).

verse.text: For You will not abandon my [note]1[/note]soul to [xref]a[/xref]Sheol, / Nor let Your [xref]b[/xref]Holy One see the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]pit.
verse.note: After His death, Christ's soul went to Sheol (Hades — [link]Eph. 4:9[/link]) and remained there for three days. That God would not abandon Christ's soul to Sheol or let Him as God's Holy One see corruption indicates that Christ's soul would be raised up from Sheol and also that Christ's physical body would be resurrected from the tomb ([link]Matt. 28:6[/link]; [link]John 20:5-9[/link]).

The Septuagint translates, corruption (cf. [link]Acts 2:27[/link]). Christ's body was resurrected from the tomb within three days ([link]1 Cor. 15:4[/link]); hence, it did not see corruption in the tomb.

verse.text: You will make known to me the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]path of [xref]b[/xref]life; / In Your [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]presence is fullness of joy; / At Your [note]2[/note]right hand there are [xref]d[/xref]pleasures forever.
verse.note: See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 2[/link].

Christ is in God's presence participating in fullness of joy, indicating that He has ascended to the heavens to God's presence in order to enjoy His attainments and His obtainments ([link]Acts 1:9-11[/link]; [link]2:36[/link]; [link]5:31[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:9-11[/link]). Christ is also enjoying pleasures forever at God's right hand, indicating that He is at the right hand of God in His ascension to surpass all for the accomplishing of God's eternal economy concerning the church, the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 1:20b-23[/link]).

verse.text: A Prayer [xref]a[/xref]of David
[note]1[/note]Hear, O Jehovah, what is righteous; / Give heed to my cry; / Give ear to my prayer, / Which is not [i]made[/i] with lips of deceit.
verse.note: Psalms 17-21 reveal David's concept concerning a man before God and concerning David's kingship before God. His concept was based on the keeping of the law and the principle of good and evil. In God's New Testament economy we should not keep the law by ourselves but should live Christ by His living in us ([link]Gal. 2:19-20[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:21a[/link]).

verse.text: May a judgment for me come forth from Your presence; / May Your eyes regard equity.
You have [xref]a[/xref]examined my heart; You have visited me by night; / You have [xref]b[/xref]tried me: You have found nothing. / I have resolved that my mouth will not transgress.
Regarding the works of man, by the word of Your lips, / I have kept myself from the paths of the violent man.
My steps have held fast to Your [xref]a[/xref]tracks; / My footsteps have not slipped.
I call on You, for You will answer me, O God; / Incline Your ear to me; hear my speaking.
Wondrously display Your [note]1[/note]lovingkindness, / You who save by Your right hand / Those who take [xref]a[/xref]refuge [i]in You[/i] from them who rise up against them.
verse.note: [link]Verses 7-9[/link] indicate an improvement in David's concept from his own righteousness in [link]vv. 1-6[/link] to God's lovingkindness and God's hiding him in the shadow of His wings.

verse.text: Guard me like the [xref]a[/xref]pupil of [i]Your[/i] eye; / In the [xref]b[/xref]shadow of Your wings hide me
From the presence of the wicked who oppress me, / [i]From[/i] my deadly enemies, who close in upon me.
They have shut up their fat [i]hearts;[/i] / With their mouths they speak arrogantly.
Now they have surrounded [note]1[/note]us in our steps; / They have fixed their eyes on casting [i]us[/i] down to the ground.
verse.note: Some MSS read, me.

verse.text: He is like a lion that is eager to tear, / And like a young lion lurking in hidden places.
Arise, O Jehovah, [note]1[/note]confront him; bring him down. / With Your sword rescue my soul from the wicked man,
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: From mortal men with Your hand, O Jehovah, / From mortal men of the world, whose portion is in this life, / And whose belly You fill with Your treasure; / They are satisfied with children, / And they leave their abundance for their little ones.
As for me, in [note]1[/note]righteousness I will behold Your face; / When I [xref]a[/xref]awake, I will be satisfied with Your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]likeness.
verse.note: The end of this psalm shows David's improvement in his being satisfied with God's likeness (i.e., presence), yet David still remained in his righteousness before God. David boasted of his righteousness in spite of his great sin of taking Bathsheba and murdering her husband, Uriah ([link]2 Sam. 11[/link]).

verse.text: To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David, the servant of Jehovah, [xref]b[/xref]who [note]1[/note]spoke to Jehovah the words of this song on the day when Jehovah delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul, and he said:
verse.note: Psalm 18 is a human talk with the divine God, implying David's intimacy with God.

verse.text: I love You, O Jehovah, my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]strength.
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-5[/link] reveal the improvement of David's concept in his enjoyment of the saving God as his strength, his crag, his fortress, his Deliverer, his God, his rock, his shield, his horn of salvation, and his high retreat, in whom he took refuge.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah is my crag and my [xref]b[/xref]fortress and my Deliverer; / My God, my [xref]c[/xref]rock, in whom I [xref]d[/xref]take refuge; / My [xref]e[/xref]shield and the [xref]f[/xref]horn of my salvation, my [xref]g[/xref]high retreat.
I called upon Jehovah, who is worthy of praise,[br/]And from my enemies I was saved.
The cords of death encompassed me; / And the torrents of destruction assailed me.
The cords of Sheol surrounded me; / The snares of death confronted me.
In my distress I [note]1[/note]called upon Jehovah / And cried out to my God. / He heard my voice from His [xref]a[/xref]temple, / And my cry before Him came to His ears.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in Gen. 4[/link].

verse.text: Then the earth shook and quaked, / And the foundations of the mountains trembled and shook about, / For He was furious.
Smoke went up from His nostrils, / And fire from His mouth devoured; / Coals blazed forth from Him.
He [xref]a[/xref]bowed the heavens and descended, / And deep darkness was under His feet.
He rode upon a [xref]a[/xref]cherub and did fly; / He darted upon the [xref]b[/xref]wings of the wind.
He made darkness His hiding place, His pavilion around Him: / Dark waterclouds, thick clouds of the skies.
Out of the brightness before Him there broke through His clouds / [xref]a[/xref]Hail and fiery coals.
Then Jehovah thundered in heaven, / And the Most High uttered His voice[note]1[/note].
verse.note: Some MSS add, hail and fiery coals.

verse.text: And He sent forth His arrows and scattered [note]1[/note]my enemies; / And He shot forth lightning bolts and discomfited them.
verse.note: Lit., them.

verse.text: The channels of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sea were seen, / And the foundations of the habitable land were laid bare / At Your rebuke, O Jehovah, / At the blast of the breath of Your nostrils.
verse.note: Following certain MSS and [link]2 Sam. 22:16[/link]; other MSS read, water.

verse.text: He reached forth from on high; He took me; / He drew me out of great waters.
He delivered me from my strong enemy / And from those who hate me, for they were too mighty for me.
They confronted me in the day of my calamity, / But Jehovah became my support.
He brought me forth to a place broad and free; / He rescued me, for He took delight in me.
Jehovah has [note]1[/note]recompensed me according to my righteousness; / According to the cleanness of my hands He has [note]1[/note]repaid me.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 20-28[/link] David considered his righteousness, perfection, faithfulness, cleanness, and purity as the cause of God's saving him, and he considered God's salvation a recompense to him. This is a wrong concept. God saves us not because of our righteousness but because of His mercy and His compassion ([link]Lam. 3:22[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:1-9[/link]; [link]Titus 3:5[/link]) and because of His own purpose ([link]2 Tim. 1:9[/link]).

verse.text: For I have kept the ways of Jehovah / And have not acted wickedly [i]by turning[/i] away from my God.
For all His judgments were before me, / And I did not turn His statutes away from me.
I was perfect toward Him, / And I kept myself from my iniquity.
Therefore Jehovah recompensed me according to my righteousness, / According to the cleanness of my hands in His sight.
[xref]a[/xref]With the faithful You show Yourself faithful, / With a perfect man You show Yourself perfect,
With the pure You show Yourself pure, / And with the perverse You show Yourself contrary.
For it is You who save the afflicted people, / But the haughty eyes You bring down;
For it is You who light my [xref]a[/xref]lamp; / Jehovah my God lights up my darkness;
For by You I can run up against a troop; / Indeed by my God I can [xref]a[/xref]leap over a wall.
As for God — His way is perfect; / The word of Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]tried. / He is a [xref]b[/xref]shield to all who [xref]c[/xref]take refuge in Him.
For who is God other than Jehovah, / And who is a [xref]a[/xref]rock but our God?
The God who girds me with strength / And makes my way perfect,
Who makes my feet like [xref]a[/xref]hinds' [i]feet[/i] / And sets me on my [xref]b[/xref]high places,
Who [xref]a[/xref]teaches my hands to wage war / So that my arms may bend a bronze bow.
And You have given me the shield of Your salvation, / And Your right hand supports me; / And Your condescending gentleness has made me great.
You have broadened the places of my steps under me, / And my feet have not slipped.
I pursued my enemies and overtook them, / And I did not turn back until they were consumed.
I shattered them, so that they were not able to rise up; / They fell under my feet.
And You girded me with strength for war; / You brought down under me those who rose up against me.
You also made my enemies turn [i]their[/i] back to me, / And I annihilated those who hated me.
They cried out, but there was no one to save [i]them;[/i] / [i]They cried out[/i] to Jehovah, but He did not answer them.
Then I beat them like dust before the wind; / Like the mud of the streets I [note]1[/note]pounded them.
verse.note: Some MSS read, emptied.

verse.text: You rescued me from the strivings of the people; / You have made me the [xref]a[/xref]head of the nations; / A people whom I had [xref]b[/xref]not known serves me.
At the [i]mere[/i] hearing of a report, they obey me; / Foreigners come [xref]a[/xref]cringing to me;
Foreigners are discouraged / And come [xref]a[/xref]quaking out of their fortresses.
Jehovah lives; and blessed be my [xref]a[/xref]rock, / And exalted be the [xref]b[/xref]God of my salvation,
The God who executes vengeance for me / And subdues peoples under me,
Who rescues me from my enemies. / Indeed You exalted me above those who rise up against me; / From the violent man You delivered me.
[xref]a[/xref]Therefore I give thanks to You among the nations, O Jehovah; / And I will [xref]b[/xref]sing psalms to Your name.
[i]It is He[/i] who magnifies salvation to His king / And executes lovingkindness to His anointed, / To David and to his [note]1[/note]seed [xref]a[/xref]forever.
verse.note: Christ is the seed of David ([link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:3[/link]) to inherit the covenant God made with David ([link]2 Sam. 7:8-16[/link]).

verse.text: To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
The [xref]a[/xref]heavens [xref]b[/xref]declare the glory of God, / And the [xref]c[/xref]expanse proclaims the work of His hands.
Day to day pours forth speech, / And night to night tells out knowledge.
There is no speech and there are no words; / Their voice is not heard.
[xref]a[/xref]In all the earth their line has gone forth, / And their words to the end of the world. / In [note]1[/note]the heavens He has made a tent for the sun,
verse.note: Lit., them.

verse.text: And he, like a [xref]a[/xref]bridegroom, goes forth from his canopy; / He rejoices like a mighty man running the course.
His going forth is from the end of the heavens, / And his circuit is unto their ends; / And there is nothing hidden from his heat.
The [note]1[/note]law of Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]perfect, / Restoring the soul; / The [note]1[/note]testimony of Jehovah is faithful, / [xref]b[/xref]Making the simple wise;
verse.note: The law of God is His testimony (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link]). In [link]vv. 7-11[/link] David esteemed the law very highly. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 1[/link].

verse.text: The precepts of Jehovah are right, / Making the heart [xref]a[/xref]joyous; / The commandment of Jehovah is clear, / [xref]b[/xref]Enlightening the eyes;
The fear of Jehovah is pure, / Enduring forever; / The [xref]a[/xref]judgments of Jehovah are truth / And altogether righteous.
More to be desired are they than [xref]a[/xref]gold, / Even much refined gold; / [xref]b[/xref]Sweeter also than honey / And the drippings of the honeycomb.
Moreover by them Your servant is warned; / In keeping them there is much reward.
Who can discern [i]his[/i] errors? / [note]1[/note]Clear me of my secret faults.
verse.note: David's prayer in [link]vv. 12-14[/link] indicates that David was endeavoring to keep the law to the extent of being dealt with in his secret faults, in his presumptuous sins, in the words of his mouth, and in the meditation of his heart. However, even if David could have been perfect, this would not have pleased God. According to the entire principle of the Bible, God does not want anything merely from man. Regardless of how good a thing is, as long as it is merely human, God will put it aside. What God wants is not a good man, or even a perfect man, but a God-man. God's desire was to be incarnated as a man by the name of Jesus, to die on the cross, to be resurrected, and in resurrection to become a life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link], [link]17a[/link]) to indwell us ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]), to live in us ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]), and to live Himself out of us ([link]Phil. 1:21a[/link]). This psalm should be evaluated in view of the entire principle of the Bible, which is that God's main purpose is to make Himself one with man and to make man one with Him, that He and man may have one life, one nature, and one living. Those who are one with God are God's organism, the Body of Christ, which will consummate in the holy city, New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:2-22:5[/link]).

verse.text: Also keep back Your servant from presumptuous [i]sins;[/i] / Do not let them have [i]dominion[/i] over me; / Then I will be blameless and cleared / Of great transgression.
May the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart / Be acceptable before You, / O Jehovah, my [xref]a[/xref]rock and my [xref]b[/xref]Redeemer.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[note]1[/note]May Jehovah answer you in the day of trouble; / May the name of the God of Jacob set you on high.
verse.note: Psalms 20 and 21 reveal David's concept concerning his kingship before God. In this psalm David blessed his people with what God is and has. According to the principle of the Bible, the greater blesses the lesser ([link]Heb. 7:7[/link]). That David could bless his people indicates that he had attained to a higher stature in life (cf. [link]Gen. 47:7[/link] and note).

verse.text: May He send you help from the [xref]a[/xref]sanctuary / And support you from [xref]b[/xref]Zion.
May He remember all your meal offerings / And accept your burnt offering. Selah
May He give you according to your heart's [i]desire[/i] / And fulfill all your intention.
May we shout victoriously in Your salvation / And raise the [xref]a[/xref]banner in the name of our God. / May Jehovah fulfill all your petitions.
Now I know / That Jehovah saves His [xref]a[/xref]anointed; / He will answer him from His holy heaven / With mighty acts of salvation from His right hand.
Some [i]boast[/i] in [xref]a[/xref]chariots, and some in horses; / But we boast in the [xref]b[/xref]name of Jehovah our God.
They are humbled and fallen, / But we have risen and stand upright.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Save, O Jehovah! / May the king answer us when we call.
verse.note: Or, Save the king, O Jehovah. May He hear us when we call.

verse.text: To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
O Jehovah, in Your strength the king rejoices, / And in Your salvation how greatly does he exult.
You have given him his heart's desire / And have not withheld the request of his lips. Selah
For You meet him with blessings of goodness; / You have set a crown of refined gold on his head.
He asked [xref]a[/xref]life of You; You granted it to him: / Length of days forever and ever.
His glory is great in Your salvation; / You have laid majesty and splendor upon him;
For You have made him to be blessings forever; / You have made him glad with rejoicing in Your presence.
For the king trusts in Jehovah; / And because of the lovingkindness of the Most High, he is not shaken.
Your hand finds all Your enemies; / Your right hand finds those who hate You.
You make them like a furnace of fire / When Your presence appears. / Jehovah swallows them in His anger, / And fire devours them.
You destroy their fruit from the earth, / And their seed from among the sons of men.
Although they intend evil against You, / [i]And[/i] they think up a scheme, they will not prevail.
For You make them turn their back; / You aim with Your bowstrings at their faces.
Be [note]1[/note]exalted, O Jehovah, in Your strength; / We will sing and psalm Your might.
verse.note: Here David blessed Jehovah. As the king, he blessed his people ([link]20:1-9[/link]), and as God's anointed one, he blessed the anointing God.

verse.text: To the choir director: according to the [note]1[/note]hind of the dawn. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
verse.note: Perhaps a reference to a melody common at that time. The hind of the dawn here signifies Christ in His resurrection, which took place at early dawn ([link]Luke 24:1[/link]). A hind is a deer known for its leaping and jumping. Christ in resurrection is the leaping One ([link]S.S. 2:8-9[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]My God, my God, why have You [note]2[/note]forsaken me? / [note]3[/note][i]Why are You[/i] so far from saving me, / From the words of my groaning?
verse.note: Psalms 22-24 are a group of psalms revealing Christ from His crucifixion to His kingship in the coming age. Psalm 22 concerns Christ's death, His resurrection, and His many brothers produced in His resurrection to form His church. [link]Psalm 23[/link] concerns Christ as the Shepherd in His resurrection. [link]Psalm 24[/link] concerns Christ as the coming King in God's kingdom.[br][br]The subject of Psa. 22 is the Christ who passed through the redeeming death and entered into the church-producing resurrection. [link]Verses 1-21[/link] give a detailed picture of Christ in His suffering of death (cf. [link]Isa. 53[/link]), as typified by David in his suffering, and [link]vv. 22-31[/link] refer to Christ in His resurrection, as typified by Solomon in his kingly reign.

The question at the beginning of this psalm was spoken by David in his suffering, but it became a prophecy concerning Christ in His suffering of His redeeming death. While Christ was on the earth, God the Father was with Him all the time ([link]John 8:29[/link]), but at a certain point in His crucifixion, God left Him ([link]Matt. 27:45-46[/link]). God's leaving Him was economical, not essential. God could never leave Christ essentially, but economically God forsook Him for a time. Nevertheless, Christ died as the Son of God, a God-man; hence, in His death there is a divine and eternal element ([link]Acts 20:28[/link]; [link]1 John 1:7[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:12[/link]). See notes [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 3[/link], [link book="Matt." chapter="27"]45[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]46[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link], and [link]7[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in 1 John 1[/link].
Or, So far from my salvation are the words of my groaning.

verse.text: O my God, I call out in the day, but You do not answer; / And in the night, but there is no rest for me.
But You are holy, You who sit [i]enthroned[/i] / Upon the praises of Israel.
In You our fathers [xref]a[/xref]trusted; / They trusted and You rescued them.
To You they cried out and were delivered; / In You they trusted and were not put to shame.
[note]1[/note]But I am a [xref]a[/xref]worm and not a man, / A reproach of men and one [xref]b[/xref]despised by the people.
verse.note: [link]Verses 6-8[/link] display Christ's suffering unto death through men's reproach, despising, deriding, sneering, head-shaking, and mocking ([link]Heb. 13:13b[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:3[/link]; [link]Luke 23:11[/link]; [link]Mark 15:29-32[/link]; [link]Matt. 27:39-44[/link]). To deride is to make fun of or laugh at in contempt. To sneer is to smile or laugh with facial expressions that show scorn or contempt. When Christ was on the cross, the ridiculers also shook, or wagged, their heads in scorn. To mock is to hold up to scorn or contempt and to imitate or mimic in derision. All these things were suffered by the Lord Jesus Christ while He was nailed on the cross.

verse.text: All who see me [xref]a[/xref]deride me; / They sneer at [i]me;[/i] they [xref]b[/xref]shake their heads, [i]saying,[/i]
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]He [xref]b[/xref]committed himself to Jehovah; let Him rescue him; / Let Him deliver him since He takes pleasure in him.
verse.note: Others read, Commit yourself.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But You are the One who drew me forth from the [xref]a[/xref]womb, / Who made me trust [i]while[/i] at my mother's breasts.
verse.note: [link]Verses 9-11[/link] show that while people were mocking Him and deriding Him, Christ trusted in God for deliverance, that is, for resurrection. He intended definitely to die and expected to be delivered from death, that is, to be resurrected from the dead ([link]Luke 18:31-33[/link]; [link]Heb. 5:7[/link]).

verse.text: I was cast upon You from [xref]a[/xref]birth; / From my mother's womb You have been my God.
Do not be far from me, / For trouble is near, / For there is none to help [i]me.[/i]
[note]1[/note]Many [xref]a[/xref]bulls surround me; / The mighty [i]bulls[/i] of Bashan encompass me.
verse.note: [link]Verses 12-18[/link] depict in vivid detail how Christ passed through His suffering of crucifixion (cf. [link]Mark 15:16-37[/link]). While Christ was being crucified on the cross, many fierce men, signified by mighty bulls, encompassed Him ([link]v. 12[/link]). They opened their mouth at Him like a ravening and roaring lion ([link]v. 13[/link]). Evil men, signified by dogs (cf. [link]Phil. 3:2a[/link]), surrounded Him, and a congregation of evildoers enclosed Him ([link]v. 16a-b[/link]). They pierced His hands and feet ([link]v. 16c[/link]). They divided His garments to themselves, and for His clothing they cast lots ([link]v. 18[/link]). They also looked, stared at Him with contempt and hatred ([link]v. 17b[/link]). On the cross He was poured out like water ([link]v. 14a[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:12[/link]). All His bones were out of joint ([link]v. 14b[/link]) because He could not hold up the weight of His body as it hung on the cross. This caused Him great agony and pain. Also, He counted all His bones ([link]v. 17a[/link]). His heart was like wax melted within Him ([link]v. 14c-d[/link]). His strength was dried up like a shard ([link]v. 15a[/link]), a piece of broken pottery. His tongue was stuck to His jaws ([link]v. 15b[/link]). God had put Him in the dust of death ([link]v. 15c[/link]).

verse.text: They open their mouth at me, / [i]Like[/i] a ravening and roaring [xref]a[/xref]lion.
I am poured out like water, / And all my [xref]a[/xref]bones are out of joint. / My heart is like wax; / It is melted within [note]1[/note]me.
verse.note: Lit., my inward parts. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Exo. 27[/link].

verse.text: My strength is [xref]a[/xref]dried up like a shard, / And my tongue is stuck to my jaws; / [note]1[/note]You have put me in the dust of death.
verse.note: Referring to God. On one hand, man crucified the Lord Jesus; on the other hand, God killed Him. If Jesus had been killed only by man, He would have been merely a martyr and not our Redeemer. But God judged Him and put Him into death for our redemption ([link]Isa. 53:10a[/link]). All the sin of the world was laid on Christ as the Lamb of God ([link]Isa. 53:6b[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:24a[/link]; [link]John 1:29[/link]). On the cross He died a vicarious death for us ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]) to redeem us from our sins, from God's judgment, and from eternal perdition ([link]1 Cor. 15:3[/link]; [link]John 3:16-17[/link]; [link]5:24[/link]).

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]dogs surround me; / A company of evildoers encloses me; / [note]1[/note]They [xref]b[/xref]pierce my [xref]c[/xref]hands and feet.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint and other ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, Like a lion, my hands and feet.

verse.text: I count all my [xref]a[/xref]bones; / They look, they [xref]b[/xref]stare at me.
They divide my garments to themselves, / And for my clothing they [xref]a[/xref]cast lots.
[note]1[/note]But You, O Jehovah, be not far off; / O my help, hasten to aid me.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 19-21[/link] Christ asked God to deliver Him from death, i.e., to raise Him up from death ([link]Heb. 5:7[/link] and note).

verse.text: Deliver my soul from the sword, / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]My precious life from the power of the [xref]b[/xref]dog;
verse.note: Lit., My only one; a reference to a person's most prized possession, his life.

verse.text: Save me from the mouth of the [xref]a[/xref]lion; / Indeed [note]1[/note]while I am in the horns of wild oxen, answer me.
verse.note: Lit., from the horns.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I will declare Your name to my [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]brothers; / In the midst of the [note]2[/note]assembly I will praise [note]3[/note]You.
verse.note: After passing through His redeeming death, Christ entered into the church-producing resurrection.
