It was in His resurrection that Christ called His disciples His brothers ([link]John 20:17[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:10[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:11[/link]), for in God's eternal view His disciples were regenerated and became God's sons in Christ's resurrection ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). In His resurrection Christ Himself was begotten to be God's firstborn Son ([link]2:7[/link]; [link]Acts 13:33[/link]) and became the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]), and all God's chosen and redeemed people were regenerated to be the many sons of God, the many brothers of Christ ([link]Heb. 2:10-12[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]).
The assembly here signifies the church, indicating that the Lord's brothers constitute the church ([link]Heb. 2:11-12[/link]). Thus, His resurrection is the church-producing resurrection.

[i]You[/i] and [i]Your[/i] in this verse refer to the Father. In resurrection Christ declared the Father's name to His brothers and praised the Father in the church ([link]Heb. 2:12[/link] and note 3).

verse.text: You who fear Jehovah, [note]1[/note]praise Him! / All you seed of Jacob, glorify Him! / And stand in awe of Him, all you seed of Israel!
verse.note: Following his praise to God in the assembly, David advised God's people to praise Jehovah and all the earth to worship Him ([link]vv. 23-26[/link], [link]29-31[/link]). Christ took the lead in praising God in the church, and the church follows Him to praise God. Now Israel should follow Christ and the church. Thus far, Israel has not followed, but when Christ comes back, all Israel will repent and be saved ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26-27[/link]). Then they will join the church to praise God.

verse.text: For He has not despised nor detested / The affliction of him who is afflicted; / And He has not hidden His face from him; / But when he cried out to Him, He heard.
From You [i]comes[/i] my praise in the great assembly; / My vows will I pay before those who fear Him.
The lowly will eat and be [xref]a[/xref]satisfied; / Those who seek after Jehovah will praise Him — / May your hearts live forever!
All the [xref]a[/xref]ends of the earth / Will remember and return to Jehovah, / And all families of the [note]1[/note]nations / Will worship before You;
verse.note: The church ushers in Christ's kingdom for Christ to rule over the nations ([link]vv. 27-28[/link]). The church, produced by Christ's resurrection, is the reality of the kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:17[/link]) and a precursor to the manifestation of the kingdom in the millennium.

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom is Jehovah's, / And [note]1[/note]He rules among the nations.
verse.note: Jehovah as Christ will rule over the nations in the millennial kingdom ([link]2:8-9[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:15[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]).

verse.text: All the flourishing of the earth / Will eat and worship. / All who go down into the dust will [xref]a[/xref]bow down before Him, / Even he who does not keep his soul alive.
A [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seed will serve Him; / That which concerns the Lord will be told to a [i]coming[/i] [xref]b[/xref]generation.
verse.note: The believers are the seed of Christ, and their declaring the Lord's righteousness (justification, salvation) to a coming generation ([link]vv. 30-31[/link]) refers to the preaching of the gospel.

verse.text: They will come and declare His righteousness / To a people yet to be born, that He has done [i]this.[/i]
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[note]1[/note]Jehovah is my [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shepherd; I will [xref]b[/xref]lack nothing.
verse.note: Psalm 23 concerns Christ as the Shepherd in His resurrection. According to this psalm, Christ shepherds us in five stages: (1) the enjoyment of Christ as the green pastures and of the Spirit as the waters of rest ([link]v. 2[/link]); (2) the revival and transformation on the paths of righteousness ([link]v. 3[/link]); (3) the experience of the resurrected pneumatic Christ while walking through the valley of the shadow of death ([link]v. 4[/link]); (4) the deeper and higher enjoyment of the resurrected Christ in fighting against the adversaries ([link]v. 5[/link]); and (5) the lifelong enjoyment of the divine goodness and kindness in the house of Jehovah ([link]v. 6[/link]).

Christ in His resurrection is the Shepherd ([link]Heb. 13:20[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:25[/link]; [link]5:4[/link]), and the church produced by Christ's resurrection is His flock ([link]Acts 20:28[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:2[/link]). By being incarnated, crucified, and resurrected to become the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), Christ as Jehovah ([link]John 8:24[/link]), the Triune God ([link]Exo. 3:14[/link]), is qualified to be our Shepherd. By His redeeming, washing, resurrecting, and regenerating us, we are qualified to be His flock. To enjoy Christ's shepherding, we need to be in the flock, i.e., in the church.

verse.text: He makes me lie down in [note]1[/note]green [xref]a[/xref]pastures; / He leads me beside [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]waters of rest.
verse.note: The pastures signify Christ as the feeding place for His sheep ([link]John 10:9[/link] and note 2), and the color green signifies the riches of life. Christ can be our green pasture through His incarnation, death, and resurrection.

The waters of rest signify the Spirit, who was consummated in Christ's resurrection ([link]John 7:37-39[/link] and note [link]39[sup]1[/sup][/link]). In the initial stage of Christ's shepherding, the lambs, the infants in Christ ([link]John 21:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:2[/link]), feed on Christ as the green pasture and drink the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]), the resurrected pneumatic Christ, as the waters of rest.

verse.text: He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]restores my soul;[br/]He [xref]b[/xref]guides me on the [note]2[/note]paths of righteousness / For His [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]name's sake.
verse.note: In the second stage of His shepherding, Christ restores (revives and transforms) our soul ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:23[/link]) and guides us (to walk according to the spirit) on the paths of righteousness (to fulfill the requirement of righteousness — [link]Rom. 8:4[/link]). To be righteous, i.e., to be right with persons, matters, and things before God according to His righteous and strict requirements, we need to be revived and transformed in our soul in order to be proper and balanced in our mind, emotion, and will.
Both the paths and the righteousness are the resurrected Christ ([link]John 14:6a[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]).

The name indicates the person. Hence, [i]for His name's sake[/i] denotes being in His person. As the pneumatic Christ, the life-giving Spirit, in His resurrection, Christ leads us inwardly to walk in the paths of righteousness in Himself as the person (cf. [link]Col. 3:17[/link]).

verse.text: Even though I walk / Through the [note]1[/note]valley of the [xref]a[/xref]shadow of death, / I do not fear evil, / For You are with me; / Your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]rod and Your [note]2[/note]staff, / They comfort me.
verse.note: In the third stage of His shepherding, we experience the presence of the resurrected pneumatic Christ as we walk through the valley of the shadow of death, i.e., through the troubles and sufferings of life. When we walk through the valley, we do not fear any evil, for the pneumatic Christ is with us ([link]Matt. 28:20b[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). His presence is a comfort, a rescue, and a sustaining power to us. When we are in the valley, we should simply remain there and rest in the Lord. Our resting in the Lord will shorten the valley, reduce the shadow, and remove the death.
The rod is for protection, and the staff is for training, for guidance, and also for sustenance. In the valley of the shadow of death, the Lord's protection, guidance, and sustenance comfort us.

verse.text: You spread a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]table before me / In the presence of my adversaries; / You [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]anoint my head with oil; / My [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]cup runs over.
verse.note: In the fourth stage of His shepherding, in the deeper and higher enjoyment of the resurrected Christ, the Lord spreads a table, a feast (Christ with His riches for our enjoyment), before us in the presence of our adversaries. If we fight the spiritual battle and defeat the adversaries, we will have a rich enjoyment of the Lord as our feast at His table (cf. [link]Gen. 14:17-18[/link]).

The Hebrew word refers to the anointing done at a festal banquet. In the fourth stage of His shepherding, the Lord anoints our head with oil (the oil of exultant joy — [link]Heb. 1:9[/link]), signifying the compound Spirit as the compound ointment ([link]Exo. 30:23-26[/link] and notes [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link]). To anoint the head is to anoint the whole body ([link]133:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:21[/link]). This is the anointing of the compound, life-giving Spirit in Christ's resurrection ([link]1 John 2:20[/link] and note 1).

In the fourth stage of Christ's shepherding, our cup (the cup of blessing — [link]1 Cor. 10:16a[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:27[/link] and note) runs over. In this verse the Triune God is implied — the Son as the table, the feast ([link]1 Cor. 11:23-26[/link]), the Spirit as the anointing oil ([link]Luke 4:18[/link]), and the Father as the source of the blessing ([link]Eph. 1:3[/link]).

verse.text: Surely [note]1[/note]goodness and lovingkindness will follow me / All the days of my life, / And I will dwell in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]house of Jehovah / For the length of [i]my[/i] days.
verse.note: The fifth stage of Christ's shepherding is the lifelong enjoyment of the divine goodness and lovingkindness in the house of Jehovah. Under the organic shepherding of the pneumatic Christ, goodness and lovingkindness follow us "all the days of [our] life," referring to the present age. [i]Goodness[/i] refers to the grace of Christ, [i]lovingkindness[/i] refers to the love of the Father, and [i]follow[/i] implies the fellowship of the Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]). Eventually, this enjoyment of the processed and consummated Triune God ushers us into the enjoyment of God in the house of God (Christ, the church, and the New Jerusalem — [link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:21[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15-16[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link], [link]22[/link]), where we will dwell "for the length of [our] days," referring to the present age, the coming age, and eternity.

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[note]1[/note]The [xref]a[/xref]earth is Jehovah's, and its [xref]b[/xref]fullness, / The habitable land and those who dwell in it.
verse.note: In [link]Psa. 22[/link] Christ is the Redeemer and the Regenerator, in [link]Psa. 23[/link] He is the Shepherd, and in this psalm He is the King who will regain the entire earth through the church, His Body, the people whom He has redeemed and regenerated and is shepherding today. At His second coming Christ will take possession of the earth ([link]Rev. 10:1-2[/link]), which has been given to Him as His possession ([link]2:8[/link]), and will establish God's kingdom on the whole earth ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]), thus recovering God's right over the earth, which has been usurped by His enemy, Satan.

verse.text: For it is He who [xref]a[/xref]founded it upon the seas / And established it upon the streams.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Who may ascend the [note]2[/note]mountain of Jehovah, / And who may stand in His holy place?
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-2[/link], concerning God's kingdom, are according to the divine concept. In [link]vv. 3-6[/link] David returned to his natural concept of keeping the law, which has nothing to do with God's kingdom. This shows again the two kinds of concepts — the human concept and the divine concept — mixed together in the Psalms. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], pars. 2 and 3, in Psa. 1[/link], and note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 15[/link].

The mountain here implies the city (see note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link]), which signifies the kingdom of God (cf. [link]30:7[/link] and note). Although the Lord has the right, the title, to the earth ([link]v. 1[/link]), today the earth is usurped by His enemy. Yet on this usurped earth there is the mountain of Jehovah, Mount Zion ([link]2:6[/link]), which is absolutely open to the Lord and absolutely possessed by Him ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]3[/link], [link]7-10[/link]). The overcomers, who are typified by Zion (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link]), are the beachhead through which the Lord will return to possess the whole earth ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]).

verse.text: He who has [xref]a[/xref]clean hands and a [xref]b[/xref]pure heart, / Who has not lifted up his soul to falsehood / Or sworn deceitfully.
He will receive blessing from Jehovah, / And righteousness from the God of his salvation.
This is the generation of those who seek Him, / Those who [xref]a[/xref]seek Your face, [i]even[/i] Jacob. Selah

[note]1[/note]Lift up your heads, O [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]gates; / And be lifted up, O [note]3[/note]long enduring [note]2[/note]doors; / And the [note]4[/note]King of [xref]b[/xref]glory will come in.
verse.note: [link]Verses 7-10[/link], unveiling the victorious Christ as the coming King in God's eternal kingdom, continue the divine concept of [link]vv. 1-2[/link].
The gates are of the cities of the nations; the doors are of the houses of the people.

Indicating waiting and expecting with long endurance ([link]Rom. 8:25[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:7[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:20[/link]). Christ is the desire of all the nations ([link]Hag. 2:7[/link]). All the nations, in a general way, are expecting Christ to come, but Christ will not come quickly according to our human concept ([link]2 Pet. 3:8-9[/link]). Thus, we need to lift up our heads and await and expect His coming with long endurance.

The King of glory is Jehovah of hosts (that is, of armies), the consummated Triune God embodied in the victorious and coming Christ ([link]vv. 7-10[/link]; [link]Luke 21:27[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:31[/link]). Jehovah is Jesus ([link]Matt. 1:21[/link] and note), and Jesus is the incarnated, crucified, and resurrected Triune God, who is strong in fighting and is victorious ([link]Rev. 5:5[/link]). He is the One who will come back in His resurrection with His overcomers to possess the entire earth as His kingdom ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]; [link]7:13-14[/link]; [link]Joel 3:11[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]19:13-14[/link]).

verse.text: Who is the King of glory? / Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]strong and mighty! / Jehovah mighty in [xref]b[/xref]battle!
Lift up your heads, O gates; / And lift up, O long enduring doors; / And the King of glory will come in.
Who is this King of glory? / Jehovah of hosts — / He is the King of glory! Selah
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note]To You, O Jehovah, / I [xref]a[/xref]lift up my soul.
verse.note: This psalm is one of the alphabetical, or acrostic, psalms. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 9[/link]. [link]Psalms 25-41[/link] show the mixed expressions of the psalmist's sentiments in his enjoyment of God in God's house. The enjoyment of Christ, as portrayed in [link]Psa. 2[/link], [link book="Psa."]8[/link], [link book="Psa."]16[/link], and [link book="Psa."]22-24[/link], led the psalmist to another state of enjoyment — the enjoyment of God in the house of God. Although God is universal and omnipresent, He has located Himself in His house so that men may contact Him and enjoy Him ([link]23:6[/link]; [link]27:4[/link]). In the Old Testament time God's house, His dwelling place, was both in the heavens ([link]1 Kings 8:30b[/link], [link]39a[/link], [link]43a[/link]) and in the temple on Mount Zion ([link]Psa. 76:2b[/link]; [link]135:21[/link]; [link]Isa. 8:18[/link]). God's physical house in the Old Testament is a type of His spiritual house in the New Testament ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]). God's house in the New Testament is, first, Christ as God's tabernacle and God's temple ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:21[/link]; [link]Col. 2:9[/link]); second, it is the church, the enlargement of Christ, as God's enlarged temple ([link]1 Cor. 3:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:21-22[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:6[/link]). Consummately, God's house will be the New Jerusalem, a composition of God's redeemed as the tabernacle ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link]) for God to dwell in and enjoy His redeemed, and the redeeming God Himself as the temple ([link]Rev. 21:22[/link]) for His redeemed to dwell in and enjoy Him — a mutual dwelling of both God and man for their mutual enjoyment. We enjoy God in His house by being in Christ and in the church in this age, and ultimately in the New Jerusalem in the next age and in eternity.

verse.text: O my God, I [xref]a[/xref]trust in You; / Do not let me be [xref]b[/xref]ashamed; / Do not let my enemies exult over me.
Indeed may all who wait on You not be ashamed; / May those who deal treacherously without cause be ashamed.
[xref]a[/xref]Make Your ways known to me, O Jehovah; / Teach me Your paths.
Guide me in Your truth, and teach me; / For You are the God of my salvation; / I wait on You all the day long.
Remember Your compassions, O Jehovah, / And Your acts of kindness, for they are from of old.
The [note]1[/note]sins of my youth and my transgressions, do not remember; / According to Your lovingkindness, remember me, / For the sake of Your goodness, O Jehovah.
verse.note: In this verse and in [link]vv. 11[/link] and [link]18[/link] David asked God not to remember but to forgive his sins, his transgressions, and his great iniquity. Our confession of sins and God's forgiveness of our sins are the threshold of the New Testament age ([link]Matt. 3:1-2[/link]; [link]Mark 1:4-5[/link]; [link]Acts 10:43[/link]; [link]Heb. 8:12[/link]; [link]1 John 1:9[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah is good and upright; / Therefore He instructs sinners concerning the way.
He guides the lowly in justice / And teaches the lowly His way.
All the paths of Jehovah are lovingkindness and truth / To those who observe His covenant and His [note]1[/note]testimonies.
verse.note: Referring to the law with the Ten Commandments, the statutes, and the ordinances. See notes [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link] and [link]6[sup]4[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].

verse.text: For the sake of Your [xref]a[/xref]name, O Jehovah, / Pardon my iniquity, for it is great.
Who then is the man who fears Jehovah? / Him will He instruct concerning the way that he should choose.
His soul will dwell in [note]1[/note]prosperity, / And his seed will possess the [xref]a[/xref]land.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 1[/link].

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]intimate [note]1[/note]counsel of Jehovah is to those who fear Him, / And His [note]1[/note]covenant will He make known to them.
verse.note: Here David put the intimate counsel of God together with the covenant, the law, indicating the mixture in the expression of his sentiment. Such mixed expressions can be seen also in [link]vv. 15-18a[/link] and [link]21[/link].

verse.text: My eyes are continually [i]turned[/i] to Jehovah, / For He will bring my feet out of the net.
Turn toward me, and be gracious to me, / For I am alone and afflicted.
[note]1[/note]Relieve the troubles of my heart, / And bring me out of my distresses.
verse.note: Others read, The troubles of my heart are enlarged; bring me out.

verse.text: Look on my affliction and my suffering, / And forgive all my sins.
Look on my enemies, for they are many; / Indeed they hate me with a violent hatred.
Keep my soul, and deliver me; / Do not let me be put to shame, / For I [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in You.
May [note]1[/note]integrity and [note]1[/note]uprightness preserve me, / For I wait on You.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 18[/link].

verse.text: Redeem Israel, O God, / Out of all his troubles.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
Judge me, O Jehovah; / For I have walked in my [note]1[/note]integrity, / And in Jehovah I have [xref]a[/xref]trusted; / I will not waver.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 7[/link]. So also for [link chapter="26"]v. 11[/link].

verse.text: Examine me, O Jehovah, and [xref]a[/xref]try me; / Test my [xref]b[/xref]inward parts and my heart.
For Your lovingkindness is before my eyes, / And I have [xref]a[/xref]walked in Your truth.
I do not [xref]a[/xref]sit with men of falsehood, / Nor will I associate with hypocrites.
I hate the assembly of evildoers, / Nor will I sit with the wicked.
I [xref]a[/xref]wash my hands in innocence / And go around Your altar, O Jehovah,
Making [i]myself[/i] heard with the voice of thanksgiving / And telling out all Your wonderful deeds.
O Jehovah, I [xref]a[/xref]love the habitation of Your house, / And the place where Your glory [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]abides.
verse.note: Here, to abide is to remain for manifestation. When the people of Israel erected the tabernacle and when they built the temple, the glory of God descended upon the tabernacle and the temple to abide there, to remain there, to be manifested to the people ([link]Exo. 40:33-35[/link]; [link]1 Kings 8:10-11[/link]). Today the church is the place where God's glory abides to be manifested ([link]Eph. 3:21[/link]).

verse.text: Do not gather my soul with sinners, / Nor my life with men of bloodshed,
In whose hand is a wicked scheme, / And whose right hand is full of bribes.
But as for me, I walk in my integrity; / Redeem me and be gracious to me.
My foot stands on level ground; / In the assemblies I will bless Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
Jehovah is my [xref]a[/xref]light and my [xref]b[/xref]salvation; / Whom shall I fear? / Jehovah is the strength of my life; / Whom shall I dread?
When evildoers come near me / To devour my flesh, / It is they, my adversaries and my enemies, / Who stumble and fall.
If an army camps against me, / My heart does not fear; / If a battle arises against me, / In spite of this I am confident.

One thing I have asked from Jehovah; / That do I seek: / To dwell in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]house of Jehovah / All the days of my life, / To [xref]b[/xref]behold the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]beauty of Jehovah, / And to inquire in His temple.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 4-6[/link] the psalmist appreciated not the law, as in [link]Psa. 1[/link], but the enjoyment of God in His house. In God's house, that is, in Christ ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:21[/link]) and in the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]), we behold God's beauty and inquire of God ([link]v. 4[/link]), are concealed from calamities and hidden from our pursuers ([link]v. 5a-b[/link]), are raised up and have our heads lifted up by God ([link]vv. 5c[/link], [link]6a[/link]), and offer up sacrifices of shouts of joy and sing and psalm to God ([link]v. 6b-c[/link]).
Or, loveliness, pleasantness, delightfulness.

verse.text: For He will conceal me in His shelter / In the day of trouble; / He will hide me in the [xref]a[/xref]hiding place of His tent; / He will raise me up upon a rock.
And now my head is lifted up / Above my enemies who surround me. / And I will offer in His tent / [xref]a[/xref]Sacrifices of shouts of joy: / I will sing and [xref]b[/xref]psalm to Jehovah.
Hear, O Jehovah, when I call with my voice, / And be gracious to me and answer me.
[i]When You say,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]Seek My face, / To You my heart says, Your face, O Jehovah, will I seek.
Do not hide Your face from me; / Do not turn Your servant away in [i]Your[/i] anger; / You have been my help. / Do not abandon me or forsake me, / O God of my salvation.
If my father and my mother forsake me, / Jehovah will take me up.
Teach me, O Jehovah, Your way, / And lead me on a level path / Because of those who lie in wait for me.
Do not give me over / To the desire of my adversaries; / For [xref]a[/xref]false witnesses have risen up against me, / And those who breathe out threats.
[note]1[/note]I have believed / That I would see the goodness of Jehovah / In the land of the living.
verse.note: Some MSS insert, Unless.

verse.text: Wait for Jehovah; / Be strong, and let your heart be encouraged. / Yes, wait for Jehovah.
To You, O Jehovah, do I call out; / My [xref]a[/xref]rock, do not be deaf to me, / Lest, if You are silent to me, / I become like those who go down into the pit.
Hear the voice of my supplications / When I cry out to You, / When I [xref]a[/xref]lift up my hands / Unto Your innermost sanctuary.
Do not drag me away with the wicked / And with the workers of iniquity, / Who speak peace to their neighbors / While evil is in their heart.
[note]1[/note]Repay them according to what they have done / And according to the evil of their deeds; / [xref]a[/xref]According to the work of their hands repay them; / Return to them their due.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 4-5[/link], see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: For they do not regard the acts of Jehovah / Or the work of His hands; / He will tear them down / And not rebuild them.
Blessed be Jehovah, / For He has heard the voice of my supplications.
Jehovah is my strength and my [xref]a[/xref]shield; / My heart trusts in Him, and I am helped; / Therefore my heart exults; / And with my song do I give thanks to Him.
Jehovah is [note]1[/note]their strength; / And He is a stronghold of salvation to His anointed.
verse.note: Some MSS read, the strength of His people.

verse.text: Save Your people, / And bless Your inheritance; / And [xref]a[/xref]shepherd them and carry them forever.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ascribe to Jehovah, O sons of the Mighty, / Ascribe to Jehovah glory and strength;
verse.note: David's prayer and praise in this psalm is too much in the material and physical realm and cannot compare with the prayer and praise in the New Testament (cf. [link]Eph. 1:15-23[/link]; [link]3:14-21[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:33-36[/link]; [link]16:25-27[/link]).

verse.text: Ascribe to Jehovah the glory of His name; / Worship Jehovah in holy [note]1[/note]splendor.
verse.note: Or, adornment.

verse.text: The voice of Jehovah is over the waters; / The God of [xref]a[/xref]glory [xref]b[/xref]thunders, / Jehovah over the great waters.
The voice of Jehovah is powerful; / The voice of Jehovah is full of majesty.
The voice of Jehovah breaks the cedars; / Indeed Jehovah breaks the cedars of Lebanon in pieces;
And He makes Lebanon [xref]a[/xref]skip like a calf, / And [note]1[/note]Sirion like a young wild ox.
verse.note: I.e., Hermon (cf. [link]Deut. 3:9[/link]).

verse.text: The voice of Jehovah cleaves out flames of fire.
The voice of Jehovah shakes the wilderness; / Jehovah shakes the wilderness of Kadesh.
The voice of Jehovah [note]1[/note]causes the hinds to calve / And strips the forests bare; / And in His temple all say, Glory!
verse.note: Others read, makes the terebinths writhe.

verse.text: Jehovah sat [i]enthroned[/i] at the Flood, / And Jehovah sits as [xref]a[/xref]King forever.
May Jehovah give strength to His people. / May Jehovah bless His people with peace.
A Psalm; a Song for the [xref]a[/xref]Dedication of the House. [xref]b[/xref]Of David
I extol You, O Jehovah, for You have drawn me up / And have not let my enemies rejoice over me.
O Jehovah my God, / I cried out to You, / And You healed me.
O Jehovah, You have brought up my soul from Sheol; / You have preserved me alive [note]1[/note]that I would not go down into the pit.
verse.note: Some MSS read, from among those who go down.

verse.text: Sing psalms to Jehovah, you [i]who are[/i] His faithful ones; / And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]praise His holy [note]2[/note]memorial.
verse.note: Or, give thanks. So throughout this psalm.
I.e., name.

verse.text: For His anger [i]lasts but[/i] a moment, / His favor, a lifetime; / Weeping may linger in the evening, / But a ringing shout [i]goes up[/i] in the morning.
As for me, I said in my prosperity, / I will never be shaken.
O Jehovah, by Your favor You had made my [note]1[/note]mountain stand strong. / You hid Your face; I was troubled.
verse.note: Referring to David's kingdom.

verse.text: To You, O Jehovah, I called out; / And to [note]1[/note]Jehovah I made my supplication.
verse.note: Some MSS read, the Lord.

verse.text: What profit is there in my blood if I go down into the pit? / Will the dust [xref]a[/xref]praise You? Will it declare Your [note]1[/note]faithfulness?
verse.note: Or, truth.

verse.text: Hear, O Jehovah, and be gracious to me. / O Jehovah, be my help.
You have turned for me my mourning into [xref]a[/xref]dancing; / You have loosened my sackcloth / And girded me with rejoicing,
That [i]my[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory might sing psalms to You and not be silent. / O Jehovah my God, I will praise You forever.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 2[/link].

verse.text: To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[xref]a[/xref]In You, O Jehovah, do I [xref]b[/xref]take refuge; / Never let me be put to shame. / [note]1[/note]Rescue me in Your righteousness.
verse.note: In this psalm David speaks of God's saving him from his distress. However, God's salvation for the New Testament believers is not mainly from their distress. In His salvation God sustains and strengthens His believers in their distresses that they may live and magnify Christ ([link]Phil. 1:19-21a[/link]).

verse.text: Incline Your ear to me; / Deliver me speedily. / Be to me a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rock of protection, / A fortress, to save me.
verse.note: In David's consideration God was a rock for his personal protection, but the Lord Jesus said that He is a rock for the building of the church ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]).

verse.text: For You are my crag and my fortress; / Therefore for Your name's sake / Lead me and guide me.
Bring me out of the net / That they have secretly laid for me, / For You are my protection.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Into Your hand I commit my spirit; / Redeem me, O Jehovah, God of truth.
verse.note: This word was spoken by the Lord Jesus at the end of His crucifixion ([link]Luke 23:46[/link]; cf. [link]John 19:30[/link]).

verse.text: I hate those who regard [note]1[/note]vanities of falsehood, / But I trust in Jehovah.
verse.note: I.e., vain idols.

verse.text: I will exult and rejoice in Your lovingkindness, / Since You have seen my affliction; / You know the distress of my soul.
And You have not delivered me into the hand of the enemy; / You have made my feet stand in a place broad and free.
Be gracious to me, O Jehovah, for I am in [note]1[/note]distress. / My eye is wasted away with grief, / [i]Indeed[/i] my soul and body.
verse.note: David's distress included his grief ([link]v. 9[/link]), sorrow ([link]v. 10[/link]), and the reproach ([link]v. 11[/link]) of his opposers. The believers today who follow the Lord also suffer much distress, including persecution ([link]2 Cor. 6:4-5[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 3:12[/link]). In the New Testament, however, the apostle Paul did not complain about his distress (cf. [link]Col. 1:24[/link]). Rather, he said that all things worked together for his good that he, as one of God's many sons, could be conformed to the image of the firstborn Son of God ([link]Rom. 8:28-29[/link]).

verse.text: For my life has been consumed in [xref]a[/xref]sorrow, / And my years, in sighing. / My strength fails because of my iniquity, / And my bones have wasted away.
Because of all my adversaries, / I have become a reproach, / And especially so to my neighbors, / And something dreaded to my acquaintances; / Those who see me on the street flee from me.
I am forgotten, like a dead man out of mind; / I am like a destroyed vessel.
For I hear the [xref]a[/xref]slander of many; / Terror is on every side. / When they take [xref]b[/xref]counsel together against me, / They scheme to take my life.
But I [xref]a[/xref]trust in You, O Jehovah; / I say, You are my God.
My [xref]a[/xref]times are in Your hand; / Deliver me from the hand of my enemies and from those who pursue me.
Cause Your face to [xref]a[/xref]shine upon Your servant; / Save me in Your lovingkindness.
O Jehovah, do not let me be put to shame when I call out to You; / Let the wicked be put to shame; let them be silent in Sheol.
Let the lips of falsehood be made dumb, / Which speak arrogantly against the righteous / With pride and contempt.
How great is Your goodness, / Which You have stored up for those who fear You, / Which You have accomplished in the sight of the sons of men / For those who [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in You!
You hide them in the [xref]a[/xref]hiding place of Your presence / Apart from the conspiracies of men; / You lay them away secretly in a shelter / Apart from the contention of tongues.
Blessed be Jehovah, / For He displayed His lovingkindness wondrously / To me in a fortified city.
I, on my part, had said in my alarm, / I am cut off before Your eyes; / But instead You heard / The voice of my supplications / When I cried out to You.
[xref]a[/xref]Love Jehovah, all [i]you who are[/i] His faithful ones; / Jehovah guards the trustworthy, / And recompenses abundantly / Him who acts haughtily.
Be strong, and let your heart be encouraged, / All you who [note]1[/note]hope in Jehovah.
verse.note: Or, wait on.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A [note]1[/note]Maschil
verse.note: The meaning of this term is uncertain. Some understand a meditative poem; others, a poem of instruction.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed is he whose transgression is [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]forgiven; / Whose sin is [xref]c[/xref]covered.
verse.note: Or, Happy. So also in [link]v. 2[/link].

God's forgiving our sins and not imputing iniquity to us are based on Christ's redemption ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]). Apart from Christ's redemption the righteous God cannot forgive our sins ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]).

verse.text: Blessed is the man to whom / Jehovah does not impute iniquity / And in whose spirit there is no deceit.
When I kept silent, my bones wasted away / Through my groaning all day long.
For day and night Your [xref]a[/xref]hand / Was heavy upon me; / My life [xref]b[/xref]sap was dried up / [i]As[/i] in the drought of summer. Selah
I [xref]a[/xref]acknowledged my sin to You, / And I did not cover my iniquity. / I said, I will confess my transgressions to Jehovah. / Then You [xref]b[/xref]forgave the iniquity of my sin. Selah
Because of this let everyone who is faithful / Pray to You at a time when You may be found; / Surely when great waters overflow, / They will not reach him.
You are my [xref]a[/xref]hiding place; / You preserve me from trouble; / You surround me with the ringing shouts of deliverance. Selah
I will instruct you and teach you concerning the way you should go; / I will counsel [i]you;[/i] my eye is upon you.
Do not be like a horse [i]or[/i] like a mule, without understanding; / Whose trappings consist of [xref]a[/xref]bit and bridle to restrain [i]them,[/i] / Else they do not come near you.
Many are the sorrows that the wicked have; / But he who trusts in Jehovah is encompassed by lovingkindness.
Rejoice in Jehovah and exult, O [note]1[/note]righteous ones; / And give a ringing shout, all you who are [note]1[/note]upright in heart.
verse.note: In the beginning of this psalm David confessed his sins ([link]vv. 1-5[/link]), but at the end he justified himself as righteous and upright in heart. In reality, apart from Christ no one is righteous and upright in heart ([link]Rom. 3:10[/link]; [link]Jer. 17:9[/link]). David's writing here is that of a person who tried to keep the law apart from Christ. In His economy God does not want us to endeavor to keep the law. He wants us to live Christ, the God-man, that He may be magnified ([link]Phil. 1:19-21a[/link]). To live Christ in order to magnify Him is to enjoy Him.

verse.text: Rejoice in Jehovah, O righteous ones. / Praise is becoming to the upright.
Give thanks to Jehovah with the lyre; / With the harp of ten strings sing psalms to Him.
Sing Him a [xref]a[/xref]new song; / Play skillfully with a joyous shout.
For the word of Jehovah is right, / And all His work is [i]done[/i] in faithfulness.
He loves righteousness and justice; / The earth is [xref]a[/xref]full of the lovingkindness of Jehovah.
By the [xref]a[/xref]word of Jehovah the heavens were made, / And all their host, by the breath of His mouth.
He gathers the water of the [xref]a[/xref]sea like a [xref]b[/xref]heap; / He puts the deep [i]waters[/i] into storage places.
Let all the earth fear Jehovah; / Let all the inhabitants of the world stand in awe of Him.
For He [xref]a[/xref]spoke, and it was; / He [xref]b[/xref]commanded, and it stood.
Jehovah brings the [xref]a[/xref]counsel of the nations to nothing; / He frustrates the intentions of the peoples.
The [xref]a[/xref]counsel of Jehovah stands forever; / The intentions of His heart [i]stand[/i] from generation to generation.
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed is the nation whose God is Jehovah, / The people whom He has [xref]b[/xref]chosen as His own possession.
Jehovah looks from heaven; / He sees all the sons of men.
From the site of His habitation He gazes / At all the inhabitants of the earth,
He who fashions the hearts of them all, / He who discerns all their works.
No king is saved by a great army; / A mighty man is not delivered by great strength.
A horse is a vain thing for salvation, / And it cannot deliver by its great power.
Behold, the [xref]a[/xref]eye of Jehovah is upon those who fear Him, / Upon those who [note]1[/note]hope in His lovingkindness,
verse.note: Or, wait for. So also in [link]v. 22[/link].

verse.text: To [xref]a[/xref]deliver their soul from death / And to preserve them alive in famine.
Our soul waits on Jehovah; / He is our help and our shield;
For in Him our heart rejoices, / Because in His holy name we trust.
May Your lovingkindness, O Jehovah, be upon us, / Even as we have hoped in You.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David, when he [xref]b[/xref]disguised his sanity before [note]1[/note]Abimelech, who drove him out, and he departed
verse.note: Probably a title referring to the kings of Philistia, as [i]Pharaoh[/i] referred to the kings of Egypt.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I will [note]2[/note]bless Jehovah at all times; / His praise will continually be in my mouth.
verse.note: This psalm is one of the alphabetical, or acrostic, psalms. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 9[/link].
To bless God is to speak well of Him, praising Him with adoration. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].

verse.text: My soul makes its boast in Jehovah; / The lowly hear and they rejoice.
[xref]a[/xref]Magnify Jehovah with me, / And let us exalt His name together.
I sought Jehovah, and He answered me; / And He delivered me from all that terrified me.
They looked to Him and were radiant; / And their faces will never be abashed.
This poor man called out, and Jehovah heard; / And He [note]1[/note]saved him out of all his troubles.
verse.note: Here David gave God the credit for delivering him from Abimelech (Achish the king of Gath — [link]1 Sam. 21:10[/link]). Actually, David delivered himself in a dishonorable way by disguising himself as being insane ([link]1 Sam. 21:10-22:1a[/link]).

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]angel of Jehovah [xref]b[/xref]encamps / Around those who fear Him, and He delivers them.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Taste and see that Jehovah is good; / [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Blessed is the man who takes refuge in Him.
verse.note: God with His goodness can be tasted by us ([link]1 Pet. 2:3[/link] and note 1). We taste and see that God is good in His house, that is, in Christ, in the church, and eventually in the New Jerusalem. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 25[/link].
Or, Happy.

verse.text: Fear Jehovah, you [i]who are[/i] His saints; / For there is no lack with those who fear Him.
The young lions hunger and starve, / But those who seek Jehovah will not lack any good thing.
Come, children; hear me. / I will teach you the fear of Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]Who is the man who desires life, / Who loves having days in order to see good?
Guard your [xref]a[/xref]tongue from evil, / And your lips from speaking deceit.
[xref]a[/xref]Turn away from evil and do good; / Seek peace and pursue it.
The eyes of Jehovah [i]are set[/i] toward the righteous, / And His ears, toward their cry.
The face of Jehovah is against those who do evil, / To cut off the memory of them from the earth.
[i]The righteous[/i] cry out, and Jehovah hears; / And He saves them out of all their troubles.
Jehovah is near to those who are broken in heart, / And He saves those who are [xref]a[/xref]contrite in spirit.
Many are the troubles of the righteous man, / But Jehovah delivers him from all of them.
He keeps all his [xref]a[/xref]bones; / [note]1[/note]Not one of them is broken.
verse.note: Here, in describing his own suffering, David typified the suffering Christ ([link]John 19:33[/link], [link]36[/link]; cf. [link]Exo. 12:46[/link]). See note [link]36[sup]2[/sup] in John 19[/link].

verse.text: Evil will slay the wicked, / And those who hate the righteous man will be condemned.
Jehovah redeems the soul of His servants, / And none who [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in Him will be condemned.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note]Strive, O Jehovah, with those who strive with me; / [note]1[/note]Battle against those who battle against me.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link]. In the New Testament economy, a spiritual person would never ask God to fight against his enemies as David asked in this psalm.

verse.text: Take hold of buckler and shield, / And rise up as my help.
Draw out also the spear, and close up [i]the way[/i] / Against those who pursue me; / Say to my soul, / I am your salvation.
[xref]a[/xref]Let those who seek my life / Be put to shame and humiliated; / Let those who devise evil for me / Be turned back and confounded.
Let them be like chaff before the wind, / With the [xref]a[/xref]angel of Jehovah driving [i]them[/i] on.
Let their way be darkness and slipperiness itself, / With the angel of Jehovah pursuing them.
For without cause they hid their net for me; / Without cause they dug a pit for me.
Let [xref]a[/xref]destruction come upon him unawares, / And let his net, which he hid, catch him; / Let him fall into it, into destruction.
Then my soul will exult in Jehovah; / It will rejoice in His salvation.
All my bones will say, / Jehovah, who is like You, / Who delivers the poor from him who is too strong for him, / And the poor and needy from him who robs him?
Malicious [xref]a[/xref]witnesses rise up; / They ask me about things I know nothing of.
They repay me evil for good; / I am bereaved in soul.
But I, when they were sick, / [i]Had[/i] sackcloth as my clothing; / I afflicted my soul with fasting, / And my prayer [xref]a[/xref]returned to my own bosom.
I conducted myself as if it had been my friend or my brother; / Like one mourning for [i]his[/i] mother, I bowed down gloomily.
But at my stumbling they rejoice and gather together; / The attackers, whom I did not know / Gather together against me; / They tear [i]at me[/i] and do not cease.
As profane mocking parasites, / They [xref]a[/xref]gnash their teeth at me.
O Lord, how long will You look on? / Rescue my soul from their destruction, / My [note]1[/note]precious life from the lions.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 22[/link].

verse.text: I will give You thanks in the great congregation; / Among a mighty people I will praise You.
Do not let those who are wrongly my enemies rejoice over me; / Do not let those who [xref]a[/xref]hate me without cause narrow their eyes [i]at me.[/i]
For they do not speak [xref]a[/xref]peace, / But devise words of deceit / Against the quiet people of the land.
And they open their mouth wide against me; / They say, Aha! Aha! Our eyes have seen [i]it.[/i]
You have seen, O Jehovah; do not be silent. / O Lord, do not be far from me.
Awake, and stir Yourself for my cause, / For my claim, O my God and my Lord.
Vindicate me according to Your righteousness, O Jehovah my God; / And do not let them rejoice over me.
Do not let them say in their heart, / [xref]a[/xref]Aha! [note]1[/note]That is what we wanted. / Do not let them say, We have swallowed him up.
verse.note: Lit., Our desire!

verse.text: May those who rejoice at my trouble / Be ashamed and confounded together; / May those who magnify themselves against me / Be clothed with shame and humiliation.

May those who delight [i]in the vindication of[/i] my righteousness / Give a ringing shout and rejoice, / And may they say continually, / Jehovah be [xref]a[/xref]magnified, / Who delights in the well-being of His servant.
And my tongue will declare Your righteousness / [i]And[/i] Your praise all day long.
To the choir director. Of the servant of Jehovah; [xref]a[/xref]of David
Transgression speaks to the wicked / Within [note]1[/note]his heart; / [xref]a[/xref]There is no [xref]b[/xref]dread of God / Before his eyes.
verse.note: Some MSS read, my.

verse.text: For he flatters himself in his own eyes, / That his iniquity cannot be found out [i]and[/i] hated.
The words of his mouth are wickedness and deceit; / He has ceased being wise [i]and[/i] doing good.
He plans wickedness on his bed; / He sets himself on a way that is not good; / He does not reject evil.
[note]1[/note]O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]Your lovingkindness is in the heavens; / Your faithfulness [i]reaches[/i] unto the skies.
verse.note: [link]Verses 5-10[/link] are David's praising of God for His lovingkindness, faithfulness, and righteousness mixed with the enjoyment of God in His house. However, such praising followed David's accusing of the wicked ([link]vv. 1-4[/link]), showing again the mixture of the human concept and the divine concept in the Psalms (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], pars. 2 and 3, in Psa. 1[/link]).

verse.text: Your righteousness is like the mountains of God; / Your judgments are [i]like[/i] the great deep; / You preserve man and beast, O Jehovah.
How precious is Your lovingkindness, O God! / Thus the sons of men take [xref]a[/xref]refuge in the shadow of Your [xref]b[/xref]wings.
They are saturated with the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fatness of Your [note]2[/note]house, / And You cause them to drink of the [xref]b[/xref]river of Your pleasures.
verse.note: Figuratively, [i]fatness[/i] means abundance; specifically, the word refers to the (fatty) ashes of sacrifices (Strong). Thus, the fatness of God's house comes from the sacrifices, the offerings, all of which typify the all-inclusive Christ ([link]Heb. 10:5-10[/link]). The fatness of God's house, therefore, refers to the riches of Christ ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]). The fatty ashes of the offerings are the signs of Christ's accomplishment through His death (cf. notes [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 4[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 6[/link]).[br][br][link]Verses 8-9[/link] reveal the Divine Trinity in His divine dispensing as the enjoyment of God's people in His house. The fatness refers to Christ, the Son; the river of the divine pleasures, to the Spirit as the river of water of life ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:1[/link]); and the fountain of life and light ([link]v. 9[/link]), to the Father as the source of life and light ([link]John 1:4[/link]; [link]1 John 1:5[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:23[/link]; [link]22:1-2[/link], [link]5[/link]). These verses indicate that even in the dispensation of law, before the dispensation of grace in the New Testament age, the seeking saints enjoyed the Triune God in His dwelling place on earth. They indicate further that the entire Bible was written according to the controlling vision that the Triune God is working Himself into His chosen and redeemed people to be their life and life supply in order to saturate their entire being with the Divine Trinity, that is, with the Father as the fountain, the Son as the fatness, and the Spirit as the river.

The house of God here refers to the temple in the Old Testament, which typifies the church as the Body of Christ in the New Testament (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in John 14[/link]). Ultimately, the house of God will consummate in the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link], [link]22[/link]). In the proper church life we enjoy Christ as the fatness, the Spirit as the river, and the Father as the fountain of life and light ([link]v. 9[/link]). This enjoyment leads us ultimately to the enjoyment of the tree of life, the river of water of life, and the light of life in the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 22:1-2[/link], [link]5[/link]).

verse.text: For with You is the [xref]a[/xref]fountain of [xref]b[/xref]life; / In Your [xref]c[/xref]light we see light.
Continue Your lovingkindness to those who know You, / And Your righteousness to those who are upright in heart.
Do not let the foot of the arrogant come upon me, / Nor let the hand of the wicked drive me away.
There the workers of iniquity are fallen; / They are cast down and unable to rise.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note]Do not be incensed because of evildoers; / Do not be envious of wrongdoers.
verse.note: This psalm is one of the alphabetic, or acrostic, psalms. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 9[/link]. It reveals David's sentiment in his logic concerning God's dealing with the righteous and with the wicked based on the principle of law-keeping, which belongs to the tree of the knowledge of good and evil (see note [link]9[sup]3[/sup] in Gen. 2[/link]).

verse.text: For they soon [xref]a[/xref]wither like grass / And fade away like green herbage.
Trust in Jehovah, and do good; / Dwell in the land, and feed on [i]His[/i] faithfulness.
Delight yourself in Jehovah, / And He will give you the requests of your heart.
[xref]a[/xref]Commit your way to Jehovah, / And trust in Him; and He will act.
And He will cause your righteousness to go forth like [xref]a[/xref]light, / And your justness like noonday.
Be still before Jehovah, and wait for Him; / Do not be incensed because of him who enjoys prosperity on his way, / Because of the man who performs [i]his[/i] evil schemes.
Cease from [xref]a[/xref]anger and forsake wrath; / Do not be incensed; it [i]leads[/i] only to evil.
For the evildoers will be cut off; / But those who wait on Jehovah, / They will [xref]a[/xref]inherit the land.
And in a little while longer there will be no wicked man; / Indeed, you will look diligently for his place, and he will not be [i]there.[/i]
But the [xref]a[/xref]lowly will inherit the land / And delight themselves in the abundance of peace.
The wicked man makes evil schemes against the righteous man / And [xref]a[/xref]gnashes his teeth at him.
The Lord will laugh at him, / For He sees that his day will come.
The wicked have drawn out the sword / And bent their bow, / To cast the poor and the needy down, / To slaughter those who are upright in [i]their[/i] way.
Their sword will enter their own heart, / And their bows will be broken.
Better is the [xref]a[/xref]little that the righteous man has / Than the abundance of many wicked.
For the arms of the wicked will be broken, / But Jehovah upholds the righteous.
Jehovah knows the days of the perfect, / And their inheritance will be forever.
They will not be put to shame in a time of evil, / And in the days of famine they will be satisfied.
But the wicked will perish, / And the enemies of Jehovah will be like the glory of the pastures: / They are consumed; in smoke they are consumed.
The wicked borrow but do not repay, / But the righteous is gracious and gives.
For those [xref]a[/xref]blessed by Him will [xref]b[/xref]inherit the land, / But those cursed by Him will be cut off.
A man's [xref]a[/xref]steps are established by Jehovah, / And He delights in his way.
If he falls, he is not utterly cast down; / For Jehovah upholds him by the hand.
I was [i]once[/i] a young man; now I am old. / Yet I have not seen the righteous man forsaken, / Nor his seed seeking bread.
He is always gracious and [xref]a[/xref]lends, / And his seed becomes a blessing.
[xref]a[/xref]Turn away from evil and do good, / And abide forever.
For Jehovah loves justice / And does not abandon His faithful ones; / They are kept forever; / But the seed of the wicked is cut off.
The righteous will inherit the land, / And they will abide in it forever.
The mouth of the righteous utters wisdom, / And his tongue speaks justice.
The law of his God is in his heart; / His steps do not slip.
The wicked man watches for the righteous man / And seeks to slay him.
Jehovah does not leave him in his hand, / Nor let him be condemned when he is judged.
Wait for Jehovah, / And keep His way; / And He will exalt you to inherit the land; / When the wicked are cut off, you will see it.
I have seen the wicked man terrorizing, / And spreading himself like a luxuriant native tree.
Then someone passes by, and behold, he is not there; / I search for him, and he is not found.
Observe the perfect man, and watch the upright man; / For there is a future for the man of [xref]a[/xref]peace.
But the transgressors will be altogether destroyed; / The future of the wicked will be cut off.
And the salvation of the righteous is from Jehovah; / He is their stronghold in a time of distress.
And Jehovah helps them and rescues them; / He rescues them from the wicked, / And saves them, for they [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in Him.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David, for remembrance
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]O Jehovah, do not rebuke me in Your indignation, / Nor chasten me in Your burning wrath.
verse.note: David's prayer in [link]Psa. 37[/link], in which he said that the righteous would inherit the land ([link]37:29[/link]) and the wicked would be cut off ([link]37:34[/link]), was according to his natural logic, but his prayer in this psalm, in which he was compelled by God's chastising ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]3[/link]) to groan before God ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]), to confess his sin ([link]v. 3[/link]), and to declare his iniquity ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]18[/link]), was according to God's revelation. Cf. note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 7[/link].

verse.text: For Your arrows have sunk deep in me, / And Your hand has come down heavy upon me.
There is no soundness in my flesh due to Your indignation; / There is no wholeness in my bones due to my sin.
For my iniquities have passed over my head; / Like a heavy burden, they are too heavy for me.
My wounds are odious and festering / Due to my foolishness.
I am bent down and bowed utterly; / I go about all day long mourning.
For my loins are filled with burning, / And there is no soundness in my flesh.
I am benumbed and crushed utterly; / I cry out due to the [note]1[/note]groaning of my heart.
verse.note: [i]Groaning[/i] here indicates that the psalmist had an inward burden to pray, but he did not know what to say. Hence, all he could do was groan. See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 8[/link].

verse.text: O Lord, all my desire is before You, / And my groaning is not hidden from You.
My heart throbs; my strength fails me; / And as for the light of my eyes, neither is it with me.
Those who love me and [i]those who are[/i] my friends stand aloof from my plague, / And my relatives stand [xref]a[/xref]far away.
And those who seek my soul lay traps [i]for me,[/i] / And those who pursue my misfortune speak of destruction, / And they contemplate deceit all day long.
But I, like a deaf man, cannot hear; / And [i]I am[/i] like a dumb man, who cannot open his [xref]a[/xref]mouth.
Indeed I am like a man who does not hear / And in whose mouth there are no reproofs.
For in You, O Jehovah, do I hope; / You will respond, O Lord my God.
For I said, May they never rejoice over me! / When my foot slips, they magnify themselves over me.
For I am ready to stumble, / And my pain is before me continually.
For I declare my iniquity; / I am anxious because of my sin.
But my enemies are vigorous; they are strong; / And those who wrongly hate me are many.
Those also who repay evil for good / Are my adversaries because I pursue what is good.
Do not abandon me, O Jehovah; / O my God, do not be far away from me.
Hasten to help me, / O Lord, my [xref]a[/xref]salvation.
To the choir director, to Jeduthun. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
I said, I will keep my ways, / So that I do not sin with my [xref]a[/xref]tongue; / I will keep a muzzle on my mouth / When the wicked are before me.
I was dumb and silent; / I held my peace, [i]even[/i] from good; / And my pain was stirred up.
My heart was hot within me; / While I mused, the fire burned; / I spoke with my tongue:
O Jehovah, cause me to know my end, / And the measure of my [xref]a[/xref]days, what it is. / May I know how transient I am.

Behold, You have made my [xref]a[/xref]days as [i]mere[/i] handbreadths, / And my lifetime is as nothing before You; / Surely every man [note]1[/note]at his best is altogether [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]vanity. Selah
verse.note: Lit., standing firm.

Or, a (mere) breath. So also in [link]v. 11[/link]. In this psalm David was brought by the Lord to realize that he was nothing and vanity. Our realizing that our condition is sinful ([link]Psa. 38[/link]) and our situation is one of vanity opens the way for Christ to crucify us and enter into us to replace us by living Himself through us and causing us to live together with Him in an organic union, as expressed by Paul in [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]. This is the divine concept of God according to the divine revelation of the New Testament.

verse.text: Surely man goes about as a semblance; / Surely they bustle about in vain: / He [xref]a[/xref]heaps up [i]riches[/i] yet knows not / [xref]b[/xref]Who will gather them.
And now what am I waiting for, O Lord? / My hope — it is in You.
Deliver me from all my transgressions; / Do not make me the fool's reproach.
I was [xref]a[/xref]dumb; I did not open my mouth; / For You have done [i]this.[/i]
Remove Your plague from me; / By the hostility of Your hand I am consumed.
With rebukes You chasten a man because of iniquity, / And cause what is desirous to him to disappear like a moth. / Surely every man is [xref]a[/xref]vanity. Selah
Hear my prayer, O Jehovah; / And give ear to my cry; / Do not hold Your peace at my tears. / For I am a stranger with You, / A sojourner, as all my fathers were.
Look away from me, that I may be cheerful, / Before I go away and am no more.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
I waited patiently on Jehovah, / And He inclined to me / And heard my cry.
Then He brought me up out of a pit of destruction, / Out of the miry clay; / And He set my feet upon a rock, / Establishing my steps.
Then He put a [xref]a[/xref]new song in my mouth, / A praise to our God. / Many see it and fear, / And they trust in Jehovah.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed is the man / Who makes Jehovah his trust / And does not turn to the proud / Or to those who turn aside after deception.
verse.note: Or, Happy.

verse.text: Many, O Jehovah my God, are the wonderful deeds which You have done / And Your [xref]a[/xref]thoughts toward us; / They cannot be set in order unto You. / Were I to declare and speak of them, / They would be too numerous to recount.

[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]You do not delight in [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sacrifice and [note]2[/note]offering; / You have [note]3[/note]prepared [xref]c[/xref]ears for Me; / You do not require burnt offering and sin offering.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 6-8[/link] is actually the word of Christ, as quoted by Paul in [link]Heb. 10:5-7[/link]. The prophecy in [link]vv. 6-8[/link] is one of the greatest revelations concerning the all-inclusive Christ in the commission that God committed to Christ in His first coming through incarnation, which was to put away the animal sacrifices of the old covenant and to establish Himself, in His body, as the sacrifice of the new covenant (see notes [link book="Heb." chapter="10"]7[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link]). This is to terminate God's Old Testament economy and to initiate God's New Testament economy, in which Christ replaces all the offerings as well as all things, all matters, and all persons (cf. [link]Matt. 17:4-8[/link]; [link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]; [link]3:10-11[/link]).[br][br]The prophecy in [link]vv. 6-8[/link] concerning Christ is the goal and destination of the revelation of Christ in [link]Psa. 2[/link], [link book="Psa."]8[/link], [link book="Psa."]16[/link], and [link book="Psa."]22-24[/link]. In this prophecy Christ comes through His incarnation to terminate God's old economy and initiate God's new economy, His New Testament economy, by replacing the animal sacrifices and establishing Himself as the unique sacrifice of the new covenant. As such a sacrifice, Christ is the factor that enacts God's New Testament economy ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]) that He may be its centrality and universality for the producing and building up of the church as His organic Body, which will consummate in the New Jerusalem. Hence, Christ has changed the age for the consummating of God's new creation out of God's old creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:15[/link]). His changing of the age is greater than the creation of the universe mentioned in [link]Gen. 1[/link].

A sacrifice is for sin and sins before God, and an offering is for fellowship with God. These two things were the elements upon which the old covenant was established, and the old covenant was the centrality and universality of God's economy in the Old Testament. God's not delighting in and not requiring sacrifice and offering points to the termination of His economy in the Old Testament. This is the importance and the greatness of this prophecy.

Lit., bored my ears. This was quoted by the apostle Paul in [link]Heb. 10:5[/link] as "a body You have prepared for Me." The boring of the slave's ears indicates that the master required the slave's obedience ([link]Exo. 21:6[/link]). It signifies that God required obedience of Christ, who in His humanity was God's slave ([link]Phil. 2:7[/link]). This obedience, spoken of by Paul in [link]Phil. 2:8[/link], was for Him to do the will of God by being the sacrifice and the offering in His crucifixion in the flesh, the body ([link]Col. 1:22[/link]; [link]Heb. 10:7-10[/link]). Based on this, Paul interpreted the boring of the ears as the preparing of a body, in which Christ offered Himself to God as the sacrifice and the offering to replace the sacrifice and the offering of animals in the Old Testament.

verse.text: Then I said, / Behold, I have [note]1[/note]come; / In the [note]2[/note]scroll of the book / It is written concerning Me.
verse.note: Indicating Christ's first coming through His incarnation for the establishing of the new testament (covenant) by Himself as the enacting sacrifice and offering ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]).

The mentioning of the scroll indicates that Christ would do God's will for the accomplishing of God's New Testament economy according to the Old Testament prophecies concerning Him ([link]Luke 24:27[/link], [link]44[/link], [link]46[/link]; [link]John 5:39[/link], [link]46[/link]).

verse.text: I delight in doing Your will, O My God; / Indeed Your law is within My [xref]a[/xref]inward parts.
I bear tidings of righteousness / In the great [xref]a[/xref]congregation. / Behold, I will not withhold My lips; / O Jehovah, You know.

I have not hidden Your righteousness / Within My heart; / I have declared Your faithfulness and Your salvation; / I have not concealed Your lovingkindness and Your truth from the great / congregation.
You, O Jehovah, do not withhold / Your compassions from me; / May Your lovingkindness and Your truth / Preserve me continually.
For evils encompass me until they cannot be counted; / My iniquities have so overtaken me / That I cannot see; / They are more numerous than the hairs of my head; / Thus my heart fails me.
[xref]a[/xref]Be pleased, O Jehovah, to deliver me; / O Jehovah, hasten to help me.
[xref]a[/xref]May those who seek my life to destroy it / Be put to shame and confounded together; / May those who take delight in my misfortune / Be turned back and humiliated.
May those who say to me, [xref]a[/xref]Aha! Aha! / Be desolate because of their shame.
May all those who seek You / Be glad and rejoice in You; / May those who love Your salvation say continually, / May Jehovah be [xref]a[/xref]magnified!
But I am poor and needy; / May the Lord think about me. / You are my help and my Deliverer; / O my God, do not delay.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
Blessed is he who considers the [xref]a[/xref]poor; / In the day of evil Jehovah will deliver him.
May Jehovah keep him and preserve him alive; / May he be [note]1[/note]blessed in the land; / And do not give him over to the desire of his enemies.
verse.note: Or, happy.

verse.text: Jehovah will sustain him on [i]his[/i] sickbed; / You make all his bed in his illness.
I said, O Jehovah, be gracious to me; / Heal my soul, for I have sinned against You.
My enemies speak evil against me: / When will he die and his name perish?
And if he comes to see [i]me,[/i] he speaks falsehood. / His heart gathers iniquity to itself; / When he goes out, he speaks [i]it.[/i]
All who hate me whisper together against me; / Against me they devise my misfortune.
[note]1[/note]Some evil illness, [i]they say,[/i] has been poured out on him; / And when he lies down, he will not rise again.
verse.note: Lit., A thing of Belial.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Even my familiar [xref]a[/xref]friend, in whom I trusted, / [xref]b[/xref]Who [xref]c[/xref]ate my bread, has lifted [i]his[/i] heel against me.
verse.note: This verse, quoted by the Lord Jesus in [link]John 13:18[/link], is a prophecy concerning Judas Iscariot, who betrayed the Lord ([link]John 6:70-71[/link]; [link]13:18[/link], [link]23-27[/link]; [link]Luke 22:21-22[/link]).

verse.text: But You, O Jehovah, be gracious to me and raise me up / That I may [note]1[/note]recompense them.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: By this I know that You delight in me, / That my enemy has not shouted in triumph over me.
And as for me, You uphold me in my [note]1[/note]integrity, / And You set me in Your presence forever.
verse.note: God upholds us not in our integrity but in His own mercy and compassions. See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 18[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Blessed be Jehovah the God of Israel, / From eternity to eternity. / [xref]b[/xref]Amen and Amen.
To the choir director. A [note]1[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of the sons of [xref]b[/xref]Korah
verse.note: See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]As the [xref]a[/xref]hart pants / After the [xref]b[/xref]streams of water, / So my soul [note]2[/note]pants / For You, O [note]3[/note]God.
verse.note: The psalms in Book One were written mainly by David. Eight psalms in Book Two ([link]Psa. 42-49[/link]), as well as [link]Psa. 84[/link], [link book="Psa."]85[/link], [link book="Psa."]87[/link], and [link book="Psa."]88[/link] in Book Three, were composed by the sons of Korah, who was the leader of a rebellion against Moses and God ([link]Num. 16:1-3[/link]). About 470 years after Korah's rebellion, Samuel the prophet, Heman the singer, and some other psalmists came forth as Korah the rebel's descendants at the time of David ([link]1 Chron. 6:31-37[/link]). The descendants of Korah continued to serve during the time of the captivity. Even the descendants of a leading rebel could become the godly writers of psalms, praising God in their holy writings as a record that has existed for generations. What a grace this was!

In this psalm the psalmist was panting and thirsting ([link]v. 2[/link]) for God at a time when he and his people had been stripped and defeated by the neighboring nations and were in captivity (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Panting and thirsting for God are different from worshipping God in a formal, religious way. God is our living water for us to drink ([link]John 4:10[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]7:37-39a[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]). We need to pant and thirst for Him and to drink Him.

[link]Psalm 1[/link], the opening word of Book One, begins with the law, but Book Two begins with God. Surely there is no comparison between God and the law. This shows us that Book Two of the Psalms is higher than Book One. Among the five books of the Psalms, the revelation is progressive. The Psalms are like a stairway of five steps that takes us higher in its revelation in a progressive way.[br][br]In Book One the psalmists were turned from the law to Christ, and Christ brought them to the enjoyment of God in His house and in His city. Book Two begins with the direct enjoyment of God and unveils the psalmists' intensified enjoyment of God in His house, and even more in His city, through the suffering, exalted, and reigning Christ. Such a Christ is the way for sinners to enter into God ([link]John 14:6[/link], [link]20[/link]). God's house is both Christ as God's tabernacle and God's temple ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:19-21[/link]) and the church as the enlargement of Christ, the enlarged temple ([link]1 Cor. 3:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:21[/link]). Jerusalem, the city of God that surrounded the temple, signifies God's kingdom. Both Christ and the church are the temple of God and the kingdom of God ([link]Luke 17:21[/link] and note 1; [link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link] and note [link]19[sup]2[/sup][/link]; [link]Rom. 14:17[/link] and note 1). The New Jerusalem will be the consummation of God's temple and God's kingdom ([link]Rev. 21:22[/link] and note 1; [link]22:1[/link], [link]3[/link]).

verse.text: My soul [xref]a[/xref]thirsts for God, / For the living God. / When will I come and [xref]b[/xref]appear / Before God?
My tears have been my food / Day and night, / While they say to me all day long, / Where is your God?

These things I [note]1[/note]remember, / And I pour out my soul within me: / That I passed through with the throng; / I led them to the [xref]a[/xref]house of God / With the voice of a joyous shout and [note]2[/note]praise, / The [xref]b[/xref]festal multitude.
verse.note: On the one hand, the psalmist was panting after God ([link]v. 1[/link]). On the other hand, he was recalling the glorious and pleasant past in his leading of the festal multitude to enjoy God in His house with His people. Actually, this recalling was a departure from his panting after God. He should have remained in the state of panting after God. We should not allow our considerations and our remembering of our past to distract us from our present enjoyment of God (cf. [link]Phil. 3:13-14[/link] and note [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link]).
Or, thanksgiving.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Why are you cast down, O my soul? / And [i]why[/i] are you disquieted within me? / Hope in God, for I will yet [note]1[/note]praise Him / [i]For[/i] the salvation of His [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]countenance.
verse.note: Or, thank. So also in [link]v. 11[/link]; [link]43:4[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]44:8[/link].

Although the psalmist was in captivity ([link]v. 6[/link] and note) and was under his adversaries' reproaching and oppression ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]9b-10[/link]), he enjoyed God's countenance, God's presence.

verse.text: O my God, my soul is cast down within me; / Therefore I [note]1[/note]remember You / From the land of the Jordan and the [xref]a[/xref]Hermons, / From Mount Mizar.
verse.note: Here the psalmist remembered God from a place quite far from Zion and Jerusalem, indicating that he was in captivity in a far away country.

verse.text: Deep calls unto deep / At the sound of Your [i]water[/i] spouts; / All Your [xref]a[/xref]waves and Your billows / Pass over me.
By day Jehovah commands / His lovingkindness, / And by [xref]a[/xref]night His song is with me, / A prayer to the God of my life.
I say to God my [xref]a[/xref]rock, / Why have You forgotten me? / Why do I go mourning / Because of the oppression of the enemy?
As with a shattering in my bones, / My adversaries reproach me, / While they say to me all day long, / Where is your God?
[xref]a[/xref]Why are you cast down, O my soul? / And why are you disquieted within me? / Hope in God, for I will yet praise Him, / The [xref]b[/xref]salvation of my countenance and my God.
[note]1[/note]Render judgment for me, O God; / And plead my cause / Before an unfaithful nation; / From the deceitful and unjust man / Deliver me.
verse.note: Or, Judge me. [link]Psalms 42[/link] and [link book="Psa."]43[/link] were probably composed as one psalm originally.

verse.text: For You are the God of my protection. / Why have You rejected me? / Why do I go about mourning / Because of the oppression of the enemy?
Send forth Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]light and Your [xref]b[/xref]truth; / They will lead me; / They will bring me to Your [xref]c[/xref]holy mountain / And to Your [xref]d[/xref]tabernacles.
verse.note: Light and truth (reality) are not separate things but are two aspects of one thing. Truth is the shining of light, and light is the source of truth ([link]1 John 1:5-6[/link] and note [link]6[sup]6[/sup][/link], final par.). When the light shines on us, we receive the truth, the reality, and when we go to God in fellowship, we are in the light. According to this verse the divine light and the divine truth lead God's captive saints to God's holy mountain and His tabernacles, which typify the local churches. Both light and truth are in the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]).

verse.text: And I will go to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]altar of God, / To God my exceeding joy; / And I will praise You with the harp, / O God, my God.
verse.note: The psalmists who wrote [link]Psa. 42-44[/link] were lovers of God in their captivity ([link]42:6[/link]). They were panting for God, thirsting for God ([link]42:1-2[/link]), and desiring to return to Jerusalem, to go to Mount Zion to reach the altar. Then they could enter into the temple to meet God their exceeding joy. This is why they prayed that God would give them the light and the truth ([link]v. 3[/link]) that they might know how to be released from their captivity and return to God's dwelling place.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Why are you cast down, O my soul? / And why are you disquieted within me? / Hope in God, for I will yet praise Him, / The salvation of my countenance and my God.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A [note]1[/note]Maschil
verse.note: See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]O God, we have heard with our ears; / Our fathers have recounted it to us, / The [xref]a[/xref]work You did in their days, / In the days of old.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1-8[/link] the psalmists were treasuring their forefathers' past history, and in [link]vv. 9-26[/link] they were sighing for their present situation. Both were distractions from their panting and thirsting for God ([link]42:1-2[/link]), i.e., from their enjoying God. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 42[/link].

verse.text: You, by Your hand, / Have [xref]a[/xref]dispossessed nations, but You have [xref]b[/xref]planted [note]1[/note]our fathers; / You afflicted peoples, but You spread [note]1[/note]our fathers forth.
verse.note: Lit., them.

verse.text: For they did not possess the land by their sword, / Nor did their arm save them; / Rather [i]it was[/i] Your [xref]a[/xref]right hand and Your arm, / And the light of Your [xref]b[/xref]countenance; / For You delighted in them.
You are my [xref]a[/xref]King, O God; / Command salvation for Jacob.
Through You we thrust back our adversaries; / Through Your name we trample those who rise up against us.
For I will not trust in my bow, / Nor will my sword save me.
But You save us from our adversaries, / And You put to shame those who hate us.
In God we [xref]a[/xref]boast all day long, / And we praise Your name forever. Selah
[note]1[/note]Nevertheless You have rejected [i]us[/i] and humiliated us, / And You have not gone forth with our armies.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: You have caused us to turn back from the adversary, / And those who hate us take spoil for themselves.
You have given us over like [xref]a[/xref]sheep to be eaten / And have [xref]b[/xref]scattered us among the nations.
You have [xref]a[/xref]sold Your people for nothing / And have not gone high on their price.
You have made us a reproach to our neighbors, / A mocking and a derision to those around us.
You have made us a [xref]a[/xref]proverb among the nations, / Something to shake the head at among the peoples.
All day long my humiliation is before me, / And the shame of my face covers me,
Because of the voice of him who reproaches and reviles, / Because of the presence of the enemy and of him who avenges himself.
All this has come upon us; but we have [note]1[/note]not forgotten You, / Nor have we been false to Your covenant.
verse.note: According to [link]Jer. 2:13[/link]; [link]11:10[/link]; and [link]Hosea 6:7[/link], the psalmist's word in [link book="Psa." chapter="44"]vv. 17-18[/link] was contrary to God's word spoken through the prophets (cf. [link]Dan. 9:13-19[/link]).

verse.text: Our heart has not turned back, / Nor have our steps deviated from Your way;
But You have crushed us in the place of jackals / And have covered us with the shadow of death.
If we have forgotten the name of our God / Or spread out our hands to a strange god,
Will God not search this out? / For He [xref]a[/xref]knows the hidden things of the heart.
But [xref]a[/xref]for Your sake we are slain all day long; / We are considered as [xref]b[/xref]sheep for slaughter.
Awake! Why are You sleeping, O [note]1[/note]Lord? / Arise! Do not reject [i]us[/i] forever.
verse.note: Many MSS read, Jehovah.

verse.text: Why do You hide Your face / [i]And[/i] forget our affliction and our oppression?
For our soul bows down to the dust; / Our body clings to the earth.
Rise up; be our help, / And redeem us for Your lovingkindness' sake.
To the choir director: according to [note]1[/note]Shoshannim. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A [note]2[/note]Maschil; a song of [note]3[/note]love
verse.note: Meaning [i]lilies;[/i] it may refer to a melody common at that time.
See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

The Hebrew word is feminine, indicating that the love here is that between a male and a female. According to [link]S.S. 1:14-15[/link], Christ is our Beloved, and we are His love. The subject of this psalm is love, and the melody is called "lilies." Here both love and lilies refer to the saints, the lovers of the Lord Jesus. A lily denotes a pure, simple, single life of trusting in God ([link]Matt. 6:28[/link]). This psalm portrays a life of purity and simplicity with an affectionate love for the Lord.

verse.text: My heart [xref]a[/xref]overflows with a good matter; / I speak what I have composed concerning the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]King. / My [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]tongue is the pen of a ready writer.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 45[/link] is a praise to Christ the King, who is typified by Solomon.
