The first section, [link]vv. 1-8[/link], is a praise concerning the King Himself, the second section, [link]vv. 9-15[/link], is a praise concerning the queen, the King's wife, and the third section, [link]vv. 16-17[/link], is a praise concerning the King's sons, the princes.[br][br][link]Verses 1-8[/link] are the praise of Christ the King from four directions: His fairness ([link]v. 2[/link]), His victory ([link]vv. 3-5[/link]), His kingdom ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]), and His virtues ([link]v. 8[/link]). In this praise there are two balanced pairs: Christ's fairness and His victory, and Christ's kingdom and His virtues. Christ's fairness is balanced by His victory with its requirements (cf. [link]Matt. 5:20[/link]; [link]25:14-30[/link]; [link]John 15:2[/link], [link]6[/link]), and His kingdom, the issue of His victory, is balanced by the sweetness of His virtues.
If we have an affectionate love for the Lord Jesus, our tongue will be the pen of a ready writer, ready to write our love and our praise.

verse.text: You are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fairer than the sons of men; / [xref]b[/xref]Grace is poured upon Your lips; / Therefore God has [xref]c[/xref]blessed You forever.
verse.note: The Lord Jesus comes to us first in the aspect of His fairness, to attract us to Himself. Our love for Him is the issue of His showing us His fairness and of our enjoying Him in His fairness.

verse.text: Gird Your sword upon Your thigh, O mighty One, / [i]In[/i] Your [note]1[/note]majesty and Your [note]1[/note]splendor.
verse.note: Both Christ's majesty and His splendor are signs of His victory. Christ, the mighty One, has overcome all His enemies and has gained the victory ([link]Eph. 4:8[/link]; [link]Rev. 5:5[/link]). Splendor is the expression of glory. While Christ was on earth, He showed His splendor only once, when He was transfigured on the mountain ([link]Matt. 17:1-2[/link]). After His resurrection and ascension, He showed Himself in His splendor and majesty to Paul ([link]Acts 26:13-15[/link]) and to John ([link]Rev. 1:9-20[/link]). In His second coming Christ will shine over the earth to illumine it with the splendor of His glory ([link]Rev. 18:1[/link]).

verse.text: And in Your splendor ride on [note]1[/note]victoriously / Because of truth and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]meekness and righteousness; / And let Your right hand [note]3[/note]teach You [note]4[/note]awesome deeds.
verse.note: Regardless of the situation on earth, Christ is riding on triumphantly, prosperously ([link]Acts 5:31[/link]). From the day of His ascension He began to ride on, and He will continue to ride until He comes back in victory ([link]Rev. 19:11-16[/link]).
Or, the meekness of righteousness.
Here [i]teach You[/i] should be understood to mean [i]perform for You.[/i]
Christ's awesome deeds include His crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension. Everything Christ does, whether great or small, is awesome.

verse.text: Your arrows are sharp: / The peoples fall under You; / [i]The arrows[/i] are in the heart of the King's enemies.
[xref]a[/xref]Your [xref]b[/xref]throne, O [note]1[/note]God, is forever and ever; / The [note]2[/note]scepter of uprightness is the scepter of Your [note]3[/note]kingdom.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Heb. 1[/link].
The scepter signifies authority. Uprightness in this verse and righteousness in [link]v. 7[/link] are related to authority ([link]89:14a[/link]).
Christ's kingdom is the issue of His victory ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]; [link]7:13-14[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:11-20:6[/link]).

verse.text: You have loved righteousness and hated wickedness; / Therefore God, [note]1[/note]Your God, has [xref]a[/xref]anointed You / With the [note]2[/note]oil of gladness above Your [note]2[/note]companions.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Heb. 1[/link].

The oil of gladness signifies the compound, consummated Spirit of God ([link]Exo. 30:23-25[/link] and note [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link]), and the companions signify the believers of Christ (see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 1[/link]). Christ's authority, throne, scepter, and all else related to the kingdom are under the anointing of the Spirit, indicating that Christ's authority and kingdom are altogether a spiritual matter ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]; see notes [link book="Luke" chapter="17"]20[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 17[/link]). He has been anointed for the purpose of the kingdom.

verse.text: All Your [note]1[/note]garments [i]smell[/i] of [xref]a[/xref]myrrh and aloes, of cassia; / From [note]2[/note]palaces of ivory, harpstrings have made You glad.
verse.note: Garments here signify Christ's virtues, which are the expression of the divine attributes ([link]Isa. 6:1[/link] and note 2); myrrh and aloes signify the sweetness of Christ's death ([link]John 19:39-40[/link]); and cassia signifies the fragrance and repelling power of Christ's resurrection (see note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 30[/link]). All Christ's virtues are filled with the savor, the sweet fragrance, of His death and resurrection.

Palaces here signify the local churches; ivory, a bone-like substance, signifies the unbroken resurrection life of Christ ([link]John 19:36[/link] and note 2); and harpstrings signify sweet, melodious praises. The local churches, which are beautiful in the eyes of the Lord and which are His expression, are built with the resurrection life of Christ, and from the local churches come the praises that make Him glad. Christ's garments, His virtues, have produced the church as His expression (cf. [link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]), and both His garments and the church are full of sweetness.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]The [note]2[/note]daughters of kings are among Your most prized; / The [note]3[/note]queen stands at Your right hand in the [note]4[/note]gold of Ophir.
verse.note: [link]Verses 9-15[/link] praise Christ the King in praising the queen with the daughters of kings and with the virgins ([link]v. 14[/link]).

The daughters of kings signify the believers of Christ in their royalty, and the king's most prized (or, honorable, glorious) women signify the believers of Christ in their honor and majesty. As those born of the King, we, the believers, have a royal and honorable status. Our conducting ourselves according to that status is a glory to Christ ([link]Eph. 4:1[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 1:11-12[/link]).

Signifying the church, especially the overcomers, as the unique wife of Christ. In [link]Rev. 19:7[/link] and [link]9a[/link], the wife of the Lamb is a corporate bride composed of the overcoming believers invited to the marriage dinner of the Lamb (see notes [link book="Rev." chapter="19"]7[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link] there). Likewise, in this psalm the queen does not signify an individual; rather, she signifies a corporate entity composed of all her companions: the daughters of kings as the honorable women and the virgins as her friends ([link]v. 14[/link]). Thus, in this psalm Solomon the king with his many wives and concubines, who were princesses, daughters of Gentile kings ([link]1 Kings 11:1[/link], [link]3[/link]), are used in a positive sense to typify Christ as the King with His corporate wife, the church ([link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:24-25[/link], [link]31-32[/link]), composed of His believers from every tribe, tongue, people, and nation ([link]Rev. 5:9[/link]).[br][br]In [link]v. 8[/link] the church is typified by the ivory palaces, the building, and in this verse the church is pictured as the queen, the wife. In the entire Scriptures these two figures — the building and the bride — are used to signify the church (cf. [link]Gen. 2:22[/link] and notes). On the one hand, the church is the building, the house, of God ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]), and on the other hand it is the bride, the wife, of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]).

The queen's being covered with gold signifies the church's appearing in the divine nature. The "gold" that covers the church is Christ, the divine One, as the believers' righteousness for their justification ([link]Luke 15:22[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). This is the first layer of the church's covering.

verse.text: Hear, O [note]1[/note]daughter, and see; and incline your ear; / And [xref]a[/xref]forget your people and your father's house;
verse.note: The daughter is the queen, who signifies the church; her people and her father's house signify the natural relationships of the church. This word corresponds to the Lord's word regarding denying the natural relationships in [link]Matt. 10:37[/link] and [link]Luke 14:26[/link].

verse.text: Thus the King will desire your [note]1[/note]beauty. / Because He is your [note]2[/note]Lord, / Worship Him.
verse.note: The queen's beauty signifies the virtues of Christ expressed through the church. This psalm praises Christ not only concerning the things that are of Him directly but also concerning the things that are of Him indirectly as manifested through His church and His overcomers. Our speaking well of the church and the believers is also a praise to Christ.

In [link]v. 1[/link] Christ is the King, in [link]v. 2[/link] He is a man, in [link]v. 6[/link] He is God, and in this verse He is the Lord. As the Lord of the church, Christ is worthy not only of the church's love but also of her worship.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]daughter of Tyre [i]will come[/i] with a gift; / The [note]1[/note]rich among the people will entreat your favor.
verse.note: The daughter of Tyre signifies the people of the flourishing world. The rich among the people signify the high class, who have great wealth but do not have God's favor (cf. [link]1 Cor. 1:26-28[/link]). The favor they entreat of the queen signifies the grace of God enjoyed by the church. As indicated by this verse, the rich will come to the church to obtain the grace of God.

verse.text: The king's [note]1[/note]daughter is all glorious within [i]the royal abode;[/i] / Her [xref]a[/xref]garment is a [note]2[/note]woven work inwrought with gold.
verse.note: The king's daughter is the queen, signifying the church, and her being all glorious within the royal abode signifies the glorious church ([link]Eph. 5:27[/link]), which takes Christ as her royal abode. First we, the believers of Christ, take Christ as our abode, and then we become His abode ([link]John 15:4[/link]; [link]14:3[/link], [link]20[/link], [link]23[/link]).

Signifying the Christ who has been dealt with through many sufferings and through death and resurrection to become the righteousness of the church to meet the righteous requirement of God that the church may be justified before God ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). Thus, the woven work inwrought with gold refers again to the first layer of covering — Christ as our righteousness, through whom we are justified — signified by the gold of Ophir in [link]v. 9[/link] (see note [link]9[sup]4[/sup][/link]). Cf. note [link]39[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 28[/link].

verse.text: She will be led to the King in [note]1[/note]embroidered [i]clothing;[/i] / The [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]virgins behind her, her [note]2[/note]companions, / Will be brought to You.
verse.note: Another garment, the second layer of her covering, signifying that the church will be led to Christ the King clothed with the righteousnesses of the saints to meet the requirement of Christ for their marriage ([link]Rev. 19:8[/link] and note 2; [link]Matt. 22:11-12[/link] and note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link]). The queen in this psalm has two garments. The first garment, "the gold of Ophir" ([link]v. 9[/link]), the woven work inwrought with gold ([link]v. 13[/link]), corresponds to Christ as our objective righteousness, which is for our justification. The second garment, the embroidered clothing, corresponds to Christ "embroidered" into us by the transforming work of the Spirit and lived out of us as our subjective righteousnesses, which are for our victory. The first garment is put upon us that we may stand in the presence of God ([link]Luke 15:22[/link]), whereas the second garment is woven into our character, embroidered into our being, that we may stand before the King.
Signifying the overcoming saints, who will be invited to the marriage dinner of Christ ([link]Rev. 19:9[/link]).

verse.text: They will be led with rejoicing and exultation; / They will [xref]a[/xref]enter the King's [note]1[/note]palace.
verse.note: Signifying that the overcoming saints will enter the New Jerusalem, Christ's palace ([link]Rev. 3:12[/link]), with rejoicing and exultation. This psalm mentions first the abode ([link]v. 13[/link]) and then the palace. When Christ becomes our abode, we become His abode — a mutual abode ([link]John 15:4[/link]). Because Christ is the King and we are the queen, eventually this mutual abode becomes the palace, signified by the New Jerusalem, which is actually the Triune God wrought into the believers and mingled with them to be one entity, the mutual dwelling of God and His redeemed for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link], [link]22[/link] and note [link]22[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: In the place of Your [note]1[/note]fathers will be Your [note]1[/note]sons; / You will make them [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]princes in all the earth.
verse.note: Verses [link]16[/link] and [link]17[/link] praise Christ the King in praising His sons. Here [i]fathers[/i] signifies Christ's forefathers in the flesh, [i]sons[/i] signifies the overcomers of Christ as His descendants, and [i]princes[/i] signifies the overcomers of Christ as His co-kings, who will reign with Christ over the nations ([link]Rev. 2:26[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]).[br][br]This psalm presents a complete view, a full picture, of Christ's beauty, which is in Christ Himself ([link]vv. 1-8[/link]), as unveiled in the four Gospels; in the church, His wife ([link]vv. 9-15[/link]), as revealed in the Epistles; and in all His sons, the overcomers as the princes ([link]vv. 16-17[/link]), as seen in Revelation.

verse.text: I will cause Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]name to be remembered in all generations; / Therefore the peoples will praise You forever and ever.
verse.note: Christ's name will be remembered in all generations through the overcoming saints, and Christ will be praised by the nations through His overcoming and co-reigning saints.

verse.text: To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. According to [note]1[/note]alamoth. A Song
verse.note: Perhaps referring to soprano voices.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]God is our [xref]a[/xref]refuge and strength; / A help in distress, He is most readily found.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 46-48[/link] praise God in His greatness, particularly in His city, Jerusalem. These psalms reveal how God dwells in the church as His city, His habitation, to be enjoyed by the saints, that in Christ He may be King over all the earth.

verse.text: Therefore we will not fear, / Though the earth change, / And the [xref]a[/xref]mountains slip into the heart of the seas;
Though the waters of the sea roar [i]and[/i] foam; / Though the mountains shake at its swelling. Selah
There is a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]river whose streams gladden the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]city of God, / The holy place of the [xref]c[/xref]tabernacles of the Most High.
verse.note: Signifying the flowing of the Triune God in Christ through the Spirit as life to His people ([link]Rev. 22:1[/link] and notes 2 and 3).

The king in [link]Psa. 45[/link] typifies Christ as the King; the city in this psalm, and often in the Bible as a whole, signifies a kingdom. As the King, Christ needs a city in which to rule and reign. The city of God is the enlarged, strengthened, and built-up church as the ruling center for God's reign in His kingdom. The church as the house of God ([link]23:6[/link]; [link]26:8[/link]; [link]27:4[/link]; [link]36:8[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]) must be enlarged to become the church as the city, the kingdom, of God ([link]Rev. 5:9-10[/link]). Eventually, in God's economy the house of God becomes the holy city, New Jerusalem, as God's eternal habitation and the ruling center of His eternal kingdom ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]22:3[/link]).

verse.text: God is in the [xref]a[/xref]midst of her; she will [note]1[/note]not be moved; / God helps her at the dawn of the morning.
verse.note: The city, which cannot be moved, is the unshakable kingdom ([link]Heb. 12:28[/link]), which is Christ Himself with His enlargement, His increase ([link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link], [link]44[/link], and note [link]35[sup]3[/sup][/link], par. 2).

verse.text: The nations rage; the kingdoms are moved. / He utters His voice; the earth melts.
Jehovah of hosts is with us; / The God of Jacob is our [xref]a[/xref]high retreat. Selah
Come, see the works of Jehovah, / How He has made desolations on earth.
He makes [xref]a[/xref]wars cease unto the end of the earth; / He breaks the bow and cuts the spear to pieces; / He burns the war wagons with fire.
[note]1[/note]Be [xref]a[/xref]still and know that I am God. / I will be exalted among the nations; I will be exalted on earth.
verse.note: This word spoken by God to the raging nations ([link]v. 6a[/link]; [link]2:1-2[/link]) is a prophecy indicating that when the church is enlarged, strengthened, and built up to be a city as God's kingdom (cf. [link]Matt. 16:18[/link]), God will have the ground to deal with the nations and possess the entire earth (cf. [link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:11-21[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah of hosts is with us; / The God of Jacob is our high retreat. Selah
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A Psalm
Clap your hands, all you peoples; / Shout to God with the voice of a triumphant sound.
For Jehovah Most High is awesome: / A great [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]King over all the earth.
verse.note: When the church is enlarged as a city (cf. [link]Rev. 21:22[/link] and note 1), in which we enjoy God as our everything ([link]Psa. 46[/link]), God will subdue the peoples and the nations through the city and rule over all the earth in Christ as the great King (see note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 46[/link]).

verse.text: He subdues peoples under us, / And nations under our [xref]a[/xref]feet.
He chose our inheritance for us, / The excellency of Jacob, whom He loved. Selah
God ascends amidst shouting; / Jehovah, at the sound of a trumpet.
Sing psalms to God, sing psalms; / Sing psalms to our [xref]a[/xref]King, sing psalms.
For God is the King of all the earth; / Sing psalms with [xref]a[/xref]understanding.
God reigns over the nations; / God [xref]a[/xref]sits upon His holy throne.
The princes of the peoples have been gathered / As the people of the God of Abraham; / For the shields of the earth belong to God; / He is greatly exalted.
A Song; a [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of the sons of Korah
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Great is Jehovah, / And much to be praised / In the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]city of our God, / In His [xref]c[/xref]holy [note]2[/note]mountain.
verse.note: This psalm is the climax of the revelation concerning the city of God. Only in the city, signifying the strong and enlarged church, can God be great and much to be praised (cf. [link]Eph. 3:20-21[/link]).
Here [i]His holy mountain[/i] is in apposition to [i]city of our God,[/i] indicating that the mountain is the city. Both the mountain and the city signify the kingdom of God.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Beautiful in elevation, / The joy of the whole earth, / Is Mount [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zion, the [xref]c[/xref]sides of the north, / The [xref]d[/xref]city of the great King.
verse.note: Zion was the city of King David ([link]2 Sam. 5:7[/link]), the center of the city of Jerusalem, where the temple as God's dwelling place on earth was built ([link]9:11[/link]; [link]74:2[/link]; [link]76:2b[/link]; [link]135:21[/link]; [link]Isa. 8:18[/link]). Zion within Jerusalem typifies the body of overcomers, the perfected and matured God-men, within the church as the heavenly Jerusalem ([link]Heb. 12:22[/link]; [link]Rev. 14:1-5[/link]). As the highlight and beauty of the holy city Jerusalem ([link]v. 2[/link]; [link]50:2[/link]), Zion typifies the overcomers as the high peak, the center, the uplifting, the strengthening, the enriching, the beauty, and the reality of the church ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]11-12[/link]; [link]20:2[/link]; [link]53:6a[/link]; [link]87:2[/link]). The overcomers as Zion are the reality of the Body of Christ and consummate the building up of the Body in the local churches to bring in the consummated holy city, New Jerusalem, the Holy of Holies as God's dwelling place, in eternity ([link]Rev. 21:1-3[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]22[/link]). In the new heaven and new earth the entire New Jerusalem will become Zion, with all the believers as overcomers ([link]Rev. 21:7[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: God has made Himself known / In her [note]1[/note]palaces as a [xref]a[/xref]high retreat.
verse.note: The city signifies the universal church as God's kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]), and the palaces within the city signify the local churches. God is known in all the local churches of the universal church.

verse.text: For, behold, the kings have assembled themselves; / They passed by together.
They saw; therefore they were astounded. / They were dismayed; they hurried off in alarm.
Trembling seized them there; / Writhing, like that of a woman in labor;
With an east wind You shattered / The ships of Tarshish.
As we have heard, / So we have seen / In the city of Jehovah of hosts, / In the city of our God. / God will [xref]a[/xref]establish her forever. Selah
We consider, O God, Your lovingkindness / In the midst of Your temple.
As Your [xref]a[/xref]name is, O God, / So is Your praise / Unto the ends of the earth; / Your right hand is full of righteousness.
Let Mount [xref]a[/xref]Zion [xref]b[/xref]rejoice; / Let the daughters of Judah exult / Because of Your judgments.
Walk about [xref]a[/xref]Zion, and go around her; / Count her [note]1[/note]towers.
verse.note: Towers and bulwarks ([link]v. 13[/link]) are for fighting the enemies to protect the city, and palaces ([link]v. 13[/link]) are for the king's dwelling. All these indicate the functions of the church ([link]Eph. 6:10-20[/link]; [link]2:20-22[/link]).

verse.text: Consider carefully her [xref]a[/xref]bulwarks; / Pass between her palaces; / That you may recount it to the [xref]b[/xref]generation following.
For this God is our God forever and ever. / He will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]guide us [i]even[/i] unto death.
verse.note: In the enjoyment of God in the city, God is our refuge ([link]46:1[/link]), our retreat ([link]46:7[/link]), and our guide. This enjoyment of God is through Christ, in Christ, and with Christ, and it is experienced in the universal church as the Body of Christ and in the local churches as the expressions of the Body.[br][br]The Psalms indicate that we first need to experience Christ. Then Christ will lead us to the local church to enjoy God ([link]23:6[/link]). When the church as the house of God is enlarged and strengthened, it becomes the city — the kingdom for God's ruling and reigning ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]). In the church as the house we enjoy God in the aspect of His dwelling. In the church as the city we enjoy God in the aspect of His ruling and reigning.

verse.text: To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A Psalm
[note]1[/note]Hear this, all you peoples; / Give ear, all you inhabitants of the world,
verse.note: [link]Psalms 49-51[/link] cover three categories of persons in relation to the enjoyment of God in Christ. The first category ([link]Psa. 49[/link]) consists of those who trust in their wealth (i.e., in anything other than Christ). In the second category ([link]Psa. 50[/link]) are those who call upon the Lord according to His covenant. The third category ([link]Psa. 51[/link]) is a single person, King David, who repented, confessed his sins to God, and asked God for His purging. Those in the first category have no share in the enjoyment of God in Christ; those in the second category participate in the enjoyment of God; and the one in the third category has a full portion of the enjoyment of God in Christ.

verse.text: Both low and high, / Rich and poor together;
My mouth will speak wisdom, / And the [note]1[/note]meditation of my heart will be that of understanding.
verse.note: Or, utterance.

verse.text: I will incline my ear to a parable; / I will disclose my riddle upon the harp.
Why should I fear in the days of evil, / When the iniquity of those who supplant me surrounds me,
Those who [xref]a[/xref]trust in their [note]1[/note]wealth / And boast in the multitude of their [note]1[/note]riches?
verse.note: In this age wealth and riches, which are mammon, represent all things other than Christ ([link]Matt. 6:24[/link]). If we trust in such things, we will have no share in the enjoyment of God in Christ in His house, the church, or in His city, the kingdom.

verse.text: None can by any means redeem [i]his[/i] brother / Or give to God [note]1[/note]a ransom for him
verse.note: Or, an expiation.

verse.text: (For the redemption of their [xref]a[/xref]soul is costly / And must be given up forever),
That he would yet [xref]a[/xref]live always / And not see [xref]b[/xref]corruption.
For he will see [i]that[/i] wise men die; / The foolish one and the senseless one perish alike / And [xref]a[/xref]leave their wealth to others.
Their inward thought is that their houses [i]will remain[/i] forever, / That their habitations [i]will remain[/i] from generation to generation; / They call lands after their own names.
But man in honor does not remain; / He is like the beasts that perish.
Such is the way of those who are [note]1[/note]self-confident, / And of those after them who approve of their sayings. Selah
verse.note: Or, foolish; as in [link]v. 10[/link].

verse.text: Like a flock, they are appointed for Sheol; / Death will shepherd them. / [note]1[/note]And straight to the grave they will descend, / And their form will be for Sheol to consume / That there be no abode for them.
verse.note: According to the conjecture of many. The Hebrew text reads, The upright will rule over them in the morning.

verse.text: But God will redeem my soul / From the power of Sheol, / For He will receive me. Selah
Do not fear when a man becomes rich, / When the glory of his house increases.
For when he dies, he will [xref]a[/xref]take nothing; / His glory will not descend after him.
Though he [xref]a[/xref]blessed his soul while he lived — / And [i]men[/i] praise you when you do good for yourself —
[note]1[/note]It will go to the generation of his fathers; / They will never see light.
verse.note: Referring to his soul in [link]v. 18[/link].

verse.text: A man in honor but without understanding / Is like the beasts that perish.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph
The [xref]a[/xref]Mighty One, God Jehovah, / Speaks and summons the earth / From the [xref]b[/xref]rising of the sun to its setting.
Out of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zion, the perfection of [xref]b[/xref]beauty, / God [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]shines forth.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link]. Zion, which typifies the church and will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the universal divine-human incorporation of the consummated Triune God and His redeemed, regenerated, transformed, and glorified tripartite elect, is the perfection of beauty in God's eternal economy (cf. [link]Eph. 2:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:10-21[/link]).
The shining forth of God out of His house is the dispensing of His goodness. Under such a shining, such a dispensing, we enjoy God in Christ. Cf. [link]Num. 6:25[/link] and notes.

verse.text: Our God has come and will not be silent; / [xref]a[/xref]Fire devours before Him, / And around Him it is exceedingly tempestuous.
He calls to the heavens above, / And to the earth that He may [xref]a[/xref]judge His people:
[xref]a[/xref]Gather My saints to Me, / Those who have made a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant with Me by sacrifice.
verse.note: To make a covenant with God by sacrifice is to make a covenant by Christ as our sacrifice ([link]Heb. 10:5[/link], [link]10[/link]) and as the Mediator between us and God ([link]1 Tim. 2:5[/link]).

verse.text: Then the [xref]a[/xref]heavens declare His righteousness, / For God Himself is Judge. Selah
[xref]a[/xref]Hear, O My people, and I will speak; / O Israel, and I will [xref]b[/xref]testify [note]1[/note]against you: / I am God, your God.
verse.note: Or, to.

verse.text: I will not reprove you because of your sacrifices, / And your [xref]a[/xref]burnt offerings are before Me continually.
I will not take a bull from your house / [i]Nor[/i] goats from your folds,
For every animal of the forest is Mine, / The cattle upon a thousand hills.
I know every bird of the mountains, / And I am aware of everything that moves in the field.
If I were hungry, I would not tell you; / For the world is Mine and the [xref]a[/xref]fullness thereof.
Shall I eat the flesh of bulls / Or drink the blood of goats?
[xref]a[/xref]Offer to God a sacrifice of [note]1[/note]thanksgiving, / And repay your [xref]b[/xref]vows to the Most High;
verse.note: This psalm tells us that some of the saints of God were offering burnt offerings and other kinds of offerings ([link]vv. 8-13[/link]), but because they were lacking in affection, they would not offer the sacrifice of thanksgiving to God. Thus, the psalmist, speaking for God, indicated that what God wants is not the burnt offering but the thanksgiving offering. We can offer certain offerings without being touched in our hearts, but when we are thankful to God and offer to Him a prayer of thanksgiving, our hearts are deeply touched and we are filled with affection and tender feeling toward God. This is the kind of offering God desires.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]call upon Me in the day of trouble: / I will deliver you, and you will glorify Me.
verse.note: In the Bible, a book of covenant, God has covenanted Himself to us through the redeeming Christ, typified by the sacrifices ([link]v. 5[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:28[/link]; [link]Luke 22:20[/link]). Now we need to call on the Lord according to this covenant that we may enjoy Him as our portion ([link]116:13[/link] and note). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 49[/link].

verse.text: But to the wicked God says, / What [i]right[/i] do you have to declare My statutes / And take up My covenant in your mouth,
Seeing that you hate correction / And cast My words behind you?
When you see a thief, you take pleasure in him; / And your portion is with adulterers.
You let your mouth loose for evil, / And your tongue frames deceit.
You sit [i]and[/i] speak against your brother; / You defame the son of your mother.
These things you do, and I keep silent; / You think that I am altogether like you. / I will rebuke you and set forth [i]the matter[/i] in order before your eyes.
Consider this then, you who forget God, / Lest I tear [i]you[/i] apart and there be none to deliver [i]you.[/i]
Whoever offers a sacrifice of thanksgiving glorifies Me; / And to him who sets [i]his[/i] way [i]right[/i] I will show the salvation of God.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David, when [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Nathan the prophet came to him, after he had gone in to [xref]c[/xref]Bath-sheba
verse.note: This psalm was composed after David's great sin in murdering Uriah and robbing him of his wife and after he was rebuked by the prophet Nathan ([link]2 Sam. 11:1-12:14[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Be gracious to me, O God, according to Your lovingkindness; / According to the greatness of Your compassions [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]blot out my transgressions.
verse.note: Or, Have mercy on me. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 49[/link].

In [link]vv. 3-5[/link] and [link]17[/link] David repented and confessed his sins to God. The verbs used by David — [i]blot out[/i] ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]9[/link]), [i]wash[/i] ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]7[/link]), [i]cleanse[/i] ([link]v. 2[/link]), and [i]purge[/i] ([link]v. 7[/link]) — indicate that his repentance and confession were thorough and that his asking for forgiveness was genuine.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity, / And from my sin cleanse me.
For I do know my transgressions, / And my sin is before me continually.
Against You [i]and[/i] You alone have I [xref]a[/xref]sinned, / And I have done what is evil in Your sight. / Therefore You are [xref]b[/xref]righteous when You speak; / You are clear when You judge.
Behold, I was [note]1[/note]brought forth in iniquity, / And [xref]a[/xref]in sin did my mother [xref]b[/xref]conceive me.
verse.note: To confess, as David did here, that we were born in sin indicates that we have no trust in ourselves (cf. [link]Rom. 7:18[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:3[/link]). Realizing that we are sinful and God is holy, we trust only in Him. Also, we realize that we need Christ to be our Mediator and our sacrifice (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: Behold, You delight in truth in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]inward parts; / And in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]hidden [i]part[/i] You would make known wisdom to me.
verse.note: The inward parts are the parts of the human soul — the mind, the emotion, and the will. The hidden part is the human spirit, which is hidden within the soul. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 3[/link].

verse.text: Purge [i]my[/i] sin with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]hyssop, and I will be clean; / Wash me, and I will be [xref]b[/xref]whiter than snow.
verse.note: Hyssop typifies Christ in His humble and humiliated human nature ([link]1 Kings 4:33a[/link]; [link]Exo. 12:22a[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:5-8[/link]). Here it implies Christ as the Mediator ([link]1 Tim. 2:5[/link]; [link]1 John 2:1[/link]) and the sacrifice ([link]Heb. 10:5[/link], [link]10[/link]).

verse.text: Let me hear gladness and joy, / That the bones which You have broken may exult.
Hide Your face from my sins, / And [xref]a[/xref]blot out all my iniquities.
Create in me a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]clean heart, O God, / And [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]renew a steadfast spirit within me.
verse.note: Or, pure.
By sinning we become old; but after we are forgiven by God, we can be renewed ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:23[/link]; [link]Titus 3:5[/link]).

verse.text: Do not cast me from Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]presence, / And do not take the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit of Your holiness away from me.
verse.note: God's presence is actually the Spirit of His holiness. If we lose God's presence, we lose everything.

The title [i]the Spirit of holiness[/i] used here and in [link]Isa. 63:10-11[/link] is not the same as [i]the Holy Spirit[/i] used in the New Testament. The Spirit of holiness in the Old Testament is for God to make His people holy by separating them unto Himself. The Holy Spirit at the initiation of the New Testament age was for God's incarnation, in which God in His divine nature was imparted into humanity and mingled with the human nature (without forming a third nature) to produce a God-man who was intrinsically holy ([link]Matt. 1:18[/link]; [link]Luke 1:35[/link]). See notes [link book="Luke" chapter="1"]15[sup]2[/sup][/link], [link]35[sup]2[/sup][/link], and [link]35[sup]3[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].

verse.text: Restore to me the [xref]a[/xref]gladness of Your salvation, / And sustain me with a willing spirit.
I will teach transgressors Your ways, / And sinners will turn back to You.
Deliver me from the guilt of [xref]a[/xref]bloodshed, O God, O God of my salvation; / [i]And[/i] my tongue will ring forth Your righteousness.
O Lord, open my lips, / And my mouth will declare Your praise.
For You do not delight in sacrifice; / Otherwise I would offer it; / You take no pleasure in [xref]a[/xref]burnt offerings.
The sacrifices of God are a broken [xref]a[/xref]spirit; / A broken and a [xref]b[/xref]contrite heart, O God, You will not despise.
Do [note]1[/note]good in Your good pleasure unto [xref]a[/xref]Zion; / [xref]b[/xref]Build the walls of Jerusalem.
verse.note: [link]Verses 18-19[/link] signify the participation in the enjoyment of God in the local church as God's house, God's dwelling, and in the universal church as God's city, God's kingdom, through the all-inclusive Christ as the offerings. If we are those who repent, confess our sins, and ask God for His purging ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]), we will have the enjoyment of God in Christ in His house, the local church, and in His city, the universal church. This enjoyment, as the "good" mentioned here, includes God's building up the church, His filling the church with His glory, and His granting the church His rich presence with Himself as joy, peace, life, light, security, and every spiritual blessing (cf. [link]Eph. 1:3[/link]).

verse.text: Then You will delight in the sacrifices of righteousness, / In burnt offerings and whole burnt offerings; / Then they will offer bulls upon Your altar.
To the choir director. A [note]1[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of David, when [xref]b[/xref]Doeg the Edomite came and told Saul and said to him, David has come to the house of Ahimelech
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Why do you boast in evil, O mighty one? / God's lovingkindness [i]endures[/i] continually.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 52-67[/link] may be considered the pious expressions of the psalmists uttered out of their complex sentiments while enjoying God in His house. On the one hand, the psalmists enjoyed God and His salvation, and on the other hand, they condemned their enemies and asked God to judge and destroy them. In these psalms the sentiments of the psalmists were strong, mixed, and complex.[br][br]The psalms in this section concern humanity in the ethical realm. They speak of being just and upright and holding on to one's integrity. However, these things are not the spirituality revealed in the New Testament. The divine revelation in the Bible is progressive. To properly appreciate the Psalms requires the revelation of God's economy in the New Testament. God's eternal economy is to impart Himself into man and dispense His riches into man's inner being ([link]Eph. 3:8-9[/link], [link]14-19[/link]) that He may be man's life and life supply. By His life and the bountiful supply of His life-giving Spirit ([link]Phil. 1:19b[/link]), man can live Him and magnify Him ([link]Phil. 1:20-21a[/link]) for His manifestation ([link]1 Tim. 3:16a[/link]). In this way, all His chosen people can corporately be His expression as His fullness, His organism, the church ([link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]; [link]3:19-21[/link]). In comparison with the spiritual standard revealed in the New Testament, the spiritual level in these psalms is much inferior. Cf. note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Job 6[/link].

verse.text: Your tongue devises destruction; / [i]It is[/i] like a sharpened razor, O worker of deceit.
You have loved evil rather than good, / Falsehood rather than speaking righteousness. Selah
You have loved all the devouring words, / O deceitful tongue.
God will likewise [note]1[/note]break you down forever; / He will take you and pluck you up from [i]your[/i] tent, / And uproot you from the land of the living. Selah
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1-7[/link] David condemned the evil man, and in [link]vv. 8-9[/link] David spoke concerning his enjoyment of God in His house. Here David's hatred toward his enemy and his praise to God are mixed together. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: And the righteous will see [i]it[/i] and fear, / And they will laugh at him, [i]saying,[/i]
Behold, this is that mighty man / Who did not make God his [note]1[/note]strength, / But [xref]a[/xref]trusted in the multitude of his riches / [i]And[/i] strengthened himself in his desire.
verse.note: Or, refuge.

verse.text: But I, like a flourishing [xref]a[/xref]olive tree / In the house of God, / Trust in God's lovingkindness / Forever and ever.
I will give You thanks forever, / For You have acted; / And I will hope in Your name in the presence of Your faithful ones, / For it is good.
To the choir director: according to [note]1[/note]mahalath. A [note]2[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of David
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is obscure; it may refer to a kind of sad melody.
See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]The [note]1[/note]fool has said in his heart, / There is no God. / They are corrupt and commit abominable deeds; / [xref]b[/xref]There is none who does good.
verse.note: This psalm of instruction refers to a time when David was being attacked by the Gentiles. Thus, the persons spoken of in [link]vv. 1-5[/link] are Gentiles. [link]Verses 1-3[/link] were quoted by Paul in [link]Rom. 3:10-12[/link], referring to all men.

verse.text: God looked down from heaven / Upon the sons of men / To see if there was anyone who had insight, / Who [xref]a[/xref]seeks after God.
[xref]a[/xref]All of them have turned back; / They are together perverse. / There is none who does good; / There is not even one.
Have they no knowledge, the workers of iniquity, / Who eat up my people as they would eat up bread / [i]And[/i] do not call upon God?

There they were in great fear, / Where there was no fear. / For God scattered the [xref]a[/xref]bones / Of him who encamped against you. / You put [i]them[/i] to shame / Because God has rejected them.
Oh that the [note]1[/note]salvation of Israel might come forth from [xref]a[/xref]Zion! / When God [xref]b[/xref]turns the captivity of His people, / Jacob will exult, Israel will rejoice.
verse.note: In David's sentiment this salvation is only for the Jews, not for the Gentiles (cf. [link]Eph. 3:6[/link]).

verse.text: To the choir director: on the stringed instruments. A [note]2[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of David, when the [xref]b[/xref]Ziphites came and said to Saul, David is indeed hiding among us!
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: O God, [note]1[/note]save me by Your name, / And execute judgment for me by Your might.
verse.note: In this psalm, instead of asking God to have mercy on his enemies in His faithfulness, David asked God to annihilate his enemies ([link]v. 5[/link]), while he himself was seeking to participate in the enjoyment of God in His help, sustenance, and salvation ([link]vv. 1-4[/link]). A spiritual person would not pray in such a way. In typifying Christ as the fighting Victor (cf. note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Chron. 22[/link]), David was justified in asking God to annihilate his enemies; but in his spiritual living, it was not right for David to hate his enemies and to ask God to destroy them. This is against the nature of the spiritual life of God's chosen people, and even against God's holy word in the Old Testament in [link]Prov. 25:21-22[/link], quoted by the apostle Paul in [link]Rom. 12:20[/link]. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: O God, hear my prayer; / Give ear to the words of my mouth.
For strangers have risen up against me, / And those who terrorize seek my life; / They do not [xref]a[/xref]set God before them. Selah
Behold, God is my [xref]a[/xref]Helper; / The Lord is among those who sustain my soul.
He will return the evil to those who lie in wait for me. / Annihilate them in Your [note]1[/note]faithfulness.
verse.note: Or, truth.

verse.text: I will offer a freewill offering to You; / I will [note]1[/note]praise Your name, O Jehovah, for it is good.
verse.note: Or, give thanks to.

verse.text: For He has delivered me from all distress, / And my eye looks [i]triumphantly[/i] upon my enemies.
To the choir director: on the stringed instruments. A [note]1[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of David
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Give ear, O God, to my prayer; / And do not hide Yourself from my supplication.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1-2[/link], [link]4-8[/link], [link]16-18a[/link], [link]22[/link], and [link]23b[/link] David sought to experience God's salvation. At the same time, while under the oppression of his enemy, he asked God to deal with his enemy ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]9-15[/link], [link]18b-21[/link], [link]23a[/link]). His request was based not on the principle of mercy and grace but on the principle of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: Give heed to me, and answer me. / I grow restless in my complaint and moan,
Because of the voice of the enemy, / Because of the oppression of the wicked man; / For they [xref]a[/xref]drop iniquity upon me, / And in anger they make me their enemy.
My heart writhes within me, / And the terrors of death have fallen upon me.
Fear and trembling have come upon me, / And shuddering overwhelms me.
And I say, Oh that I had [xref]a[/xref]wings like a dove! / Then I would fly away and be at rest.
Indeed I would wander far away; / I would lodge in the wilderness. Selah
I would hasten my escape / From the storm wind and the tempest.
Confuse, O Lord, divide their tongue; / For I have seen violence and contention in the city.
Day and night they go around it, / Upon its walls; / And iniquity and trouble are in the midst of it.
Utter ruin is in the midst of it, / And oppression and deceit / Do not depart from its streets.
For it is not an enemy who reproaches me; / Otherwise I could bear it. / It is not he who hates me who magnifies himself against me; / Otherwise I could hide myself from him.
But it is you, [note]1[/note]my equal, / My close [xref]a[/xref]friend and my acquaintance.
verse.note: Lit., a man according to my own estimate. In these verses David prophesied concerning Judas' betraying of Christ ([link]41:9[/link]; [link]John 13:18[/link]). David was a type of the suffering Christ (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Kings 2[/link]). In his pious expression of his complex sentiment concerning his suffering of his enemies' oppression, he uttered this prophecy, indicating that Judas' betrayal of Christ was a part of the sufferings of Christ.

verse.text: We were in sweet counsel together; / We walked with the throng in the [xref]a[/xref]house of God.
[note]1[/note]Let death surprise them; / May they go down into Sheol alive. / For evil is in their dwelling, in the midst of them.
verse.note: Others read, Desolations be upon them.

verse.text: As for me, I call out to God, / And Jehovah will save me.
Evening and morning and at noontime / I complain and moan, / And He hears my voice.
He has redeemed my soul in peace / From the battle against me, / For many are they [i]who strive[/i] with me.
God hears and answers them — / Even He who sits [i]enthroned[/i] from of old — Selah / Because with them there is no change, / And they do not fear God.
[note]1[/note]He put forth his hands against those who were at peace with him; / He profaned his covenant.
verse.note: I.e., the betraying friend in [link]v. 13[/link].

verse.text: Smooth were the buttery words of his mouth, / But his heart was war; / More soothing than oil were his words, / But they were [i]in fact[/i] drawn swords.
[xref]a[/xref]Cast your burden upon Jehovah, / And He will sustain you; / He will never allow the righteous to be moved.
But You, O God, will bring them down / Into the pit of decay.[br/]Men of bloodshed and deceit / Will not live out half their days; / But I will trust in You.
To the choir director: according to the [note]1[/note]dove on the distant terebinths. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A [note]2[/note]Michtam, when the [xref]b[/xref]Philistines seized him in Gath
verse.note: Perhaps a reference to a melody common at the time.
See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 16[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Be gracious to me, O God; for man tramples me; / All day long he, fighting, oppresses me.
verse.note: In this psalm David trusted in God and enjoyed God in His delivering him from death and stumbling ([link]vv. 1-4[/link], [link]8-13[/link]). At the same time, he asked God to cast down his enemies ([link]vv. 5-7[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 54[/link].

verse.text: Those who lie in wait for me trample me all day long, / For many are those who arrogantly fight against me.
When I am afraid, / I trust in You.
In God, whose word I praise, / [xref]a[/xref]In God do I trust, and I will not be [xref]b[/xref]afraid. / What can flesh do to me?
All day long they wrest my words; / All their thoughts are against me for evil.
They gather themselves; they lurk; / They [xref]a[/xref]watch my steps, / As they have waited [i]to take[/i] my life.
Will there be deliverance for them in spite of [i]their[/i] iniquity? / In anger cast down the peoples, O God.
You have counted my wanderings. / Put my tears into Your bottle. / Are they not in Your [xref]a[/xref]book?
Then my enemies will turn back / When I call; / This I know, / That God is for me.
In God, [i]whose[/i] word I praise, / In Jehovah, [i]whose[/i] word I praise,
[xref]a[/xref]In God do I trust; I will not be afraid. / What can man do to me?
Your vows, O God, are on me; / I will render thank offerings to You.
[xref]a[/xref]For You have delivered my soul from death, / Indeed, my feet from stumbling, / That I may walk before God / In the [xref]b[/xref]light of the living.
To the choir director: [note]1[/note]Do not destroy. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A [note]2[/note]Michtam, when he fled from Saul, in the [xref]b[/xref]cave
verse.note: According to the Masoretic text. Others understand a reference to a melody common at the time beginning with the word [i]Destroy,[/i] referring to the enemies of the nation.
See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 16[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Be gracious to me, O God, be gracious to me; / For my soul [xref]a[/xref]takes refuge in You; / Indeed in the shadow of Your [xref]b[/xref]wings I will take refuge, / Until the destruction passes by.
verse.note: In this psalm David trusted in God and enjoyed God in His salvation, lovingkindness, and faithfulness ([link]vv. 1-5[/link], [link]7-11[/link]). At the same time, he rejoiced at the misfortune of his enemies ([link]v. 6b[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 54[/link].[br][br]While we are trusting in God and enjoying His care according to His lovingkindness and faithfulness, we need to learn the lessons of God's discipline. We need to find out the reason for the oppositions against us in our environment, for they are God's discipline to correct us, to break us, and to bring us down for our eventual transformation in life ([link]Heb. 12:5-11[/link] and notes [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:12-19[/link] and note [link]17[sup]1[/sup][/link]). We should not pray that God would put others down; we are the ones who need to be brought down and broken by God. We should not have the shortage, displayed in many of the psalms, of being devoid of learning the lessons of God's discipline. Cf. note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Job 2[/link].

verse.text: I call out to God the [xref]a[/xref]Most High, / To the God who accomplishes [i]all things[/i] for me.
He sends forth from heaven and saves me; / He reproaches him who would trample me; Selah / God sends forth / His lovingkindness and His [note]1[/note]faithfulness.
verse.note: Or, truth. So also in [link]v. 10[/link].

verse.text: My soul is among lions; / I lie down among those who blaze forth, the sons of men, / Whose teeth are spears and arrows, / And whose tongue is a sharp sword.
[xref]a[/xref]Be exalted above the heavens, O God; / Let Your glory be above all the earth.
They have prepared a net for my steps; / My soul is bowed down. / They have dug a pit before me; / They have fallen into it [i]themselves.[/i] Selah
My heart is steadfast, O God; / [xref]a[/xref]My heart is steadfast. / I will sing, indeed I will sing psalms.
Awake, my [xref]a[/xref]glory; / Awake, O harp and lyre! / I will awaken the dawn.
[xref]a[/xref]I will give thanks to You among the peoples, O Lord; / I will sing psalms to You among the nations.
For Your [xref]a[/xref]lovingkindness is as great as the heavens; / And Your faithfulness [i]reaches[/i] unto the skies.
[xref]a[/xref]Be exalted above the heavens, O God; / [i]Let[/i] Your glory be above all the earth.
To the choir director: [note]1[/note]Do not destroy. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A [note]2[/note]Michtam
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 57[/link].
See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 16[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Do you indeed, O [note]2[/note]judges, speak righteousness? / Do you judge in uprightness, O sons of men?
verse.note: In this psalm David first condemned the sons of men ([link]vv. 1-5[/link]) and then prayed for their destruction ([link]vv. 6-11[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 54[/link].
Or, mighty ones; others translate, gods.

verse.text: No, in heart you perform injustice; / You weigh out the violence of your hands on earth.
The wicked are estranged from the womb; / They err from [i]their[/i] birth, speaking lies.
Their venom is like the venom of a serpent; / They are like the deaf cobra that has shut its ear,
Which does not hear the sound of the charmers / [i]Or[/i] the wise spellbinder.
O God, break their teeth in their mouth; / Break off the fangs of the young lions, O Jehovah.
Let them melt like water that runs off. / When he shoots his arrows, / Let them be as though they were cut off.
[i]Let them be[/i] like a snail that melts and goes away, / [i]Like[/i] a woman's miscarriage, which by no means sees the sun.
Before your pots can feel [i]the fire of[/i] the thorns, / Whether green or burning, He will sweep them away.
The righteous man will rejoice when he sees vengeance; / He will wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.
And men will say, Indeed there is fruit for the righteous man; / Indeed there is a God who [xref]a[/xref]judges on earth.
To the choir director: [note]1[/note]Do not destroy. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A [note]2[/note]Michtam, when Saul sent men, and they [xref]b[/xref]watched the house in order to kill him
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 57[/link].
See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 16[/link].

verse.text: Deliver me from my enemies, O my God; / Set me on high, [i]secure[/i] from those who rise up against me.
Deliver me from the workers of iniquity, / And save me from men of bloodshed.
For behold, they lie in wait for my soul; / The strong gather themselves against me. / Not because of any transgression of mine nor because of any sin of / mine, O Jehovah,
Not for any fault [i]of mine,[/i] they run and ready themselves; / Awake to meet me, and see.
Indeed You, O Jehovah, God of hosts, God of Israel, / Arise to punish all the nations; / Have no mercy upon any who treacherously commit iniquity. Selah
They return in the evening; / They growl like a dog / And go around the city.
Behold, they belch forth with their mouth; / Swords are in their lips; / For, Who, [i]they say,[/i] hears?
But You, O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]laugh at them; / You have all the nations in derision.
O [note]1[/note]my strength, I will watch for You; / For God is my [xref]a[/xref]high retreat.
verse.note: Some MSS read, His strength.

verse.text: My God in His lovingkindness will meet me; / God will let me look [i]triumphantly[/i] upon those who lie in wait for me.
Do not slay them, lest my people forget; / Scatter them by Your power, and bring them down, / O Lord our shield.
For the sin of their mouth, / For the word of their lips, / Let them even be taken in their arrogance, / And because of the cursing and the lying that they speak.
Consume [i]them[/i] in wrath; consume [i]them[/i] so that they are no more; / And [i]men[/i] will know that God rules in Jacob / Unto the ends of the earth. Selah
They return in the evening; / They growl like a dog / And go around the city.
They wander about for food; / And if they are not filled, they [note]1[/note]linger.
verse.note: Others read, murmur.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But I will sing of Your strength; / And I will joyfully sing of Your [xref]a[/xref]lovingkindness in the morning. / For You have been my [xref]b[/xref]high retreat / And a [xref]c[/xref]refuge in the day of my distress.
verse.note: David's praise to God in [link]vv. 16-17[/link] is preceded by his accusing and condemning his enemies. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 54[/link].

verse.text: O my strength, unto You I will sing psalms, / For God is my high retreat, / My God of lovingkindness.

To the choir director: according to the [note]1[/note]lily of the testimony. A [note]2[/note]Michtam [xref]a[/xref]of David, for instruction, when he struggled with [xref]b[/xref]Aram-naharaim and with Aram-zobah, and Joab returned and struck twelve thousand of Edom in the Valley of Salt
verse.note: Perhaps a reference to a melody common at the time.
See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 16[/link].

verse.text: O God, You have rejected us; You have broken out upon us; / You have been angry. Restore us.
You have caused the earth to quake; You have split it open. / Heal the breaks in it, for it totters.
You have shown Your people hard things; / You have made us drink wine to stagger [i]us.[/i]
You have given a [xref]a[/xref]banner to those who fear You, / To be displayed because of the truth. Selah
[xref]a[/xref]That Your beloved ones may be delivered, / Save with Your right hand, and answer [note]1[/note]us.
verse.note: Others read, me.

verse.text: God has spoken in His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]holiness: I will exult; / I will divide Shechem / And measure out the Valley of Succoth.
verse.note: Or, holy place.

verse.text: Gilead is Mine, and Manasseh is Mine, / And Ephraim is the helmet for My head; / Judah is My [xref]a[/xref]scepter.
[xref]a[/xref]Moab is My washbowl; / Upon [xref]b[/xref]Edom I will cast My sandal; / Philistia, shout aloud because of Me.
Who will bring me into the besieged city? / Who will lead me to Edom?
Will not You, O God, who [xref]a[/xref]rejected us? / And will You not go forth, O God, with our armies?
Give us help from the adversary, / For a salvation by man is vain.
In God we will do valiantly, / And it is He who will [xref]a[/xref]tread down our adversaries.
To the choir director: on the stringed instruments. [xref]a[/xref]Of David
Hear, O God, my cry; / Give heed to my prayer.
From the end of the earth / I will call out unto You / When my heart faints; / Lead me to the [xref]a[/xref]rock that is higher than I.
For You are a [xref]a[/xref]refuge to me, / A strong tower before the enemy.
Let me sojourn in Your [xref]a[/xref]tent forever; / Let me take [xref]b[/xref]refuge in the covering of Your [xref]c[/xref]wings. Selah
For You, O God, have heard my vows; / You have given [i]me[/i] the inheritance of those who fear Your name.
You will add [xref]a[/xref]days to the days of the king; / May his years be like generation after generation.
May he dwell forever before God; / Appoint lovingkindness and [note]1[/note]faithfulness, that they may preserve him.
verse.note: Or, truth.

verse.text: So I will sing psalms to Your name forever, / As I [note]1[/note]repay my vows day by day.
verse.note: The thought here of repaying God for His lovingkindness and faithfulness ([link]v. 7[/link]) suggests a commercial transaction between the psalmist and God (cf. [link]Matt. 19:27[/link] and note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link]).

verse.text: To the choir director, to Jeduthun. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
My soul waits in silence for God alone; / My salvation is from Him.
He alone is my [xref]a[/xref]rock and my salvation, / My [xref]b[/xref]high retreat; I will not be greatly shaken.
How long will you assail a man / So that you may slay [i]him,[/i] all of you, / Like a leaning wall or a tottering fence?
They only make plans to thrust him down from his dignity; / They take delight in lies; / With their mouth they bless, / But inwardly they curse. Selah
My soul, wait in silence for God alone, / For my expectation is from Him.
He alone is my [xref]a[/xref]rock and my salvation, / My [xref]b[/xref]high retreat; I will not be shaken.
On God my salvation and my glory [i]depend;[/i] / The [xref]a[/xref]rock of my strength, my [xref]b[/xref]refuge, is in God.
Trust in Him at all times, O people; / [xref]a[/xref]Pour out your heart before Him; / God is a [xref]b[/xref]refuge to us. Selah
Men of low degree are but a vapor; / Men of high degree, a lie. / In the balances they go up; / Together they are less than a [xref]a[/xref]vapor.
Do not trust in oppression, / And do not vainly hope in robbery; / If wealth increases, / Do not set [i]your[/i] heart on [i]it.[/i]
Once has God spoken; / Twice have I heard this, / That strength belongs to God.
To You also, O Lord, belongs lovingkindness; / For You [xref]a[/xref]repay every man according to his work.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David, when he was in the [xref]b[/xref]wilderness of Judah
O God, You are my God; I seek You diligently. / My soul [xref]a[/xref]thirsts for You, / My flesh faints in longing for You, / In a dry and weary land without water.
So I have looked upon You in the [xref]a[/xref]sanctuary, / Seeing Your power and Your glory.
Because Your lovingkindness is better than life, / My lips praise You.
Thus I bless You while I live; / I [xref]a[/xref]lift up my hands in Your name.
My soul is [xref]a[/xref]satisfied as with the rich fatness, / And my mouth praises [i]You[/i] with lips of joyous shouting,
When I remember You [i]while[/i] on my bed, / [i]When[/i] I consider You in the night watches.
For You have been my help, / And in the shadow of Your [xref]a[/xref]wings I will shout for joy.
My soul pursues after You; / Your right hand upholds me.
But those who seek my [note]1[/note]life to destroy [i]it[/i] / Will go into the [xref]a[/xref]lower parts of the earth;
verse.note: In [link]vv. 5-8[/link] the psalmist treasures the enjoyment of God, but in [link]vv. 9-11[/link] he rejoices in God's punishing of his enemies. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 54[/link].

verse.text: They will be given over to the power of the sword; / They will be the portion of foxes.
But the king will rejoice in God; / Everyone who swears by Him will boast; / For the mouth of those who speak falsehood will be stopped.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
Hear, O God, my voice in my complaint; / Preserve my life from the enemy's dread.
Hide me from the secret counsel of evildoers, / From the throng of the workers of iniquity,
Who have sharpened their tongue like a sword, / [i]Who[/i] have aimed their arrow, [i]their[/i] bitter word,
To shoot in secret places at the [note]1[/note]perfect man. / They shoot suddenly at him and do not fear.
verse.note: The psalmist's use of [i]perfect man[/i] here and [i]righteous man[/i] and [i]upright in heart[/i] in [link]v. 10[/link] indicates that he considered himself perfect, righteous, and upright. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 7[/link].

verse.text: They firm up for themselves an evil matter; / They talk of laying snares secretly; / They say, Who will see them?
They seek out injustices, [i]saying:[/i] / We have completed a carefully sought-out plan. / Indeed each man's inward thought / And heart are deep.
But God will shoot an arrow at them; / Suddenly they are wounded.
They are made to stumble over each other by their own tongue; / All who see them shake their heads.
And all men will fear / And declare what has been done by God, / And they will ponder His work.
The righteous man will rejoice in Jehovah and [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in Him, / And all the upright in heart will boast.
To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David; a Song
Praise awaits You, O God, in [xref]a[/xref]Zion; / And to You is the vow paid.
O You who [xref]a[/xref]hear prayer, / To You all [xref]b[/xref]flesh comes.
Iniquities prevail against me; / As for our transgressions, You make [xref]a[/xref]propitiation for them.

Blessed is he whom You have [xref]a[/xref]chosen and bring [xref]b[/xref]near / To [xref]c[/xref]dwell in Your courts. / We will be [xref]d[/xref]satisfied with the goodness of Your house, / Of Your holy temple.
By awesome deeds You answer us in righteousness, / O [xref]a[/xref]God of our salvation, / You who are the trust of all the [xref]b[/xref]ends of the earth / And of the remotest sea;
Who established the mountains in His strength, / Girded with might;
Who [xref]a[/xref]stilled the roaring of the seas, / The roaring of their billows, / And the tumult of the peoples.
And they who dwell in the uttermost parts / Are afraid of Your signs; / You make the exitways of the morning and the evening / Shout for joy.

You visit the earth and [xref]a[/xref]water it; / You enrich it greatly: / The [xref]b[/xref]river of God is full of water. / You provide [note]1[/note]men grain, for so You have prepared [note]2[/note]the earth.
verse.note: Lit., them.
Lit., it.

verse.text: Saturating its furrows, settling its ridges, / You soften it with [xref]a[/xref]showers; / You bless its sprouting forth.
You place a crown on a year with Your goodness, / And Your [i]wagon[/i] tracks drop fatness;
The wilderness pastures overflow, / And the hills gird themselves with exultation.
The meadows are clothed with the flock, / And the valleys cover themselves in grain; / They shout for joy; indeed they [xref]a[/xref]sing.
To the choir director. A Song; a Psalm
Shout joyfully to God, all the earth;
[note]1[/note]Sing forth the glory of His name; / Make glorious His praise.
verse.note: Or, Sing in psalms the glory...

verse.text: Say to God, How awesome are Your deeds! / Because of the greatness of Your strength, Your enemies come cringing / to You.
All the earth will [xref]a[/xref]worship You / And sing psalms to You; / They will sing psalms to Your name. Selah
Come and see the works of God; / He is awesome in [i]His[/i] deeds toward the sons of men.
He turned the sea into [xref]a[/xref]dry land; / Through the river they crossed on foot. / There we rejoiced in Him.
He rules by His [xref]a[/xref]might forever; / His eyes observe the nations: / Let not the rebellious exalt themselves. Selah
Bless our God, O peoples; / And make the voice of His praise heard,
Who has kept our soul in life / And does not allow our feet to slip.
For You have [xref]a[/xref]tried us, O God; / You have [xref]b[/xref]refined us as silver is refined.
You have brought us into the net; / You have put a heavy burden on our loins.
You have made men ride over our heads; / We have gone through [xref]a[/xref]fire and water; / But You have brought us forth into abundance.
I will come into Your house with burnt offerings; / I will pay my vows to You,
Which my lips uttered / And my mouth spoke when I was in distress.
I will offer to You burnt offerings of fatlings / With the smoke of rams; / I will offer cattle with goats. Selah
Come, hear, all you who fear God, / And I will recount what He has done for my soul.
To Him I called out with my mouth, / And [note]1[/note]He was extolled with my tongue.
verse.note: Or, there was extolling under my tongue.

verse.text: If I regarded iniquity in my heart, / The Lord did [xref]a[/xref]not hear.
But indeed God has heard; / He has given heed to the voice of my prayer.
Blessed be God, / Who has not turned my prayer away / Nor His lovingkindness from me.
To the choir director: on the stringed instruments. A Psalm; a Song
God be gracious to us and bless us; / May He make His face [xref]a[/xref]shine upon us; Selah
That Your way may be known on earth, / [i]And[/i] Your salvation among all the nations.
Let the peoples praise You, O God; / Let the peoples praise You, all of them.
Let the nations rejoice and shout for joy, / For You will judge the peoples equitably / And will guide the nations on the earth. Selah
Let the peoples praise You, O God; / Let the peoples praise You, all of them.
The earth has yielded its increase; / God, our God, blesses us.
God blesses us; / And all the ends of the earth will fear Him.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A Psalm; a Song
[note]1[/note]Let God [xref]a[/xref]arise; let His [note]2[/note]enemies be scattered; / And let those who hate Him flee before Him.
verse.note: A quotation of Moses' prayer in [link]Num. 10:35[/link], uttered when the Ark of the Covenant set out from Mount Sinai. [link]Psalm 68[/link] is the highest peak of the divine revelation concerning Christ in all the Psalms. It is written in poetry, with types and signs, portraying the steps in God's move on the earth in Christ. The Ark (typifying Christ — [link]Exo. 25:10-22[/link] and notes) was the center of the tabernacle (also typifying Christ — [link]John 1:14[/link]). God's move in the tabernacle with the Ark among Israel, His elect, from Sinai to Zion typifies the Triune God's move in Christ as His all-inclusive embodiment from Christ's incarnation to His ascension. In the type, God's move was from Sinai ([link]vv. 8b[/link], [link]17b[/link]), beginning with the decreeing of the law and the erecting of the tabernacle, which signifies the incarnated Christ, through the wilderness ([link]vv. 4b[/link], [link]7b[/link]), which signifies the earth, to Mount Zion ([link]v. 16[/link]), God's dwelling place, which signifies God's dwelling place in the heavens ([link]Rev. 14:1[/link]). In the reality, God's move in Christ and through Christ for the accomplishing of His New Testament economy began with Christ's incarnation, which was the setting up of the real and living tabernacle in whom God dwelt and through whom He could move on earth; continued through Christ's human living on the earth with His crucifixion and resurrection; and concluded with Christ's ascension to Zion in the heavens. This unique move of God is portrayed in [link]vv. 1-18[/link] of this psalm. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 4[/link].
The enemies here typify Satan and his forces of evil in the heavenlies ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]). This prayer is actually the aspiration of all God's elect. Cf. note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: As smoke is driven away, You will drive [i]them[/i] away; / As wax melts before fire, / The wicked will perish [xref]a[/xref]before God.
But the righteous will rejoice; they will exult before God / And be glad with rejoicing.

Sing to God; sing psalms to His name; / [note]1[/note]Triumph in Him who rides through the [xref]a[/xref]deserts — / For [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jah is His name — and [note]1[/note]exult before Him.
verse.note: Indicating that Israel, God's elect, triumphed in God and exulted before Him in His move on the earth. Today we too should exult in the move of God on earth from Christ's incarnation to His ascension.
A shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]

verse.text: A Father to the [note]1[/note]orphans and a Judge for the widows / Is God in His holy [xref]a[/xref]habitation.
verse.note: God causes the believers in Christ as the needy ones (the orphans and widows), the bound ones (the prisoners — [link]v. 6[/link]), and the solitary ones ([link]v. 6[/link]) to dwell in His habitation, the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). The church is a building that includes such people.

verse.text: God causes the solitary to dwell in a household; / He brings the prisoners forth into prosperity; / But the rebellious dwell in a parched land.
[xref]a[/xref]O God, when You went forth [xref]b[/xref]before Your people, / When You marched through the desert, Selah
The earth [xref]a[/xref]trembled, the heavens also dripped, / At the presence of God; / Sinai there [i]quaked[/i] / At the presence of God, the God of Israel.
You shed forth bountiful [xref]a[/xref]rain, O God; / You confirmed Your inheritance when it languished.
Your living [i]flock[/i] dwelt in [note]1[/note]the land; / In Your goodness You provided for the poor, O God.
verse.note: Lit., it.

verse.text: The Lord gives the command; / The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]women who [note]2[/note]bear the [xref]b[/xref]glad tidings are a great host.
verse.note: Signifying the weak ones ([link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]), i.e., all the believers in Christ (cf. [link]2 Cor. 12:9-10[/link]), who can do nothing except proclaim the glad tidings of God's victory in Christ ([link]v. 12a[/link]).

This signifies the announcing of the glad tidings ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]) of Christ's victory and the spoil gained by Him as the portion of God's elect. While we announce the glad tidings, we enjoy the Triune God as the spoil gained for us by Christ (see notes [link]12[sup]4[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]kings of the armies flee. / They flee! / And [note]2[/note]she who [note]3[/note]abides at home / [xref]a[/xref]Divides the [note]4[/note]spoil.
verse.note: Here the defeated and scattered kings typify Satan and the evil world-rulers ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]), who were defeated by God through His move in Christ ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]; [link]Col. 2:15[/link]).
Referring collectively to the women in [link]v. 11[/link].
Abiding at home signifies not going out to the battle. Although we did not fight in the battle, we enjoy Christ's victory and divide the spoil.

Signifying all the gains of the accomplishment, consummation, attainment, and obtainment of Christ as the reapings of the victory of His death, resurrection, and ascension. This "spoil" is actually the riches of the processed and consummated Triune God as the portion of God's elect, typified by the dove, the silver, and the gold in [link]v. 13[/link]. See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Though you [note]1[/note]lie among the sheepfolds, / There are [note]2[/note]dove wings covered with [xref]a[/xref]silver, / And its pinions, with greenish-yellow gold.
verse.note: Signifying resting in God's provision and care for His elect.

The dove signifies the Spirit ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]), and the wings signify the moving power of the Spirit; silver signifies Christ in His all-inclusive redemption for His believers' justification as the entrance into His full salvation; pinions (the feathers at the end of a bird's wings that supply the strength to fly and soar) signify the soaring power of the Spirit; and gold signifies God in His divine nature. Here the gold is greenish-yellow, green signifying the divine life and yellow, the divine glory. Hence, greenish-yellow gold signifies God in His nature glittering in His life and glory. The contents of the above items, as the spoil ([link]v. 12[/link]) gained by Christ in His victory for the enjoyment of God's elect, are actually the Triune God — the Spirit, Christ, and God the Father — with all the items of His complete, full, and all-inclusive salvation.

verse.text: When the [note]1[/note]Almighty scattered / The [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]kings in [note]3[/note]the land, / It snowed on Zalmon.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Shaddai.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Gen. 17[/link].
See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Lit., it.

verse.text: O [note]1[/note]mighty mountain, O mountain of Bashan, / O many-peaked mountain, O mountain of Bashan:
verse.note: Others translate, mountain of God.

verse.text: Why do you look with envy, O many-peaked mountains, / At the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mountain on which God desires to dwell? / Indeed Jehovah will dwell [i]there[/i] forever.
verse.note: The dwelling place of God is built on Mount Zion ([link]76:2b[/link]), signifying the highest peak in the universe, the heavens ([link]Heb. 12:22[/link]; [link]Rev. 14:1[/link]). The built-up church as the reality of Zion is not earthly but heavenly. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]chariots of God are twenty thousand, / Thousands upon thousands; / The Lord is among them, / [i]As at[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Sinai, in the sanctuary.

You have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ascended on high; You have led captive [note]2[/note]those taken captive; / You have received [note]3[/note]gifts among men, / Even the rebellious ones also, / That [note]4[/note]Jehovah God may [note]5[/note]dwell [i]among them.[/i]
verse.note: Referring to Christ's ascension to the third heaven, the highest peak in the universe (cf. [link]Isa. 14:13[/link]). See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 4[/link]. Paul's quoting of this verse in [link]Eph. 4[/link] in reference to the building up of the church is a strong proof that the building up of the temple in the ancient times is a type of the building of the church. It also provides a strong basis to say that the temple, the house, and the city referred to in the Psalms typify the church.
See note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in Eph. 4[/link].

When Christ ascended to the Father, He presented to the Father all the ones whom He had captured and brought with Him. The Father then returned all these captured ones to Christ, making each of them a gift to Christ. See note [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 4[/link].
Heb. [i]Jah Elohim.[/i]

This indicates that Christ uses all the gifts, i.e., all the believers in Christ as gifted persons, who do the one work of the ministry, to build up the Body of Christ as God's dwelling place on earth today ([link]Eph. 4:7-12[/link], [link]16[/link]).

verse.text: Blessed be the Lord, who day by day [note]1[/note]loads us [i]with[/i] [note]2[/note][i]good;[/i] / God is our salvation. Selah
verse.note: The enjoyment of God in His house ([link]vv. 19-23[/link]) follows the building up of His dwelling place ([link]v. 18b[/link]).

Signifying not the "good" of material things but the Triune God Himself enjoyed by us as the spoil of Christ's victory (see notes [link]12[sup]4[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link]). See note [link]28[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 8[/link].

verse.text: God is to us / A God of deliverance, / And with Jehovah the Lord / Are the [note]1[/note]goings forth [i]even[/i] from [xref]a[/xref]death.
verse.note: The way to go forth from death is to enjoy God in Christ as the resurrection life ([link]John 11:25[/link]).

verse.text: Indeed God will [note]1[/note]smash / The [xref]a[/xref]head of His enemies, / The hairy crown / Of him who goes about in his guiltiness.
verse.note: In God's house we also enjoy His victory over the enemies. See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 16[/link].

verse.text: The Lord said, I will bring [i]them[/i] again from Bashan; / I will bring [i]them[/i] again from the depths of the sea,
That you may [note]1[/note]bathe your foot in blood, / That the tongue of your dogs may have their portion from the enemies.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, shatter.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]They have seen Your [note]1[/note]goings, O God, / The goings of my God, my [xref]a[/xref]King, in the [note]1[/note]sanctuary:
verse.note: Here [i]they[/i] refers to the enemies, to the unbelievers; [i]goings[/i] refers to God's activities; and the sanctuary signifies the church.

verse.text: Singers go before; players after; / In the midst of [note]1[/note]virgins sounding the tambourines.
verse.note: Signifying the believers ([link]Matt. 25:1[/link] and note 3).

verse.text: Bless God in the congregations, / [i]Even[/i] [note]1[/note]Jehovah, [i]O you who are[/i] of the [xref]a[/xref]fountain of Israel.
verse.note: Some MSS read, the Lord.
