verse.text: There are little [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Benjamin, who rules them, / [i]And[/i] the princes of [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Judah [i]in[/i] their company, / The princes of [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Zebulun, the princes of [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]Naphtali.
verse.note: In the praise rendered to God by His elect in [link]vv. 24-28[/link], a scenery in typology is portrayed concerning God's New Testament economy in the accomplishing of God's redemption by Christ for God's salvation and in the spreading of the glad tidings of Christ's accomplishment with the goodly words of the gospel. Benjamin, mentioned here, had two names, the first of which was Ben-oni. This name, given to him by his mother Rachel as she was dying in childbirth, means [i]son of my affliction[/i] ([link]Gen. 35:18a[/link]). As the son of affliction, Benjamin typifies Christ, who, as the man of sorrows ([link]Isa. 53:3[/link]) in His incarnation and human life on earth, accomplished God's eternal redemption for His full salvation ([link]Heb. 9:12[/link]). Whereas Rachel named her son Ben-oni, Jacob immediately changed the child's name to Benjamin, which means [i]son of the right hand[/i] ([link]Gen. 35:18b[/link]). To be at the right hand is to be in a position of glory and honor. As the son of the right hand, Benjamin typifies Christ, who, as the Son of the right hand in His resurrection, victory, and ascension, ministers in the heavens to carry out the application of God's redemption for His salvation ([link]Heb. 8:1-2[/link]; [link]7:25[/link]). Christ was incarnated to be Ben-oni, the man of sorrows, but in resurrection He became Benjamin, the Son of the right hand in glory and honor ([link]80:17[/link]; [link]Mark 16:19[/link]; [link]Acts 2:33[/link]; [link]5:31[/link]).

Judah is the lion with the power and the scepter, and he is the peace (Shiloh) to God's people ([link]Rev. 5:5a[/link]; [link]Gen. 49:8-10[/link]). Whereas Benjamin typifies Christ mainly in His humanity, Judah typifies Christ mainly in His divinity. In His divinity Christ is not a man of sorrows but a lion with power and authority (signified by the scepter). In particular, Judah typifies Christ as the victory for God's people and the peace to God's people. In the application of redemption, Christ is our peace ([link]Eph. 2:14-15[/link]).[br][br]Judah, the kingly tribe, was accompanied always by Benjamin, a warrior tribe ([link]Gen. 49:27[/link]), for God's kingdom on the earth. In typology Judah and Benjamin, who were joined geographically, form a group for the accomplishment and application of Christ's redemption for God's salvation. With Benjamin the emphasis is on the accomplishment of redemption; with Judah the emphasis is on the application (in Christ's ascension) of redemption.

Dwelling at the shore of the sea (Galilee) and being a shore for ships ([link]Gen. 49:13[/link]), Zebulun typifies Christ as the "shore" of the evangelists for the transportation and spreading in the preaching of God's gospel. After Christ accomplished all the things that are to be proclaimed as the gospel, on the day of Pentecost at least 120 gospel "ships," all of whom were Galileans ([link]Acts 2:7[/link]; [link]13:31[/link]), set out from the "shore" to spread the gospel. See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 49[/link].

According to [link]Gen. 49:21[/link] (see note there), Naphtali is a hind let loose, and he gives beautiful words. Naphtali typifies Christ as the One who is released from death in resurrection, signified by the hind let loose ([link]Psa. 22[/link], title; [link]S.S. 2:8-9[/link]), and gives beautiful words for the preaching of His gospel ([link]Matt. 28:18-20[/link]).[br][br]In typology Zebulun and Naphtali form a group for the spreading and the propagating of the glad tidings of Christ's redemption, accomplished for God's salvation. The people of both Zebulun and Naphtali were men of Galilee ([link]Matt. 4:12-17[/link]; [link]Acts 1:11[/link]), from whom the gospel of Christ has been spread, preached, and propagated.

verse.text: Your God has commanded your strength; / [note]1[/note]Strengthen, O God, that which You have done for us.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 28b-29a[/link] indicates that after God's strengthening of what He has done for His elect, the influence of the enjoyment of God in His house spreads to the entire city of Jerusalem because of the house of God, which was at Jerusalem. The house of God signifies the local churches, and the city of Jerusalem signifies the kingdom, the strengthening and the safeguard of the church.

verse.text: Because of Your temple at Jerusalem, / [note]1[/note]Kings will bring a [xref]a[/xref]gift to You.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 29b-35[/link] indicates that the influence of the enjoyment of God in His house and His city will gain the whole earth for God. The scenery portrayed in these verses will consummate in the coming age of restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Acts 3:20-21[/link]), in which all the earth will come to Jerusalem to worship God and to receive instruction and enlightenment ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]; [link]14:16[/link]).

verse.text: Rebuke the [note]1[/note]animals of the reeds, / The herd of the bulls among the calves of the peoples, / Trampling on those who lust after silver; / Scatter the [note]2[/note]peoples who take delight in war.
verse.note: Signifying the Egyptians.
Signifying the nations.

verse.text: Nobles will come out of [xref]a[/xref]Egypt; / [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Cush will quickly stretch out its hands to God.
verse.note: I.e., Ethiopia.

verse.text: O [xref]a[/xref]kingdoms of the [xref]b[/xref]earth, / Sing to God, / Sing psalms to the Lord, Selah
To Him who rides upon the ancient [xref]a[/xref]heaven of heavens. / Behold, He utters His voice, a mighty voice.
Ascribe strength to God; / His excellence is over Israel, / And His strength is in the skies.
[i]You are[/i] awesome, O God, from Your sanctuaries. / The God of Israel, He gives strength and power to the people. / Blessed be God!
To the choir director: according to [note]1[/note]Shoshannim. [xref]a[/xref]Of David
verse.note: See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 45[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Save me, O God; for the waters / Threaten my life.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 69[/link] is on the suffering Christ, typified by the suffering David, and [link]Psa. 72[/link] is on the reigning Christ, typified by the reigning Solomon. In this psalm the sufferings of Christ are portrayed in a detailed way: Christ was hated by many without cause ([link]v. 4a[/link]; [link]John 15:25[/link]); He was reproached for the sake of God ([link]vv. 7a[/link], [link]9b[/link]; [link]Rom. 15:3[/link]); He was devoured by the zeal of God's house ([link]v. 9a[/link]; [link]John 2:17[/link]); He suffered much, and no one took pity on Him ([link]vv. 29a[/link], [link]19-20[/link]; [link]John 16:32[/link]); He wept and entreated God to deliver Him out of death ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]13-17[/link], [link]1-2[/link]; [link]Heb. 5:7[/link]); He was given gall as His food while He was suffering on the cross ([link]v. 21a[/link]; [link]Matt. 27:34[/link]); He was given vinegar to drink in His thirst on the cross ([link]v. 21b[/link]; [link]John 19:28-30[/link]); He was stricken and wounded by God ([link]v. 26[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:10a[/link]); and He was betrayed by one of His disciples ([link]v. 25[/link]; [link]Acts 1:16-20a[/link]). After His life of suffering on earth, typified by the sufferings of David, Christ ascended to the heavens, where He is now reigning as the King, typified by Solomon.

verse.text: I sink in deep mire, / And there is no place to stand; / I have come to the depths of water, / And the flood flows over me.
I am weary of my crying; / My throat is parched; / My eyes fail / While I wait for my God.

More numerous than the hairs of my head / Are those who [xref]a[/xref]hate me without cause; / Mighty are those who would destroy me, / Those who are wrongly my enemies. / What I did not steal, / I must then restore.
O God, You know my foolishness, / And my sins of guilt are not hidden from You.
Do not let those who wait on You be put to shame because of me, / O Lord Jehovah of hosts; / Do not let those who seek You be humiliated because of me, / O God of Israel.
Because for Your sake I have borne [xref]a[/xref]reproach; / Humiliation has covered my face.
I have become a stranger to my [xref]a[/xref]brothers, / And a foreigner to my mother's children.
For the [xref]a[/xref]zeal of Your house has devoured me, / And the [xref]b[/xref]reproaches of those who reproach You have fallen on me.
When I [xref]a[/xref]wept, [i]when[/i] my soul was in fasting, / [i]That[/i] became a reproach to me.
When I made sackcloth my clothing, / I became a [xref]a[/xref]proverb to them.
Those who sit in the gate [xref]a[/xref]talk about me, / And [i]I am[/i] the [i]mocking[/i] song of those who drink liquor.
But as for me, my prayer is to You, / O Jehovah, in an [xref]a[/xref]acceptable time; / O God, in the abundance of Your lovingkindness answer me, / In the faithfulness of Your salvation.
Deliver me out of the mire, and let me not sink; / May I be delivered from those who hate me, / And out of the depths of water.
Do not let the flood of water flow over me, / Nor let the deep swallow me, / Nor let the pit close its mouth over me.
Answer me, O Jehovah; for Your lovingkindness is good; / According to the abundance of Your compassions turn to me.
And do not hide Your face from Your servant, / For I am in distress; hurry [i]and[/i] answer me.
Draw near to my soul; redeem it; / Ransom me because of my enemies.
You know my [xref]a[/xref]reproach / And my shame and my humiliation; / All my adversaries are before You.
Reproach has broken my heart, / And I am sick; / I looked for pity, but there was none; / And for comforters, but I found [xref]a[/xref]none.
But they gave me [xref]a[/xref]gall for my food, / And for my [xref]b[/xref]thirst they gave me [xref]c[/xref]vinegar to drink.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]May their table become a snare before them / And a trap [i]when they are[/i] at peace.
verse.note: [link]Verses 22-24[/link] and [link]27-28[/link] are the psalmist's expression from his complex sentiments concerning his enemies. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: May their eyes be darkened so that they cannot [xref]a[/xref]see; / And make their loins shake continually.
Pour out Your indignation upon them; / And may the burning fierceness of Your anger overtake them.
[xref]a[/xref]May their camp be desolate; / May there be no one to dwell in their tents.
For they persecute him whom You have [xref]a[/xref]stricken, / And they recount the pain of those whom You have wounded.
Add iniquity to their iniquity, / And do not let them come into Your righteousness.
May they be blotted out of the [xref]a[/xref]book of life, / And may they not be written with the righteous.
But I am poor and pained; / May Your salvation, O God, set me on high.
I will praise the name of God with a song / And will [xref]a[/xref]magnify Him with thanksgiving;
And it will be better to Jehovah than an ox / [i]Or[/i] a bull with horns and hooves.
The meek have seen [i]it;[/i] they rejoice. / You who seek God, let your heart revive.
For Jehovah listens to the needy, / And He does not despise His prisoners.
[xref]a[/xref]Let the heavens and the earth praise Him, / The seas and everything that moves in them.
For God will save [xref]a[/xref]Zion / And build the cities of Judah; / And they will abide there and possess it.
And the seed of His servants will inherit it, / And those who love His name will dwell in it.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David, for remembrance
[xref]a[/xref]O God, [i]hasten[/i] to deliver me; / O Jehovah, hasten to help me.
[xref]a[/xref]May those who seek my life / Be put to shame and confounded; / May those who take delight in my misfortune / Be turned back and humiliated;
May those who say, Aha! Aha! / Turn away because of their shame;
May all those who seek You / Be glad and rejoice in You; / And may those who love Your salvation / Say continually, / May God be magnified!
But I am poor and needy; / O God, hasten to me. / You are my help and my Deliverer; / O Jehovah, do not delay.
[xref]a[/xref]In You, O Jehovah, do I [xref]b[/xref]take refuge; / Never let me be put to shame.
In Your righteousness deliver me and rescue me; / Incline Your ear to me and save me.
Be to me a [xref]a[/xref]rock of habitation [i]for me[/i] to come to continually. / You have given command to save me, / For You are my rock and my [xref]b[/xref]fortress.
My God, rescue me from the hand of the wicked, / From the hand of the unjust and cruel;
For You are my hope, O Lord Jehovah, / My trust from my youth.
On You I have been sustained since [xref]a[/xref]birth; / It was You who took me from my mother's [xref]b[/xref]womb; / My praise is continually of You.
I am like a wonder to many, / But You are my strong [xref]a[/xref]refuge.
My mouth is filled with Your praise, / With Your [note]1[/note]glory, all day long.
verse.note: Or, honor, majesty.

verse.text: Do not cast me off in the time of [xref]a[/xref]old age; / When my strength fails, do not forsake me.
For my enemies speak concerning me, / And those who watch for my soul take [xref]a[/xref]counsel together,
Saying, God has forsaken him; / Pursue and lay hold of him, for there is no one to deliver [i]him.[/i]
O God, do not be far away from me; / My God, hasten to help me.
May those who are the adversaries to my soul / Be put to shame and consumed; / May those who seek my misfortune / Wrap themselves in reproach and humiliation.
But I will hope continually / And will add yet more to all Your praise.
My mouth will recount Your righteousness, / Your salvation, all day long; / For I do not know [i]its full[/i] numbers.
I will come with [i]the proof of[/i] the mighty acts of the Lord Jehovah; / I will remind [i]men[/i] of Your righteousness, Yours alone.
O God, You have taught me from my youth; / And until now I have declared Your wondrous deeds.

So even into [i]my[/i] [xref]a[/xref]old age and grayheadedness, / O God, do not forsake me, / Until I have declared Your strength / Unto the [i]next[/i] generation, / Your might unto everyone who is to come.
And Your righteousness, O God, is so high, / You who have done [xref]a[/xref]great things. / O God, [xref]b[/xref]who is like You?
You who have shown [note]1[/note]me / Many great troubles / Will [xref]a[/xref]revive [note]1[/note]me again / And bring [note]1[/note]me up again / From the depths of the earth.
verse.note: Others read, us (three times).

verse.text: You will increase my greatness / And will turn [i]and[/i] comfort me.
I will also praise You with the harp, / [i]I will praise[/i] Your [note]1[/note]faithfulness, my God; / I will sing psalms to You with the lyre, / O Holy One of Israel.
verse.note: Or, truth.

verse.text: My lips will give a ringing shout / When I sing psalms to You, / And my soul, which You have redeemed.
My tongue also will declare / Your righteousness all day long; / For they are put to shame, for they are confounded, / They who seek my misfortune.
[xref]a[/xref]Of Solomon
O God, give Your judgments to the [note]1[/note]king, / And Your righteousness to the son of the king.
verse.note: In this psalm the reigning Christ is typified by the reigning Solomon (see superscription), the son of David ([link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]22:42[/link]), in his prosperous and flourishing time ([link]1 Kings 9-10[/link]). The reign of Christ typified by the reign of Solomon will be in the millennium in the age of restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]).

verse.text: He will judge Your people in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteousness, / And Your poor with [note]1[/note]justice.
verse.note: The reigning of Christ will be in righteousness and justice (see note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 89[/link]) and will issue in peace ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]7[/link]; cf. [link]Isa. 32:17[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:11[/link]).

verse.text: The mountains will bear [xref]a[/xref]peace to the people, / And the hills, in righteousness.
He will judge the poor of the people; / He will save the children of the needy / And crush the oppressor.
They will fear You as long as the sun endures / And as long as the moon endures / Throughout the generations.
He will [note]1[/note]drop like rain upon mown grass, / Like abundant [xref]a[/xref]showers dripping on the earth.
verse.note: In His second coming Christ will gain the earth not mainly by exercising His righteous judgment but by coming like showers to water the people of the earth. He will have mercy on the earth and will come back graciously like showers of rain to satisfy the thirsty ones (cf. [link]Rev. 22:17[/link]). In that day all the nations will be rained on by Christ and will be happy under His dominion.

verse.text: In His days the righteous will flourish, / And there will be an abundance of peace / Until the [xref]a[/xref]moon is no more.
And He will have [xref]a[/xref]dominion from sea to sea / And from the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]River unto the ends of the earth.
verse.note: I.e., the Euphrates.

verse.text: The desert dwellers will bow down before Him, / And His enemies will lick the dust.
The kings of Tarshish and of the [note]1[/note]coastlands / Will pay tribute; / The kings of Sheba and Seba / Will present [xref]a[/xref]gifts.
verse.note: I.e., the islands and shores of the Mediterranean Sea.

verse.text: And all the [xref]a[/xref]kings will bow down before Him; / All the nations will serve Him.
For He will deliver the needy man when he cries, / And the poor man who has no one to help him.
He will have pity on the weak and needy, / And the souls of the needy He will save.
From oppression and violence / He will redeem their soul, / And their blood will be [xref]a[/xref]precious in His sight.
So He shall live and to Him shall be given / The [xref]a[/xref]gold of Sheba; / And prayer shall be made continually for Him; / He shall be blessed all the day long.

There will be an abundance of grain on the earth, / [i]Even[/i] at the tops of the mountains. / Its fruit will wave like [i]the forests of[/i] Lebanon, / And those of the city will blossom like the foliage of the earth.
His name will be forever; / As long as the sun endures, His name will spread; / And men will be [xref]a[/xref]blessed in Him; / All the nations will call Him [xref]b[/xref]blessed.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed be Jehovah God, the God of Israel, / Who alone does wondrous deeds;
verse.note: [link]Psalm 41:13[/link] concludes Book One of the Psalms, and [link chapter="72"]vv. 18-19[/link] of this psalm conclude Book Two. The two are similar, but the conclusion in this psalm is improved by the mentioning of God's glorious name and the filling of the whole earth with His glory because of the gaining of the earth through the enjoyment of God in His house and His city (see note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 68[/link]).

verse.text: And blessed be His glorious name forever; / And may His [xref]a[/xref]glory fill the whole earth. / [xref]b[/xref]Amen and Amen.
The prayers of David the son of Jesse are ended.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph
[note]1[/note]Surely God is good to Israel, / To those who are [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]pure in heart.
verse.note: The first four psalms in Book Three, [link]Psa. 73-76[/link], cover four matters: the personal sufferings of the seeking saints ([link]Psa. 73[/link]), the desolation of God's house ([link]Psa. 74[/link]), the judgment of Christ on the desolators ([link]Psa. 75[/link]), and the victory of God in His dwelling place ([link]Psa. 76[/link]).
To be pure in heart is to have God as our one goal and aim. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: But as for me, my feet were nearly [note]1[/note]turned aside; / My steps had almost slipped.
verse.note: [link]Verses 2-16[/link] are a record of the suffering of the seeking psalmist and his perplexity because of the prosperity of the wicked. Whereas [link]Psa. 1:3-4[/link] says that the law-keeper prospers and the wicked do not prosper, here the psalmist was puzzled ([link]v. 16[/link]) and nearly stumbled by his own suffering ([link]vv. 13-14[/link]) and the prosperity of the wicked, who are at ease and heap up riches ([link]v. 12[/link]). See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 1[/link].

verse.text: For I was envious of the arrogant, / [i]When[/i] I saw the [xref]a[/xref]prosperity of the wicked.
For they have no pangs in their death, / And their body is well nourished.
They do not [i]find themselves[/i] in the hardship of men, / Nor are they plagued like [i]other[/i] men.
Therefore pride is a necklace for them, / Violence covers them like a garment.
Their eyes bulge out from fatness; / The imaginations of [i]their[/i] heart overflow.
They mock and wickedly speak of oppression; / They speak loftily.
They set their mouth against the heavens, / And their [xref]a[/xref]tongue walks about on the earth.
Therefore His people return here, / And waters of abundance are drained by them;
And they say, How does God know? / And is there knowledge with the Most High?
Behold, these are the wicked; / And always at ease, they [xref]a[/xref]heap up riches.
Surely I have purified my heart in [note]1[/note]vain, / And I have [xref]a[/xref]washed my hands in innocence.
verse.note: The psalmist considered that he had purified his heart in vain because, instead of enjoying material prosperity, he was plagued all day long and chastened every morning ([link]v. 14[/link]). However, the real vanity is anything besides God. Idols are vanity; material prosperity is vanity; anything other than God is vanity ([link]Eccl. 1:2[/link]). A pure heart is one that is set on nothing but God. The psalmist realized this when he entered into the sanctuary of God ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]25-26[/link]; see notes [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: For I have been plagued all day long / And chastened every morning.
If I had said, I will speak thus; / Behold, I would have betrayed the generation of Your children.
When I considered this in order to understand [i]it,[/i] / It was a troublesome task in my sight,
Until I went into the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctuary of God; / [i]Then[/i] I perceived their end.
verse.note: The solution to the psalmist's perplexity concerning the prosperity of the wicked was obtained in God's sanctuary. First, God's sanctuary, His habitation, is in our spirit ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]) and, second, it is the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). Thus, to go into the sanctuary of God, we need to turn to our spirit and go to the meetings of the church. Once we are in the sanctuary — in the spirit and in the church — we will have another view, a particular perception, of the situation concerning the wicked ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]). In our spirit and in the church we receive divine revelation and obtain the explanation to all our problems.

verse.text: Surely You set them in slippery places; / You cast them down into ruins.
How they are made desolate in a moment! / They are utterly consumed by terrors.
Like a dream, when one awakes, You, O Lord, / Upon arising, will despise their image.
When my heart was embittered, / And inwardly I was pricked;
I was brutish and knew nothing; / I was [i]like[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]beast before You.
Nevertheless I am continually [xref]a[/xref]with You; / You have taken hold of my [xref]b[/xref]right hand.
You will guide me with Your counsel, / And afterward You will receive me in [xref]a[/xref]glory.
[note]1[/note]Whom do I have in heaven [i]but You?[/i] / And besides You there is nothing I [xref]a[/xref]desire on earth.
verse.note: This verse reveals that God's pure seeker would have God as his only possession in heaven and his unique desire on earth. God was the psalmist's unique goal. The psalmist did not care for anything except God and gaining Him. In this matter Paul was the same ([link]Phil. 3:8[/link]).

verse.text: My flesh and my heart fail, / [i]But[/i] God is the [xref]a[/xref]rock of my heart and my [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]portion forever.
verse.note: In God's sanctuary the psalmist was instructed to take only God Himself as his portion, not anything other than God. The one who does not care for God may gain many things and seem to prosper. However, the one who cares for God will be restricted by God and even stripped by God of many things, as was the case with Job ([link]Job 1:6-2:10[/link]) and the apostle Paul ([link]Phil. 3:7-8[/link]). God's intention with His seekers is that they may find everything in Him and not be distracted from the absolute enjoyment of Himself. It is not a matter of keeping the law, as in [link]Psa. 1[/link], or of being right or wrong, but of gaining God and keeping God as everything. See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Job 2[/link].

verse.text: For behold, those who are far from You will perish; / You destroy all who go about as harlots away from You.
But as for me, [xref]a[/xref]drawing near to God is good for me; / I have made the Lord Jehovah my [xref]b[/xref]refuge, / That I may declare all Your works.
A [note]1[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of Asaph
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Why, O God, have You [xref]a[/xref]cast [i]us[/i] off forever? / [i]Why[/i] does Your anger smoke against the [xref]b[/xref]sheep of Your pasture?
verse.note: This psalm concerns the desolation of the house of God. After reaching the highest enjoyment of God in His house and His city at the end of Book Two, the psalmist lost this enjoyment, and God's house was desolated, as described in this psalm. [link]Verses 1-11[/link] are the psalmist's painful presentation of the perpetual ruins and damage in the sanctuary of God ([link]v. 3[/link]). The temple, God's house, was desolated to such an extent that it was burned ([link]vv. 7-8[/link]), and the city surrounding it was ruined ([link]2 Chron. 36:19[/link]). The intrinsic reason for the desolation was that Christ was not exalted by God's people; they did not give Him the preeminence, the first place, in everything ([link]Jer. 2:13[/link]; cf. [link]Col. 1:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:4[/link] and note 2). The problem of desolation is solved by Christ being properly appreciated and exalted by God's people (see note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 80[/link]). The enjoyment of God in the house and the city of God can be maintained and preserved only when Christ is properly appreciated and exalted by God's people.

verse.text: Remember Your [note]1[/note]assembly, which You have [xref]a[/xref]purchased of old, / Which You have redeemed as the tribe of Your inheritance, / [i]And[/i] Mount [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zion, where You dwell.
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-2[/link] indicate that the psalmist was concerned about two things — God's people and God's dwelling place, both of which had been damaged. Regarding this, the psalmist was deeply disappointed.

verse.text: Lift up Your steps unto the perpetual ruins; / The enemy has damaged everything in the [xref]a[/xref]sanctuary.
Your adversaries have roared in the midst of Your assembly place; / They have set up their symbols as signs.
It looked like when men bring up axes / On the thicket of the trees.
And now they have struck down with hatchet and hammer / Its [xref]a[/xref]carved work altogether.
They have [xref]a[/xref]set fire to Your sanctuary; / They have defiled the dwelling place of Your name to the ground.
They said in their heart, Let us oppress them completely. / They have burned down all God's assembly places in the land.
We do not see our signs; there is no longer a [xref]a[/xref]prophet, / Nor is there anyone among us who knows how long.
How long, O God, will the adversary reproach? / Will the enemy despise Your name forever?
Why do You withdraw Your hand, even Your [xref]a[/xref]right hand? / [i]Bring it forth[/i] from the midst of Your bosom; destroy [i]them.[/i]
[note]1[/note]But God is my [xref]a[/xref]King of old, / Accomplishing salvation in the midst of the earth.
verse.note: [link]Verses 12-23[/link] are a desperate cry for God's interest ([link]v. 22a[/link]) that appeals to His power ([link]vv. 13-17[/link]) and is based on His faithfulness to His covenant ([link]v. 20[/link]). This is an example of the best kind of prayer. Eventually, God heard this prayer and came in to restore the ruined sanctuary ([link]Ezra 1-6[/link]).

verse.text: You [xref]a[/xref]divided the sea by Your strength; / You broke the heads of the sea serpents on the waters.
You crushed the heads of the [note]1[/note]leviathan; / You gave him as food to the creatures of the desert.
verse.note: Probably the crocodile.

verse.text: You broke open the [xref]a[/xref]fountain and the torrent; / You [xref]b[/xref]dried up the ever-flowing streams.
The day is Yours; the night also is Yours; / You prepared the moon and the sun.
You established all the [xref]a[/xref]borders of the earth: / You formed the summer and the winter.
Remember this: The enemy has reproached Jehovah, / And a foolish people has despised Your name.
Do not give the soul of Your turtledove to the wild beast; / Do not forget the life of Your poor forever.
Regard the [xref]a[/xref]covenant, / For the dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of violence.
Do not let him who is oppressed return ashamed. / May the poor and needy praise Your name.
Arise, O God; contend for Your own cause; / Remember how the foolish man reproaches You all day long.
Do not forget the voice of Your adversaries; / The roar of those who rise up against You goes up continually.
To the choir director: [note]1[/note]Do not destroy. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph; a Song
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 57[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]We give thanks to You, O God; we give thanks, / For Your name is near; [i]men[/i] tell of Your wondrous deeds.
verse.note: This psalm concerns the judgment of Christ on the desolators in answer to the prayer in [link]Psa. 74[/link]. Although this psalm does not mention Christ or the Messiah, the very God who judges ([link]v. 7[/link]) must be Christ, for God has given all judgment to Christ the Son ([link]John 5:22[/link]). Christ, the second of the Divine Trinity, is the One who will execute judgment upon all sinners ([link]Acts 10:42[/link]). Here the judgment is upon the desolators, who had gone too far in executing God's judgment on His people (see note [link]13[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Isa. 26[/link]).

verse.text: When I choose the appointed [note]1[/note]time, / It is I who [xref]a[/xref]judge with equity.
verse.note: Christ's judgment upon the desolators will be at the time appointed by Him (cf. [link]Acts 17:31[/link]).

verse.text: The earth and all who dwell in it melt; / I have established its pillars. Selah
I said to the boastful, Do not boast; / And to the wicked, Do not lift up the horn.
Do not lift your horn on high; / Do not speak arrogantly with a [i]haughty[/i] neck.
For neither from the east nor from the west, / And neither from the [note]1[/note]south, does exaltation [i]come;[/i]
verse.note: The fact that exaltation comes neither from the east nor from the west nor from the south indicates that it comes from the north, i.e., from God, who dwells in the north (cf. [link]Isa. 14:13-14[/link]; [link]Ezek. 1:4[/link]; [link]Psa. 48:2[/link]). Furthermore, this indicates that Christ as the Judge (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link]) is unique. Exaltation should not come from any direction other than where He dwells. Therefore, preeminence should be given to Him ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]).

verse.text: For God is the Judge: / He puts this one down and [xref]a[/xref]exalts that one.

For there is a [xref]a[/xref]cup in the hand of Jehovah, / And the wine foams; it is full of mixture, / And He pours from it; indeed its dregs will all the wicked of the earth / Drain off [i]and[/i] drink up.
But as for me, I will declare forever, / I will sing psalms to the God of Jacob.
And all the horns of the wicked will I cut off, / [i]But[/i] the horns of the righteous man will be exalted.
To the choir director: on the stringed instruments. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph; a Song
[note]1[/note]God is known in Judah; / His name is great in Israel.
verse.note: This psalm concerns the victory of God in His dwelling place. [link]Verses 1-5[/link] are a declaration concerning the victory of God, as the glorious and excellent One, in His tabernacle. [link]Verses 6-12[/link] are the praise of the psalmist concerning the wrath and fearfulness of God.

verse.text: And in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Salem is His tabernacle, / And His dwelling place, in [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zion.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]2[/sup] in Gen. 14[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]There He broke the flashing [i]arrows[/i] of the [xref]a[/xref]bow, / The shield and the sword and the battle. Selah
verse.note: Referring to God's dwelling place ([link]v. 2[/link]). It is in God's dwelling place, that is, in the church, that God defeats the enemy and destroys his instruments of war. See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 16[/link].

verse.text: More glorious are You, / More excellent than the mountains of prey.
The stouthearted are despoiled; / They slept their sleep, / And none of the men of strength / Have found their hands.
At Your rebuke, O God of Jacob, / Both chariot and horse fall into [xref]a[/xref]deep sleep.
You, indeed You, are to be feared; / And who may [xref]a[/xref]stand before You once You are angry?
You caused judgment to be heard from the heavens; / The earth feared and was still,
When God rose for judgment, / To save all the meek of the earth. Selah
For the wrath of man will praise You; / You will gird Yourself with the remainder of wrath.
Make vows and pay [i]them[/i] to Jehovah your God; / Let all who are around Him bring gifts to Him who is to be feared.
He will cut off the spirit of the princes; / He is terrible to the kings of the earth.
To the choir director, to Jeduthun. [xref]a[/xref]Of Asaph. A Psalm
[note]1[/note]My voice [i]calls out[/i] to God, and I will cry out; / My voice [i]calls out[/i] to God, and He will give ear to me.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 77-83[/link] form a cluster of psalms that cover the devastation of three holy things — the holy temple, the holy city, and the holy people. In particular, these psalms reveal the way of restoration — to exalt Christ. These seven psalms were written by Asaph, a Levite who had served in the temple. The fact that these psalms speak of the desolation of the temple, the city of Jerusalem, and the people indicates that they were written after the children of Israel had been taken captive to Babylon.

verse.text: In the day of my distress I sought the Lord; / My hand was stretched out in the night, and it did not drop. / My soul refused to be comforted.
I remember God, and I moan; / I complain, and my spirit faints. Selah
You hold [i]open[/i] my eyelids; / I am disturbed and cannot speak.
I consider the days of old, / The years of ancient times;
I remember my [xref]a[/xref]song in the night; / I muse with my own heart, and my [xref]b[/xref]spirit carefully searches.
Will the Lord [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cast [i]us[/i] off forever, / And will He never be favorable [i]to us[/i] again?
verse.note: The psalmist was puzzled and complained to God because God had cast off His people for a while ([link]vv. 1-9[/link]). God has chosen us, and He will never forsake us ([link]Deut. 31:6[/link]; [link]Josh. 1:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:5[/link]). He may allow us to depart from Him for a time; then He touches us, and we come back to Him (cf. [link]Rom. 11:24-25[/link]).

verse.text: Has His lovingkindness ceased forever? / Has the promise come to an end for all generations?
Has God forgotten to be gracious? / Or has He in anger shut up His compassions? Selah
Then I said, This is my infirmity; / [note]1[/note][i]But I recall[/i] the years of the right hand of the Most High.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 10b-20[/link] the psalmist recalled the past and mused on God's wondrous doings for His people. In this way he introduced the subject of restoration. The temple had been destroyed, the city had been devastated, and many of the people had been either killed or taken captive. This does not mean, however, that Israel is finished, for there will be restoration through the exalting of Christ (see note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 80[/link]).

verse.text: I will bring to remembrance the deeds of [note]1[/note]Jehovah, / For I will remember Your wonders from of old.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah;[/i] a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And I will meditate on all that You have done / And muse on Your doings.
O God, Your way is in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctuary; / Who is so [xref]b[/xref]great a god as God?
verse.note: God's way is hidden in the sea, and His paths in the great waters, with His footsteps, are not known to men ([link]v. 19[/link]), but His way is revealed in His sanctuary, i.e., in our spirit and in the church ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). When we exercise our spirit and live in the church, God's way becomes clear to us. See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 73[/link].

verse.text: You are the God who does wonders; / You have made known Your strength among the peoples.
You [xref]a[/xref]redeemed Your people with [i]Your[/i] arm, / The sons of Jacob and Joseph. Selah
The [xref]a[/xref]waters saw You, O God; / The waters saw You; they were afraid; / Indeed the depths trembled.
The clouds poured forth water; / The skies sent forth a sound; / Indeed Your arrows went here and there.
The sound of Your thunder was in the whirlwind; / Lightning illuminated the world; / The earth [xref]a[/xref]trembled and quaked.
Your way was in the [xref]a[/xref]sea, / And Your paths in the great waters; / And Your footsteps were not known.
You led Your people like a [xref]a[/xref]flock / By the hand of Moses and Aaron.
A [note]1[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of Asaph
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Give ear, O my people, to my [note]1[/note]instruction; / Incline your ears to the words of my mouth.
verse.note: The subject of this psalm is man's failure and God's restoration. [link]Verses 1-58[/link] are the psalmist's recalling of Israel's failure in the past; [link]vv. 59-64[/link] describe the issue of Israel's failure; and [link]vv. 65-72[/link] is a word concerning God's restoration of Israel.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I will open my mouth in a [xref]b[/xref]parable; / I will utter riddles from of old,
Which we have heard and known, / And our fathers have related to us.
We will not hide [i]them[/i] from their children, / [i]But[/i] will relate to the generation to come / The praises of Jehovah and His strength / And His wondrous deeds that He has done.
Indeed He has established a testimony in Jacob / And appointed a law in Israel, / Which He commanded our fathers / That they should make them known to their [xref]a[/xref]children;
That the generation to come, / The children to be born, may know [i]them,[/i] / [i]Who[/i] should arise and relate [i]them[/i] to their children;
That they might set their hope in God, / And not forget the deeds of God, / But observe His commandments;

That they might not be like their fathers, / A stubborn and rebellious generation, / A [xref]a[/xref]generation that did not set their [xref]b[/xref]heart right, / And whose spirit was not faithful to God.
The children of Ephraim, armed archers with bows, / Turned back in the day of battle.
They did not keep the covenant of God, / And they refused to walk in His law.
And they forgot His doings / And His wondrous deeds that He had shown them.
He did something [xref]a[/xref]wonderful in the sight of their fathers / In the land of Egypt, in the field of Zoan.
He [xref]a[/xref]divided the sea and caused them to pass through, / And He made the water stand as a [xref]b[/xref]heap.
And He led them with the [xref]a[/xref]cloud by day / And all the night with a light of fire.
He split [xref]a[/xref]rocks in the wilderness / And gave [i]them[/i] abundant drink, as from the depths.
He also brought forth streams from the rock / And made water run down like rivers.
Yet they still continued to sin against Him, / To rebel against the Most High in the desert.
And they put God to the [xref]a[/xref]test in their heart, / By asking for food according to their desire.
They also spoke against God; / They said, Can God prepare a [xref]a[/xref]table in the [xref]b[/xref]wilderness?
Behold, He struck the [xref]a[/xref]rock, / And water gushed out, / And streams overflowed; / Can He also give [i]us[/i] bread, / Or provide meat for His people?
Therefore Jehovah heard and was [xref]a[/xref]angry. / And a fire was kindled against Jacob, / And also anger went up against Israel;
Because they did [xref]a[/xref]not believe in God, / And they did not trust in His salvation.
Yet He commanded the skies above / And opened the doors of heaven;
And He rained down upon them [xref]a[/xref]manna to eat / And gave them the [xref]b[/xref]food of heaven.
Man ate the bread of the mighty; / He sent them full provision.
He made the east [xref]a[/xref]wind blow in the heavens / And guided the south wind by His strength.
And He rained upon them meat like dust, / And winged [xref]a[/xref]birds like the sand of the seas.
And He made [i]it[/i] fall in the midst of their camp, / Around their habitations.
So they ate and were well filled; / Indeed what they desired He brought to them.
They were not estranged from what they desired; / Their food was still in their mouths
When the [xref]a[/xref]anger of God went up against them / And slew [i]some[/i] of their fattest ones / And struck down the choice men of Israel.
In spite of all this they still sinned / And did [xref]a[/xref]not believe in His wondrous deeds.
Therefore He consumed their days with vanity, / And their years with terror.
When He slew them, they [xref]a[/xref]inquired after Him, / And they returned and diligently sought God.
And they remembered that God was their [xref]a[/xref]rock, / And the Most High God, their Redeemer.
But they flattered Him with their mouth / And lied to Him with their tongue.
For their [xref]a[/xref]heart was not steadfast toward Him, / Nor were they faithful to His covenant.
But He, being [xref]a[/xref]merciful, forgave [i]their[/i] iniquity / And did not destroy [i]them;[/i] / Indeed He turned back His anger many times / And did not stir up all His wrath.
And He remembered that they were [xref]a[/xref]flesh, / A [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]wind that goes away and does not return.
verse.note: Or, breath.

verse.text: How often they rebelled against Him in the wilderness / And [xref]a[/xref]grieved Him in the desert!
And they repeatedly put God to the [xref]a[/xref]test / And provoked the [xref]b[/xref]Holy One of Israel.
They did not remember His hand, / The day when He ransomed them from the adversary;
[xref]a[/xref]When He set His signs in Egypt / And His wonders in the field of Zoan;
And He turned their rivers into [xref]a[/xref]blood, / As well as their streams, so that they could not drink.
He sent among them a swarm [i]of[/i] [xref]a[/xref][i]flies,[/i] which devoured them; / And [xref]b[/xref]frogs, which destroyed them.
And He gave their increase to the consuming [xref]a[/xref]locust, / And their labor to the swarming locust.
And He killed their vines with [xref]a[/xref]hail, / And their sycamores with [note]1[/note]ice stones.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew term is uncertain.

verse.text: He gave over their [xref]a[/xref]cattle also to the hail / And their herds to the lightning bolts.
He sent among them the burning fierceness of His anger, / Overflowing wrath and indignation and trouble, / A mission of angels of evils.
He leveled a path for His anger; / He did not spare their soul from death, / But gave their life over to the [xref]a[/xref]pestilence.
And He [xref]a[/xref]struck all the firstborn in Egypt, / The firstfruits of their vigor in the tents of Ham.
But He set forth His people like sheep / And led them like a [xref]a[/xref]flock in the wilderness.
And He led them to safety, so that they did not fear; / But the sea [xref]a[/xref]covered their enemies.
And He brought them forth to His holy border, / The [xref]a[/xref]mountain, which His right hand had acquired.
And He [xref]a[/xref]drove out the nations before them / And allotted them as an [xref]b[/xref]inheritance by line, / And He made the tribes of Israel dwell [i]there[/i] in their tents.
Yet they put [i]Him[/i] to the test and rebelled against God the Most High, / And did not keep His testimonies.
And they turned back and dealt treacherously, as their fathers [i]had done;[/i] / They turned aside like a deceitful bow.
Indeed they provoked Him to anger with their [xref]a[/xref]high places / And made Him [xref]b[/xref]jealous with their graven images.
God heard, and He was angered; / And He greatly abhorred Israel.
Thus He forsook the tabernacle in [xref]a[/xref]Shiloh, / The tent [i]in which[/i] He dwelt among men;
And He gave over His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ark into captivity, / And His [note]2[/note]glory into the hand of the adversary.
verse.note: Lit., strength. This refers to the capture of the Ark by the Philistines before the temple was built ([link]1 Sam. 4[/link]).
Or, beauty.

verse.text: He also delivered His people to the sword / And was angry with His inheritance.
Fire devoured their young men, / And their virgins had no marriage song.
Their priests [xref]a[/xref]fell by the sword, / And their widows did not lament.
Then the Lord awoke as if from sleep, / Like a mighty man who shouts because of wine.
And He struck His adversaries [i]and sent them[/i] back; / He put an everlasting reproach upon them.
And He rejected the tent of Joseph, / And the tribe of Ephraim He did not choose.
Rather He [xref]a[/xref]chose the tribe of Judah, / Mount [xref]b[/xref]Zion, which He loved.
And He built His sanctuary like the heights, / Like the earth that He has founded forever.
Moreover He chose David His servant / And took him from the [xref]a[/xref]sheepfolds;
From following after the ewes He brought him / To [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]shepherd Jacob His people / And Israel His inheritance.
verse.note: Or, pasture, feed. So also in the next verse. Here David ([link]v. 70[/link]) is a type of Christ as the Shepherd of God's people ([link]Matt. 2:6[/link]; [link]John 10:11[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:20[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:25[/link]; [link]5:4[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Psa. 23[/link]. In the restoration of God's people there is always the shepherding, the feeding, of Christ.

verse.text: And he shepherded them according to the integrity of his heart, / And guided them by the skillfulness of his hands.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph
O God, the [xref]a[/xref]nations have come into Your inheritance; / They have defiled Your holy temple; / They have turned [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem into heaps.
They have given the [xref]a[/xref]dead bodies of Your servants / As food for the birds of heaven, / The flesh of Your saints to the animals of the earth.
They have poured out their blood like water around Jerusalem, / And there was no one to bury [i]them.[/i]
We have become a reproach to our neighbors, / A mocking and a derision to those around us.
How long, O Jehovah? Will You be angry forever? / Will Your [xref]a[/xref]jealousy burn like fire?
[xref]a[/xref]Pour out Your wrath upon the nations / Who do [xref]b[/xref]not know You, / And upon the kingdoms / Who do not call upon Your name.
For they have devoured Jacob / And have desolated his habitation.
Do not remember against us the iniquities of [i]our[/i] forefathers; / May Your compassions quickly meet us, / For we have been brought very low.
Help us, O God of our salvation, / For the glory of Your name; / And deliver us and expiate our sins, / For Your name's sake.
Why should the nations say, / Where is their God? / May the [xref]a[/xref]avenging of the blood of Your servants, which has been poured out, / Be known among the nations in our sight.
May the sighing of the prisoner come before You. / According to the greatness of Your power preserve those appointed to die,
And render to our neighbors sevenfold into their bosom / Their reproach, with which they have reproached You, O Lord.
And we, Your people and the [xref]a[/xref]sheep of Your pasture, / Will give You thanks forever; / From generation to generation we will tell out Your praise.
To the choir director: according to [note]1[/note]shoshannim-eduth. [xref]a[/xref]Of Asaph. A Psalm
verse.note: Meaning [i]lilies, a testimony;[/i] it may refer to a melody common at the time.

verse.text: O [xref]a[/xref]Shepherd of Israel, give ear, / You who lead Joseph like a [xref]b[/xref]flock; / You who [xref]c[/xref]are enthroned [i]between[/i] the cherubim, shine forth.
Before Ephraim and Benjamin and Manasseh / Stir up Your might, / And come to save us.
O God, restore us; / And cause Your face to [xref]a[/xref]shine, and we will be saved.
O Jehovah God of hosts, / How long will You fume / Against the prayer of Your people?
You have fed them with the bread of tears / And have made them drink tears in large measure.
You have made us a cause of strife to our neighbors, / And our enemies deride [i]us[/i] among themselves.
O God of hosts, restore us; / And cause Your face to [xref]a[/xref]shine, and we will be saved.
You brought a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vine out of Egypt; / You [xref]b[/xref]drove out nations and planted it;
verse.note: In [link]vv. 8-13[/link] the psalmist speaks regarding God's dealing with Israel as His vine, which He brought out of Egypt and planted. Whereas the vine once was flourishing, it eventually became desolate (cf. [link]Isa. 5[/link]).

verse.text: You cleared [i]the ground[/i] before it, / And it took deep root and filled the land.
The mountains were covered with its shadow, / And its boughs were [i]like[/i] the cedars of God.
It put forth its branches unto the sea, / And its shoots unto the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]River.
verse.note: I.e., the Euphrates.

verse.text: Why have You broken down its [xref]a[/xref]hedges, / So that all who pass by on the way pluck it?
The boar from the forest ravages it, / And that which moves through the field feeds on it.
O God of hosts, turn, we beseech You; / Look down from heaven and see, / And [note]1[/note]visit this vine,
verse.note: In [link]vv. 14-19[/link] the psalmist asks God to visit His vine for the sake of Christ as the man of His right hand ([link]v. 17[/link]).

verse.text: Even the [xref]a[/xref]stock which Your right hand has planted / And the [note]1[/note]son whom You have strengthened for Yourself.
verse.note: The son here and in [link]v. 17[/link] is the Lord Jesus. [link]Hosea 11:1[/link] and [link]Matt. 2:15[/link] indicate that when Christ became a man, He, the Son of God, joined Himself to Israel. During the time Israel was forsaken by God, this unique One was strengthened by God for Himself.

verse.text: It is burned with fire; it is cut down; / They perish at the rebuke of Your countenance.
Let Your [xref]a[/xref]hand be upon the [note]1[/note]man of Your right hand, / Upon the [xref]b[/xref]son of man whom You have strengthened for Yourself;
verse.note: This man is Christ, who is at the right hand of God ([link]Mark 16:19[/link]; [link]Acts 2:33[/link]; [link]5:31[/link]), the highest place in the universe. God has given the first place, the highest position, the preeminence, in the entire universe to Christ. This is the exaltation of Christ ([link]Phil. 2:9-11[/link]). The way to be restored from desolation is to exalt Christ. Whenever God's people do not give Christ the preeminence, the house of God, signifying the church, becomes desolate. Whenever God's people exalt Christ, giving Him the preeminence in every aspect of their living, there is restoration ([link]v. 19[/link]) and revival ([link]v. 18[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 74[/link].

verse.text: Then we will not turn back from You. / Revive us, and we will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]call upon Your name.
verse.note: Christ is now at the right hand of God ([link]Rom. 8:34[/link]; [link]Col. 3:1[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 3:22[/link]), and whoever calls upon Him as such a One will be restored and revived ([link]Acts 2:33[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]Rom. 10:12-13[/link]).

verse.text: O Jehovah God of hosts, restore us; / Cause Your face to [xref]a[/xref]shine, and we will be saved.
To the choir director: on the [note]1[/note]gittith. [xref]a[/xref]Of Asaph
verse.note: See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 8[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Sing for joy to God our strength; / Make a [xref]a[/xref]joyful noise to the God of Jacob.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 81-83[/link] reveal God's intention to gain the earth for Christ's inheritance ([link]82:8[/link]) through His habitations, the local churches, and Satan's plot to possess God's habitation for himself and thus withhold the earth from God ([link]83:3[/link], [link]12[/link]).

verse.text: Lift up a song and sound the tambourine, / The pleasant lyre with the harp.
Blow the [xref]a[/xref]trumpet at the new moon, / At the full moon, on our feast day.
For that is a [note]1[/note]statute of Israel, / An ordinance of the God of Jacob.
verse.note: According to God's ordination Israel, God's elect, should live a joyful life (cf. [link]Phil. 4:4[/link]). The annual feasts, as well as the sabbatical year and the year of jubilee, are times of rejoicing, singing, and shouting ([link]Lev. 23[/link] and [link book="Lev."]25[/link], and notes).

verse.text: He appointed [i]it[/i] as a testimony in Joseph / When He went out over the land of Egypt. / I heard a language that I did not know:
I turned [note]1[/note]your shoulder from the [xref]a[/xref]burden; / Your hands were freed from the basket.
verse.note: Lit., his (twice).

verse.text: You called in trouble, and I delivered you; / I answered you from the secret place of thunder; / I proved you at the waters of [xref]a[/xref]Meribah. Selah
[xref]a[/xref]Hear, O My people, and I will testify [note]1[/note]against you: / O Israel, if you would listen to Me!
verse.note: Or, to.

verse.text: There shall be no [xref]a[/xref]strange god among you, / Neither shall you worship any [xref]b[/xref]foreign god.
I am [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah your God, / Who brought you up out of the land of Egypt; / Open your [xref]b[/xref]mouth wide, and I will fill it.
But My people did not listen to My voice, / And Israel would not consent to Me.
So I [xref]a[/xref]gave them over to the stubbornness of their heart: / They walked after their own counsels.
Oh that My people had listened to Me, / That Israel had walked in My ways!
I would have soon subdued their enemies / And turned My hand against their adversaries.
Those who hate Jehovah would have come cringing to Him, / And their time would be forever.
And He would have fed them with the finest of [xref]a[/xref]wheat; / Indeed with [xref]b[/xref]honey from the rock I would have satisfied you.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph
God stands in the congregation of God; / He [xref]a[/xref]judges in the midst of the [note]1[/note]gods.
verse.note: Or, judges; Heb. [i]elohim.[/i] So also in [link]v. 6[/link].

verse.text: How long will you judge unjustly / And respect the persons of the wicked? Selah
Judge the poor and the orphan; / Execute justice for the afflicted and the destitute;
Rescue the poor and the needy; / Deliver [i]them[/i] from the hand of the wicked.
[note]1[/note]You do not know, nor do you understand; / You go about in darkness; / All the foundations of the earth are shaken.
verse.note: Lit., they (three times).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I said, You are gods, / And all of you are [xref]b[/xref]sons of the Most High.
Nevertheless you will die like men / And fall like one of the princes.
Arise, O God; [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]judge the earth; / For You will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]inherit all the nations.
verse.note: This is the aspiration of the psalmist for Christ to judge the earth and to inherit the nations. Christ is the One appointed to judge the earth ([link]John 5:22[/link]; [link]Acts 17:31[/link]) and the One worthy to inherit all the nations. See notes [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 75[/link] and [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 2[/link].

verse.text: A Song; a [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of Asaph
O God, do not keep silent; / Do not be quiet, and do not be still, O God.
For, behold, Your enemies are in tumult, / And those who hate You lift up [i]their[/i] heads.
They [note]1[/note]devise crafty counsel against Your people, / And conspire against Your [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]hidden ones.
verse.note: Satan's plot is to possess God's habitations, the local churches, for himself through the nations who conspire against God's hidden ones, the believers in Christ ([link]vv. 2-12[/link]).

Today we, the believers in Christ, are God's hidden ones, and the worldly people do not know us ([link]1 John 3:1[/link]). However, when the Lord Jesus comes back, the hidden ones will become the manifested ones ([link]Col. 3:3-4[/link]). Today is the time for us not to be manifested but to be hidden.

verse.text: They have said, Come and let us [xref]a[/xref]destroy them from [i]being[/i] a nation, / That the name of Israel may no longer be remembered.
For they have [xref]a[/xref]conspired together with one heart; / It is against You that they have made an alliance:
The tents of Edom and the Ishmaelites, / Moab and the Hagarites,
Gebal and Ammon and Amalek, / Philistia along with the inhabitants of Tyre;
Assyria is also joined with them; / They have been a help to the children of Lot. Selah
Do with them as with [xref]a[/xref]Midian, / As with [xref]b[/xref]Sisera and Jabin, at the brook Kishon:
They were destroyed at [xref]a[/xref]Endor; / They became dung for the earth.
Make their nobles like [xref]a[/xref]Oreb and Zeeb, / And all their princes like [xref]b[/xref]Zebah and Zalmunna,
Who said, Let us possess for ourselves / The habitations of God.
[note]1[/note]O my God, make them like a tumbleweed, / Like stubble before the wind.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1[/link] and [link]13-18[/link] the psalmist prayed that God would deal with the nations that they may know that God alone is the Most High over all the earth and that they may seek His name. These things will take place in the millennium, the time of restoration ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-22[/link]).

verse.text: Like fire that burns a forest / And like a flame that sets mountains on fire,
So pursue them with Your tempest, / And terrify them with Your storm.
Fill their faces with shame, / That they may seek Your name, O Jehovah.
May they be ashamed and dismayed forever, / And may they be confounded and perish;
That they may know that You alone, whose name is Jehovah, / Are the [xref]a[/xref]Most High over all the earth.
To the choir director: on the [note]1[/note]gittith. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A Psalm
verse.note: See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 8[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]How [note]1[/note]lovely are Your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]tabernacles, / O Jehovah of hosts!
verse.note: This psalm, concerning the psalmist's love for the house of God with Christ, follows the psalms on the stripping of God's seekers and the desolation of God's house, beginning with [link]Psa. 73[/link]. In the recovery and restoration ([link]Psa. 80[/link]) the loveliness and sweetness of God's house is intensified.[br][br]The intrinsic content of [link]Psa. 84[/link] is the secret revelation concerning the enjoyment of Christ as the incarnated Triune God, the God-man. The center of this secret revelation is the house of God ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]10[/link]), typified by the tabernacle ([link]Exo. 40:2-8[/link]) and the temple ([link]1 Kings 6:1-3[/link]; [link]8:3-11[/link]). Christ as the embodiment of the Triune God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]) is the fulfillment of the types of the tabernacle and the temple. This fulfillment commenced in His incarnation as the individual Christ ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:21[/link]) and will continue until it consummates in the New Jerusalem as the corporate Christ, the great God-man ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link], [link]22[/link]). The New Testament, from Matthew through Revelation, covers the entire span of the incarnation of the Triune God and is a record of the divine incarnation. The enjoyment of Christ as the incarnated Triune God in God's house is portrayed by the arrangement of the tabernacle and its furnishings (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter and notes [link book="Heb." chapter="9"]4[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 9[/link]).
See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: My soul [note]1[/note]longs, indeed even [note]1[/note]faints, / For the [xref]a[/xref]courts of Jehovah; / My heart and my flesh cry out / To the living God.
verse.note: The psalmist's longing and even fainting to be in God's tabernacles indicates to what extent the psalmist loved God's tabernacles. This love was matured through many trials.

verse.text: At Your [note]1[/note][i]two[/i] altars even the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]sparrow has found a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]home; / And the [note]2[/note]swallow, a [note]3[/note]nest for herself, / Where she may lay her young, / O Jehovah of hosts, my [xref]c[/xref]King and my God.
verse.note: The bronze altar for the sacrifices and the golden altar of incense. The two altars signify the leading consummations of the work of the incarnated Triune God, who is Christ as the embodiment of God for His increase. The mentioning of these two altars together in [link]Exo. 40:5-6[/link] indicates that they are closely related in our spiritual experience. At the bronze altar, a type of the cross of Christ, our problems before God are solved through the crucified Christ as the sacrifices. This qualifies us to enter into the tabernacle, a type of Christ as the incarnated and enterable Triune God, and to contact God at the incense altar. At the golden altar of incense in front of the Holy of Holies (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 9[/link]), the resurrected Christ in His ascension is the incense for us to be accepted by God in peace. Through our prayer at the incense altar we enter into the Holy of Holies — our spirit ([link]Heb. 10:19[/link]) — where we experience Christ as the Ark of the Testimony with its contents. Through such an experience of Christ we are incorporated into the tabernacle, the incarnated Triune God, to become a part of the corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]) as God's testimony for His manifestation. See notes [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link] and [link]33[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Jer. 31[/link].
Signifying the believers, who are small and frail.

A home is a place of rest, and a nest is a place of refuge. Through the two altars God's redeemed can find a nest as their refuge and a home with God in rest. The cross of Christ, typified by the bronze altar, is our "nest," our refuge, where we are saved from our troubles and where we "lay" our young, i.e., produce new believers through the preaching of the gospel. When we experience the resurrected Christ in His ascension, typified by the golden altar of incense, we are accepted by God in such a Christ and find a home, a place of rest, in the house of God. This house is the processed and consummated Triune God united, mingled, and incorporated with all His redeemed, regenerated, and transformed elect ([link]John 14:1-23[/link]) to be the Body of Christ in the present age and the New Jerusalem as the mutual dwelling place of God and His redeemed in eternity ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link], [link]22[/link]).

verse.text: Blessed are those who [xref]a[/xref]dwell in Your [note]1[/note]house; / They will yet be praising You. Selah
verse.note: In type, the house is the church as a totality ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]), and the tabernacles ([link]v. 1[/link]) are the local churches ([link]Rev. 1:11[/link]).

verse.text: Blessed is the man whose strength is in You, / In whose heart are the [note]1[/note]highways [i]to Zion.[/i]
verse.note: The highways to Zion signify our intention to enter into the church as the house of God and to seek the incarnated Triune God in His consummations, typified by the furniture in the tabernacle (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter and note [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 9[/link]). On the one hand, we have entered into God; on the other hand, we are still on the highways to enter into God. That the highways are in our heart means that we need to take the way of the church internally, not merely externally.

verse.text: Passing through the valley of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Baca, / They make it a [note]2[/note]spring; / Indeed the [note]3[/note]early rain covers it with blessings.
verse.note: Meaning weeping. On the one hand, those on the highways to Zion are strengthened in God ([link]v. 5[/link]); on the other hand, they are opposed by Satan, who causes them to suffer persecution. The trouble and persecution caused by Satan can make the highway a valley of weeping. This special term indicates that the psalmist had been disciplined by God and had been stripped by Him (see notes [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 73[/link] and [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Job 3[/link]).

When we pass through the valley of Baca, God makes this valley a spring (cf. [link]Col. 1:24[/link]; [link]Heb. 10:34[/link]). This spring is the Spirit ([link]John 4:14[/link]; [link]7:38-39[/link]). The more we weep on the highways to Zion, the more we receive the Spirit. While we are weeping, we are being filled with the Spirit, and the Spirit becomes our spring.

Those who come into the church life by passing through the valley of weeping find that this weeping eventually becomes a great blessing to them. This blessing is the Spirit ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link]). The tears they shed are their own, but these tears issue in a spring, which becomes the early rain, the Spirit as the blessing.

verse.text: They go from strength to strength; / [i]Each[/i] [xref]a[/xref]appears before God in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zion.
verse.note: In the church as God's house, although we are on earth, we are nonetheless in the heavenly Zion ([link]Heb. 12:22[/link]). See notes [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Gen. 22[/link] and [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: O Jehovah God of hosts, hear my prayer; / Give ear, O God of Jacob. Selah
Behold our [note]1[/note]shield, O God; / And look upon the face of Your [note]1[/note]anointed.
verse.note: Referring to David the king, who typifies Christ as the shield to God's people and as God's Anointed.

verse.text: For a day in Your courts is better than a thousand; / I would rather stand at the threshold of the house of my God / Than dwell in the tents of the wicked.
For Jehovah God is a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sun and a [xref]b[/xref]shield; / Jehovah gives grace and glory; / He does not withhold anything good / From [note]2[/note]those who walk uprightly.
verse.note: The blessings of our dwelling in the house of God are our enjoyment of the incarnated and consummated Triune God as our sun to supply us with life ([link]John 1:4[/link]; [link]8:12[/link]), as our shield to protect us from God's enemy ([link]Eph. 6:11-17[/link]), as grace for our enjoyment ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]), and as glory for the manifestation of God in splendor ([link]Rev. 21:11[/link], [link]23[/link]).
Probably referring, in the complex sentiments of the psalmist, to those who keep God's law. See notes [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 18[/link] and [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 73[/link].

verse.text: O Jehovah of hosts, [xref]a[/xref]blessed is the [note]1[/note]man / Who trusts in You.
verse.note: Probably referring, also in the complex sentiments of the psalmist, to the man who dwells in God's house.

verse.text: To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A Psalm
[note]1[/note]You have been pleased, O Jehovah, with Your land; / You have [xref]a[/xref]turned the captivity of Jacob.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 85-89[/link] form a cluster. [link]Psalms 85[/link], [link book="Psa."]86[/link], and [link book="Psa."]88[/link] concern three matters: the restoration of God's people, personal salvation, and release from sufferings, respectively. These three matters have been the continual concern of God's people for centuries. According to the human concept, these matters are positive, but God does not regard these things as we do. [link]Psalms 87[/link] and [link book="Psa."]89[/link] reveal that God's concern, according to His heart, is Christ with Zion, in which are many saints and which is for the house of God and the city of God that Christ may possess the entire earth.

verse.text: You have [xref]a[/xref]forgiven the iniquity of Your people; / You have covered all their sin. Selah
You have taken away all Your wrath; / You have turned from the fierceness of Your anger.
[note]1[/note]Restore us, O God of our salvation, / And cause Your indignation toward us to cease.
verse.note: The subject of this psalm is the seeking of the sons of Korah for the restoration of Israel.

verse.text: Will You be angry with us forever? / Will You extend Your anger from generation to generation?
Will You not again [xref]a[/xref]revive us, / That Your people may rejoice in You?
Show us, O Jehovah, Your lovingkindness, / And grant us Your salvation.
I will hear what God Jehovah will speak, / For He will speak [xref]a[/xref]peace / To His people and to His faithful ones; / But let them not turn again unto folly.
Surely His salvation is near to those who fear Him, / That glory may dwell in our land.
Lovingkindness and truth have met together; / [xref]a[/xref]Righteousness and peace have kissed each other.
Truth has sprung forth from the earth, / And righteousness has looked down from heaven.
Indeed Jehovah will give what is [xref]a[/xref]good, / And our land will give its increase.
Righteousness will go before Him / And make His footsteps a way [i]to walk in.[/i]
A Prayer [xref]a[/xref]of David
[note]1[/note]Incline Your ear, O Jehovah; answer me; / For I am poor and needy.
verse.note: This psalm concerns David's seeking for his personal salvation. Salvation is not for ourselves. God saves people for His economy, for His Christ, for Zion, and for His house and His city in order that one day He might gain the entire earth through Christ with His overcomers. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 85[/link].

verse.text: Keep my soul; for I am faithful; / Save Your servant who trusts in You, O You [i]who are[/i] my God.
Be gracious to me, O Lord; / For to You do I call out all day long.
Cause the soul of Your servant to rejoice, / For unto You, O Lord, do I [xref]a[/xref]lift up my soul.
For You, O Lord, are good and ready to forgive / And abundant in lovingkindness to all who call upon You.
[xref]a[/xref]Give ear, O Jehovah, to my prayer, / And give heed to the voice of my supplications.
In the day of my distress I call upon You, / For You answer me.
There is none [xref]a[/xref]like You among the gods, O Lord; / Nor are there any works like Yours.
All the nations which You have made will come / And [xref]a[/xref]worship before You, O Lord; / And they will glorify Your name.
For You are great, and You do wondrous deeds; / You alone are God.
Teach me, O Jehovah, Your way; / I will walk in Your truth. / Make my heart single in fearing Your name.
I will praise You, O Lord my God, with all my heart; / And I will glorify Your name forever.
For Your lovingkindness is great toward me, / And You have delivered my soul from the lowest Sheol.
O God, the proud have risen up against me, / And a company of violent men seek my life; / And they do not [xref]a[/xref]set You before them.
But You, O Lord, are a [xref]a[/xref]compassionate and gracious God, / Long-suffering and abundant in lovingkindness and truth.
Turn to me and be gracious to me; / Give Your strength to Your servant, / And save the son of Your female servant.
Show me a token of goodness, / That those who hate me may see [i]it[/i] and be ashamed; / For You, O Jehovah, have helped me and comforted me.
[xref]a[/xref]Of the sons of Korah. A Psalm; a Song
His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]foundation is in the [xref]b[/xref]holy mountains.
verse.note: This divine foundation, typifying Christ as God's unique foundation for the building up of His house, the church ([link]1 Cor. 3:11[/link]), is built in the "holy mountains," which typify the local churches. Jerusalem was built on these holy mountains, and among these mountains the highest peak is the one on which Zion was built, which typifies the overcomers in the church. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]loves the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]gates of [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Zion / More than all the dwellings of Jacob.
verse.note: Gates are for coming in and going out, signifying fellowship. The fact that the New Jerusalem will have twelve gates ([link]Rev. 21:12[/link], [link]21[/link]) indicates that God's holy city will be full of fellowship.

This psalm concerns the desire of God for Zion with Christ. In both the Old Testament and the New Testament, Zion implies God's house and God's city. Zion is a poetic title of the church in both the universal sense and the local sense ([link]Heb. 12:22[/link]). The heavenly Zion is the final place of rest for the overcomers ([link]Rev. 14:1[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: Glorious things are spoken of you, / O [xref]a[/xref]city of God. Selah
I will make mention of [note]1[/note]Rahab and Babylon as those who know Me; / Behold, Philistia and Tyre along with [note]2[/note]Cush: / [note]3[/note]This one was born there, [i]they say.[/i]
verse.note: I.e., Egypt.
I.e., Ethiopia.
The people from the five places mentioned in this verse represent all the people on earth. The people in these places boast of the famous persons born there.

verse.text: But of [xref]a[/xref]Zion it will be said, / [note]1[/note]This one and that one were born in her, / And the Most High Himself will [xref]b[/xref]establish her.
verse.note: [i]This One[/i] in [link]v. 6[/link] (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link]) and [i]this one[/i] and [i]that one[/i] in this verse indicate that Christ Himself and all the saints were born in the heavenly Zion ([link]Matt. 1:20[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:26-31[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:22-23a[/link]). This is God's counting, God's record, concerning Zion ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah will count / When He records the peoples: / This [note]1[/note]One was born there. Selah
verse.note: The unique One, Christ, who is the totality of all the saints ([link]v. 5[/link]) as the One who is all the saints and in all the saints ([link]Col. 3:11[/link]). This psalm unveils Christ with all the saints to be God's house for God's city and for God to gain the whole earth.

verse.text: Then singing as well as dancing, [i]they will say,[/i] / All my [xref]a[/xref]springs are in [note]1[/note]you.
verse.note: I.e., the city of God.

verse.text: A Song; a [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of the sons of Korah. To the choir director: according to [note]1[/note]mahalath leannoth. A [note]2[/note]Maschil of Heman the Ezrahite.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is obscure. It may refer to the singing of a sad melody with a subdued voice.
See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: O Jehovah, the God of my [note]1[/note]salvation, / I have cried out [xref]a[/xref]by day and in the night before You.
verse.note: This psalm concerns the seeking of Heman, a son of Korah, for his release from sufferings. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 85[/link].

verse.text: May my prayer come before You; / Incline Your ear to my cry.
For my soul is full of troubles, / And my life draws near to Sheol.
I am accounted among those who go down into the pit; / I am like a man without any [note]1[/note]help,
verse.note: Or, strength.

verse.text: Abandoned among the dead, / Like the slain that lie in the grave, / Whom You remember no more, / And they are cut off from Your hand.
You have put me in the lowest pit, / In the dark places, in the depths.
Your wrath lies heavily upon me, / And You have afflicted me with all Your waves. Selah
You have put my acquaintances [xref]a[/xref]far from me; / You have made me an abomination to them. / I am shut in and cannot go out.
My eye wastes away at the affliction; / I have called out to You, O Jehovah, every day; / I have spread out my hands to You.
Will You perform wonders for the dead? / Will the [xref]a[/xref]deceased rise up [i]and[/i] praise You? Selah
Will Your lovingkindness be declared in the grave, / Or Your faithfulness in [note]1[/note]Abaddon?
verse.note: Meaning [i]destruction.[/i]

verse.text: Will Your wonders be made known in the darkness, / Or Your righteousness in the land of forgetfulness?
But I, O Jehovah, have cried out to You; / And in the morning my prayer comes before You.
Why, O Jehovah, have You rejected my soul? / [i]Why[/i] do You hide Your face from me?
I have been afflicted and about to die since my youth; / I bear Your terrors; I am [note]1[/note]overwhelmed.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint; the meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain.

verse.text: Your fierce wrath has gone over me; / Your terrors have cut me off.
They surrounded me like water all day long; / They altogether encompassed me.
You have put far from me / Lover and friend; / My acquaintances are [i]in[/i] darkness.
A [note]1[/note]Maschil of Ethan the Ezrahite
verse.note: See note on the superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I will sing of the lovingkindness of Jehovah forever; / From generation to generation I will make known Your faithfulness with / my mouth.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 89[/link], especially [link]vv. 3-4[/link], [link]19-29[/link], and [link]34-37[/link], unveils the intention of God that Christ, His Anointed, would possess the entire earth. In [link]vv. 19-20[/link] Christ, the unique One in God's record ([link]87:6[/link]), has become God's Holy One, God's mighty One, God's anointed One ([link]Acts 2:27[/link]; [link]Isa. 9:6[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:16[/link]). He calls God His Father and His God ([link]v. 26[/link]; [link]John 20:17[/link]). He has become the Firstborn and "the highest of the kings of the earth" ([link]v. 27[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5a[/link]). His throne will be like the sun before God; it will be established forever like the moon ([link]vv. 36-37[/link]; [link]72:5[/link]). God will establish His seed forever and "His throne as the days of heaven" ([link]v. 29[/link]). God will extend the territory of this unique One so that He will possess the entire earth, setting "His hand on the sea and His right hand on the rivers" ([link]v. 25[/link]; cf. [link]Rev. 10:1-2[/link]). The sea probably refers to the Mediterranean Sea, the center of the populated earth. That Christ's territory will be extended to all the rivers indicates that Christ will possess all the parts of the earth, signified by their rivers; that is, He will possess the whole earth ([link]2:8[/link]).
