Both Book Two and Book Three end with the extension of God's kingdom to the whole earth ([link]72:8[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]89:25[/link], [link]27[/link]).

verse.text: For I have said, Lovingkindness will be built up forever; / In the heavens themselves You will establish Your faithfulness.
I have made a [xref]a[/xref]covenant with My chosen one; / I have [xref]b[/xref]sworn to David My servant:
I will establish your seed [xref]a[/xref]forever, / And I will build up your throne from generation to generation. Selah
And the heavens will praise Your wonders, O Jehovah, / Indeed Your faithfulness in the congregation of the holy ones.
For who in the skies can be compared to Jehovah? / [i]Who[/i] among the sons of the mighty is like Jehovah,
[i]Like[/i] God, greatly feared in the council of the holy ones / And awesome beyond all around Him?
O Jehovah God of hosts, who is [xref]a[/xref]like You, the mighty [note]1[/note]Jah? / Your faithfulness also surrounds You.
verse.note: A shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]

verse.text: You rule the swelling of the sea: / When its waves rise up, You [xref]a[/xref]still them.
You crushed [note]1[/note]Rahab like one slain; / You [xref]a[/xref]scattered Your enemies with the arm of Your strength.
verse.note: I.e., Egypt.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]heavens are Yours; the [xref]b[/xref]earth also is Yours; / The [xref]c[/xref]world and its fullness You have founded.
You created the north and the south; / Tabor and Hermon shout for joy at Your name.
You have an arm with might; / Your [xref]a[/xref]hand is strong; Your right hand is high.
[xref]a[/xref]Righteousness and justice are the [note]1[/note]foundation of Your throne; / Lovingkindness and truth go before Your face.
verse.note: Righteousness and justice, two of the main attributes of God's divine nature, are the foundation of God's throne. This corresponds with the fact that the foundation of God's throne in the New Jerusalem is pure gold, signifying God's nature in the attributes of righteousness and justice ([link]Rev. 21:18b[/link]; [link]22:1[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Isa. 32[/link].

verse.text: Blessed are the people who know the joyful shout; / They walk, O Jehovah, in the [xref]a[/xref]light of Your countenance.
In Your name they exult all day long, / And in Your righteousness they are exalted.
For You are the [note]1[/note]glory of their strength, / And in Your favor our horn is exalted.
verse.note: Or, beauty.

verse.text: For our shield belongs to Jehovah, / And our king, to the Holy One of Israel.
Then You spoke in vision / Of [xref]a[/xref]Your [note]1[/note]Holy One, and You said, / I have given help to One who is mighty; / I have exalted One chosen from My people.
verse.note: Some MSS read, holy ones.

verse.text: I have [xref]a[/xref]found [note]1[/note]David My Servant; / With My holy oil I have [xref]b[/xref]anointed Him,
verse.note: Referring to Christ, typified here by David (cf. [link]Jer. 30:9[/link]; [link]Ezek. 34:23[/link]; [link]Hosea 3:5[/link]; [link]Amos 9:11[/link]).

verse.text: With whom My hand will be established; / My arm will also strengthen Him.
The enemy will not exact [i]anything[/i] from Him, / Nor will the son of wickedness afflict Him.
And I will crush His adversaries before Him, / And I will strike those who hate Him.
And My faithfulness and My lovingkindness will be with Him, / And in My name His horn will be exalted.
And I will set His hand on the [xref]a[/xref]sea / And His right hand on the rivers.
He will call upon Me, [i]saying,[/i] You are My [xref]a[/xref]Father, / My God and the [xref]b[/xref]rock of My salvation.
I will also make Him the [xref]a[/xref]Firstborn, / The [xref]b[/xref]highest of the kings of the earth.
I will keep My lovingkindness for Him forever, / And My covenant will stand firm with Him.
And I will establish His [xref]a[/xref]seed forever, / And His [xref]b[/xref]throne as the days of heaven.
If His [xref]a[/xref]children forsake My law / And do not walk in My ordinances,
If they profane My statutes / And do not keep My commandments,
I will punish their transgression with a rod / And their iniquity with stripes.
But My lovingkindness I will not utterly take away from Him, / Nor will I be false to My own faithfulness.
I will not profane My covenant, / Nor will I change what has gone forth from My lips.
Once I have sworn by My holiness; / I will not lie to David.
His [xref]a[/xref]seed shall endure forever, / And His throne, like the sun before Me;
It shall be established forever like the moon; / And the witness in the skies is firm. Selah
But You have [xref]a[/xref]cast off and rejected; / You have been angry with Your anointed.
You have abhorred the covenant of Your servant; / You have profaned his crown [i]by casting it[/i] to the ground.
You have broken down all his walls; / You have brought his strongholds to ruin.
All who pass by on the way plunder him; / He has become a reproach to his neighbors.
You have exalted the right hand of his adversaries; / You have caused all his enemies to rejoice.
Indeed You have turned back the edge of his sword / And have not made him stand in the battle.
You have made his brightness cease / And have cast down his throne to the ground.
You have shortened the days of his youth; / You have covered him with shame. Selah
How long, O Jehovah? Will You hide Yourself forever? / [i]How long[/i] will Your wrath burn like fire?
Remember how short my time is — / For what vanity You have created all the sons of men!
What man will live and not see death? / Will he deliver his soul from the power of Sheol? Selah
Where are Your former acts of lovingkindness, O [note]1[/note]Lord, / Which You [xref]a[/xref]swore to David in Your faithfulness?
verse.note: Many MSS read, Jehovah.

verse.text: Remember, O Lord, the reproach of Your servants, / How I bear in my bosom [i]the reproach of[/i] all the mighty peoples,
With which Your enemies have reproached, O Jehovah, / With which they have reproached the footsteps of Your anointed.
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed be Jehovah forever. / [xref]b[/xref]Amen and Amen.
A Prayer of Moses, the [xref]a[/xref]man of God
O Lord, You have been our [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dwelling place / In all generations.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 90-92[/link] concern the saints' deeper experience of God in their being identified with Christ. [link]Psalm 36:8[/link] speaks of drinking the river of God's pleasures and eating the fatness of God's house, indicating that we can experience the Lord by eating and drinking Him (cf. [link]John 6:48-58[/link], [link]63[/link]; [link]7:37[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:3-4[/link]; [link]12:13[/link]). According to Moses, the giver of the law and the writer of this psalm, we can also dwell in the eternal Triune God as our Lord ([link]v. 1[/link]; [link]91:9[/link]; [link]Deut. 33:27[/link]; cf. [link]John 15:4[/link]; [link]1 John 4:15-16[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:22[/link]). To dwell in God is to have our living in God ([link]Col. 2:6[/link]; [link]3:3[/link]; [link]1 John 4:16[/link]), taking Him as our everything. This is deeper than eating and drinking Him. To take God as our habitation, our eternal dwelling place, is the highest and fullest experience of God.[br][br]Book Four of the Psalms unveils the saints' deeper experience of God in the identification with Christ, and God's recovery of His title and right over the earth. This indicates that our experience of dwelling in God paves the way for Christ to come to possess the earth that God may recover His title (ownership) and right over the earth (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 93[/link]). Without the saints' deeper experience of God, God has no way to recover this title and right.

verse.text: Before the [xref]a[/xref]mountains were brought forth, / And [i]before[/i] You gave birth to the earth and the world, / Indeed from [xref]b[/xref]eternity to eternity, You are God.
You return man to [xref]a[/xref]dust / And say, Return, you sons of men.
For a [xref]a[/xref]thousand years in Your sight / Are like yesterday when it passes by / And [i]like[/i] a watch in the night.
You sweep them away as with a rain flood; they are [i]as in[/i] a sleep: / In the morning [i]they are[/i] like [xref]a[/xref]grass that comes up anew.
In the morning it flourishes and comes up anew; / In the evening it is cut down, and it dries up.
For we have been consumed by Your anger, / And by Your wrath we have been troubled.
You have set our iniquities before You, / Our secret [i]sins[/i] in the light of Your countenance.
For all our days have passed away in Your overflowing wrath; / We bring our years to an end like a sigh.

The [note]1[/note]days of our years are [xref]a[/xref]seventy years, / Or, if because of strength, [xref]b[/xref]eighty years; / But their pride is labor and sorrow, / For it is soon [xref]c[/xref]gone, and we fly away.
verse.note: If we take God as our dwelling place, we will realize that the span of our life on earth is brief and is full of sins and afflictions ([link]vv. 3-11[/link]). We need to dwell in God, living in Him every minute, for outside of Him there are sins and afflictions ([link]v. 8[/link]; [link]John 16:33[/link]).

verse.text: Who knows the power of Your anger, / And Your overflowing wrath according to the fear that is due You?
Teach us then to [xref]a[/xref]number our days / That we may gain a heart of wisdom.
Return, O Jehovah! How long? / And repent concerning Your servants.
Satisfy us in the [xref]a[/xref]morning with Your lovingkindness / That we may give a ringing shout and rejoice all our days.
Cause us to rejoice according to the days that You have afflicted us, / [i]According to[/i] the years that we have seen evil.
Let Your work appear to Your servants, / And Your splendor, to their children.
And let the [note]1[/note]favor of the Lord our God be upon us, / And establish the work of our hands upon us; / Indeed the work of our hands, establish it.
verse.note: Or, beauty.

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note]dwells in the [xref]a[/xref]secret place of the Most High / Will abide in the [xref]b[/xref]shadow of the [note]2[/note]Almighty.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 91[/link] concerns the saints' identification with Christ in His taking God as His dwelling place (see note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link]). In their identification with Christ, the saints make Jehovah the Most High their habitation, dwelling in His secret place and abiding in His shadow under His wings ([link]vv. 1-9[/link]). This is the genuine oneness with God. Here, we are constituted with Him, and we and God live together as one.
Heb. [i]Shaddai.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Gen. 17[/link].

verse.text: I say of Jehovah, / My [xref]a[/xref]refuge and My fortress, / My God in whom I trust!
For He will deliver You / From the snare of the fowler, / From the deadly pestilence.
With His pinions He will cover You, / And under His [xref]a[/xref]wings You will [xref]b[/xref]take refuge; / His truth is a shield and a buckler.
You will not be afraid of the terror by night, / [i]Or[/i] of the arrow that flies by day,
[i]Or[/i] of the pestilence that walks in darkness, / [i]Or[/i] of the destruction that lays waste at noon.
A thousand will fall at Your side, / And ten thousand at Your right hand; / [i]But[/i] it will not come near to You.
You will only look on with Your eyes / And see the recompense of the wicked.
For [note]1[/note]You have made Jehovah, [i]who is[/i] my [xref]a[/xref]refuge, / [i]Even[/i] the Most High, [note]1[/note]Your [xref]b[/xref]habitation,
verse.note: [i]You[/i] and [i]Your[/i] in [link]vv. 9-13[/link] refer to Christ, as proven by the fact that [link]vv. 11-12[/link] of this psalm are quoted by Satan in [link]Matt. 4:6[/link] in reference to Christ. This indicates that in this psalm it is Christ who takes God as His habitation, His dwelling place. Thus, not only Moses took God as his dwelling place ([link]90:1[/link]), but even the Lord Jesus, while He was on earth, took God the Father as His habitation. Moses, the lawgiver, and Christ, the grace-giver, were the same in taking God as their dwelling place, as their habitation. Thus, the saints (represented by Moses) and Christ are identified as one.[br][br]To be identified with Christ is to be identified with Him not only in His death, in His resurrection, and in His ascension but also in His taking God as His habitation. If we would be identified with Christ in His death, resurrection, and ascension, we need to abide in Christ ([link]John 15:4[/link]), and to abide in Christ is not only to remain in Him but also to dwell in Him, taking Him as our everything.

verse.text: No evil will befall You, / Nor will any plague come near Your tent.
[xref]a[/xref]For He will give His [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]angels charge concerning You / To keep You in all Your ways.
verse.note: In the identification with Christ, we are under the preserving care of the angels ([link]Matt. 4:11[/link]; [link]Acts 12:7-10[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:13-14[/link]) and are protected from Satan and the evil spirits ([link]v. 13[/link] and note).

verse.text: They will bear You up in their hands, / Lest You dash Your foot against a stone.
You will tread upon the [note]1[/note]lion and the [note]1[/note]cobra; / You will trample the young lion and the [xref]a[/xref]serpent.
verse.note: Here Satan is likened to a lion that devours God's people ([link]1 Pet. 5:8[/link]) and a serpent that poisons God's people ([link]Rev. 12:9[/link]).

verse.text: Because [note]1[/note]He has set His love upon Me, I will rescue Him; / I will set Him on high, because He has known My name.
verse.note: [i]He, Him,[/i] and [i]His[/i] in [link]vv. 14-16[/link] also refer to Christ (cf. note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link]). These verses are a prophecy concerning Christ. Christ loved God the Father ([link]John 14:31[/link]); He has been set on high, exalted to the highest place in the heavens ([link]Phil. 2:9-11[/link]); and He is now seeing God's salvation in the extension of His days in resurrection ([link]v. 16[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:18a[/link]). In all these matters we should be identified with Christ. Then we will live with Him and love God. Thus, we will be exalted, and we will see God's salvation in the extension of our days.

verse.text: He will call upon Me, and I will answer Him. / I will be with Him in distress; / I will deliver Him and honor Him.
With an [xref]a[/xref]extension of [i]His[/i] days I will satisfy Him, / And I will show Him My salvation.
A Psalm; a Song for the Sabbath day
It is good to [note]1[/note]give thanks to Jehovah / And to sing psalms to Your name, O Most High;
verse.note: [link]Psalm 92[/link] shows the issue of the deeper experience of God in the saints' identification with Christ in taking God as their dwelling place ([link]Psa. 90-91[/link]). The first issue is that the saints rejoice in the great works of Jehovah ([link]vv. 1-9[/link]). When we dwell in God, taking Him as our habitation, we see His great works in the accomplishing of His economy and rejoice in them (see note [link]4[sup]4[/sup] in Psa. 45[/link]).

verse.text: To [xref]a[/xref]declare Your lovingkindness in the [xref]b[/xref]morning / And Your faithfulness in the nights,
Upon an instrument of ten strings and upon a harp, / Upon the [note]1[/note]higgaion of the lyre.
verse.note: Referring perhaps to a resounding musical swell or to a meditative choral pause.

verse.text: For You have made me rejoice, O Jehovah, because of what You have done; / Because of the works of Your hands I will shout for joy.
How great are Your works, O Jehovah! / So very deep are Your thoughts!
A senseless man does not know [i]them,[/i] / Nor does a fool understand [note]1[/note]them.
verse.note: Lit., this.

verse.text: When the wicked sprout like grass, / And all the workers of iniquity blossom, / It is so that they may be destroyed forever.
But You are on high forever, O Jehovah.
For behold, Your enemies, O Jehovah; / For behold, Your enemies will perish; / All the workers of iniquity will be scattered.
But You have exalted my [note]1[/note]horn like that of a wild ox; / I am [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]anointed with fresh oil.
verse.note: Before we dwell in God as our habitation, we may be low and frequently defeated. A further issue of our dwelling in God is that our horn (fighting strength) is exalted over our spiritual enemies ([link]Eph. 6:10-13[/link]).

Or, mingled; the same word is used in [link]Lev. 2:4[/link] (see note 3 there). Another issue of our dwelling in God as our habitation is our being mingled with fresh oil, which signifies the consummated Spirit ([link]Exo. 30:23-25[/link] and note [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link]), who is fresh and present.

verse.text: And my eye has seen [i]its desire[/i] for my enemies; / My ears have heard [i]their desire[/i] for the evildoers who rise up against me.
The righteous man will [note]1[/note]flourish like the [xref]a[/xref]palm tree; / He will grow like a cedar in Lebanon.
verse.note: Still another issue of our dwelling in God, taking Him as everything in our living in His house, is that we are securely planted in His house and flourish in the riches of His divine life to such an extent that we bear fruit even in old age ([link]vv. 12-14[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Planted in the house of Jehovah, / They will flourish in the [xref]b[/xref]courts of our God.
They will still bring forth fruit in old age; / They will be [xref]a[/xref]full of sap and green;
To declare that Jehovah is upright; / [i]He is[/i] my [xref]a[/xref]rock, and there is [xref]b[/xref]no unrighteousness in Him.

Jehovah [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reigns; He is [xref]b[/xref]clothed with majesty. / Jehovah is clothed, He has girded Himself, with strength. / Indeed the world has been [note]2[/note]established; it will not be moved.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 93-101[/link] are a cluster showing that God will recover His full title and right over the earth through the reign of Christ. God has the right over the earth because the earth with all its fullness — all the different peoples of all races and colors — was created by Him. Thus, He is the Possessor of the earth and holds the title deed. He has the full right to claim the earth, and He will do it through the reign of Christ (cf. [link]Psa. 2:8[/link]; [link]Rev. 10:2[/link]; [link]11:15[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 90[/link].

Apart from the reign of Christ the earth is easily shaken. When God recovers His title and right over the earth through the reign of Christ, the earth will no longer be shaken but will be established.

verse.text: Your [xref]a[/xref]throne is established from of old; / You are from eternity.
The floods have lifted up, O Jehovah; / The floods have lifted up their voice; / The floods lift up their roaring.
More than the voices of many waters, / [i]Than[/i] the mighty breakers of the sea, / Jehovah on high is mighty!
Your testimonies are very sure; / Holiness befits Your house, / O Jehovah, forevermore.
O God of vengeance, O Jehovah, / O God of vengeance, [note]1[/note]shine forth!
verse.note: [link]Psalm 94[/link] reveals that Christ will execute His judgment over the world. When Christ reigns, He will shine, and this shining will be His vengeance executed over the unjust world.

verse.text: Lift Yourself up, O [xref]a[/xref]Judge of the earth; / Render the reward upon the proud.
How long, O Jehovah, will the wicked, / How long will the wicked exult?
They burst out; they speak arrogantly; / All the workers of iniquity boast.
They crush Your people, O Jehovah, / And afflict Your inheritance.
They slay the widow and the stranger, / And they murder orphans.
And they say, [note]1[/note]Jehovah does [xref]a[/xref]not see, / And the God of Jacob does not consider.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah;[/i] a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i] So also in [link]v. 12[/link].

verse.text: Consider, you senseless ones among the people; / And you foolish ones, when will you become wise?
He who planted the [xref]a[/xref]ear, does He not hear? / And He who formed the eye, does He not see?
He who [note]1[/note]disciplines the nations, / He who teaches man knowledge, does He not reprove?
verse.note: When Christ reigns, He will discipline the nations much like a father disciplines his children. Cf. [link]Heb. 12:5-11[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah knows the thoughts of man, / That they are vanity.
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed is the man / Whom You [xref]b[/xref]discipline, O Jehovah, / And teach out of Your law;
That You may give him rest from the days of evil / Until the pit is dug for the wicked.
For Jehovah will [xref]a[/xref]not abandon His people, / Nor will He forsake His inheritance.
For judgment will [note]1[/note]return unto righteousness, / And all the upright in heart will follow it.
verse.note: This indicates that on earth today judgment has gone astray from righteousness; but when Christ comes back to reign, He will bring in justice and will cause judgment to return to righteousness. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Isa. 32[/link].

verse.text: Who will rise up for me against the evildoers? / Who will stand up for me against the workers of iniquity?
Unless Jehovah had been my help, / My soul would have soon dwelt in silence.
When I said, My foot has slipped, / Your lovingkindness, O Jehovah, upheld me.
When my disquieting thoughts within me are many, / Your comfortings delight my soul.
Shall the seat of destruction be united with You, / Which devises trouble through [i]its[/i] statutes?
They band together against the soul of the righteous man / And condemn innocent blood.
But Jehovah has been my high tower, / And my God the [xref]a[/xref]rock of my [xref]b[/xref]refuge;
And He will return their iniquity upon them / And destroy them in their own evil; / Jehovah our God will destroy them.
Come, let us sing for joy to Jehovah; / Let us make a [xref]a[/xref]joyful noise to the [xref]b[/xref]rock of our salvation.
Let us [xref]a[/xref]come before His presence with thanksgiving; / Let us make a joyful noise to Him with psalms.
For Jehovah is a [xref]a[/xref]great God / And a [note]1[/note]great [xref]b[/xref]King above all gods.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 95[/link] unveils that Jehovah as Christ is a great King who possesses the earth ([link]vv. 4-7[/link]).

verse.text: In His hand are the depths of the earth, / The heights of the mountains are His also.
The sea is His, and He made it; / And His hands formed the [xref]a[/xref]dry land.
Come, let us worship and bow down; / Let us kneel before Jehovah our [xref]a[/xref]Maker.
For He is our God, / And we are the people of His [xref]a[/xref]pasture / And the flock of His hand. / [xref]b[/xref]Today, if you hear His voice,
Do not [xref]a[/xref]harden your heart as at [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Meribah, / As in the day of [note]2[/note]Massah in the wilderness;
verse.note: Translated [i]provocation[/i] in the Septuagint (cf. [link]Heb. 3:8[/link]).
Translated [i]testing[/i] in the Septuagint (cf. [link]Heb. 3:8[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]When your fathers [xref]b[/xref]tested Me; / They tried Me, even though they had seen My work.
For [xref]a[/xref]forty years I loathed [i]that[/i] [xref]b[/xref]generation, / And I said, They are a people who go astray in heart; / And they do not know My [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]ways;
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 3[/link].

verse.text: Therefore I [xref]a[/xref]swore in My anger: / [xref]b[/xref]They shall by no means enter into My [note]1[/note]rest!
verse.note: Typifying Christ as the rest to God's people. See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].

verse.text: Sing to Jehovah a [xref]a[/xref]new song; / [xref]b[/xref]Sing to Jehovah, all the earth.
Sing to Jehovah, bless His name; / Proclaim His salvation from day to day.
Declare His glory among the [note]1[/note]nations, / His wondrous deeds among all the [note]2[/note]peoples.
verse.note: [link]Verses 3-13[/link] indicate that Jehovah as Christ will come to judge the earth, the world, and the peoples with righteousness and truth, and that He will reign over the nations.

The word [i]peoples[/i] in [link]vv. 3[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]7[/link], [link]10[/link], and [link]13[/link] indicates that people of every race and color will be judged by Christ in His reign over the nations (cf. [link]Matt. 25:31-46[/link]).

verse.text: For Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]great and much to be praised; / He is to be feared above all gods.
For all the [xref]a[/xref]gods of the peoples are idols, / But Jehovah made the heavens.
Majesty and splendor are before Him; / Strength and beauty are in His sanctuary.
[xref]a[/xref]Ascribe to Jehovah, O families of the peoples, / Ascribe to Jehovah, glory and strength;
Ascribe to Jehovah the glory of His name; / Bring an offering, and come into His courts.
Worship Jehovah in holy [note]1[/note]splendor; / Tremble before Him, all the earth.
verse.note: Or, adornment.

verse.text: Say among the nations, Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]reigns; / Indeed the world has been [note]1[/note]established; it will not be moved; / He will [xref]b[/xref]judge the peoples with equity.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Psa. 93[/link].

verse.text: Let the heavens rejoice and the [xref]a[/xref]earth be glad; / [xref]b[/xref]Let the sea and its fullness roar.
Let the field and all that is in it exult; / Then all the trees of the forest will sing for joy
[xref]a[/xref]Before Jehovah, for He is coming; / For He is coming to judge the earth; / He will [xref]b[/xref]judge the world with righteousness, / And the peoples with His truth.
Jehovah [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reigns! Let the earth be glad; / Let the many islands rejoice.
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 1-2[/link], [link]4-6[/link], [link]8-9[/link], and [link]11[/link], Jehovah as Christ will reign, and because of this the earth will be glad and rejoice.

verse.text: Clouds and [xref]a[/xref]deep darkness surround Him; / [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Righteousness and justice are the foundation of His throne.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 89[/link].

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]fire goes before Him / And burns up His adversaries all around.
His [xref]a[/xref]lightning illumines the world; / The earth sees and trembles.
The mountains [xref]a[/xref]melt like wax at the [xref]b[/xref]presence of Jehovah, / At the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.
The [xref]a[/xref]heavens declare His righteousness, / And all the peoples see His [xref]b[/xref]glory.
Let all who serve a graven image be ashamed, / Who make their boast in idols; / [xref]a[/xref]Worship Him, all you [note]1[/note]gods.
verse.note: Heb. [i]elohim;[/i] translated [i]angels[/i] in the Septuagint (cf. [link]Heb. 1:6[/link]; [link]Psa. 8:5[/link]).

verse.text: Zion hears and [xref]a[/xref]rejoices, / And the daughters of Judah are glad, / Because of Your judgments, O Jehovah.
For You, O Jehovah, are [xref]a[/xref]most high over all the earth; / You are exalted far above all gods.
O you who love Jehovah, hate evil! / He preserves the souls of His faithful ones; / He [xref]a[/xref]delivers them from the hand of the wicked.
Light is sown for the righteous man, / And rejoicing for the upright in heart.
Rejoice in Jehovah, O righteous ones; / And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]praise [note]2[/note]His holy memorial.
verse.note: Or, give thanks to.
I.e., His holy name.

verse.text: A Psalm
Sing to Jehovah a [xref]a[/xref]new song, / For He has done wonderful things. / His [xref]b[/xref]right hand and His holy [xref]c[/xref]arm / Have accomplished salvation for Him.
Jehovah has made His [xref]a[/xref]salvation known; / In the sight of the nations / He has revealed His [xref]b[/xref]righteousness.
He [xref]a[/xref]remembered His lovingkindness and His faithfulness / Toward the house of Israel; / All the ends of the earth have seen / The [xref]b[/xref]salvation of our God.
Make a [xref]a[/xref]joyful noise to Jehovah, all the earth; / Break forth, and sing for joy, and sing psalms.
Sing psalms to Jehovah with the lyre, / With the lyre and the sound of melody.
With trumpets and the sound of the horn / Make a [xref]a[/xref]joyful noise before the [xref]b[/xref]King, Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]Let the sea and its fullness roar, / The world and those who inhabit it.
Let the rivers clap [i]their[/i] hands; / Let the mountains sing for joy together
[xref]a[/xref]Before Jehovah, for He is coming / To judge the earth. / He will [xref]b[/xref]judge the world with righteousness / And the peoples with equity.
Jehovah [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reigns; let the peoples tremble. / He [xref]b[/xref]is enthroned [i]between[/i] the cherubim; let the earth shake.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 93[/link].

verse.text: Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]great in [xref]b[/xref]Zion, / And He is exalted over all the peoples.
Let them praise Your great and awesome name — / It is holy —
And the strength of the King, [i]who[/i] loves justice. / You have established equity; / You have executed / Justice and righteousness in Jacob.
Exalt Jehovah our God, / And worship at His [xref]a[/xref]footstool; / Holy is He.
[xref]a[/xref]Moses and [xref]b[/xref]Aaron among His priests, / And [xref]c[/xref]Samuel among those who [xref]d[/xref]called on His name — / They called out to Jehovah, / And He answered them.
In the [xref]a[/xref]pillar of cloud He spoke to them; / They kept His testimonies and the statute that He gave them.
O Jehovah our God, You answered them; / You were a forgiving God to them, / Yet One avenging their deeds.
Exalt Jehovah our God, / And worship on His [xref]a[/xref]holy mountain; / For holy is Jehovah our God.
A Psalm [note]1[/note]of thanksgiving
verse.note: Or, for the thank offering.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Make a [xref]a[/xref]joyful noise to Jehovah, all the earth.
verse.note: This psalm opens with a charge given to all the earth to make a joyful noise to Jehovah as Christ, the reigning One.

verse.text: Serve Jehovah with rejoicing; / [xref]a[/xref]Come before His presence with joyful singing.
Know that it is Jehovah who is God; / It is He who has [xref]a[/xref]made us and [note]1[/note]not we ourselves. / [i]We are[/i] His people and the [xref]b[/xref]sheep of His pasture.
verse.note: Others read, we are His.

verse.text: Enter His gates with thanksgiving, / His [xref]a[/xref]courts with praise; / Give thanks to Him; bless His name.
For Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]good; His lovingkindness is forever, / And His faithfulness is to all generations.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David. A Psalm
[note]1[/note]I will sing of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]lovingkindness and justice; / To You, O Jehovah, I will sing psalms.
verse.note: The [i]I[/i] here is David, a type of Christ, indicating that this word is the word spoken by Christ to God. In this psalm David, God's anointed, typifies Christ as the man anointed by God to reign over the earth for God.

Lovingkindness and justice will be the base of the reign and judgment of Christ, typified here by David. Therefore, this psalm unveils how Christ will reign over the earth with lovingkindness and justice and deal with all the wicked ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]8[/link]).

verse.text: I will give careful heed to the perfect way. / When will You come to me? / I will walk in the perfectness of my heart / Within my house.
I will not set anything base / Before my eyes; / I hate what those who turn aside do; / It will not cling to me.
A perverse heart will depart from me; / No evil will I know.
He who secretly slanders his neighbor, / Him I will destroy; / [i]He who is[/i] of a haughty look and a proud heart, / Him I will not tolerate.
My eyes are on the faithful of the land, / That they may abide with me; / He who walks in the perfect way, / He will minister to me.
He who practices deceit / Will not dwell within my house; / He who speaks lies will not be maintained / In my sight.
Morning by morning I will destroy / All the wicked of the land, / In order to cut off from the [xref]a[/xref]city of Jehovah / All the workers of iniquity.
A Prayer of an afflicted one, when he is fainting and pours out his complaint before Jehovah
O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]hear my [note]1[/note]prayer; / And let my cry come unto You.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 102-106[/link] form a group. The title of [link]Psa. 102[/link] indicates that it is a prayer of an afflicted one, one who was suffering. The psalmist, a godly one, was suffering because of the destruction and devastation of Zion with the temple and the holy city. This psalm has three sections: [link]vv. 1-11[/link], concerning suffering and affliction; [link]vv. 12-22[/link], concerning the rebuilding of Zion, the restoration of the destroyed temple and the holy city; and [link]vv. 23-28[/link], unveiling the Lord as the One who is everlasting in His resurrection. That this psalm concerns Christ is indicated by the fact that [link]vv. 25-27[/link] are quoted in [link]Heb. 1:10-12[/link].

verse.text: Do not hide Your face from me / On the day of my distress; / Incline Your ear to me; / On the day when I call out, answer me quickly.
For my days are consumed in [xref]a[/xref]smoke, / And my bones burn like a hearth.
My heart is stricken like grass and dried up; / Indeed I have [i]even[/i] forgotten to eat my bread.
Because of the voice of my groaning / My bones cling to my flesh.
I am like a [xref]a[/xref]pelican of the wilderness; / I have become like an owl of the desolate places.
I [xref]a[/xref]watch, and I am like / A lone [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sparrow on a housetop.
verse.note: The affliction of the psalmist refers to the affliction of Christ ([link]vv. 6-8[/link]). This verse is a particular verse concerning Christ's suffering, which was related to His zeal for God's house ([link]John 2:17[/link]; [link]Psa. 69:9[/link]). Here Christ is likened to a lone sparrow on a housetop, referring to the flat roof of a Jewish house, where people would often go to pray ([link]Acts 10:9[/link]). This indicates that when the Lord Jesus was on earth, probably there were times when in the night He, like a lone bird on a housetop, would watch and pray ([link]Matt. 14:23[/link]; [link]Luke 6:12[/link]), caring not for His own interest but for the interest of God and of God's house.[br][br]In typology, [link]Psa. 102[/link] first refers to Christ's suffering, especially to His death. Christ's suffering consummated in His death, and through His death the church, God's house, came into existence. Eventually, the church as God's house becomes God's city, God's kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:17[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:19[/link]).

verse.text: All day long my enemies reproach me; / Those who deride me use me as a curse.
For I have eaten ashes like bread, / And have mixed my drink with weeping,
Because of Your indignation and Your wrath; / For You have taken me up and cast me away.
My days are like a [xref]a[/xref]shadow that declines, / And I am dried up like [xref]b[/xref]grass.
[xref]a[/xref]But You, O Jehovah, abide forever; / And Your [xref]b[/xref]memorial is from generation to generation.
You will arise [i]and[/i] have compassion on [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zion, / For it is time to be gracious to her; the [xref]b[/xref]appointed time has come.
verse.note: This psalm unveils Christ's death and His existence in His resurrection ([link]vv. 23-28[/link] and note [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link]). The product of Christ's death and resurrection is the church, typified by Zion with God's house and God's city ([link]Gal. 4:26[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:22-23[/link]). Zion is the center of the city of Jerusalem ([link]vv. 16[/link], [link]21[/link]), and in this psalm it typifies the church as the center of God's kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link] and note [link]19[sup]2[/sup][/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: For Your servants take pleasure in her [xref]a[/xref]stones, / And show favor to her [note]1[/note]soil.
verse.note: In this verse the stones typify the believers as the building materials of the church ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]), and the dust, the soil, typifies the ground of the church. We should take pleasure in all the members of the church and should favor the ground of the church, which is the ground of oneness ([link]Deut. 12:5-28[/link]; [link]14:23-25[/link]; [link]John 17:11[/link], [link]21-23[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:10-13a[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:3-6[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:11[/link]).

verse.text: And the nations will fear the name of Jehovah, / And all the kings of the earth, Your glory;
For Jehovah has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]built up [xref]b[/xref]Zion; / He has appeared in His [xref]c[/xref]glory.
verse.note: Here the rebuilding of Zion typifies the rebuilding of the church. The history of Israel is a portrait of the history of the church ([link]1 Cor. 9:24-10:11[/link]). After existing on the earth for a time, Israel passed through a period of destruction and devastation, and the people of Israel were carried away to captivity in Babylon ([link]2 Kings 24-25[/link]). Likewise, the church was produced through Christ's death and in Christ's resurrection, and then it existed on earth for a time before it became degraded (see notes [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Tim. 1[/link], [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Pet. 1[/link], and [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 2[/link]) and was eventually devastated. The book of Revelation shows that Babylon the Great is versus the church ([link]Rev. 17:1-6[/link]). Eventually, Babylon the Great will fall ([link]Rev. 17:16[/link]; [link]18:2[/link]) and the church will be fully established ([link]Rev. 21:2-22:5[/link]).

verse.text: He has regarded the prayer of the destitute, / And has not despised their prayer.
This will be written for a generation to come, / And a people to be created will praise [note]1[/note]Jehovah.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah;[/i] a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]

verse.text: For He has [xref]a[/xref]looked down from the height of His sanctuary; / From heaven Jehovah beheld the earth,
To hear the groaning of the prisoner, / To release those appointed to die;
That the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]name of Jehovah may be declared in [xref]b[/xref]Zion, / And His praise, in Jerusalem,
verse.note: [link]Verses 21-22[/link] indicate that it is through the established, restored Zion (signifying the church) that all the nations and kingdoms will be brought into the praise and worship of Jehovah. The rebuilding of the devastated church, typified by the rebuilding of Zion ([link]v. 16[/link]), will turn all the nations to the Lord, and the kingdom of the world will become the kingdom of God and of Christ ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]).

verse.text: When the peoples are gathered together, / And the [xref]a[/xref]kingdoms, to serve Jehovah.
He has weakened my strength in the way; / He has shortened my days.
I said, My God, / Do not take me away in the middle of my days; / Your years are throughout all generations.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Of old You laid the [xref]b[/xref]foundation of the earth, / And the heavens are the [xref]c[/xref]work of Your hands.
verse.note: [link]Verses 25-27[/link], quoted in [link]Heb. 1:10-12[/link], speak of Christ's continuing existence in His resurrection. Christ is the key that turns the earth to the Lord because of His eternal and unchanging existence ([link]Rev. 1:18[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:8[/link]). Christ's suffering ([link]vv. 6-8[/link]) was for redemption, and His redemption was to produce the church as the house of God and the city of God ([link]John 19:34[/link] and note). It is in Christ's resurrection, by Christ's resurrection, and through Christ's resurrection that the church continues its existence and will consummate in the restoration ([link]vv. 12-22[/link]; [link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Acts 3:21[/link]), in which the entire earth with the peoples of all the nations will turn to the Lord ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]; [link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-22[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]They will perish, but You [xref]b[/xref]endure; / Indeed all of them will wear out like a [xref]c[/xref]garment; / Like clothing You will change them, / And they will be changed.
But You are the [xref]a[/xref]same, / And Your years are without end.
The children of Your servants will continue, / And their seed will be established before You.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bless Jehovah, O my soul; / And all that is within me, [i]bless[/i] His holy name.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 103-106[/link] are the praising of Jehovah, who has recovered the title and the right over the whole earth through the reign of Christ. In these four psalms there is a narration of God's history. This psalm speaks of God's history in His lovingkindness and compassions in His forgiving of sins, healing, redeeming, and caring for His people. This is the first part of God's history.

verse.text: Bless Jehovah, O my soul; / And do not forget all His benefits:
He [xref]a[/xref]pardons all your iniquities; / He [xref]b[/xref]heals all your diseases;
He redeems your life from the pit; / He crowns you with lovingkindness and compassions;
He satisfies the [note]1[/note]prime of your life with good, / [i]So that[/i] your youth is renewed like the [xref]a[/xref]eagle.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain; some translate, your years; others, your desires.

verse.text: Jehovah executes righteous acts, / And judgments for all who are oppressed.
He made His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ways known to Moses; / His [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]acts, to the children of Israel.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 3[/link]. To the experienced ones, such as Moses, God makes His ways known, and to the younger ones, to the children, He makes His acts known. Both God's ways and God's acts are benefits to us.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah is compassionate and gracious, / Long-suffering and abundant in lovingkindness.
[xref]a[/xref]He will not always contend [i]with us,[/i] / Nor will He keep His [xref]b[/xref][i]anger[/i] forever.
He has not dealt with us according to our [xref]a[/xref]sins, / Nor has He recompensed us according to our iniquities.
For as high as the heavens are above the earth, / So great is His lovingkindness upon those who fear Him.
As far as the east is from the west, / So far has He removed our [xref]a[/xref]transgressions from us.
As compassionate as a [xref]a[/xref]father is toward [i]his[/i] children, / So compassionate is Jehovah toward those who fear Him.
For He knows our frame; / He remembers that we are [xref]a[/xref]dust.
Man — his days are like [xref]a[/xref]grass; / He flourishes like a field [xref]b[/xref]flower:
For the wind passes over it, and it is no more; / And its own place knows of it no longer.
But Jehovah's lovingkindness is from eternity / Unto eternity upon those who fear Him, / And His righteousness is to the children's children;
To those who keep His covenant / And remember His precepts so as to do them.
Jehovah has established His [xref]a[/xref]throne in the heavens, / And His kingdom rules over all.
Bless Jehovah, you His angels, / Who are mighty in strength to perform His word, / By obeying the voice of His word.
Bless Jehovah, all you His hosts, / You His ministers who execute His will.
Bless Jehovah, all you His works, / In all places of His dominion. / Bless Jehovah, O my soul.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bless Jehovah, O my soul. / O Jehovah my God, You are very great. / You are clothed with majesty and splendor,
verse.note: [link]Psalm 104[/link] concerns God's greatness in the creation of the universe and all the things in it. This, too, is a part of God's history (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 103[/link]).

verse.text: Wrapped with [xref]a[/xref]light as with a garment; / You [xref]b[/xref]stretch out the heavens like a tent curtain.
He lays the beams of His upper chambers in the [note]1[/note]waters; / He makes the clouds His chariot; / He walks upon the wings of the wind.
verse.note: I.e., the upper waters above the expanse (cf. [link]Gen. 1:7[/link]).

verse.text: He makes [xref]a[/xref]winds His messengers, / Flames of fire His ministers.
He established the [xref]a[/xref]earth upon its foundations, / So that it cannot be moved forever and ever.
You covered it with the deep as with a garment; / The waters stood above the [xref]a[/xref]mountains.
At Your [xref]a[/xref]rebuke they fled; / At the voice of Your thunder they rushed away —
The [xref]a[/xref]mountains rose, the valleys sank — / To the place that You established for them.
You set a [xref]a[/xref]border that they may not pass over, / That they may not turn back to cover the earth.
He makes the [xref]a[/xref]springs gush forth in the valleys; / They run among the mountains;
They give drink to every beast of the field; / The wild asses quench their thirst.
The birds of heaven dwell alongside them; / They utter their voice among the branches.
He [xref]a[/xref]waters the mountains from His upper chambers. / The earth is satisfied with the fruit of Your works.
He causes the [xref]a[/xref]grass to grow for the cattle, / And [xref]b[/xref]herbage for man's use, / That he may bring forth food from the earth:
Even [xref]a[/xref]wine that cheers man's heart, / [xref]b[/xref]Oil that makes [i]his[/i] face shine, / And bread that sustains man's [xref]c[/xref]heart.
The trees of Jehovah are [xref]a[/xref]full [i]of sap,[/i] / The cedars of Lebanon, which He planted,
Where the birds build their nests; / As for the stork, the cypresses are her house.
The high mountains are for the wild goats; / The cliffs are a refuge to the rock badgers.
He made the moon to [i]mark[/i] [xref]a[/xref]seasons; / The [xref]b[/xref]sun knows [i]the time[/i] of its going down.
You make darkness, and it is night, / In which all the beasts of the forest creep about.
The young lions roar after their prey, / Even to seek their food from God.
The sun rises: they retreat / And lie down in their dens.
Man goes forth to his work / And to his [xref]a[/xref]labor until evening.
How many are Your works, O Jehovah! / In wisdom You have made all of them; / The earth is full of Your creatures.
Yonder is the sea, great and extensively wide; / There the creeping things are, even without number, / The small animals with the great.
There the ships go; / Leviathan is there, whom You have formed / To play in it.
They all wait for You, / That You may give them [xref]a[/xref]food at the proper time.
You give to them; they gather. / You open Your hand; they are satisfied with good.
You hide Your face; they are troubled. / You take away their breath; they perish, / And return to their [xref]a[/xref]dust.
You send forth Your [xref]a[/xref]Spirit; they are created, / And You renew the surface of the ground.
May the glory of Jehovah endure forever! / May Jehovah rejoice in His works,
He who looks on the earth, and it trembles; / He who touches the mountains, and they [xref]a[/xref]smoke!
[xref]a[/xref]I will sing to Jehovah while I live; / I will sing psalms to my God while I yet have being.
May my musing be sweet to Him; / I will rejoice in Jehovah.
May the sinners be consumed from off the earth, / And may the wicked be no more. / Bless Jehovah, O my soul. / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]praise Jah; Jah[/i] being a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 19[/link]. The praise of Jehovah in [link]Psa. 103-106[/link] issues in hallelujahs, beginning in this verse and continuing in [link]105:45[/link] and [link]106:1[/link], [link]48[/link], because the earth has been fully recovered by God and brought under Christ's dominion (cf. [link]Rev. 19:1-6[/link]; [link]11:15[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Give thanks to Jehovah; [xref]b[/xref]call upon His name; / Make known His deeds among the peoples.
Sing to Him; sing psalms to Him; / Muse upon all His wondrous deeds.
Glory in His holy name; / Let the heart of those who seek Jehovah rejoice.
[xref]a[/xref]Seek Jehovah and His strength; / [xref]b[/xref]Seek His face continually.
Remember His wondrous deeds, which He has done, / His signs and the judgments of His mouth,
O seed of Abraham His servant, / O children of Jacob, His chosen ones.
He is Jehovah our God; / His judgments are in all the earth.
He has remembered His [note]1[/note]covenant forever, / The word that He commanded to a thousand generations,
verse.note: [link]Psalm 105[/link] speaks of God in His dealing with Abraham and his descendants according to His covenant ([link]Gen. 15[/link]). This is another part of God's history (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 103[/link]).

verse.text: [i]The covenant[/i] that He made with [xref]a[/xref]Abraham, / And His oath unto [xref]b[/xref]Isaac.
And He confirmed it unto [xref]a[/xref]Jacob as a statute, / Unto Israel [i]as[/i] an eternal covenant,
Saying, To you I will [xref]a[/xref]give the land of Canaan, / The portion of your inheritance;
When they were men few in number, / Indeed very [xref]a[/xref]few and [xref]b[/xref]strangers in [note]1[/note]the land.
verse.note: Lit., it.

verse.text: And they went about from nation to nation, / From [i]one[/i] kingdom to another people.
He [xref]a[/xref]allowed no man to oppress them; / Indeed He [xref]b[/xref]rebuked kings for their sake.
[i]Saying,[/i] Do not touch My anointed ones, / And do My prophets no harm.
And He called a [xref]a[/xref]famine upon the land; / He broke the whole staff of bread.
He sent a man [xref]a[/xref]before them; / Joseph was [xref]b[/xref]sold as a servant.
They afflicted his feet with fetters; / He himself was [xref]a[/xref]placed in irons.
Until the time when his word [xref]a[/xref]came to pass, / The word of Jehovah tried him.
The king sent [i]men[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]freed him, / Even the ruler of the peoples, and let him go.
He made him lord of his house / And [xref]a[/xref]ruler over all his possessions,
To imprison his princes at will, / And to teach his elders wisdom.
Then Israel came into [xref]a[/xref]Egypt, / And Jacob sojourned in the land of Ham.
And He made His people very [xref]a[/xref]fruitful, / And caused them to be mightier than their adversaries.
He turned their heart to hate His people, / To deal [xref]a[/xref]craftily with His servants.
He [xref]a[/xref]sent Moses His servant, / [i]And[/i] Aaron, whom He had chosen.
[xref]a[/xref]They set His signs among them, / And wonders in the land of Ham.
He sent [xref]a[/xref]darkness and made it dark; / And they did not rebel against His words.
He turned their waters into [xref]a[/xref]blood, / And killed their fish.
Their land teemed with [xref]a[/xref]frogs, / [i]Even[/i] in the chambers of their kings.
He spoke, and a swarm of [xref]a[/xref]flies came; / [i]There were[/i] [xref]b[/xref]gnats within all their borders.
He gave them [xref]a[/xref]hail for rain, / [i]And[/i] flaming fire in their land.
He struck their vines and their fig trees, / And He [xref]a[/xref]broke the trees of their borders.
He spoke, and the swarming [xref]a[/xref]locusts came, / And the licking locusts, even without number.
And they ate every herb in their land, / And they ate the fruit of their ground.
He [xref]a[/xref]struck all the firstborn in their land, / The firstfruits of all their vigor.
And He brought them out with silver and [xref]a[/xref]gold, / And there was none among His tribes who stumbled.
Egypt rejoiced at their [xref]a[/xref]going forth, / For a dread of them had fallen upon them.
He spread a [xref]a[/xref]cloud for a covering, / And a fire to give light by night.
They asked, and He brought [xref]a[/xref]quails; / And He satisfied them with the [xref]b[/xref]bread of heaven.
He opened the [xref]a[/xref]rock, and water gushed forth; / It ran in the dry places [i]like[/i] a river.
For He remembered His holy word / [i]And[/i] Abraham His servant.
And He brought forth His people with gladness, / His chosen ones with a ringing shout.
And He gave them the lands of the nations, / And they took [xref]a[/xref]possession of the labor of the peoples,
So that they might keep His statutes / And observe His laws. / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah. / [xref]b[/xref]Give thanks to Jehovah, for He is good, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link]. So also for [link chapter="106"]v. 48[/link]. [link]Psalm 106[/link] concerns God in His dealing with Israel in the wilderness and in the promised land with His favor according to His covenant. This is yet another part of God's history. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 103[/link].

verse.text: Who can utter the mighty acts of Jehovah, / Or declare all His praise?
Blessed are those who maintain justice, / Who execute righteousness at all times.
Remember me, O Jehovah, with [i]Your[/i] favor toward Your people; / Visit me with Your salvation,
That I may see the prosperity of Your chosen ones, / That I may rejoice in the joy of Your nation, / That I may glory with Your inheritance.
We [xref]a[/xref]have sinned with our fathers; / We committed iniquity; we have acted wickedly.
Our fathers in Egypt / Did not understand Your wonders; / They did not remember the multitude of Your [xref]a[/xref]acts of lovingkindness, / But [xref]b[/xref]rebelled by the sea, at the Red Sea.
But He saved them for His name's sake, / That He might make His power known.
Thus He [xref]a[/xref]rebuked the Red Sea, and it [xref]b[/xref]dried up; / And He led them through the depths as through the wilderness.
And He [xref]a[/xref]saved them from the hand of him who hated [i]them,[/i] / And redeemed them from the hand of the enemy.
The water then [xref]a[/xref]covered their adversaries; / Not one of them was left.
Then they [xref]a[/xref]believed His words; / They [xref]b[/xref]sang His praise.
Soon they forgot His works; / They did not wait for His counsel,
But [xref]a[/xref]lusted exceedingly in the wilderness, / And [xref]b[/xref]tempted God in the desert.
And He gave them their request, / But He sent leanness into their soul.
And they were [xref]a[/xref]jealous of Moses in the camp / [i]And[/i] of Aaron, the holy one of Jehovah.
The earth opened, and it [xref]a[/xref]swallowed up Dathan / And covered the company of Abiram.
And a [xref]a[/xref]fire burned among their company; / A flame engulfed the wicked.
They made a [xref]a[/xref]calf in Horeb, / And worshipped a molten image.
Thus they exchanged their [xref]a[/xref]glory / For the image of an ox that eats grass.
They forgot God their Savior, / Who had done great things in Egypt,
Wondrous deeds in the land of Ham, / Awesome things by the Red Sea.

Therefore He said that He would [xref]a[/xref]destroy them, / [i]And would have,[/i] had not Moses His chosen one / Stood in the breach before Him / To turn away His wrath from destroying [i]them.[/i]
Then they despised the [xref]a[/xref]pleasant land; / They did [xref]b[/xref]not believe in His word;
Rather they [xref]a[/xref]murmured in their tents; / They did not listen to the voice of Jehovah.
Therefore He lifted up His hand [i]and swore[/i] to them / That He would make them [xref]a[/xref]fall in the wilderness,
And that He would make their seed fall among the nations, / And that He would [xref]a[/xref]disperse them among the lands.
Then they joined themselves to [xref]a[/xref]Baal-peor, / And ate sacrifices [i]offered[/i] to the dead.
Thus they provoked [i]Him[/i] to anger by their actions, / And the plague broke out among them.
Then [xref]a[/xref]Phinehas stood up and intervened, / And the plague was stayed;
And it has been accounted to him as [xref]a[/xref]righteousness / From generation to generation unto eternity.
Then they angered [i]Him[/i] at the waters of [xref]a[/xref]Meribah, / So that it went ill with Moses on account of them;
For they rebelled against His Spirit, / And he [xref]a[/xref]spoke rashly with his lips.
They did not [xref]a[/xref]destroy the peoples, / As Jehovah had commanded them;
But they [xref]a[/xref]mingled themselves with the nations / And learned their practices.
And they [xref]a[/xref]served their idols, / Which became a snare to them.
They also sacrificed their sons / And their daughters to [xref]a[/xref]demons,
And poured out innocent blood, / The blood of their sons and daughters, whom they sacrificed to the idols / of Canaan; / And the land was [xref]a[/xref]polluted with bloodshed.
Thus they were defiled by their practices, / And went about as [xref]a[/xref]harlots by their actions.
And the anger of Jehovah was kindled against His people, / And He abhorred His inheritance.
And He [xref]a[/xref]gave them over into the hand of the nations: / And those who hated them ruled over them,
And their enemies [xref]a[/xref]oppressed them, / And they were subdued under their hand.
Many times He delivered them, / But they were rebellious in their counsel, / And they were brought low in their iniquity.
Yet He regarded their distress / When He heard their cry,
And for their sake He remembered His [xref]a[/xref]covenant, / And repented according to the multitude of His acts of lovingkindness;
And He caused them to find [xref]a[/xref]compassion / With all their captors.
[xref]a[/xref]Save us, O Jehovah our God; / And gather us out of the nations, / That we may give thanks to Your holy name, / That we may glory in Your praise.
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed be Jehovah the God of Israel, / From eternity to eternity. / And let all the people say, [xref]b[/xref]Amen. / Hallelujah.
[xref]a[/xref]Give thanks to Jehovah, for He is good, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
Let the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]redeemed of Jehovah say [i]so,[/i] / Whom He redeemed from the hand of the adversary,
verse.note: [link]Psalm 107[/link] concerns God's care for and deliverance of His redeemed in Christ. The word [i]redeemed[/i] here implies Christ, for He is our Redeemer ([link]Gal. 3:13[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]) and even our redemption ([link]Luke 2:38[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). In Christ we enjoy God's care and deliverance, which imply His rescue and saving every day.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gathered out of the lands, / From the east and from the west, / From the north and from the south.
verse.note: This gathering corresponds to [link]Rev. 5:9[/link], which speaks of those purchased for God by Christ's blood "out of every tribe and tongue and people and nation."

verse.text: They [note]1[/note]wandered in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness, on the desert way; / They found no city of habitation.
verse.note: God's care and deliverance of the famished wanderers in [link]vv. 4-9[/link], of those imprisoned in darkness and the shadow of death in [link]vv. 10-16[/link] (cf. [link]Acts 26:18[/link]), of the ones who are sick because of their way of transgression in [link]vv. 17-22[/link] (cf. [link]Matt. 9:2[/link]), of the seafarers in [link]vv. 23-32[/link], and of the needy in [link]vv. 34-43[/link], typify His care for and deliverance of His believers in the church life. According to the New Testament revelation, God's care for the believers and His deliverance of the believers require that Christ be sitting in His ascension at the right hand of God, as revealed in [link]Psa. 110[/link]. Because Christ is our High Priest in the heavens interceding for us ([link]Rom. 8:34[/link]; [link]Heb. 7:25[/link]), God's care is Christ's care for us and God's deliverance is Christ's deliverance of us.

verse.text: Hungry and thirsty, / Their soul fainted within them.
Then they cried out to Jehovah in their trouble, / [i]And[/i] He delivered them from their distresses.
And He led them on a straight way / That they might come to a city of habitation.
Let them give thanks to Jehovah for His lovingkindness / And for His wondrous deeds to the children of men.
For He [xref]a[/xref]satisfies the thirsty soul, / And the [xref]b[/xref]famished soul He fills with good.
Some inhabited [xref]a[/xref]darkness and the shadow of death, / And were bound in affliction and irons,
Because they rebelled against the words of God / And spurned the counsel of the Most High;
Therefore He brought down their heart with labor; / They stumbled, and there was no one to help [i]them.[/i]
Then they cried out to Jehovah in their trouble, / [i]And[/i] He saved them from their distresses.
He brought them out of [xref]a[/xref]darkness and the shadow of death, / And He broke apart their bonds.
Let them give thanks to Jehovah for His lovingkindness / And for His wondrous deeds to the children of men.
For He breaks down the doors of bronze / And cuts down the bars of iron.
Some were fools, because of their way of transgression; / And because of their iniquities, they were afflicted.
Their soul loathed all food, / And they drew near to the gates of death.
Then they cried out to Jehovah in their trouble, / [i]And[/i] He saved them out of their distresses.
He sent forth His word and [xref]a[/xref]healed them, / And He delivered them from the pits [i]of destruction.[/i]
Let them give thanks to Jehovah for His lovingkindness / And for His wondrous deeds to the children of men.
And let them offer sacrifices of thanksgiving / And declare His doings in joyful song.
Those who go down to the sea in ships, / Conducting business on the mighty waters,
These see Jehovah's doings / And His wondrous deeds in the deep.
For He commanded and raised up a storm wind, / And it lifted up [note]1[/note]the waves of the sea.
verse.note: Lit., its waves.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]They mounted up to the heavens; they went down to the depths; / Their soul melted in the calamity.
verse.note: I.e., the seafarers mentioned in [link]vv. 23-24[/link].

verse.text: They reeled and staggered like a drunken man, / And all their skill was swallowed up.
Then they cried out to Jehovah in their trouble, / And He brought them out of their distresses.
He made the storm be still, / And [note]1[/note]the waves of the sea were [xref]a[/xref]calm;
verse.note: Lit., their waves.

verse.text: And they rejoiced that they were quiet, / And He brought them to the haven they desired.
Let them give thanks to Jehovah for His lovingkindness / And for His wondrous deeds to the children of men.
And let them exalt Him in the congregation of the people / And praise Him in the assembly of the elders.
He turns [xref]a[/xref]rivers into a wilderness, / And springs of water into thirsty ground;
Fruitful land into a [xref]a[/xref]salt flat, / Because of the wickedness of those who dwell in it.
He turns a wilderness into a pool of water, / And a dry land into [xref]a[/xref]springs of water.
And He makes the hungry dwell there, / That they may prepare a city of habitation
And sow fields and plant vineyards / And get a fruitful yield.
He also blesses them, and they are multiplied greatly; / And He does not let their cattle decrease.
When they are diminished and bowed down / Through oppression, trouble, and sorrow,
He pours contempt on princes, / And makes them wander in a pathless waste.
But He raises the needy man high above affliction / And makes [i]his[/i] families like flocks.
The upright see [i]it[/i] and rejoice; / And all iniquity stops its mouth.
Who is [xref]a[/xref]wise? Then let him observe these things / And consider the lovingkindness of Jehovah.
A Song; a [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[xref]a[/xref]My heart is fixed, O God; / I will sing, indeed I will sing psalms, / Even [i]with[/i] my glory.
Awake, O harp and lyre! / I will awaken the dawn.
I will give thanks to You among the peoples, O Jehovah; / And I will sing psalms to You among the nations.
For Your lovingkindness is higher than the heavens, / And Your [note]1[/note]faithfulness [i]reaches[/i] to the sky.
verse.note: Or, truth.

verse.text: Be exalted above the heavens, O God; / And [i]let[/i] Your glory be above all the earth.
[xref]a[/xref]That Your beloved ones may be delivered, / [note]1[/note]Save with Your right hand, and answer [note]2[/note]us.
verse.note: [link]Verses 6-13[/link], a quotation from [link]Psa. 60:5-12[/link], portray God's victory in Christ over the enemies.
Others read, me.

verse.text: God has spoken in His [note]1[/note]holiness: I will exult; / I will divide Shechem / And measure out the Valley of Succoth.
verse.note: Or, holy place.

verse.text: Gilead is Mine; Manasseh is Mine; / And Ephraim is the helmet for My head; / Judah is My [xref]a[/xref]scepter.
Moab is My washbowl; / Upon Edom I will cast My sandal; / Over Philistia I will shout.
Who will bring me into the fortified city? / Who will lead me to Edom?
Will not You, O God, who [xref]a[/xref]rejected us / And who did not go forth, O God, with our armies?
Give us help from the adversary, / For salvation by man is vain.
In God we will do valiantly, / And it is He who will tread down our adversaries.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A Psalm
[note]1[/note]O God of my praise, do not be silent;
verse.note: [link]Psalm 109[/link] is a prayer of David concerning his sufferings and is also a description of his sufferings. David here is a type of Christ, and David's sufferings typify Christ's sufferings in His flesh ([link]Heb. 5:7-8[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:1[/link]). This is indicated by the fact that [link]v. 8[/link] is quoted in [link]Acts 1:20[/link] and applied to Judas, who betrayed Christ.[br][br]David's prayer in this psalm typifies Christ's prayer ([link]Heb. 5:7[/link] and note). The prayer in this psalm is answered in the next, which unveils Christ in His ascension, indicating that God's answer to Christ's prayer was not only through resurrection but also in ascension.

verse.text: For the mouth of the wicked man and the mouth of deceit are opened / against me; / They speak to me with a lying tongue.
And with words of hatred they have surrounded me / And have fought against me without cause.
In return for my love they have become my adversaries, / But I am [i]all[/i] prayer.
And they have set against me evil in return for good / And hatred in return for my love.
Appoint a wicked man over him, / And let an adversary stand at his right hand.
When he is judged, let him come forth wicked; / And let his prayer be counted as sin.
May his days be few; / [xref]a[/xref]May another take his office.
May his children be orphans, / And his wife a widow.
And may his children wander all about and beg, / And may they seek [i]food[/i] far from their desolated ruins.
May the creditor seize all that he has, / And may strangers plunder the fruit of his labor.
May there be no one to extend him mercy, / Nor anyone to be kind to his orphans.
May his posterity be cut off; / In the generation following may [note]1[/note]his name be blotted out.
verse.note: Some MSS read, their.

verse.text: May his father's iniquity be remembered before Jehovah, / And may his mother's sin not be blotted out.
May they be before Jehovah continually, / So that He may cut off the memory of them from the earth;
Because he did not remember to show lovingkindness, / But persecuted the poor and needy and brokenhearted, / To put [i]them[/i] to death.
Indeed he loved cursing, so it came on him; / And he took no delight in blessing, so it was far from him.
And he clothed himself with cursing like his garment, / So it came into his inward parts like water / And into his bones like oil.
Let it be to him like the cloak that he wraps around himself, / And as a belt with which he constantly girds himself.
This is the reward from Jehovah for my adversaries / And for those who speak evil against my soul.
But You, O Jehovah Lord, deal with me, / For Your name's sake; / Because Your lovingkindness is good, deliver me.
For I am poor and needy, / And my heart is wounded within me.
I am gone like a shadow that declines; / I am shaken off like the locust.
My knees wobble through fasting, / And my flesh has become lean, without fatness.
I have also become a [xref]a[/xref]reproach to them: / When they see me, they [xref]b[/xref]shake their heads.
Help me, O Jehovah my God; / Save me according to Your lovingkindness;
And they will know that this is Your hand, / [i]That[/i] it is You, O Jehovah, who have done it.
Let them curse, but You bless; / When they arise, they will be put to shame, / And Your servant will rejoice.
May my adversaries be clothed with humiliation, / And may they wrap themselves with their own shame as with a mantle.
I will give much thanks to Jehovah with my mouth, / And in the midst of the multitude I will praise Him;
For He stands at the right hand of the needy / To save [i]him[/i] from those who judge his soul.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David. A Psalm
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jehovah declares to my Lord, / Sit at My [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]right hand / Until I make Your enemies / Your [note]3[/note]footstool.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 110[/link] unveils Christ in His ascension. In this psalm Christ is revealed as the King ([link]v. 2[/link]), the Priest ([link]v. 4[/link]), the Warrior ([link]v. 3[/link]), and the Victor ([link]vv. 5-7[/link]).[br][br]This verse concerning Christ's ascension is quoted numerous times in the New Testament ([link]Matt. 22:44[/link]; [link]Mark 12:36[/link]; [link]Luke 20:42-43[/link]; [link]Acts 2:34-35[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:13[/link]), and Christ's sitting at the right hand of God is referred to a number of other times ([link]Mark 16:19[/link]; [link]Acts 2:33[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:34[/link]; etc.).

See note [link]20[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link]. Christ's ascension to the right hand of God is not merely a matter of His being in a place but of His being in a person, the Father. In His ascension Christ entered into the Father's being and sat down there ([link]John 16:28[/link]). Cf. note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 22[/link].[br][br]This word concerning Christ's sitting at the right hand of God implies Christ's kingship. In His ascension Christ was made by God the Lord, the Christ, the Leader of the entire universe, and the Savior ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]; [link]5:31[/link]; [link]10:36[/link]).
See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 1[/link].

verse.text: Jehovah will send forth / The [xref]a[/xref]scepter of Your strength from [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zion: / [xref]c[/xref]Rule in the midst of Your enemies.
verse.note: Zion here is not the Zion on earth but the Zion in the heavens, as mentioned in [link]Heb. 12:22[/link] and [link]Rev. 14:1[/link]. From this heavenly Zion God will send forth the scepter of Christ's strength to rule over all the nations, who are Christ's enemies, at His return ([link]2:6[/link], [link]8-9[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:15[/link]).

verse.text: Your people will [note]1[/note]offer themselves [xref]a[/xref]willingly / In the day of Your warfare, / In the [note]2[/note]splendor of [i]their[/i] consecration. / Your young men will be to You / Like the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]dew from the womb of the dawn.
verse.note: Lit., be freewill offerings.

In the eyes of the Lord our willing consecration, our offering ourselves to Him, is a matter of splendor. Although the church has become degraded, throughout the centuries there has been a line of those who have offered themselves willingly to the Lord in the splendor, the beauty, of their consecration.[br][br]The word may also be translated [i]adornment.[/i] The splendor of consecration is an adornment. If we offer ourselves willingly to the Lord, we will be beautified with a divine, heavenly splendor.

Here Christ likens Himself to a plant that needs the watering of the mild, soft, gentle dew. As Christ is on His way to carry out God's economy, He needs to be watered. Christ is watered by those who offer themselves willingly to Him. Whoever volunteers himself to Christ as an offering is a young man likened to the dew conceived in the womb of the dawn for watering Christ.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah has sworn, / And He will [xref]b[/xref]not change: / [xref]c[/xref]You are a [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Priest [xref]e[/xref]forever / According to the [note]2[/note]order of [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]Melchizedek.
verse.note: Christ is not only the King with power and authority ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]); He is also the High Priest ([link]Heb. 2:17[/link]; [link]4:14[/link]; [link]6:20[/link]; [link]8:1[/link]; [link]9:11[/link]). Christ's heavenly ministry in His ascension includes both His kingship and His priesthood. As the King He has the scepter to rule over the earth and to manage our affairs, and as the High Priest He is interceding for us and taking care of our case before God ([link]Heb. 7:25-26[/link]; [link]9:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:34[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:12-13[/link]).
See note [link]18[sup]3[/sup] in Gen. 14[/link].
See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 14[/link].

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]Lord is at Your [xref]a[/xref]right hand; / He will shatter kings in the day of His [xref]b[/xref]anger.
verse.note: Christ, who is the Lord, the Master, and who is at God's right hand ([link]v. 1[/link]), will shatter kings in the day of His anger at His coming back with His overcomers and will execute judgment among the nations ([link]v. 6[/link]; [link]2:9[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link], [link]44[/link]; [link]Joel 3:11-12[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:14[/link]; [link]19:11-21[/link]). Thus, Christ will be the greatest Victor.

verse.text: He will execute [xref]a[/xref]judgment among the nations; / He will fill [i]the place[/i] with corpses; / He will shatter the head / Over a [note]1[/note]great land.
verse.note: Signifying the entire earth.

verse.text: He will drink from the [note]1[/note]brook by the way; / Therefore He will [note]2[/note]lift up [i]His[/i] head.
verse.note: The brook signifies the overcomers. As Christ is taking the lead to fight through to the end, He will need water to drink, and this water will be the overcomers. Cf. note [link]3[sup]3[/sup][/link]. See note [link]34[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Dan. 2[/link].
Christ's lifting up His head is a sign of His victory, His triumph, in overcoming all the enemies.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah! / [note]2[/note]I will give thanks to Jehovah with all [i]my[/i] heart / In the council of the upright and [xref]b[/xref]in the assembly.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link]. [link]Psalms 111-118[/link] are a group consisting of the praise of God's elect, which consummates in the revelation of Christ in His particular position as the cornerstone ([link]118:22[/link]).
[link]Psalm 111[/link] is one of the alphabetical, or acrostic, psalms. The first letter of each line, beginning with this line, follows the order of the Hebrew alphabet.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Great are the [note]1[/note]works of Jehovah, / [i]And[/i] sought out by all who delight in them.
verse.note: This psalm is the praise of God's elect for God's great works according to His covenant that He made with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

verse.text: His work is majesty and splendor, / And His righteousness endures forever.
He has caused His wondrous deeds to be remembered; / Jehovah is gracious and compassionate.
He gives food to those who fear Him; / He remembers His covenant forever.
He has shown His people the power of His works / By giving them the [xref]a[/xref]heritage of the nations.
The works of His hands are truth and justice; / All His precepts are sure:
They are maintained forever and ever, / They are executed in truth and uprightness.
He has sent [xref]a[/xref]redemption to His people; / He has commanded His covenant forever; / [xref]b[/xref]Holy and awesome is His name.
The [xref]a[/xref]fear of Jehovah is the beginning of wisdom; / All who practice [note]1[/note]His precepts have a good understanding. / His praise endures forever.
verse.note: Lit., them.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah! / [note]2[/note]Blessed is the man who [xref]b[/xref]fears Jehovah, / Who delights greatly in His commandments.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link]. [link]Psalm 112[/link] is the praise of God's elect for God's blessing given because of their fearing Him ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]) and because of their virtues, mainly in their giving to the poor ([link]vv. 4-5[/link], [link]9[/link]; cf. [link]2 Cor. 9:6-11[/link]).
[link]Psalm 112[/link] is one of the alphabetical, or acrostic, psalms. The first letter of each line, beginning with this line, follows the order of the Hebrew alphabet.

verse.text: His seed will be mighty on the earth; / The generation of the upright will be blessed.
Wealth and riches are in his house, / And his righteousness endures forever.
Light in the darkness arises to the upright; / [i]They are[/i] gracious and compassionate and righteous.
It is well with the man who is gracious and [xref]a[/xref]lends; / He will maintain his cause in judgment.
For he will never be moved; / The righteous man will be remembered forever.
He will not be afraid of evil tidings; / His heart is steadfast, trusting in Jehovah.
His heart is sustained, he is not afraid, / Until he sees [i]what should happen[/i] to his adversaries.
[xref]a[/xref]He has scattered abroad; he has [xref]b[/xref]given to the needy; / His righteousness endures forever; / His horn will be exalted with honor.
The wicked man will see [i]it[/i] and be angry; / He will gnash his teeth and melt away; / The desire of the wicked will perish.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah! / Praise, you servants of Jehovah, / Praise the name of Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link]. This psalm is the praise of God's elect for God's exaltation ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]) and His humility ([link]v. 6[/link]) in taking care of the lowly and needy ones ([link]vv. 7-9[/link]). God's humility was manifested in His incarnation. Christ humbled Himself and, because of His humility, was exalted ([link]Phil. 2:5-11[/link]).

verse.text: Let the name of Jehovah be [xref]a[/xref]blessed, / From now and to eternity.
From the [xref]a[/xref]rising of the sun to its setting / The name of Jehovah is to be praised.
Jehovah is high above all the nations, / And His [xref]a[/xref]glory is above the heavens.
[xref]a[/xref]Who is like Jehovah our God, / Who has set His throne on high,
Who humbles Himself to behold / The heavens and the earth?
[xref]a[/xref]He raises the poor from the dust; / From the ash heap He lifts the needy;
That He may seat [i]them[/i] with princes, / With the princes of His people.
He causes the [xref]a[/xref]barren woman to keep house / [i]As[/i] a joyful mother of children. / Hallelujah.
When Israel [xref]a[/xref]went forth from Egypt, / The house of Jacob from among a people of unintelligible speech,
Judah became His [xref]a[/xref]sanctuary, / Israel, His dominion.
The [xref]a[/xref]sea saw and fled; / The [xref]b[/xref]Jordan turned back.
The mountains skipped like rams, / The hills, like lambs.
What troubles you, O sea, that you flee? / O Jordan, that you turn back?
O mountains, [i]that[/i] you skip like rams? / O hills, like lambs?
Tremble at the [xref]a[/xref]presence of the Lord, O earth, / At the presence of the God of Jacob,
Who turns the [xref]a[/xref]rock into a pool of water, / The flint into a fountain of water.
Not to us, O Jehovah, not to us, / But to Your name give [xref]a[/xref]glory, / For the sake of Your lovingkindness and Your [note]1[/note]truth.
verse.note: Or, faithfulness.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Why should the nations say, / Where then is their God?
But our God is in the heavens; / He does whatever He pleases.
[xref]a[/xref]Their idols are [i]mere[/i] silver and gold, / The work of human [xref]b[/xref]hands.
They have mouths, but they do [xref]a[/xref]not speak; / They have eyes, but they do [xref]b[/xref]not see.
