They have ears, but they do not hear; / They have noses, but they do not smell.
They have hands, but they do not feel; / They have feet, but they do not walk; / They make no sound in their throat.
Those who make them, / All who [xref]a[/xref]trust in them, / Are [note]1[/note]like them.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: O Israel, [xref]a[/xref]trust in Jehovah. / He is their help and their shield.
O house of Aaron, trust in Jehovah. / He is their help and their shield.
O you who fear Jehovah, trust in Jehovah. / He is their help and their shield.
Jehovah has been mindful of us; He will bless [i]us;[/i] / He will bless the house of Israel; / He will bless the house of Aaron;
He will bless those who fear Jehovah, / Both small and great.
May Jehovah give you increase, / Both you and your children.
May you be blessed of Jehovah, / [xref]a[/xref]Maker of heaven and earth.
The heavens are the heavens of Jehovah, / But He has given the [xref]a[/xref]earth to the children of men.
The [xref]a[/xref]dead do not praise [note]1[/note]Jehovah, / Nor do any that go down into silence.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah;[/i] a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i] So also in the next verse.

verse.text: But we will bless Jehovah / From now and to eternity. / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link].

verse.text: I love Jehovah because He hears / My voice, my supplications,
Because He inclines His ear to me; / Therefore I will call upon [i]Him all[/i] my days.
The bonds of death encompassed me, / And the distresses of Sheol fell upon me; / I fell upon trouble and sorrow.
But I [xref]a[/xref]called upon the name of Jehovah. / O Jehovah, I pray, deliver my soul.
Jehovah is gracious and righteous, / Indeed our God is compassionate.
Jehovah preserves the simple: / I was brought low, and He saved me.
Return to your rest, O my soul; / For Jehovah has dealt bountifully with you.
[xref]a[/xref]For You have delivered my soul from death, / My eyes from tears, / My feet from stumbling.
I will walk before Jehovah / In the [note]1[/note]land of the living.
verse.note: Following the ancient versions; the Hebrew reads, lands.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I believed, [note]1[/note]therefore I spoke; / I was afflicted greatly.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint (cf. [link]2 Cor. 4:13[/link]); the Hebrew reads, for, or, when.

verse.text: I said in my haste, / [xref]a[/xref]All men are liars.
What shall I [xref]a[/xref]return to Jehovah / For all His benefits toward me?
I will take up the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cup of salvation / And [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]call upon the name of Jehovah.
verse.note: God's rich and full salvation is a cup, a portion, given to us, and the way for us to drink this cup and partake of this salvation is to call on the name of the Lord ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]4[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]Gen. 4:26[/link]; [link]Isa. 12:2-4[/link]; [link]Acts 2:21[/link]; [link]Rom. 10:12-13[/link]).

verse.text: I will pay my vows to Jehovah, / Oh, in the presence of all His people.
[xref]a[/xref]Precious in the sight of Jehovah / Is the [xref]b[/xref]death of His faithful ones.
O Jehovah! / Surely I am Your [xref]a[/xref]servant; / I am Your servant, the son of Your female servant; / You have loosed my bonds.
To You I will offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving, / And I will [xref]a[/xref]call upon the name of Jehovah.
I will pay my vows to Jehovah, / Oh, in the presence of all His people,
In the [xref]a[/xref]courts of the house of Jehovah, / In the midst of you, O Jerusalem. / [xref]b[/xref]Hallelujah.
[xref]a[/xref]Praise Jehovah, all you nations; / Laud Him, all you peoples.
For His lovingkindness is great toward us, / And the faithfulness of Jehovah is forever. / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link].

verse.text: Give [note]1[/note]thanks to Jehovah, for He is good, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
verse.note: In [link]Psa. 118[/link] there is the thanksgiving of God's elect for God's bountiful goodness and everlasting lovingkindness ([link]vv. 1-21[/link], [link]27-29[/link]), leading to Christ as the cornerstone for God's building ([link]vv. 22-26[/link]).

verse.text: Let Israel say, / His lovingkindness is forever.
Let the house of Aaron say, / His lovingkindness is forever.
Let those who fear Jehovah say, / His lovingkindness is forever.
Out of my distress I [xref]a[/xref]called upon [note]1[/note]Jehovah; / [note]1[/note]Jehovah answered me [i]and set me[/i] in a place [xref]b[/xref]broad and free.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah;[/i] a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i] So frequently throughout this psalm.

verse.text: Jehovah is for me; [xref]a[/xref]I will not be afraid. / What can man do to me?
Jehovah is for me as my Helper, / And I will see [i]what should happen[/i] to those who hate me.
It is better to [xref]a[/xref]take refuge in Jehovah / Than to trust in man.
It is better to take refuge in Jehovah / Than to trust in princes.
All nations surrounded me; / In the name of Jehovah I indeed cut them down!
They surrounded me; yes, they surrounded me; / In the name of Jehovah I indeed cut them down!
They surrounded me like bees; / They were extinguished like a fire of thorns; / In the name of Jehovah I indeed cut them down!
[note]1[/note]I was pushed hard that I might fall; / But Jehovah helped me.
verse.note: Following some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, You (i.e., the enemy) have pushed me hard.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah is my strength and my song, / And He has become my [note]1[/note]salvation.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 12[/link].

verse.text: The voice of rejoicing and salvation / Is in the tents of the righteous. / The [xref]a[/xref]right hand of Jehovah does valiantly;
The right hand of Jehovah is exalted; / The right hand of Jehovah does valiantly.
I will not die, but live, / And declare the works of Jehovah.
Jehovah has severely chastened me, / But He has not given me over to [xref]a[/xref]death.
Open to me the [xref]a[/xref]gates of righteousness: / I will enter in through them; I will give thanks to Jehovah.
This is the gate of Jehovah; / The righteous shall [xref]a[/xref]enter in through it.
I will give thanks to You, for You have answered me / And have become my salvation.
[xref]a[/xref]The [note]1[/note]stone which the [note]1[/note]builders rejected / Has become the [note]2[/note]head of the [xref]b[/xref]corner.
verse.note: See notes [link]42[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link], [link book="Acts" chapter="4"]11[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in Acts 4[/link], and [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Pet. 2[/link].

Or, chief cornerstone. See notes [link]42[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link], [link]20[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 2[/link], and [link book="1 Pet." chapter="2"]4[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 2[/link]. Christ as the cornerstone is for the building up of the church in the New Testament age. In God's New Testament economy Christ as the cornerstone, in His saving us ([link]Acts 4:11-12[/link]), first makes us living stones for the building up of God's spiritual house ([link]Matt. 16:16-18[/link]; [link]John 1:42[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:2-6[/link]), and then, in the process of His transforming us ([link]Rom. 12:2a[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]), builds us up into a dwelling place of God ([link]Eph. 2:19-22[/link]), that He may carry out God's eternal economy for God's good pleasure ([link]Eph. 1:9[/link]; [link]3:9-11[/link]).

verse.text: This is from Jehovah; / It is wonderful in our sight.
This is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]day that Jehovah has made; / Let us exult and rejoice in it.
verse.note: This day is the day of Christ's resurrection. On the day of His resurrection the Lord Jesus was made the cornerstone by God. Christ was chosen by God in eternity past to be the cornerstone for God's spiritual building ([link]1 Pet. 1:20[/link]; [link]2:4[/link]). Then, the Jewish leaders as the builders rejected Him to the uttermost, to such an extent that they put Him on the cross ([link]Matt. 21:38-42a[/link]). God chose Christ as the cornerstone a second time in Christ's resurrection ([link]Acts 4:10-11[/link]), thereby confirming His initial choosing of Christ in eternity past. After God resurrected Christ, He uplifted Him to the heavens ([link]Luke 24:51[/link]; [link]Acts 1:9[/link]). Christ's ascension to Zion in the heavens ([link]Rev. 14:1[/link]) was a further confirmation that God had chosen Him to be the cornerstone ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:6[/link]). Both Christ's resurrection and His ascension prove and confirm that He is the One whom God has chosen to be the head of the corner for God's building.[br][br]As the all-inclusive stone Christ is the centrality of God's move for the building up of His eternal habitation ([link]Matt. 21:42[/link], [link]44[/link]; [link]Zech. 3:9[/link], cf. [link]Rev. 5:5-6[/link]; [link]Acts 4:10-12[/link]; [link]Isa. 28:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:19-22[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:4-8[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]; [link]Zech. 4:7[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:11[/link], cf. [link]4:3[/link]). Everything Christ is, everything He has done, and everything He is doing is due to the fact that He is the cornerstone. It is by His being the cornerstone that He could die for us, that we could be crucified with Him, made alive with Him, resurrected with Him, and seated with Him in the heavenlies, and that He could save us, transform us into precious stones, and build us together to be God's habitation, God's unique temple in the universe.

verse.text: O Jehovah, [note]1[/note]do [xref]a[/xref]save, we pray! / O Jehovah, do send [note]2[/note]prosperity, we pray!
verse.note: Heb. [i]hoshiah-na,[/i] the source for [i]hosanna[/i] in the New Testament ([link]Matt. 21:9[/link]; [link]Mark 11:9-10[/link]; [link]John 12:13[/link]).

Typifying not material prosperity but the heavenly, spiritual, and divine blessings given to us by the Triune God, as described in [link]Eph. 1:3-14[/link] (see notes there), which come to us by Christ's being the cornerstone ([link]v. 22[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Blessed is He who [note]1[/note]comes in the name of Jehovah; / We bless you from the house of Jehovah.
verse.note: Christ's coming in the name of Jehovah occurs twice. The first time is mentioned in [link]Matt. 21:5-11[/link]. After that, He was rejected by the Jews. When He comes the second time, the Jews will again welcome Him warmly with these words ([link]Matt. 23:39[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah is God, / And He has given us light; / Bind the sacrifice of the feast with cords / To the [xref]a[/xref]horns of the altar.
You are my God, and I give thanks to You. / [i]You are[/i] my God; I will exalt You.
Give thanks to Jehovah, for He is good, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
[note]1[/note]a (Aleph)
verse.note: [link]Psalm 119[/link] is one of the alphabetical, or acrostic, psalms. The first letters of each group of eight verses follow the order of the Hebrew alphabet. The twenty-two sections of this psalm thus correspond to the twenty-two letters of the Hebrew alphabet. Furthermore, all the verses in a particular section begin with the same Hebrew letter.

verse.text: Blessed are those whose way is perfect, / Who [xref]a[/xref]walk in the [note]1[/note]law of Jehovah.
verse.note: The word [i]law[/i] is used twenty-five times in this psalm ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]18[/link], etc.). A number of different synonyms for law are also used, including [i]testimony[/i] (once, in [link]v. 88[/link]), [i]testimonies[/i] (twenty-two times, in [link]vv. 2[/link], [link]14[/link], etc.), [i]word[/i] (thirty-six times, in [link]vv. 9[/link], [link]11[/link], etc.), [i]words[/i] (six times, in [link]vv. 57[/link], [link]103[/link], etc.; cf. [link]Exo. 34:28[/link], lit.), [i]commandment[/i] (once, in [link]v. 96[/link]), [i]commandments[/i] (twenty-one times, in [link]vv. 6[/link], [link]10[/link], etc.), [i]statutes[/i] (twenty-two times, in [link]vv. 5[/link], [link]8[/link], etc.), [i]ordinances[/i] (seventeen times, in [link]vv. 7[/link], [link]13[/link], etc.), [i]judgments[/i] (three times, in [link]vv. 75[/link], [link]120[/link], [link]137[/link]), and [i]precepts[/i] (twenty-one times, in [link]vv. 4[/link], [link]15[/link], etc.). All these terms from [i]law[/i] to [i]precepts[/i] consummate in the [i]way[/i] (four times, in [link]vv. 14[/link], [link]27[/link], [link]32[/link], [link]33[/link]) or [i]ways[/i] (three times, in [link]vv. 3[/link], [link]15[/link], [link]37[/link]), signifying Christ as the way of God for His people ([link]John 14:6[/link]). [link]Psalm 119[/link] is a psalm of 176 verses describing Christ, who is the reality of the law, the commandments, the ordinances, the statutes, the precepts, and the judgments.

verse.text: Blessed are those who keep His [note]1[/note]testimonies, / Who [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]seek Him with all [i]their[/i] heart.
verse.note: Christ is the reality of the law as the testimony of God. The testimony of God signifies Christ, the embodiment of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), as the living portrait of what God is. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link].

There are two kinds of people in relation to the law: (1) the letter-keepers, illustrated by the Judaizers and Saul of Tarsus ([link]Phil. 3:6b[/link]), and (2) the God-seekers, illustrated by the psalmists, especially by the writer of this psalm, and by the apostle Paul ([link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link]). As a lover of God, the psalmist sought God with all his heart, loved God's name and remembered it ([link]vv. 132[/link], [link]55[/link]), sought God's favor by entreating His countenance ([link]v. 58[/link]), asked God to cause His face to shine upon him ([link]v. 135[/link]), walked in God's presence ([link]v. 168[/link]), considered God's law to be His living and loving word breathed out of His mouth ([link]vv. 13[/link], [link]72[/link], [link]88[/link]; cf. [link]2 Tim. 3:16[/link]), tasted God's word and found it sweeter than honey to his mouth ([link]v. 103[/link]), esteemed God's word as more precious than fine gold ([link]v. 127[/link]), and considered God's word a lamp to his feet and a light to his path ([link]v. 105[/link]).[br][br]In this psalm many different verbs are used to express the attitude of the God-seekers toward God's law as God's testimony and God's word: choosing it ([link]vv. 30[/link], [link]173[/link]); believing it ([link]v. 66[/link]); lifting up their hands unto it ([link]v. 48a[/link] and note); loving it ([link]vv. 47[/link], [link]48[/link], [link]97[/link], etc.); delighting in it ([link]vv. 16[/link], [link]24[/link], [link]35[/link], etc.); tasting it ([link]v. 103[/link]); rejoicing in it ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]111[/link], [link]162[/link]); singing of it ([link]v. 54[/link]; cf. [link]Eph. 5:18-20[/link]); regarding it ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]117[/link]); having a sound heart in it ([link]v. 80[/link]); inclining their heart unto it ([link]vv. 36[/link], [link]112[/link]); seeking it ([link]vv. 45[/link], [link]94[/link]), longing for it ([link]vv. 20[/link], [link]40[/link], [link]131[/link]), and hoping in it with prayer ([link]vv. 43[/link], [link]74[/link], [link]114[/link], [link]147[/link]); trusting in it ([link]v. 42[/link]); musing on it ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]48[/link], [link]78[/link], [link]99[/link], [link]148[/link]; see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup][/link]); considering it ([link]v. 95[/link]); esteeming it right concerning all things ([link]v. 128a[/link]); learning it ([link]vv. 71[/link], [link]73[/link]); treasuring it as much as all riches ([link]v. 14[/link]), as great spoil ([link]v. 162[/link]), better than gold and silver ([link]vv. 72[/link], [link]127[/link]), and as a heritage forever ([link]v. 111[/link]); treasuring it up in their heart ([link]v. 11[/link]; cf. [link]Col. 3:16[/link]); remembering it and not forgetting it ([link]vv. 52[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]93[/link]); standing in awe of it ([link]vv. 161b[/link], [link]120[/link]); clinging to it ([link]v. 31[/link]); not forsaking it, not swerving from it, not turning aside from it, and not going astray from it ([link]vv. 87[/link], [link]51[/link], [link]157[/link], [link]102[/link], [link]110[/link]); turning their feet toward it ([link]v. 59[/link]); keeping, observing, and doing it ([link]vv. 33[/link], [link]69[/link]); and walking in it and running the way of it ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]32a[/link]).

verse.text: Surely they do no wrong; / They walk in His ways.
You have commanded [i]that[/i] Your precepts / Be diligently kept.
Oh that my ways may be established / So as to keep Your [note]1[/note]statutes!
verse.note: For the commandments ([link]v. 6[/link]), statutes ([link]v. 5[/link]), and ordinances ([link]v. 7[/link]), see note [link]6[sup]4[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].

verse.text: Then I will not be put to shame, / When I regard all Your commandments.
I will give thanks to You with uprightness of heart / When I learn Your righteous ordinances.
I will keep Your statutes; / Do not utterly forsake me.
b (Beth)
With what should a young man keep his way pure? / By guarding [i]it[/i] according to Your [note]1[/note]word.
verse.note: Christ is the reality of the law in the sense of its being not only the testimony of God but also the word of God. In total, He is the Word of God ([link]John 1:1[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:13b[/link]). The words of this psalm are the written words of God, but Christ is the living Word of God breathed out by God ([link]2 Tim. 3:16a[/link]). The written words are the letters, but the living Word is the Spirit ([link]John 6:63[/link]; [link]Eph. 6:17[/link]), who is the reality of the letters. The law is the person of Christ, and the person of Christ is the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]). The Spirit is the reality of whatever God is ([link]John 16:13[/link]; [link]1 John 5:6[/link]). Hence, as the Spirit, Christ is the reality of the law.

verse.text: With all my heart I have sought You; / Do not let me wander from Your commandments.
In my [xref]a[/xref]heart I have treasured up Your word / That I might not sin against You.
Blessed are You, O Jehovah; / Teach me Your statutes.
With my lips I have declared / All the ordinances of Your mouth.
I have rejoiced in the way of Your testimonies / As much as in all riches.
I will [note]1[/note]muse upon Your precepts / And regard Your ways.
verse.note: Rich in meaning, the Hebrew word for [i]muse[/i] (often translated [i]meditate[/i] in the KJV) implies to worship, to converse with oneself, and to speak aloud. To muse on the word is to taste and enjoy it through careful considering. Prayer, speaking to oneself, and praising the Lord may also be included in musing on the word. To muse on the word of God is to enjoy His word as His breath ([link]2 Tim. 3:16[/link]) and thus to be infused with God, to breathe God in, and to receive spiritual nourishment.

verse.text: I will take delight in Your statutes; / I will not forget Your word.
g (Gimel)
Deal bountifully with Your servant that I may live / And keep Your word.
[xref]a[/xref]Open my eyes that I may behold / Wondrous things out of Your law.
I am a [xref]a[/xref]sojourner in the earth; / Do not hide Your commandments from me.
My soul is crushed with longing / For Your ordinances at all times.
You have rebuked the proud, the cursed, / Who wander from Your commandments.
Roll away from me reproach and contempt, / For I have kept Your testimonies.
Princes as well have sat and spoken against me, / [i]But[/i] Your servant [xref]a[/xref]mused upon Your statutes.
Also Your testimonies are my delight; / [i]They are[/i] my counselors.
d (Daleth)
My soul clings to the dust; / [xref]a[/xref]Enliven me according to Your word.
I have recounted my ways, and You have answered me; / Teach me Your statutes.
Cause me to understand the way of Your precepts, / And I will muse upon Your wondrous deeds.
My soul melts because of grief; / Strengthen me according to Your word.
Remove from me the way of falsehood, / And graciously grant me Your law.
I have chosen the way of faithfulness; / Your ordinances I have set [i]before me.[/i]
I cling to Your testimonies; / O Jehovah, do not put me to shame.
I run the way of Your commandments, / For You [xref]a[/xref]enlarge my heart.
h (He)
Teach me, O Jehovah, the way of Your statutes; / And I will keep it to the end.
Give me understanding, and I will observe Your law; / Indeed I will keep it with all [i]my[/i] heart.
Cause me to go on the path of Your commandments, / For in it I delight.
Incline my heart to Your testimonies / And not to unjust gain.
Turn my eyes from beholding vanity, / And enliven me in Your ways.
Confirm to Your servant Your word, / Which is for fearing You.
Turn away my reproach, which I fear; / For Your ordinances are good.
Behold, I have longed after Your precepts; / Enliven me in Your righteousness.
w (Vav)
May Your lovingkindness also come to me, O Jehovah, / Your salvation according to Your word.
Thus I will have an answer for him who reproaches me, / For I trust in Your word.
And do not take the word of truth utterly from my mouth, / For I have hoped in Your ordinances.
Thus I will keep Your law continually, / Forever and ever.
And I will walk at liberty, / For I have sought Your precepts.
I will also speak of Your testimonies before [xref]a[/xref]kings / And not be ashamed.
And I will take delight in Your commandments, / Which I love.
And I will [note]1[/note]lift up my hand to Your commandments, which I love; / And I will [xref]a[/xref]muse upon Your statutes.
verse.note: To lift up our hand unto the word of God is to indicate that we receive it warmly and gladly and that we say Amen to it ([link]Neh. 8:5-6[/link]).

verse.text: z (Zayin)
Remember the word to Your servant / In which You have made me hope.
This is my comfort in my affliction, / For Your word has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]enlivened me.
verse.note: There are two aspects of the law — the aspect of the letter and the aspect of the Spirit. "The letter kills, but the Spirit gives life" ([link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link]). If our attitude in coming to the law is to care only for the commandments in letters, we will have the law in the aspect of the killing letter. However, if we take every part of the law — all the commandments, ordinances, statutes, precepts, and judgments — as the word breathed out by the God whom we love, we will have the law in the aspect of the life-giving Spirit.[br][br]The function of the law also has two aspects. On the negative side, the law exposes man's sin ([link]Rom. 3:20b[/link]; [link]7:7b[/link]) and subdues sinners before God ([link]Rom. 3:19[/link]). It also guards God's chosen people in its custody that they might be conducted to Christ ([link]Gal. 3:23-24[/link]). On the positive side, as God's living testimony, the law functions to minister the living God to His seekers ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]88[/link]), and as God's living word, the law functions to dispense God Himself as life and light into those who love the law ([link]vv. 25[/link], [link]116[/link], [link]130[/link]). See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup], par. 3, in Exo. 19[/link].

verse.text: The proud have derided me greatly; / I have not swerved from Your law.
I have remembered Your ordinances from long ago, / O Jehovah, and have comforted myself.
Raging indignation seizes me because of the wicked, / Who forsake Your law.
Your statutes have become my songs of praise / In the house of my pilgrimage.
I have remembered Your name / In the night, O Jehovah, / And have kept Your law.
This has been mine, / That I have kept Your precepts.
j (Heth)
Jehovah is my [xref]a[/xref]portion; / I have promised to keep Your words.
I entreated Your [note]1[/note]favor with [i]my[/i] whole heart; / Be gracious to me according to Your word.
verse.note: Lit., face.

verse.text: I considered my ways / And turned my feet toward Your testimonies.
I hurried and did not delay / To keep Your commandments.
The cords of the wicked surround me, / [i]But[/i] I have not forgotten Your law.
At [xref]a[/xref]midnight I rise up to give thanks to You / Because of Your righteous ordinances.
I am a companion to all who fear You / And to those who keep Your precepts.
Your lovingkindness, O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]fills the earth; / Teach me Your statutes.
f (Teth)
You have dealt well with Your servant, / O Jehovah, according to Your word.
Teach me proper discernment and knowledge, / For I believe in Your commandments.
Before I was afflicted, I went astray; / But now I keep Your word.
You are [xref]a[/xref]good and One who does good; / Teach me Your statutes.
The proud have plastered lies against me; / With [i]my[/i] whole heart I will keep Your precepts.
Their heart is heavy as with fat; / [i]But[/i] I delight in Your law.
It is good for me that I have been afflicted, / That I might learn Your statutes.
The law of Your mouth is better to me / Than thousands of [i]pieces of[/i] [xref]a[/xref]gold and silver.
y (Yodh)
Your hands have [xref]a[/xref]made me and fashioned me; / Give me understanding that I may learn Your commandments.
Those who fear You will see me and rejoice, / For I have hoped in Your word.
I know, O Jehovah, that Your judgments are righteous / And that in faithfulness You afflicted me.
Let Your lovingkindness, I beseech You, be my comfort, / According to Your word to Your servant.
Let Your compassions come to me, and I will live; / For Your law is my delight.
Let the proud be put to shame, for they have subverted my cause with a lie; / [i]But[/i] I will muse upon Your precepts.
Let those who fear You turn to me, / And they will know Your testimonies.
May my heart be perfect in Your statutes, / That I may not be put to shame.
k (Kaph)
My soul faints [i]while longing[/i] for Your salvation; / I hope in Your word.
My eyes faint [i]while longing[/i] for Your word, / As I say, When will You comfort me?
For I have become like a wineskin in the smoke; / [i]But[/i] I do not forget Your statutes.
How many are the days of Your servant? / When will You execute justice upon my persecutors?
The proud have dug pits for me, / Those who are not according to Your law.
All Your commandments are faithful; / They persecute me falsely; help me.
They have almost consumed me upon the earth; / But I have not forsaken Your precepts.
[xref]a[/xref]Enliven me according to Your lovingkindness, / And I will keep the testimony of Your mouth.
l (Lamedh)
Forever, O Jehovah, / Does Your [xref]a[/xref]word stand firm in heaven.
Your faithfulness is from generation to generation; / You established the earth, and it abides.
They abide to this day according to Your ordinances, / For all things are Your servants.
Unless Your law had been my delight, / I would have perished in my affliction.
I will never forget Your precepts, / For by them You have enlivened me.
I [xref]a[/xref]am Yours; save me, / For I have sought Your precepts.
The wicked have waited for me in order to destroy me, / [i]But[/i] I consider Your testimonies.
I have seen an end to all perfection, / [i]But[/i] Your commandment is all-expansive.
m (Mem)
Oh, how I love Your law! / All day long it is my musing.
Your commandments make me [xref]a[/xref]wiser than my enemies, / For they are always with me.
I have more insight than all my teachers, / For Your testimonies are my musing.
I understand more than the aged, / For I have kept Your precepts.
I have withheld my feet from every evil way, / That I might keep Your word.
I have not turned aside from Your ordinances, / For You have taught me.
How sweet are Your words to my taste! / [xref]a[/xref][i]Sweeter[/i] than honey to my mouth!
Through Your precepts I gain understanding; / Therefore I hate every false way.
n (Nun)
Your word is a [xref]a[/xref]lamp to my feet / And a [xref]b[/xref]light to my path.
I have sworn and will confirm [i]it,[/i] / That I will keep Your righteous ordinances.
I have been greatly afflicted; / O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]enliven me according to Your word.
Accept, I pray, the freewill offerings of my mouth, O Jehovah; / And teach me Your ordinances.
My soul is continually in my hand, / But I do not forget Your law.
The wicked have laid a trap for me, / But I do not stray from Your precepts.
Your testimonies are my heritage forever, / For they are the gladness of my heart.
I have inclined my heart to perform Your statutes / Forever, to the end.
s (Samekh)
I hate those who are double-minded, / But I love Your law.
You are my hiding place and my shield; / In Your word do I hope.
Depart from me, you evildoers, / That I may keep the commandments of my God.
Uphold me according to Your word that I may live, / And do not let me be ashamed of my hope.
Hold me up that I may be safe, / And I will regard Your statutes continually.
You spurn all those who stray from Your statutes, / For their deceitfulness is vain.
You do away with all the wicked ones of the earth [i]like[/i] dross; / Therefore I love Your testimonies.
My flesh trembles for fear of You, / And I am afraid of Your judgments.
u (Ayin)
I have performed justice and righteousness; / Do not leave me to my oppressors.
Guarantee Your servant's well-being; / Do not let the proud oppress me.
My eyes faint [i]while longing[/i] for Your salvation / And for Your righteous word.
Deal with Your servant according to Your lovingkindness, / And teach me Your statutes.
I am Your servant; give me understanding, / That I may know Your testimonies.
It is time for Jehovah to act, / [i]For[/i] they have broken Your law.
Therefore I love Your commandments / More than [xref]a[/xref]gold, indeed, more than fine gold;
Therefore I esteem all [i]Your[/i] precepts concerning all things to be right, / [i]And[/i] I hate every false way.
p (Pe)
Your testimonies are wonderful; / Therefore my soul keeps them.
The [note]1[/note]opening of Your words gives [xref]a[/xref]light, / Imparting understanding to the simple.
verse.note: Or, unfolding. When God's word is opened, or unfolded, to us, it gives us light, shining inwardly over our heart and our spirit to impart wisdom and revelation to us ([link]Eph. 1:17-18a[/link]).

verse.text: I opened my mouth wide and panted, / For I longed for Your commandments.
Turn to me, and be gracious to me, / As is [i]Your[/i] custom with those who love Your name.
Establish my footsteps in Your word, / And do not let any iniquity have dominion over me.
Redeem me from man's oppression, / That I may keep Your precepts.
Cause Your [xref]a[/xref]face to shine on Your servant, / And teach me Your statutes.
My eyes [xref]a[/xref]shed streams of water, / Because [note]1[/note]men do not keep Your law.
verse.note: Lit., they.

verse.text: x (Tsadhe)
You are righteous, O Jehovah; / And Your judgments are upright.
You have commanded Your testimonies in righteousness / And great faithfulness.
My [xref]a[/xref]zeal has consumed me, / For my adversaries have forgotten Your words.
Your word is very [xref]a[/xref]pure, / And Your servant loves it.
I am small and despised, / [i]But[/i] I do not forget Your precepts.
Your righteousness is an eternal righteousness, / And Your law is truth.
Distress and anguish have come upon me, / [i]But[/i] Your commandments are my delight.
Your testimonies are righteous forever; / Give me understanding, and I will live.
q (Qoph)
I called with [i]my[/i] whole heart; answer me, O Jehovah. / I will keep Your statutes.
I called upon You; save me, / And I will observe Your testimonies.
I anticipated the [xref]a[/xref]dawn and cried out; / I hoped in Your words.
My eyes anticipated the night watches, / That I might [xref]a[/xref]muse upon Your word.
Hear my voice according to Your lovingkindness; / O Jehovah, according to Your ordinances enliven me.
Those who persecute me with evil intent draw near; / They are far from Your law.
You are near, O Jehovah; / And all Your commandments are truth.
Of old I have known from Your testimonies / That You have founded them forever.
r (Resh)
Look at my affliction, and deliver me; / For I have not forgotten Your law.
Plead my case, and redeem me; / [xref]a[/xref]Enliven me according to Your word.
Salvation is far from the wicked, / For they do not seek Your statutes.
Great are Your compassions, O Jehovah; / Enliven me according to Your ordinances.
Many are my persecutors and my adversaries, / [i]But[/i] I have not swerved from Your testimonies.
I saw the treacherous and loathed [i]them,[/i] / Because they did not keep Your word.
See how I have loved Your precepts; / O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]enliven me according to Your lovingkindness.
The sum of Your [xref]a[/xref]word is truth, / And all Your righteous ordinances are forever.
? (Shin)
Princes have persecuted me without cause, / But my heart stands in awe of Your words.
I rejoice at Your word, / Like one who finds great spoil.
I hate and abhor falsehood, / [i]But[/i] I love Your law.
[xref]a[/xref]Seven times a day I praise You / For Your righteous ordinances.
There is great peace for those who love Your law, / And there is no occasion of stumbling for them.
I have hoped for Your salvation, O Jehovah; / And I have done Your commandments.
My soul has kept Your testimonies, / And I love them very much.
I have kept Your precepts and Your testimonies, / For all my ways are before You.
t (Tav)
Let my cry come before You, O Jehovah; / Give me understanding according to Your word.
Let my supplication come before You; / Deliver me according to Your word.
Let my lips pour forth praise, / For You teach me Your statutes.
Let my tongue sing of Your word, / For all Your commandments are righteousness.
Let Your hand be ready to help me, / For I have chosen Your precepts.
I have longed for Your salvation, O Jehovah, / And Your law is my delight.
Let my soul live, and it will praise You; / And let Your ordinances help me.
I have gone astray like a [xref]a[/xref]lost sheep; seek Your servant, / For I have not forgotten Your commandments.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
[note]1[/note]In my [note]2[/note]distress I called out to Jehovah, / And He answered me.
verse.note: [link]Psalms 120-134[/link] are a particular group known as the Songs of Ascents. Instead of speaking concerning the law, these psalms are related to the matter of captivity. The people of Israel loved the law, but because they transgressed the law, even going so far as to turn from God and worship idols ([link]Jer. 2:13[/link]), God sent them into captivity in a land of idols. As the people were suffering in captivity, they could not forget Zion and Jerusalem, which were signs, symbols, of the very God whom they worshipped. When the people of Israel were captured, they were in a downward situation. To return to Jerusalem and to Zion was to be in an upward situation, to "go up" ([link]122:4[/link]). Jerusalem was built on Mount Zion. Therefore, when the people journeyed to Jerusalem, they had to ascend, and as they were ascending they sang a song of ascents.
[link]Psalm 120[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's delivering him from his distress, referring, perhaps, to the afflictions he suffered in his captivity.

verse.text: O Jehovah, deliver my soul from lying lips, / From a [xref]a[/xref]tongue of deceit.
What should be given to you, / And what further shall be done to you, / O tongue of deceit?
The sharp arrows of a mighty man, / With the [i]burning[/i] coals of the broom tree!
Woe is me, for I sojourn in [note]1[/note]Meshech, / I dwell among the tents of [note]1[/note]Kedar.
verse.note: Meshech was a place far to the north in Assyria, and Kedar was a place to the south in Arabia ([link]Isa. 21:13[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]Ezek. 27:21[/link]). Both may refer to the places in which the psalmist was captured in the Assyrian invasion ([link]2 Kings 18:11[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 32:1[/link]).

verse.text: Long has my soul had its dwelling / With him who hates peace.
I am [i]for[/i] peace; but when I speak, / They are for war.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
[note]1[/note]I will lift up my eyes to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]hills. / From where will my help come?
verse.note: [link]Psalm 121[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's keeping him from all evil, all disasters ([link]v. 7[/link]).
An allusion to Jehovah, who created the heavens and the earth, including the hills ([link]2 Kings 19:15[/link]).

verse.text: My [xref]a[/xref]help [i]comes[/i] from Jehovah, / Who made heaven and earth.
He will not let your foot slip; / He who keeps you will not slumber.
Behold, Israel's Keeper / Will neither slumber nor sleep.
Jehovah is your Keeper; / Jehovah is your [xref]a[/xref]shade at your right hand.
The [xref]a[/xref]sun will not strike you by day, / Nor the moon by night.
Jehovah will keep you from all evil; / He will keep your soul.
Jehovah will keep your going out and your coming in / From now and to eternity.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents. [xref]b[/xref]Of David
I rejoiced when they said to me, / Let us go to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]house of Jehovah.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 122[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning his love for the house of God in Jerusalem. This psalmist cared not for the law but for Zion and Jerusalem.

verse.text: Our feet [note]1[/note]are standing / Within your [xref]a[/xref]gates, O Jerusalem.
verse.note: Or, were standing.

verse.text: Jerusalem has been [xref]a[/xref]built as a city / That has been [xref]b[/xref]compacted together;
To which the tribes [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]go up, / The tribes of [note]2[/note]Jehovah — / A testimony for Israel — / To give thanks to the name of Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 120[/link].
Heb. [i]Jah;[/i] a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]

verse.text: For there thrones are set for judgment, / Thrones of the house of David.
Pray for the [xref]a[/xref]peace of [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem. / Those who love you will prosper.
Peace be within your [xref]a[/xref]bulwarks, / [i]And[/i] prosperity within your citadels.
For my brothers' and companions' sake I will now say, / Peace be within you.
For the sake of the [xref]a[/xref]house of Jehovah our God / I will seek your good.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
To You do I lift up my [xref]a[/xref]eyes, / You who sit [i]enthroned[/i] in heaven.

Behold, as the eyes of the servants / [i]Look[/i] to the hand of their masters, / As the eyes of a servant girl / [i]Look[/i] to the hand of her mistress, / So our eyes [i]look[/i] to Jehovah our God, / Until He is [note]1[/note]gracious to us.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 123[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning God's being gracious to the returned captives. It is not a matter of our loving God's law but of His being gracious to us.

verse.text: Be gracious to us, O Jehovah, be gracious to us; / For we are greatly filled with contempt.
Our soul is greatly filled / With the scorn of those who are at ease, / With the contempt of the proud.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents. [xref]b[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note]If it had not been Jehovah who was on our side, / Let Israel say,
verse.note: [link]Psalm 124[/link] is the praise of Israel, in their going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's help to Israel in the invasions of their enemies.

verse.text: If it had not been Jehovah who was on our side / When men rose up against us;
Then they would have swallowed us up alive / When their anger burned against us;
Then the waters would have washed us away; / The stream would have passed over our soul;
Then the [note]1[/note]proud waters / Would have passed over our soul.
verse.note: Or, insolent, raging.

verse.text: Blessed be Jehovah, who has not given us / As prey to their teeth.
Our soul has escaped like a bird, / Out of the snare of the fowlers; / The snare is broken, / And we have escaped.
Our [xref]a[/xref]help is in the name of Jehovah, / Who made heaven and earth.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
Those who [xref]a[/xref]trust in Jehovah are like Mount [xref]b[/xref]Zion, / Which cannot be moved [i]but[/i] abides forever.
Jerusalem — mountains surround her; / And Jehovah [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]surrounds His people / From now and to eternity.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 125[/link] is the praise of the saints, in their going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's surrounding of His people.

verse.text: For the scepter of wickedness will not rest / Upon the allotment of the righteous, / That the righteous would not put forth / Their hands to iniquity.
Do good, O Jehovah, to the [note]1[/note]good / And to those upright in their hearts.
verse.note: No one is good except God ([link]Mark 10:18[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:12[/link]). The expression here indicates that the psalmist's concept was still according to the principle of good and evil. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 7[/link].

verse.text: But as for those who turn aside to their crooked ways, / Jehovah will lead them off with the workers of iniquity. / [xref]a[/xref]Peace be upon Israel.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
When Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]turned again the [note]1[/note]captivity of Zion, / We were like those who dream.
verse.note: Lit., turning; not the same word as in [link]v. 4[/link].

verse.text: At that time our mouth was filled with laughter / And our tongue with a ringing shout. / At that time they said among the nations, / Jehovah has done [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]great things for them.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 126[/link] is the praise of the returned captives, in their going up to Zion, concerning the great things that Jehovah had done for them.

verse.text: Jehovah has done great things for us; / We are joyful.
Turn [note]1[/note]again, O Jehovah, our captivity / Like the streams in the south.
verse.note: Although some of the people had returned, many remained in captivity; hence, the psalmist prayed for them.

verse.text: Those who sow in [xref]a[/xref]tears / Will [xref]b[/xref]reap with a ringing shout.
He who goes forth and weeps, / Bearing [note]1[/note]seed for scattering, / Will no doubt come in with a ringing shout, / Bearing his sheaves [i]with him.[/i]
verse.note: Referring, perhaps, to the captives. In a human sense, their captivity in foreign countries was a suffering. In a divine sense, however, it was a sowing through their preaching to the Gentiles concerning God. As a result, a number of Gentiles (sheaves) were brought to God through these captives. This indicates that the captives sowed the seed of the knowledge of God among the heathen. Cf. [link]Ruth 1:16[/link] and note 2.

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents. [xref]b[/xref]Of Solomon

[note]1[/note]Unless Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]builds the [note]2[/note]house, / Those who build it [xref]b[/xref]labor in vain. / Unless Jehovah [xref]c[/xref]keeps the [note]2[/note]city, / The guard watches in vain.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 127[/link] is the praise of the saints, in their going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's care for and blessing to His people.

Unless the Lord builds the church as God's house ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]), those who build it ([link]1 Cor. 3:10-12[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:11-12[/link], [link]16[/link]) labor in vain. Unless the Lord keeps the city, i.e., keeps the church as the kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:17[/link]), those who guard the church ([link]Acts 20:28-31[/link]) watch in vain.

verse.text: It is [note]1[/note]vain for you to rise up early, / To stay up late, / To eat the bread of toil; / All the same, He gives to His beloved while they sleep.
verse.note: If the Lord does not do anything for us, whatever we do will be in vain. We need to labor in the Lord and by His grace ([link]1 Cor. 15:10[/link], [link]58[/link]; [link]Col. 1:28-29[/link]), but what the result will be depends not on our labor but on God's care and blessing. Instead of toiling and striving in ourselves, we need to trust in Him and rest in Him, for He gives to His beloved even while they sleep.

verse.text: Behold, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]children are the heritage of Jehovah, / The fruit of the womb a reward.
verse.note: Instead of striving without trusting in the Lord, we should simply be a good father producing children. We cannot gain much by our toil, but we can produce spiritual children (cf. [link]1 Cor. 4:15[/link]). In addition to His caring for us, God blesses us with increase, with children. Increase does not depend on what we do; it depends on how much God gives. Both the care and the blessing come from Him.

verse.text: Like arrows in the hand of a mighty man, / So are the children of [i]one's[/i] youth.
Blessed is the man / Who fills his quiver with them. / [note]1[/note]He will not be put to shame / When [note]1[/note]he speaks with enemies in the gate.
verse.note: Lit., They.

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
[note]1[/note]Blessed is everyone who fears Jehovah, / Who walks in His ways.
verse.note: The sequence of [link]Psa. 128-134[/link], the remaining seven Songs of Ascents, is significant. [link]Psalm 128[/link] speaks of Jehovah's blessing to Israel from Zion and the prosperity of Jerusalem in Israel's enjoyment. [link]Psalm 129[/link] concerns God's righteous dealing with the persecutors of Israel and the haters of Zion. Because Israel, like their persecutors and haters, has many sins and iniquities, [link]Psa. 130[/link] is a psalm of forgiveness and redemption. Then [link]Psa. 131[/link] indicates that after we experience God's forgiveness, we become humble and quiet before God. In such a situation God can rise up, enter into us, and take us as His resting place. This is Zion becoming God's habitation, His resting place, as revealed in [link]Psa. 132[/link]. Next, [link]Psa. 133[/link] shows that Zion, God's resting place, is the unique place where the brothers can come together in oneness and receive the commanded blessing of God, even life forever. Finally, in [link]Psa. 134[/link] the children of Israel first charge the priests to praise God in the night, and then they bless the priests, indicating that the children of Israel, having become Zion, are the highest people, even higher than the priests (cf. [link]Heb. 7:7[/link]).

verse.text: You will indeed eat the labor of your hands; / You will be blessed, and it will go well with you.
Your wife will be like a [xref]a[/xref]fruitful vine / In the innermost parts of your house. / Your children will be like [xref]b[/xref]olive shoots / Round about your table.
Thus will the man be blessed / Who fears Jehovah.
Jehovah [note]1[/note]bless you [note]2[/note]from [xref]a[/xref]Zion; / And may you see the [note]1[/note]prosperity of Jerusalem / All the days of your life.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 128[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's blessing to Israel from Zion (signifying the overcomers in the churches — see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link]) and the prosperity of Jerusalem (signifying the church as God's kingdom) in their enjoyment.
God always blesses His people from Zion, that is, from the overcomers (cf. [link]Num. 6:23-27[/link]; see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link]).

verse.text: May you also see the children of your children. / [xref]a[/xref]Peace be upon Israel.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
Many times have they afflicted me since my youth, / Let Israel say,
Many times have they afflicted me since my youth, / Yet they did not prevail against me.
The plowers plowed on my back; / They made their furrows long.
Jehovah is righteous; / He has cut the cords of the wicked.
May all who [note]1[/note]hate Zion / Be put to shame and turned back.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 129[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning God's righteous dealing with the persecutors of Israel and the haters of Zion. Here Israel signifies the New Testament believers ([link]Gal. 6:16[/link]), and Zion signifies the overcomers in the church (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link]). The more we love the Lord Jesus, the more we will be hated and persecuted ([link]John 15:18-20a[/link]).

verse.text: May they be like grass on the housetops, / Which withers before it grows up,
With which the reaper does not fill his hand, / Or he who binds sheaves, his bosom.
Nor may those who pass by say, / The blessing of Jehovah be upon you! / We bless you in the name of Jehovah.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
Out of the depths I have [xref]a[/xref]called upon You, O Jehovah.
O Lord, hear my voice; / Let Your ears be attentive / To the voice of my supplications.
If You, O [note]1[/note]Jehovah, marked iniquities, / Who, O Lord, would stand?
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah.[/i]

verse.text: But with You there is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forgiveness, / That You would be [note]2[/note]feared.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 130[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning God's forgiveness to Israel and His redeeming ([link]v. 7[/link]) Israel from all their iniquity. We are not better than the persecutors and the haters mentioned in [link]Psa. 129[/link]. Our imperfections need God's forgiveness and our filthiness needs His cleansing ([link]1 John 1:7[/link], [link]9[/link]).
The more the Lord forgives us, the more we fear Him, and the more we love Him ([link]Luke 7:40-47[/link] and notes [link]42[sup]3[/sup][/link] and [link]47[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: I wait for Jehovah; my soul waits, / And in His word I hope.
My soul [i]waits[/i] for the Lord / More than watchmen for the morning, / [i]Yes,[/i] watchmen for the morning.
Hope in Jehovah, O Israel; / For with Jehovah there is lovingkindness, / And with Him abundantly there is redemption;
And it is He who will redeem Israel / [xref]a[/xref]From all its iniquities.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents. [xref]b[/xref]Of David
O Jehovah, my [note]1[/note]heart is not proud, / Nor are my eyes haughty; / Nor do I go about in things too great / Or too wondrous for me.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 131[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning his humbled heart and quieted soul ([link]v. 2[/link]) before Jehovah. This was a result of God's forgiveness and redemption mentioned in [link]Psa. 130[/link].

verse.text: Surely I have calmed / And quieted my soul, / Like a [note]1[/note]weaned [xref]a[/xref]child with its mother; / Like a weaned child is my soul within me.
verse.note: The psalmist had been weaned, or stripped, of everything except the Lord (cf. [link]Psa. 73[/link]). When we have become like the psalmist, humble, calm, quiet, and weaned, we can advise others to hope in God ([link]v. 3[/link]).

verse.text: Hope in Jehovah, O Israel, / From now and to eternity.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
Remember, O Jehovah, for [note]1[/note]David's sake / All his [note]2[/note]afflictions;
verse.note: [link]Psalm 132[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's habitation and rest in Zion through David (typifying Christ) His anointed.
Typifying all the afflictions of Christ.

verse.text: How [xref]a[/xref]he swore to Jehovah / [i]And[/i] vowed to the Mighty One of Jacob:
I shall not go into the tent of my house; / I shall not go up onto the couch of my bed;
I shall not give sleep to my eyes, / Slumber to my eyelids;
Until I find a place for Jehovah, / A [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle for the Mighty One of Jacob.
Behold, we heard of it in [xref]a[/xref]Ephrathah; / We found it in the [xref]b[/xref]fields of [note]1[/note]Jaar.
verse.note: I.e., Kiriath-jearim, where the Ark remained in the house of Abinadab for twenty years ([link]1 Sam. 6:21-7:1[/link]) before it was brought up by David to the city of David and placed in a tent that David had pitched for it ([link]2 Sam. 6:1-17[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 13:1-14[/link]; [link]15:1-16:1[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Sam. 6[/link].

verse.text: We will go into His [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle; / We will worship at His [xref]b[/xref]footstool.
[xref]a[/xref]Arise, O Jehovah, unto Your resting place, / You and the Ark of Your strength.
Let Your priests be clothed with [xref]a[/xref]righteousness, / And let Your faithful ones give a ringing shout.
For the sake of David Your servant, / Do not turn away the face of Your Anointed One.
Jehovah has sworn unto David in truth; / He will not turn from it: / Of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fruit of your body I will set [i]One[/i] upon your throne.
verse.note: See notes [link book="2 Sam." chapter="7"]12[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]12[sup]2[/sup][/link], and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Sam. 7[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]If your children keep My covenant / And My testimonies that I will teach them, / Their children also will sit / Upon your throne forever.
For Jehovah has chosen [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zion; / He has desired it for His habitation.
verse.note: As Jehovah's resting place ([link]v. 14[/link]), Zion typifies the overcomers in the churches. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 48[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]This is My [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]resting place forever; / Here will I dwell, for I have desired it.
verse.note: While the psalmist was speaking of God's choosing and desiring Zion in [link]v. 13[/link], God suddenly intervened to continue the psalmist's speaking in [link]vv. 14-18[/link]. This is the wonderful way in which the Psalms were written.

[link]Psalm 132[/link] mentions seven items related to the overcomers: resting with God, dwelling with God ([link]v. 14[/link]), food for satisfaction ([link]v. 15[/link]), glorious clothing ([link]v. 16[/link]), the horn of victory ([link]v. 17[/link]), the enlightening lamp ([link]v. 17[/link]), and the shining crown ([link]v. 18[/link]). These items are at the top of the church life. They portray the situation of the overcomers in Zion, the highest peak of God's mountain.

verse.text: I will abundantly bless its provision; / I will satisfy its poor with bread.
And its priests I will [xref]a[/xref]clothe with salvation, / And its faithful ones will shout with a ringing shout.
There I will cause a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]horn of David to shoot forth; / I have prepared a [xref]b[/xref]lamp for My anointed one.
verse.note: A figure of strength, power, and victory.

verse.text: I will clothe his enemies with shame, / But on him his crown will shine.
A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents. [xref]b[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note]Behold, [note]2[/note]how good and [note]2[/note]how pleasant it is / For brothers to dwell in [note]3[/note]unity!
verse.note: [link]Psalm 133[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning Jehovah's commanded blessing on brothers who dwell in oneness. When Zion is built up and when God is resting there and dwelling in Jerusalem, as depicted in [link]Psa. 132[/link], we have a place where we can gather and where we can dwell together in oneness. How good and how pleasant this is!

In this psalm the believers' dwelling together in oneness is likened to the inestimable goodness of the precious ointment on the head of Aaron and to the incalculable pleasantness of the dew of Hermon on the mountains of Zion.

The unity spoken of here is a picture of the genuine oneness in the New Testament. This oneness is the processed and consummated Triune God mingled with the believers in Christ ([link]John 17:21-23[/link]). Since the Body of Christ is such a mingling ([link]Eph. 4:4-6[/link]), the Body itself is the oneness. According to the picture in this psalm, the genuine oneness is constituted of the spreading ointment and the descending dew for the gradual building up of the Body of Christ in the divine dispensing of the Divine Trinity.

verse.text: It is like the fine [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]oil upon the head / That [note]2[/note]ran down upon the beard, / Upon [xref]b[/xref]Aaron's beard, / That ran down upon the [xref]c[/xref]hem of his garments;
verse.note: Referring to the holy anointing oil in [link]Exo. 30:23-33[/link] (see notes there), which signifies the all-inclusive, compound, anointing Spirit as the consummation of the processed Triune God ([link]1 John 2:20[/link], [link]27[/link]).

Aaron typifies Christ as the High Priest ([link]Heb. 5:4-5[/link]), and Aaron's garments typify the church, the Body of Christ, as the fullness, the expression, of Christ ([link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]; see notes [link book="Exo." chapter="28"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 28[/link]). The oil running down from Aaron's head to the hem of his garments signifies that both the Head and the Body, both Christ and the church, are under the anointing of God's fine oil ([link]Heb. 1:9[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:21[/link]). The anointing of the compound, all-inclusive, life-giving Spirit is the element of the genuine oneness ([link]Eph. 4:3-4a[/link] and note [link]3[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: Like the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dew of [xref]b[/xref]Hermon / That came down upon the [note]2[/note]mountains of [xref]c[/xref]Zion. / For there Jehovah commanded the [xref]d[/xref]blessing: / [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]Life forever.
verse.note: Signifying the fresh and refreshing grace of God, which comes to us through God's fresh compassions ([link]Lam. 3:22-23[/link]; cf. [link]Prov. 19:12[/link]). This grace — the Triune God processed and consummated to be our life supply for our enjoyment ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]16-17[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]) — waters us. Hermon, a high mountain, signifies the heavens, the highest place, from which the dew descends. The anointing of the Spirit ([link]v. 2[/link]) and the supply of grace make it possible for us to live in oneness. Cf. note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link].
The many mountains of the one Zion typify the many local churches as the components of the unique universal church. In the local churches we daily enjoy the Lord's grace as the descending dew.

Referring to the eternal life of God ([link]John 3:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:18[/link]), which is commanded by God as a blessing to those who dwell together in oneness in the church life. [link]Psalm 132[/link] typifies the church life, in which God enters into His rest and we obtain satisfaction and rest in the habitation of God. [link]Psalm 133[/link] typifies the church living — the highest living, a living in which the brothers dwell together in oneness. Such a living causes God to come in to bless us with the anointing Spirit, the watering grace, and the eternal life.

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]Song of Ascents
[note]1[/note]Bless Jehovah now, / All you [xref]a[/xref]servants of Jehovah / Who stand by night in the house of Jehovah.
verse.note: As the last of the Songs of Ascents (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 120[/link]), [link]Psa. 134[/link] is the praise of a saint, in his going up to Zion, concerning the charge and the blessing given by the children of Israel to the serving priests in the house of God. [link]Verses 1-2[/link] are the charge of the children of Israel to the serving priests to bless Jehovah, and [link]v. 3[/link] is the blessing of the children of Israel to the serving priests. This psalm indicates that the spiritually highest people, those who are in Zion, can bless everyone and instruct everyone (cf. note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 47[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Lift up your hands in the sanctuary, / And bless Jehovah.
May Jehovah, who made heaven and earth, / [xref]a[/xref]Bless you [note]1[/note]from [xref]b[/xref]Zion.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in Psa. 128[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hallelujah! Praise the name of Jehovah; / Praise [i]Him,[/i] you [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]servants of Jehovah,
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 104[/link]. [link]Psalms 135[/link] and [link book="Psa."]146-150[/link] are "hallelujah" psalms, for each begins and ends with "Hallelujah."

The subject of [link]Psa. 135[/link] is the charging of the priests who serve Jehovah in His house to praise Jehovah for His virtues.[br][br][link]Psalms 135-139[/link] were written from different directions to express the sentiments of the psalmists before God. These psalms reveal that the writers were very close to God and were concerned for God's interests. The psalmists must have been persons who were soaked with God and who were in the divine presence. Only in this way could they have been qualified to write such intimate psalms to the One whom they loved. Like the writers of these psalms, we should aspire to be those who are intimate with God and who live and walk not only in God's presence but even in God Himself ([link]1 John 4:15-16[/link]).

verse.text: Who [xref]a[/xref]stand in the house of Jehovah, / In the courts of the house of our God.
Praise [note]1[/note]Jehovah, for Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]good; / Sing psalms to His name, for it is pleasant.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Jah.[/i] So also in [link]v. 4[/link].

verse.text: For Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]chosen Jacob for Himself, / Israel for His [xref]b[/xref]personal treasure.
For I know that Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]great / And that our Lord is above all gods.
Whatever Jehovah pleases He does / In heaven and on earth, / In the seas and all the depths.
[xref]a[/xref]He causes the vapors to ascend from the ends of the earth; / He makes lightning for the rain; / He brings forth wind from His treasuries.
He [xref]a[/xref]struck the firstborn of Egypt, / Both of man and of beast.
He sent [xref]a[/xref]signs and wonders into your midst, O Egypt, / Upon Pharaoh and all his servants.
He struck many nations / And [xref]a[/xref]slew mighty kings:
[xref]a[/xref]Sihon the king of the Amorites / And Og the king of Bashan / And all the kingdoms of Canaan.
And He gave their land as an [xref]a[/xref]inheritance, / An inheritance to Israel His people.
O Jehovah, Your name is forever; / O Jehovah, Your memorial is from generation to generation.
[xref]a[/xref]For Jehovah will [note]1[/note]execute judgment for His people, / And He will have compassion concerning His servants.
verse.note: Or, judge His people.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]The [xref]b[/xref]idols of the nations are [i]mere[/i] silver and gold, / The work of human [xref]c[/xref]hands.
They have mouths, but they do not speak; / They have eyes, but they do not see.
They have ears, but they do not give ear; / And there is no breath in their mouths.
Those who make them, / All who trust in them, / Will be like them.
O house of [xref]a[/xref]Israel, [note]1[/note]bless Jehovah. / O house of Aaron, bless Jehovah.
verse.note: To bless God is to speak well of Him (cf. [link]Eph. 1:3[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: O house of Levi, bless Jehovah. / O you who fear Jehovah, bless Jehovah.
Blessed be Jehovah from [xref]a[/xref]Zion, / Who [xref]b[/xref]dwells in Jerusalem. / Hallelujah.
[note]1[/note]Give thanks to Jehovah, for He is good; / For His lovingkindness is forever.
verse.note: The subject of [link]Psa. 136[/link] is the charging of the people to give thanks to Jehovah for His everlasting lovingkindness.

verse.text: Give thanks to the God of gods, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
Give thanks to the [xref]a[/xref]Lord of lords, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who alone does great wonders, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who by [xref]a[/xref]understanding [xref]b[/xref]made the heavens, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who spread forth the [xref]a[/xref]earth over the waters, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who made the [xref]a[/xref]great lights, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
The sun for ruling the day, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
The moon and the stars for ruling the night, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who [xref]a[/xref]struck Egypt in their firstborn, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And [xref]a[/xref]brought forth Israel from their midst, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
With a mighty [xref]a[/xref]hand and an outstretched arm, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who [xref]a[/xref]divided the Red Sea apart, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And brought Israel over through the midst of it, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And shook off Pharaoh and his force into the [xref]a[/xref]Red Sea, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who marched His people through the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
To Him who [xref]a[/xref]struck great kings, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And slew majestic kings, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
Sihon the king of the Amorites, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And Og the king of Bashan, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And gave their land as an inheritance, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
An inheritance to Israel His servant, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
Who remembered us in our low estate, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
And rescued us from our adversaries, / For His lovingkindness is forever;
Who gives [xref]a[/xref]food to all flesh, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
Give thanks to the [xref]a[/xref]God of heaven, / For His lovingkindness is forever.
By the [xref]a[/xref]rivers of Babylon, / There we sat down; indeed, we [xref]b[/xref]wept / When we [note]1[/note]remembered [xref]c[/xref]Zion.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 137[/link] speaks of Israel's remembering Zion and not forgetting Jerusalem ([link]v. 5[/link]) in their captivity. After returning from their captivity, the captives had a sweet remembrance of the sorrowful experience of captivity. In spiritual experience, when we fall and are brought back by the Lord, in our reminiscence we taste the sweetness of the Lord's mercy in restoring us.

verse.text: On the willows in the midst of it / We hung up our lyres,
For there our captors required of us songs, / And those who tormented us [i]required of us[/i] mirth, [i]saying,[/i] / Sing for us / One of the [xref]a[/xref]songs of Zion.
How can we sing the song of Jehovah / In a foreign land?
If I [xref]a[/xref]forget you, O Jerusalem, / Let my right hand forget [i]its skill.[/i]
Let my tongue cling to the roof of my mouth, / If I do not remember you, / If I do not prefer [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem / Above my chief joy.
Remember, O Jehovah, / [note]1[/note]Against the children of [xref]a[/xref]Edom, / The day of Jerusalem, / Who said, Lay [i]it[/i] bare! Lay [i]it[/i] bare, / Down to its foundation!
verse.note: The psalmist's prayer here against Edom and his cursing of Babylon in [link]vv. 8-9[/link] are according to the principle of good and evil (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link]). According to the teaching of the New Testament, we should bless and not curse those who oppose us ([link]Rom. 12:14[/link]), and we should pray for those who persecute us ([link]Matt. 5:44[/link]).

verse.text: O daughter of Babylon, who are to be devastated, / Happy will he be who [xref]a[/xref]repays you / The recompense of what you have rendered to us.
Happy will he be who seizes your little ones / And dashes them against the rock.
[xref]a[/xref]Of David
I will [note]1[/note]give You thanks with all my heart; / Before the gods I will sing psalms to You.
verse.note: The subject of [link]Psa. 138[/link] is the thanking of Jehovah in the worship toward His holy temple.

verse.text: I will bow toward Your holy [xref]a[/xref]temple / And give thanks to Your name / For Your lovingkindness and Your truth, / For You have magnified Your word above all Your name.
On the day that I called out, You answered me; / You encouraged me with strength in my soul.
All the kings of the earth will give thanks to You, O Jehovah; / For they have heard the words of Your mouth.
And they will sing of the ways of Jehovah, / For great is the glory of Jehovah.
For though Jehovah is high, He [xref]a[/xref]regards the lowly; / And the [xref]b[/xref]haughty He knows from afar.
Though I [xref]a[/xref]walk in the midst of trouble, / You will preserve me; / Against the wrath of my enemies You will [xref]b[/xref]stretch out Your hand, / And Your right hand will save me.
Jehovah will complete that which concerns me. / O Jehovah, Your lovingkindness is forever; / Do not forsake the works of Your own hands.
To the choir director. [xref]a[/xref]Of David. A Psalm
O Jehovah, You have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]searched me and [xref]b[/xref]known me.
verse.note: The subject of [link]Psa. 139[/link] is the psalmist's asking Jehovah for His searching and trying. [link]Verses 1-6[/link] speak of God's omniscience, and [link]vv. 7-12[/link], of God's omnipresence.

verse.text: You know when I [xref]a[/xref]sit down and when I rise up; / You understand my thoughts from afar.
You thoroughly [xref]a[/xref]search my path and my lying down, / And You are acquainted with all my ways.
For a word is not yet on my tongue, / [i]And[/i] already You, O Jehovah, know it completely.
You have closed in on me behind and before / And have laid Your hand on me.
Oh, knowledge too wonderful for me! / It is so high; I cannot attain to it.
Where shall I go, away from Your Spirit, / And where shall I flee [xref]a[/xref]from Your presence?
If I ascend into [xref]a[/xref]heaven, You are there; / If I make my bed in Sheol, there You are.
If I take the wings of the dawn / [i]And[/i] settle at the limits of the sea,
There also Your hand will [xref]a[/xref]lead me, / And Your right hand will take hold of me.
And if I say, Surely darkness will cover me, / And the light around me will be night;
Even the [xref]a[/xref]darkness is not dark to You, / And night shines like day; / The darkness is like the light.
For it was You who [xref]a[/xref]formed my inward parts; / You wove me together in my mother's womb.
I will praise You, for I am awesomely and wonderfully made; / Your [xref]a[/xref]works are wonderful, / And my soul knows [i]it[/i] well.
My frame was not hidden from You / When I was made in secret, / [xref]a[/xref]Skillfully fashioned in the depths of the earth.
Your eyes saw my unformed substance; / And in Your book all of them were written: / The days that were ordained [i]for me,[/i] / When not one of them was yet.
And how precious are Your [xref]a[/xref]thoughts to me, O God! / How great is the sum of them!
If I should count them, they would be more than the sand. / When I awake, I am still with You.
Oh that You, O God, would [note]1[/note]slay the wicked — / Depart from me therefore, you men of bloodshed —
verse.note: [link]Verses 19-22[/link] describe the psalmist's hating and loathing the wickedness of the wicked according to the principle of good and evil. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 7[/link].

verse.text: Those who speak of You with evil intent, / Who as Your enemies take [i]Your name[/i] in vain.
Do I not hate those who hate You, O Jehovah? / And do I not loathe those who rise up against You?
I hate them with a perfect hatred; / They have become my own enemies.
[xref]a[/xref]Search me, O God, and know my heart; / Try me, and know my anxious thoughts;
And see if there is some [note]1[/note]harmful way in me, / And lead me on the eternal way.
verse.note: Others understand, idolatrous.

verse.text: To the choir director. A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
[note]1[/note]Deliver me, O Jehovah, from evil men; / From violent men preserve me;
verse.note: [link]Psalms 140-145[/link] are David's final prayers. These psalms do not contain great or important matters, but as David's prayers (especially in [link]vv. 6-7[/link]; [link]141:3[/link], [link]5b[/link]; [link]142:3a[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]143:2b[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]9b-10[/link]; and [link]144:1-2[/link], [link]5a[/link], [link]12-15[/link]) they are full of the expressions of his intimacy with God. However, as in earlier psalms written by David, four of these six psalms are also full of the principle of good and evil ([link]vv. 9b-13[/link]; [link]141:10[/link]; [link]143:12[/link]; [link]145:20[/link]). See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 7[/link].

verse.text: Who devise evil schemes in [i]their[/i] hearts / [i]And[/i] continually stir up wars.
They have sharpened their tongues like that of a serpent; / The [xref]a[/xref]poison of adders is under their lips. Selah
Keep me, O Jehovah, from the hands of the wicked; / From violent men preserve me; / Who devise [i]schemes[/i] to thrust me down.
The proud have hidden a trap for me and cords; / They have spread a net by the wayside; / They have set snares for me. Selah
I said to Jehovah, You are my God; / Give ear, O Jehovah, to the voice of my supplications.
O Jehovah Lord, strength of my salvation, / You have covered my head in the day of battle.
O Jehovah, do not grant the desires of the wicked man; / Do not let his evil scheme advance, / [i]Lest[/i] he be exalted. Selah
As for the head of those who surround me, / May the mischief of their own lips cover them.
May burning coals drop down upon them; / May they be thrown down into the fire, / Into deep pits, never to rise again.
Let no slanderer be established in the land; / Let evil hunt down the violent man speedily.
I know that Jehovah will maintain the cause of the afflicted / And justice for the needy.
Surely the righteous will give thanks to Your name; / The upright will dwell in Your presence.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
O Jehovah, I have called upon You; hasten to me. / Give ear to my voice when I call out to You.
Let my [xref]a[/xref]prayer be set before You as incense, / The lifting up of my hands as the evening offering.
Set a watch, O Jehovah, before my mouth; / Keep the door of my lips.
Do not let my heart turn to anything evil, / To practice deeds of wickedness / With men who commit iniquity; / And let me not eat of their delicacies.
Let the righteous strike me in kindness and reprove me; / Let not my head refuse [xref]a[/xref]oil upon the head, / For still my prayer is against their evil deeds.
Their judges are thrown down by the sides of the rock, / And they hear my words, that they are pleasant.
As when one plows and breaks up the earth, / Our bones are scattered at the mouth of Sheol.
For my eyes are upon You, O Jehovah Lord; / In You I [xref]a[/xref]take refuge; do not pour out my soul.
Keep me from the trap they have set for me / And [i]from[/i] the snares of the workers of iniquity.
May the wicked [note]1[/note]fall into their own nets / While I alone pass by.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: A [note]1[/note]Maschil [xref]a[/xref]of David, when he was in the [xref]b[/xref]cave. A Prayer
verse.note: See note on superscription of [link]Psa. 32[/link].

verse.text: With my voice I cry to Jehovah; / With my voice I make my supplication to Jehovah.
I pour out my complaint before Him; / I declare my trouble before Him.
When my spirit fainted within me, / You knew my path. / On the way on which I walked / They have hidden a trap for me.
Look on [i]my[/i] right hand and see, / For there is no one who regards me; / Refuge has failed me; / No one cares for me.
I cried to You, O Jehovah; / I said, You are my [xref]a[/xref]refuge, / My [xref]b[/xref]portion in the land of the living.
Give heed to my cry, / For I have been brought very low; / Deliver me from those who persecute me, / For they are stronger than I.
Bring my soul out of prison, / That I may give thanks to Your name. / The righteous will surround me, / For You will deal bountifully with me.
A [xref]a[/xref]Psalm of David
O Jehovah, hear my prayer; / Give ear to my supplications; / Answer me in Your faithfulness [i]and[/i] in Your righteousness;
And do not enter into judgment with Your servant, / For [xref]a[/xref]no one alive is righteous in Your sight.
For the enemy has persecuted my soul; / He has crushed my life down to the ground; / He has caused me to dwell in dark places, like those who have been long dead.
Therefore my spirit faints within me; / My heart is appalled in the midst of me.
[xref]a[/xref]I remember the days of old; / I meditate upon all that You have done; / I muse upon the work of Your hands.
I spread out my hands to You; / My soul [xref]a[/xref][i]thirsts[/i] for You like a parched land. Selah
Hurry and answer me, O Jehovah; / My spirit fails. / Do not hide Your face from me, / Lest I become like those who go down into the pit.
Cause me to hear Your [xref]a[/xref]lovingkindness in the morning, / For in You I trust. / Make known to me the way on which I should walk, / For to You I lift up my soul.
Deliver me from my enemies, O Jehovah; / [note]1[/note]I have fled to You for a [xref]a[/xref]refuge.
verse.note: Some MSS read, I hide myself in You.

verse.text: Teach me to do Your will, / For You are my God; / Let Your [xref]a[/xref]good Spirit lead me / In a plain country.
For Your name's sake, O Jehovah, preserve me alive; / In Your righteousness bring my soul out of trouble.
And in Your lovingkindness [note]1[/note]cut off my enemies / And destroy all those who oppress my soul, / For I am Your [xref]a[/xref]servant.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Of David
Blessed be Jehovah my [xref]a[/xref]rock, / Who teaches my hands for war / [i]And[/i] my fingers for battle:
My [i]Lord of[/i] lovingkindness and my fortress, / My [xref]a[/xref]high retreat and my Deliverer, / My shield and He in whom I [xref]b[/xref]take refuge, / Who subdues my people under me.
O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]what is man, that You take knowledge of him, / [i]And[/i] the son of mortal man, that You think of him?
Man is like a [xref]a[/xref]breath; / His days are like a passing shadow.
O Jehovah, bow Your heavens down and descend; / Touch the mountains, and they will smoke.
Flash forth lightning, and scatter them; / Send forth Your arrows, and discomfit them.
Stretch forth Your hand from on high; / Rescue me and deliver me / From the great waters, / From the hand of foreigners;
Whose mouth speaks deceit, / And whose right hand is a right hand of falsehood.
O God, I will sing a [xref]a[/xref]new song to You; / Upon a harp of ten strings I will sing psalms to You,
Who gives salvation to kings, / Who [xref]a[/xref]rescues David His servant from the hurtful sword.
Rescue me and deliver me from the hand of foreigners, / Whose mouth speaks deceit, / And whose right hand is a right hand of falsehood.
[note]1[/note]May our sons be like [xref]a[/xref]plants / Grown up in their youth; / May our daughters be like corner pillars / Hewn out in fashion for a palace;
verse.note: As an Old Testament saint, David prayed in [link]vv. 12-15[/link] concerning prosperity in material things. See notes [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 1[/link], [link book="Psa." chapter="73"]13[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 73[/link], and [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in Psa. 118[/link].

verse.text: May our barns be full, / Furnishing produce of all kinds; / May our sheep bring forth thousands / And ten thousands in our fields;
May our oxen be fully laden; / May there be no breaking in [i]to rob[/i] or going forth [i]to fight,[/i] / Or outcry in our streets.
Blessed are the people who are so; / [xref]a[/xref]Blessed are the people whose God is Jehovah.
A Song of Praise. [xref]a[/xref]Of David
[note]1[/note]I will [note]2[/note]extol You, O my God and [xref]a[/xref]King; / And I will bless Your name forever and ever.
verse.note: [link]Psalm 145[/link] is one of the alphabetic, or acrostic, psalms. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 9[/link].
[link]Psalms 140-144[/link] issue in the extolling and praising of God in [link]Psa. 145[/link] for God's reigning in Christ and His kingdom ([link]vv. 11-13[/link]).

verse.text: Every day I will bless You, / And I will praise Your name forever and ever.
